title: Block-wise Random Diffusion Encryption Using 4D Dynamic Feedback Memristive Chaotic System
authors: Jiebing Xia, Wenjun Zeng, Chongfu Zhang, Yanwei Li, Xinshuai Liang, Yue Lin, Kun Qiu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: The growing data exchange among consumer-electronic (CE) devices demands encryption methods that balance security, efficiency, and real-time performance. Thus, we introduce a four-dimensional Dynamic Feedback Memristive Chaotic System (4D-DFMCS) and then propose a chaotic encryption method based on block-wise diffusion. Specifically, a 4D-DFMCS with enhanced chaotic properties is constructed by introducing the nonlinear properties of the memristor. It has a larger chaotic range and can improve chaotic dynamic degradation compared with traditional systems, thereby enhancing the security and stability of the encryption algorithm. Using this system for block data diffusion, a novel block-wise random diffusion mechanism is designed. By introducing global dependencies, this method significantly reduces the risk of system deciphering due to eavesdropping attacks. This further enhances the protection of sensitive visual data on CE devices against diverse attacks. In addition, the pre-sharing defects of initial value are prevalent in existing chaotic cryptographic systems, so a novel initial key generation and dynamic update mechanism based on Elliptic Curve Diffie-Hellman Ephemeral (ECDHE) protocol is developed. Finally, the result shows that the key space reaches 4.26×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">178</sup>. The Number of Pixels Change Rate (NPCR) and Unified Average Changing Intensity (UACI) values are obtained as 99.6056% and 33.4333%. It further demonstrates the scheme’s robustness against eavesdropping under SNR constraints, with decrypted outputs appearing noise-like below 15 dB. These results demonstrate the strong security performance of the proposed scheme in CE applications requiring both high confidentiality and real-time processing.

title: STAR-CD: Style-Aligned Remote Sensing Change Detection with Appearance-Relation Modeling
authors: Qian Hu, Yuxuan Wang, Yan Zhang, Wen Yang, Fang Xu, Gui-Song Xia
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Remote sensing change detection plays a crucial part in monitoring the evolution of land cover. Despite remarkable progress in recent years, existing change detection models still struggle with two major challenges that lead to inaccurate change predictions. For one, current models lack sufficient global relation modeling, resulting in coarse boundary prediction and false identification of unwanted variations. For another, bitemporal images often display divergent imaging styles due to lighting, sensor, or seasonal differences, and this cross-temporal style inconsistency would amplify the pseudo-changes caused by non-semantic variations. In this paper, we present the style-alignment and appearance-relation modeling change detection model (STAR-CD) to tackle the above challenges. First, we propose an appearance-relation modeling block (ARMB) to jointly explore semantic differences from both local textures and global structures of remote sensing images, effectively reducing false alarms and refining change boundary predictions. Second, we design a Fourier-inspired style alignment module (FSAM), which suppresses style-induced noise and reveals true changes by texture-style decoupling in the frequency domain. Extensive experiments on the WHU-CD, LEVIR-CD, and CDD datasets demonstrate the superiority of our STAR-CD over state-of-the-art methods. In particular, STAR-CD surpasses previous methods by 2.40% and 4.34% in F1 and IoU on the CDD datasets, respectively. Visual comparisons further validate its strength in predicting precise change boundaries and robustly suppressing pseudo-changes.

title: Achieving Safety-Aware and Efficient Robot Motion via Dynamic Task-Scaling: From the Null-Space Control Perspective
authors: Xiaokai Zhou, Boyu Ma, Baoshi Cao, Yang Liu, Wandong Sun, Jianfei Yang, Zongwu Xie
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics
abstract: Future redundant manipulators require multitask operation in complex constrained environments. Manipulator must handle potential hazards such as joint profile oscillations or whole-arm collisions within feasible motion ranges. This article addresses discontinuous joint velocities during obstacle avoidance and resolves redundancy resolution across multiple tasks. To mitigate discontinuous joint velocities caused by switching between the closest link-obstacle pairs, a method is introduced that linearly combines obstacle avoidance behaviors across all link-obstacle pairs to generate smooth avoidance motions. Furthermore, a differential inverse kinematic method is proposed that simultaneously handles multiple Cartesian-space and joint-space equality tasks. This algorithm autonomously scales within joint limits to identify feasible solutions. The proposed approach was validated through simulations and experiments with the 7-DoF Franka Emika Panda manipulator in both dynamic and static environments. Simulation and experiment videos can be found at <ext-link ext-link-type="uri" xlink:href="https://github.com/ZhouXK1997/TIE_2025_3610739_Video" xlink:type="simple" xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"/>.

title: Edge AI-Based Adaptive Human Sitting Detection System
authors: Bor-Shyh Lin, Chih-Wei Peng, Yi-Jyun Shih, Bor-Shing Lin
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: Prolonged sitting and poor posture are major risk factors for musculoskeletal and chronic diseases, underscoring the need for a practical and noncontact posture monitoring solution. This study proposes an edge artificial intelligence–based sitting posture recognition system that combines infrared wide-angle cameras with a lightweight YOLOv11 model optimized for embedded deployment. A position calibration mechanism was developed to ensure robustness across diverse body types and office chair designs. The system can accurately classify 18 sitting postures and maintain high recognition performance even under occlusion conditions, such as when users wear long skirts. To address the challenges of latency and energy efficiency in edge AI deployment, the model was implemented on a TB-RK3399ProX embedded board using its neural processing unit for real-time inference. Experimental results demonstrated an accuracy of 93.15% and an inference delay of 8.73 ms, confirming the system’s stability and responsiveness in various seating environments. Compared with traditional wearable or pressure-sensor-based systems, the proposed noncontact solution offers superior comfort, efficiency, and deployment feasibility for practical posture monitoring.

title: Machine-interpretable Engineering Design Standards for Valve Specification
authors: Anders Gjerver, Rune Frostad, Vedrana Barisic, Melinda Hodkiewicz, Caitlin Woods, Mihaly Fekete, Arild Braathen Torjusen, Johan W Kluwer
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Engineering design processes use technical specifications and must comply with standards. Product specifications, product type data sheets, and design standards are still mainly document-centric despite the ambition to digitalize industrial work. In this paper, we demonstrate how to transform information held in engineering design standards into modular, reusable, machine-interpretable ontologies and use the ontologies in quality assurance of the plant design and equipment selection process. We use modelling patterns to create modular ontologies for knowledge captured in the text and in frequently referenced tables in International Standards for piping, material and valve design. These modules are exchangeable, as stored in a W3C compliant format, and interoperable as they are aligned with the top-level ontology ISO DIS 23726-3: Industrial Data Ontology (IDO). We test these ontologies, created based on international material and piping standards and industry norms, on a valve selection process. Valves are instantiated in semantic asset models as individuals along with a semantic representation of the environmental condition at their location on the asset. We create "functional location tags" as OWL individuals that become instances of OWL class Valve Data Sheet (VDS) specified valves. Similarly we create instances of manufacturer product type. Our approach enables automated validation that a specific VDS is compliant with relevant industry standards. Using semantic reasoning and executable design rules, we also determine whether the product type meets the valve specification. Creation of shared, reusable IDO-based modular ontologies for design standards enables semantic reasoning to be applied to equipment selection processes and demonstrates the potential of this approach for Standards Bodies wanting to transition to digitized Smart Standards.

title: Breaking Neural Networks Through Algebraic Lens: A Preliminary Analysis of Mathematical Vulnerabilities in AI Architectures
authors: Sandeep Gupta, Budesh Kanwer, Pankaj Dadheech, Sumit Srivastava
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Modern deep neural networks, particularly transformer architectures, have achieved unprecedented performance across various domains through sophisticated mathematical structures that remain incompletely understood from a security perspective. This paper presents a comprehensive framework for identifying and analyzing algebraic vulnerabilities in contemporary AI architectures through computational algebra and discrete mathematics. We demonstrate that the composition of linear transformations, non-linear activation functions, and attention mechanisms creates exploitable polynomial systems that can be systematically analyzed using advanced algebraic techniques. Our methodology reveals fundamental weaknesses in popular architectures including Vision Transformers (ViTs), BERT-based models, and Residual Networks (ResNets), showing how adversaries can construct attacks that exploit polynomial-time algorithms while acknowledging current computational limitations. Through rigorous mathematical analysis and experimental validation on networks up to 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">5</sup> parameters, we establish theoretical bounds for these vulnerabilities and demonstrate attack success rates of 52-78% on individual network components. We provide detailed end-to-end attack demonstrations showing measurable prediction changes, with attack success defined as achieving targeted modifications in network outputs that exceed 10% deviation from original predictions. While computational scalability remains a significant constraint, the findings suggest that algebraic structure analysis provides crucial insights into AI system security that require consideration from both cryptographic and machine learning communities. We position this work as contributing to both mathematical interpretability of neural networks and security vulnerability analysis, with implications for developing algebraically-robust architectures.

title: Nonlinear Auto-Tuning PI Control With Desired Precision Within User-Specifiable Time
authors: Kaili Xiang, Yongduan Song, Petros Ioannou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cybernetics
abstract: This article presents a novel nonlinear adaptive proportional–integral (PI)-like tracking control approach designed for a class of uncertain nonlinear systems. The proposed method offers several key advantages: 1) it maintains a simple PI structure while incorporating nonlinear elements; 2) unlike traditional PI control, which typically employs fixed PI gains and is susceptible to integration saturation, this approach utilizes self-tuning PI gains to effectively eliminate saturation issues, thereby addressing the long-standing windup problem; and 3)it skillfully manages both the transient behavior and steady-state accuracy of the tracking error through a new prescribed performance function that is independent of initial conditions. This ensures that, for any unknown bounded initial tracking errors, the proposed PI-like control can uniformly confine the tracking error to a specified boundary (accuracy) within a predetermined time rather than over an infinite duration. The effectiveness and advantages of this method are validated through simulation results.

title: A Large-scale Benchmark on Geological Fault Delineation Models: Domain Shift, Training Dynamics, Generalizability, Evaluation and Inferential Behavior
authors: Jorge Quesada, Chen Zhou, Prithwijit Chowdhury, Mohammad Alotaibi, Ahmad Mustafa, Yusufjon Kumakov, Mohit Prabhushankar, Ghassan AlRegib
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Machine learning has taken a critical role in seismic interpretation workflows, especially in fault delineation tasks. However, despite the recent proliferation of pretrained models and synthetic datasets, the field still lacks a systematic understanding of the generalizability limits of these models across seismic data representing a variety of geologic, acquisition and processing settings. Distributional shifts between different data sources, limitations in fine-tuning strategies and labeled data accessibility, and inconsistent evaluation protocols all represent major roadblocks in the deployment of reliable and robust models in real-world exploration settings. In this paper, we present the first large-scale benchmarking study explicitly designed to provide answers and guidelines for domain shift strategies in seismic interpretation. Our benchmark encompasses over 200 combinations of model architectures, datasets and training strategies, across three diverse datasets (synthetic and real data) including FaultSeg3D, CRACKS, and Thebe. We systematically assess pretraining, fine-tuning, and joint training strategies under varying degrees of domain shift. Our analysis highlights that commonly used fine-tuning practices can lead to catastrophic forgetting, especially when source and target datasets are distributionally disjoint, and that larger models such as Segformer tend to be more robust to adaptation than smaller architectures. Interestingly, we also find that common domain adaptation methods outperform fine-tuning when the distributional shift is large, yet underperform when source and target domains are similar. Finally, we complement conventional segmentation metrics with a novel analysis based on fault characteristic descriptors, revealing how models absorb structural biases from different training datasets. Overall, we establish a robust experimental baseline to provide insights into the tradeoffs inherent to current fault delineation workflows, and shed light on directions for developing more generalizable, interpretable and effective machine learning models for seismic interpretation. The insights and analyses reported provide a set of guidelines on the deployment of fault delineation models within seismic interpretation workflows.

title: VVI-GFM: A Voltage Vector-Informed Grid-Forming Control for Post-Disturbance Fast Synchronization Recovery
authors: Rui Kong, Shan Jiang, Subham Sahoo, Georgios Konstantinou, Frede Blaabjerg
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Electronics
abstract: Maintaining synchronization stability after large grid disturbances is a vital requirement for grid-forming (GFM) converters. Existing enhanced GFM control strategies are often designed for a specific disturbance scenario, requiring extended recovery times or exhibiting frequency fluctuations. This paper reveals that synchronization instability triggered by two typical grid disturbance events, phase jumps and voltage sags, can be unified according to underlying similarities during the post-disturbance recovery. Based on these insights, this paper proposes a novel voltage vector-informed grid-forming (VVI-GFM) control strategy by fully leveraging the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$d$</tex-math></inline-formula>/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$q$</tex-math></inline-formula> components of the point of common coupling (PCC) voltage vector, which can offer fast synchronization recovery and minimize frequency deviations under both phase jumps and voltage sags. The post-disturbance dynamics of the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$d$</tex-math></inline-formula>/<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$q$</tex-math></inline-formula> components of the PCC voltage vector are quantitatively characterized, thus mechanistically demonstrating the effectiveness and applicability of the VVI-GFM control. Moreover, detailed guidelines about the feedforward path design and critical control parameter calculation are provided to ensure normal operation across varying grid strengths. Simulations and experimental results under diverse grid disturbance scenarios further validate the advantages and robustness of the proposed control strategy.

title: Robotic Double Patch Clamp Based on Interactive Mechanical Modeling for Functional Connectivity Measurement Between Neurons_supp6-3642790.pdf
authors: Qili Zhao
publish: N/A
abstract: Double patch clamp technique, using two micropipette electrodes to patch and measure electrophysiological signals of two neurons, is essential for investigating the functional connections between neurons in brain. However, the interactive mechanical disturbances from the dual-micropipette motions inside viscoelastic brain tissue cause dynamic drifts of neurons, making double patching low efficiency and challenging. In this paper, an interactive mechanical modeling of two micropipettes approaching two cells in elastic environment was established to estimate the dynamic drift of the cells. Based on that, a synchronous descent strategy, an appropriate relative position of two cells, and an online trajectory plan of two micropipettes were determined to improve double patch clamp efficiency. Finally, a robotic double patch clamp operation process was established for functional connectivity measurement between neurons in brain slice. The effectiveness of the proposed work is validated through both finite element modeling and experiments. The double patch clamp experiments on neurons in visual cortex demonstrate that our method achieves a 40% improvement in success rate and a 38% improvement in speed in comparison to the traditional manual method. With the above advantages, diverse functional connectivity activities between neurons were found using our system, paving a solid ground for further research.

title: TrajAgents: A Multi-Agent Framework for Interpretable and Semantically Consistent V2I Trajectory Prediction
authors: Yue Liu, Xingyuan Dai, Yonglin Tian, Rui Tian, Xinjie Dong, Yisheng Lv
publish: 2025 21st IEEE International Conference on Mechatronic and Embedded Systems and Applications (MESA)
abstract: Trajectory prediction is critical for autonomous vehicle planning. While single-view prediction has advanced, it remains limited by the ego vehicle’s narrow field of view and incomplete scene understanding, resulting in inaccurate predictions in occluded or complex interactive scenarios. Vehicle-to-Infrastructure (V2I) cooperation addresses this by offering broader context through roadside sensing and communication. However, effectively leveraging such rich semantic context remains challenging. Existing trajectory prediction methods primarily rely on lightweight predictors that emphasize dynamic feasibility, yet often overlook semantic cues provided by V2I, leading to physically plausible but semantically invalid trajectories. Conversely, vision language models (VLMs) excel in high-level semantic reasoning but struggle with accurate numerical prediction. To leverage the complementary strengths of lightweight predictors and VLMs, we propose TrajAgents, a multi-agent framework integrating trajectory-level prediction and semantic-level reasoning via five specialized agents. Results on V2X-Seq-TFD demonstrate TrajAgents’ superiority in accuracy and semantics consistency.

title: End-to-End Predictive Cruise Control of Connected Autonomous and Vehicles via Distributed Model Predictive Control
authors: Jiaze Li, Weinan Gao, Yujie Chen
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: This paper presents an end-to-end predictive cruise control (PCC) framework based on distributed model predictive control (DMPC) for the cooperative control of connected and autonomous vehicles (CAVs). By integrating multi-dimensional data including vehicle speed, headway, physical length, and traffic light phases, a two-stage optimal desicion is made to generate the optimal reference speed for platoons to reduce stops through intersections under safety constraints, thereby enhancing traffic efficiency. To follow the reference speed, the control layer employs a hierarchical architecture: the upper-layer PID generates torque demands, while the lower-layer DMPC dynamically manages powertrain energy and optimizes energy consumption and engine operating points via sequential quadratic programming (SQP). Simulations are conducted to verify precise speed tracking, ensure satisfaction of torque constraints, and effectively balance safety, energy efficiency, and traffic throughput.

title: Silent Threats, Smart Shields: A Dual-Strategy Framework Against Stealthy Attacks in EV Charging Systems
authors: Mohammed Almehdhar, Abdullatif Albaseer, Ala Al-Fuqaha, Mohamed Abdallah
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Smart electric vehicle charging stations (EVCSs) are crucial in advancing sustainable transportation by scheduling charging based on user preferences and grid constraints. However, their reliance on digital communication makes them vulnerable to attacks that can shift the EV aggregator’s load profile to different times, leading to substantial financial losses. They can also alter charging times in ways that degrade battery health and overburden the grid. Although the existing literature has explored various strategies to mitigate these risks, most prior work has focused on simple, handcrafted charge manipulation attacks (CMAs). This makes them often fall short when confronted with artificially intelligent methods to remain undetected. To address these limitations, we propose a novel framework that both generates and defends against highly evasive CMAs. First, we utilize deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to craft advanced, stealthy attacks capable of bypassing intrusion detection systems (IDS). Second, we introduce an IDS built on LSTM variational autoencoders, which captures the nuanced temporal dependencies of smart CMAs, as well as intricate patterns. This enables our IDS to significantly enhance the detection and mitigation of complex threats. We conduct extensive simulations using real-world datasets, which reveal critical security gaps in existing benchmark approaches while highlighting the strong performance of our proposed framework. Notably, our IDS achieves detection accuracies of 0.97, 0.96, and 0.96 across different scenarios, even against highly evasive CMAs.

title: Evaluation of Application-Oriented Relay Deployment in IEEE 802.11ah IoT Mesh Networks
authors: Yoshiko Sueda, Arata Koike
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: We evaluated the impact of relay node placements on communication performance in an IoT mesh network using IEEE 802.11ah (Wi-Fi HaLow™) through real-world experiments. Specifically, we investigated how the location of relay nodes affects TCP and UDP communication. While previous research on mesh networks have mainly relied on simulations, focused on Wi-SUN using smart meter infrastructure, or conventional Wi-Fi systems, few evaluations have been conducted for actual Wi-Fi HaLow equipment. This study provides practical insights through experiments conducted in a real environment using devices that support MAP mode. The results showed that TCP performance decreased with distance, whereas UDP was less affected.

title: Incorporating Serendipity and Receptivity into Personalized Recommendation Systems
authors: Naoki Matsukawawatari, Takahiro Uchiya, Yuichiro Tateiwa
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study proposes a personalized recommendation system that incorporates serendipity, the provision of unexpected items to users, and receptivity, a parameter representing the degree to which users are open to new genres. User receptivity and relevance are dynamically updated based on the user database, and a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) is employed to predict the genre likely to be preferred next. This enables flexible and effective recommendations aligned with user’s current preferences. Evaluation experiments conducted on the MovieLens-1M dataset demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in comparison with prior study.

title: A Contactor Design for the Commutation Path in Fuse-Current-Limiting Hybrid DC Circuit Breakers
authors: Yuki Okegawa, Shungo Zen, Nozomi Takeuchi, Wataru Ohnishi, Yusuke Nakano, Naoto Kodama, Yuki Inada
publish: 2025 IEEE 70th Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts (HLM)
abstract: Reliable and cost-effective DC circuit breakers (DC CBs) are essential for DC power systems. In a previous study, we developed a hybrid DC CB that utilizes a current-limiting fuse as the main path. Additionally, the commutation path incorporates a single IGBT and a contactor connected in series to suppress the voltage across the IGBT. However, its practical implementation faces challenges related to operational delay and speed. In this study, the limitations of using a typical contactor, a plate-plate contactor, is first verified. To address these challenges, two novel contactor designs is proposed: a hemisphere-plate contactor and a sliding contactor. These designs are expected to reduce the duration between the commutation and interruption, thereby providing a promising solution to ensure reliable fault current interruption in hybrid DC CBs.

title: Encryption-Aware PHY Security: Optimal Cooperative Jamming and Achievable Rates
authors: Mehdi Hosseinali Zadeh, Tarig Sadig, Mehdi Maleki, Nghi H. Tran, Hamid Reza Bahrami
publish: IEEE Communications Letters
abstract: Conventional physical layer (PHY) security assumes unencrypted transmissions, requiring zero information leakage to adversaries. By incorporating encryption, this constraint can be relaxed, enabling higher secure transmission rates while tolerating limited leakage. This paper investigates an encryption-aware power allocation strategy and achievable transmission rate of a Gaussian wiretap channel in the presence of multiple cooperative jammers. By analyzing the rate-equivocation region and the corresponding rate maximization problem, optimal cooperative jamming strategy that maximizes the encryption-aware secrecy capacity is first addressed. The encryption-aware rate maximization problem is then shown to be equivalent to a non-convex beamforming vector optimization under a non-linear constraint, which is explicitly solved. Our numerical results illustrate that by utilizing the prior knowledge of encryption, optimizing the power allocation among jamming nodes significantly enhances the achievable secrecy rates.

title: Environmental Knowledge-Driven Transfer Strategy With Collaborative Learning for Dynamic Constrained Multi-Objective Optimization_supp1-3643205.pdf
authors: Wei Song
publish: N/A
abstract: In recent years, transfer learning-based dynamic constrained multi-objective optimization algorithms (TL-DCMOAs) have shown great promise in handling dynamic constrained multi-objective optimization problems (DCMOPs). In existing TL-DCMOAs, environmental similarity is typically assessed by measures based on Euclidean distance. However, such measures merely capture overall numerical differences between two environments, which are sensitive to local fluctuations in environmental information, potentially leading to misjudgments of environmental similarity. Besides, most existing TL-DCMOAs leverage historical constrained and unconstrained Pareto-optimal solutions as knowledge, but neglect relations and implicit solutions behind them for acquiring knowledge. To address the above issues, an environmental knowledge-driven transfer strategy with collaborative learning (EKTS-CL) is proposed in this article. Specifically, we design two structural similarity measures (SSMs) which consider the mean, variance, and covariance of environmental information, to comprehensively assess the environmental structural discrepancies with respect to concentration, divergence, and correlation, respectively. Using SSMs, the most structurally similar historical unconstrained Pareto-optimal solutions (UPS) and constrained Pareto-optimal solutions (CPS) can be obtained. Additionally, true CPS and UPS share partial solutions across all environments or the majority of environments of a DCMOP. From the obtained CPS and UPS that separately approximate the true CPS and UPS of the current environment, we extract implicit shared solutions and exclusive ones through collaborative learning, providing high-quality knowledge than the obtained plain solutions for knowledge transfer. Our experimental results include comprehensive comparisons with seven state-of-the-art DCMOAs, and show that the proposed EKTS-CL brings significant performance improvements in solving DCMOPs.

title: A spatial-temporal seamless evapotranspiration product based on TSEB-SM model and DNN-ETo method across China_supp1-3642952.pdf
authors: Lisheng Song
publish: N/A
abstract: Accurate, seamless products of evapotranspiration (ET) are crucial for understanding the hydrological and energy cycles. Currently, there is no routinely available daily ET product based on the thermal infrared satellite data and two source energy balance (TSEB) models over China. In this study, we developed a seamless ET dataset (also including transpiration, T and evaporation, E) for China from 2001 to 2020, with spatial and temporal resolutions of 0.01° and daily, respectively. This dataset is generated through the two-source energy balance model coupled to soil moisture (TSEB-SM) and a novel reconstruction method (DNN-ETo) using deep neural networks and reference evapotranspiration. This dataset showed good agreement with ground measurements across various landcover types with a RMSE, bias, NSE and KGE of 1.02 mm day-1, -0.17 mm day-1, 0.51 and 0.73. Regarding spatial distributions and interannual variations, TSEB-SM ET exhibits similar performance to previous studies, while providing more reasonable values in the arid and semi-arid regions. The dataset has high potential in water resources management and climate change research. The TSEB-SM ET product is freely available at https://doi.org/10.11888/Terre.tpdc.301340.

title: LLM-based Fuzzing Method Using UI-based Input Value Generation for IoT Devices
authors: Hibiki Nakanishi, Kento Hasegawa, Seira Hidano, Kazuhide Fukushima, Nozomu Togawa
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: The widespread adoption of IoT devices has raised concerns about security, especially as these devices increasingly handle sensitive data. Many modern IoT devices are operated via web-based user interfaces (UIs), which may block communications not via the UI by existing protocol fuzzing due to authentication mechanisms. To address this, we propose a UI-based fuzzing approach that generates test inputs using a large language model (LLM) and mutates the generated inputs. Evaluation experiments on an IoT device demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in detecting vulnerabilities.

title: Predicting Dynamic Travel Time Between Points of Interest Using Machine Learning Models
authors: Shoma Kaji, Toshinori Takayama, Siya Bao, Nozomu Togawa
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: The travel planning problem aims to find the optimal travel routes between various points of interest (POIs), and routing searching methods such as Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) are commonly used for the problem-solution. These routing searching methods require fast and accurate travel time estimation. Traditional API (Application Programming Interface) provides accurate dynamic travel times, however, the response time might be second-level long. On the other hand, the machine-learning-based methods could predict efficiently at the microsecond level. Thus, we propose three machine-learning-based methods for dynamic travel time prediction using XGBoost, LightGBM, and CatBoost. We conducted the evaluation experiment with a $4.6 \times 10^{3} \mathrm{~km}^{2}$ area in Kyoto, Japan, and compared them with a commercial detailed route API. As a result, our proposed three methods succeed in predicting travel times with 10 ms which is two digits faster than API and the prediction error rate is between $-0.37 \%$ and $+0.31 \%$. Especially, the method using CatBoost obtains the fastest prediction speed of three digits faster than API.

title: Course Selection Optimization using pVSQA on Quantum Computers
authors: Takeru Ota, Tatsuhiko Shirai, Nozomu Togawa
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm (QAOA) is a quantum algorithm capable of solving combinatorial optimization problems on gate-based quantum computers. Postprocessing Variationally Scheduled Quantum Algorithm (pVSQA) is an enhanced approach that combines a quantum variational algorithm like QAOA with a postprocessing step that transforms infeasible solutions into feasible ones. Compared to QAOA, pVSQA can more efficiently solve constrained combinatorial optimization problems. In this paper, we define the personalized course selection problem (PCSP), which involves finding the optimal combination of courses for a student, and then propose a method that integrates a postprocessing algorithm into pVSQA to effectively solve PCSP. Experimental results show that, compared to conventional QAOA, pVSQA significantly improves both the probability to obtain feasible solutions and the energy expectation among feasible solutions.

title: Leveraging Textual Analysis and Predictive Modeling for Tourism Insights in India: A Machine Learning Approach
authors: H Pooja, C Shivakumar, Neeluri Punarvika, K Shreya, P. Sharani Sai, V Varun
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: This study explored the efficacy of regression models for predicting location ratings from textual and categorical data. The dataset, encompassing location details such as descriptive text and optimal visitation times, served as the foundation for training and evaluating models, including Support Vector Regression, Linear Regression, Random Forest Regressor, CatBoost Regressor, Gradient Boosting Regressor, XGBoost Regressor. To prepare the data for model training, preprocessing techniques were employed, such as stopword elimination for textual data and one-hot encoding for categorical features. The performance of these models was assessed using a combination of evaluation metrics: R-squared, Mean Squared Error, Root Mean Squared Error, Mean Absolute Error. Among the tested models, Gradient Boosting Regressor achieved the highest level of success, exhibiting a composite score of 0.625, surpassing other models in predictive accuracy. This work demonstrates the power of sophisticated machine learning techniques in predicting location ratings based on textual and categorical information, offering valuable insights for location-based services and decision-making processes.

title: Adaptive Neural Output-feedback Control for Discrete-time Hysteretic Nonlinear Systems and Their Applications
authors: Zhengnian He, Xiuyu Zhang, Xinkai Chen, Yue Wang, Yingzhou Wang, Miaolei Zhou
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: Hysteresis is a widespread nonlinear phenomenon in smart material actuators, and its presence reduces the positioning accuracy of the actuator, especially when creep is also present. In order to mitigate the butterfly-like hysteresis with creep in dielectric elastomer actuators (DEAs), an adaptive piecewie implicite inverse finite-time control scheme is proposed in this paper. The implicit inverse indicates that this is not a direct inverse of the hysteresis, but an online decoupling algorithm to approximate the search for the actual control signal. A state observer is built to estimate the unmeasurable state of the system, and the radial basis function neural networks are utilized to approximate the unknown dynamical part of the system, which is combined with the dynamic surface technique so that the system does not have to do complex coordinate transformations. It is proved that all signals of the closed-loop system are semiglobally finite-time stabilized (SGFTS). The effectiveness of the scheme is verified on the DEA actuated motion control platform.

title: Integrated lightning prediction system: Technological advances for safety and efficiency in mining
authors: Waterson Soares, Fabricio Fonseca, Luciano Guerra, Edmilson Castro, Guilherme Araujo
publish: 2025 IEEE ESW Brazil – Electrical Safety Workshop Brazil (ESW Brazil)
abstract: The phenomena of nature are still a great mystery to the scientific community, and we are sometimes surprised by uncertainties. Predicting lightning strikes is a critical need, especially in sectors such as mining, where workers are often exposed to open field conditions. To ensure the safety of these professionals, it is essential to use technologies that allow lightning to be accurately anticipated and effective alerts to be issued. This article highlights the importance of prediction systems that combine different technologies, such as weather radars, satellites, electric and magnetic field sensors, wind speed and relative humidity measurements, all in line with the NBR-16785 and IEC-62793 standards. The proposed methodology aims to optimize alert times, increasing safety and operational efficiency. The previous system, which relied mainly on weather radars, satellites and long-distance electromagnetic field measurements, was improved with the installation of point sensors that measure electric field, magnetic field, wind speed and relative humidity. This integration resulted in an average 80% reduction in the duration of alerts, providing significant gains in operation, maintenance and production in the mineral extraction and processing process. The model was implemented in several mines and evaluated during the full rainy season between 2024 and 2025, demonstrating its effectiveness in protecting workers and improving productivity. This innovative approach not only increases safety, but also contributes to the optimization of mining processes, showing that the combination of technologies can be the key to predicting and mitigating the risks associated with lightning strikes.

title: Experimental Analysis of Channel Estimation Algorithms in VANETs Considering Doppler Effects and High Mobility
authors: Yunjie Liu, Yi Li, Shuangshuang Han, Kasun Hemachandra, Yueyun Chen
publish: 2025 21st IEEE International Conference on Mechatronic and Embedded Systems and Applications (MESA)
abstract: Vehicular ad-hoc networks (VANETs) face significant challenges in channel estimation, primarily due to the rapidly changing environment and the impact of Doppler frequency shifts caused by high-speed vehicle movement. This paper aims to evaluate the performance of existing channel estimation algorithms under scenarios with Doppler frequency shifts through computational experiments, with the assessment metric being the bit error rate (BER) performance of the algorithms under various signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions. Based on simulation results, this paper systematically compares the effects of the least squares (LS), linear minimum mean square error (LMMSE), radial basis function (RBF), and genetic algorithm-optimized RBF (GA-RBF) in both relay-free and relayed scenarios, assessing their effectiveness in low-speed and high-speed environments. The results show that the LMMSE and GA-RBF algorithms significantly outperform other methods under high SNR conditions and high-speed scenarios, highlighting their robustness to Doppler frequency shifts. These findings provide valuable insights for the optimization of channel estimation technology in VANETs, and also offer key trade-offs for algorithm selection and optimization in dynamic channel environments.

title: RIB-SLAM: A Radar-Inertial-Barometer SLAM System with High-Precision Elevation Estimation
authors: Hang Zhen, Ronghe Jin, Zekai Luan, Zhi Gao
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: 4D radar is capable of providing four-dimensional observations, including velocity and three-dimensional spatial data, and demonstrates robustness under adverse weather con-ditions, leading to its widespread application. However, 4D radar data suffers from sparsity and noise, particularly along the vertical direction, resulting significant elevation drift in pure 4D Radar SLAM, which is difficult to address even with loop closure. This paper proposes a multi-sensor SLAM system based on Radar-Inertial-Barometer integration, where the IMU optimizes relative elevation between frames, and the barometer provides altitude information to constrain absolute elevation, thereby improving pose estimation, especially in elevation, and effectively mitigating radar drift. Experiments on the NTU4DRadLM dataset demonstrate that the proposed system achieves out-standing performance, even without loop closure, significantly improving the accuracy of 4D radar-based SLAM.

title: Deep Learning for Accurate Angular Speed Estimation: An LSTM-Based Strong Observer
authors: Iván Hernández, Luis Ibarra, Wen Yu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: Accurate angular speed estimation is critical for controlling mechanical and electromechanical systems. Linear Hall sensors are widely used for this purpose, but their signals are often distorted by magnet misalignment and manufacturing imperfections. These distortions introduce nonlinear effects that traditional filters and observers cannot handle effectively, leading to poor estimation performance. Conventional models often rely on compensation mechanisms to correct these distortions, but such strategies are limited and reflect the inability to fully capture the system's true behavior. This paper proposes a novel AI-powered strong observer using a single-layer Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural network. The method maps magnetic field measurements directly to angular speed, avoiding the need for compensation, explicit modeling, or prior knowledge of distortion characteristics. Trained on real-world data, the observer inherently captures nonlinearities and signal dynamics, providing robust and accurate estimation across a wide range of operating conditions. Experimental results confirm the effectiveness and practical advantages of the proposed approach in AI-based control and estimation systems.

title: Adaptive Neural Tracking Control for Switched Nonlinear Systems with Predictive Performance Based on Command Filter
authors: Xue Wang, Weimin Chen, Zhijie Ye
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: In this paper, a new prescribed performance control scheme is developed for a class of switched nonlinear systems. Firstly, a command filter is designed to reduce computational complexity. Through an effective compensatory mechanism, the impact of filter transients on control performance is eliminated. Secondly, a barrier function and a normalized function are introduced to achieve prescribed performance control, which ensures that the tracking error preserves in the prescribed boundary. Finally, a simulation example is presented to verify the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed control.

title: A High-Performance Sketch with Dynamic Memory Allocation for Priority-Oriented Data Stream Processing
authors: Jinbin Hu, Houqiang Shen, Jiawei Huang, R. Simon Sherratt, Jin Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computers
abstract: Sketch is widely used in many traffic estimation tasks due to its good balance among accuracy, speed, and memory usage. In scenarios with priority flows, priority-aware sketch, as an emerging method, provides differentiated detection accuracy for flows of different priorities, optimizing resource allocation and improving the detection accuracy of high-priority flows. However, existing priority-aware sketches methods struggle to effectively handle the dynamic changes in flow priority distribution in realworld detection environments, leading to wasted or insufficient storage space. To address this issue, this paper proposes a new priority-aware sketch with Dynamic Memory Allocation called DMA-Sketch. It dynamically adjusts the detection framework based on flow priority distribution information and adaptively allocates appropriate memory space to each storage region. The experimental results show that DMA-Sketch improves the overall priority accuracy, high-priority accuracy and throughput by up to 1.33×, 16.39× and 1.88×, respectively, under the scenarios with changing flow priority distribution over the state-of-the-art schemes.

title: Road Anomaly Detection by Integrating Features from On-board Edge System and XRAIN Data
authors: Chang Wang, Sho Takahashi, Masahiro Yagi, Toshio Yoshii
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper presents a winter road anomaly detection method aimed at improving model performance by integrating latent road features extracted from an on-board edge system with Extended Radar Information Network (XRAIN) data. The proposed method employs the Isolation Forest (iForest) model to identify anomaly under severe winter road environments. Experimental results show that the integration of multiple features significantly enhances the accuracy compared to the model using individual feature. Offering practical value for remote road monitoring and timely intervention in snowy regions.

title: Efficient Resource Allocation for Semantic Video Surveillance Transmission over LEO Satellites
authors: Mohamed Karaa, Hakim Ghazzai, Gianluca Setti, Lokman Sboui
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Video surveillance in remote areas poses significant challenges due to limited network coverage and the high data requirements of video transmission. In such environments, satellite communication offers a viable solution to provide coverage under limited bandwidth conditions. At the same time, emerging semantic communication technology addresses the issue of data volume by transmitting only the most relevant information. This work proposes a semantic communication framework for video surveillance data transmission in remote areas. The framework transmits compact semantic representations from cameras over LEO satellites using Narrowband communication technology. More importantly, we formulate and solve a resource allocation problem that maximizes semantic information transmission under bandwidth constraints by optimally selecting semantic representations and satellite resource units. Our approach demonstrates the feasibility of semantic video surveillance using limited-bandwidth IoT standards such as LTE eMTC and NB-IoT over LEO satellites.

title: An Embedding-Aware LSTM-Refined Feature Attention Network for Structured Cyber Attack Detection
authors: Akshat Gaurav, Brij B Gupta, Nadia Nedjah, Ching-Hsien Hsu, Kwok Tai Chui
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: An embedding-aware LSTM-refined feature attention network for structured cyberattack detection is presented in this work. The suggested model converts the input traffic into token-like representations by integrating continuous and categorical features using scaling and embedding layers, respectively. While values are refined using an LSTM layer to incorporate sequential context, queries and keys are generated using linear projections. These representations are aligned by an attention mechanism to highlight the most instructive aspects. The model’s robustness is demonstrated by evaluation on the CIC-DDoS2019 dataset, which yielded a 93% accuracy rate.

title: A Consideration on Visualization Function of Cyber Security Exercise Program for Beginners in Information Communication for Control System Operators
authors: Masatoshi Enomoto, Shu Hosokawa, Kenji Sawada
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper details the development of a cybersecurity exercise program designed for control system operators. The program is designed to guide participants to consider countermeasures using the PDCA cycle and verify the effectiveness of the considered countermeasures. The effectiveness of the countermeasures is verified using a test bed developed for the exercise. However, exercise outcomes revealed that while the impact of cyberattacks on the testbed is visible, the underlying communication patterns that cause these incidents are not. This lack of visibility hinders novice participants’ ability to analyze root causes. Therefore, this paper defines the requirements for a visualization function within the exercise program to enhance exercise effectiveness by illustrating attack scenarios and their associated communications. The findings from this definition process are also presented.

title: CAAC-Net: Combining Attention and Convolution for Deformable Medical Image Registration
authors: Zilong Xue, Kangjian He, Dan Xu, Jian Gong, Zihang Sun, Yijie He, Qingxin Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Deformable image registration plays a crucial role in image diagnosis, disease monitoring, and surgical navigation by establishing anatomical correspondences between moving and fixed images. Traditional methods typically require time-consuming iterative optimization processes, leading to high computational costs. Recently, deep learning techniques have gained significant attention in medical image registration, offering improved computational efficiency. However, these methods often rely on intensive computing and storage resources, which limits their applicability in resource-constrained environments. To address this issue, we propose CAAC-Net, a highly efficient network designed to reduce computational overhead while maintaining high registration accuracy. By introducing a dual-stream pyramid structure, CASA module, and CoConv module, we effectively reduce computational costs and improve registration performance. Experimental results demonstrate that CAAC-Net achieves the highest accuracy on the LPBA40 dataset, significantly reducing GPU memory usage while enhancing computational efficiency. These improvements make CAAC-Net well-suited for resource-constrained clinical applications.

title: Joint Fiber and Free Space Optical Infrastructure Planning for Hybrid Integrated Access and Backhaul Networks
authors: Charitha Madapatha, Piotr Lechowicz, Carlos Natalino, Paolo Monti, Tommy Svensson
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Integrated access and backhaul (IAB) is one of the promising techniques for 5G networks and beyond (6G), in which the same node/hardware is used to provide both backhaul and cellular services in a multi-hop architecture. Due to the sensitivity of the backhaul links with high rate/reliability demands, proper network planning is needed to ensure the IAB network performs with the desired performance levels. In this paper, we study the effect of infrastructure planning and optimization on the coverage of IAB networks. We concentrate on the cases where the fiber connectivity to the nodes is constrained due to cost. Thereby, we study the performance gains and energy efficiency in the presence of free-space optical (FSO) communication links. Our results indicate hybrid fiber/FSO deployments offer substantial cost savings compared to fully fibered networks, suggesting a beneficial trade-off for strategic link deployment while improving the service coverage probability. As we show, with proper network planning, the service coverage, energy efficiency, and cost efficiency can be improved.

title: Coexistence of Real-Time Source Reconstruction and Broadband Services Over Wireless Networks
authors: Anup Mishra, Nikolaos Pappas, Čedomir Stefanović, Onur Ayan, Xueli An, Yiqun Wu, Petar Popovski, Israel Leyva-Mayorga
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Achieving flexible and efficient wireless resource sharing across diverse applications and services is among the key goals of the sixth-generation of mobile systems (6G). This work investigates the performance of a real-time system coexisting with a broadband service in a frame-based wireless channel. Specifically, we consider a remote tracking device that monitors an information source and transmits updates to a base station (BS) for real-time source reconstruction, and potential remote actuation. We revise the common idealized assumptions in real-time remote tracking studies, such as instantaneous feedback and pervasive wireless resources, as they do not hold in practical scenarios. We consider a monitoring device and a broadband user communicating with the BS via a grant-free access mechanism over wireless resources defined for either orthogonal or non-orthogonal access, with feedback scheduled at the end of each frame. We analyze system performance using goal-oriented performance metrics for real-time remote reconstruction, alongside throughput and energy efficiency for the broadband user. Our results show that the ‘Idealistic’ model considered in conventional studies achieves better performance but incurs disproportionately high overhead compared to the Frame-Based model. Moreover, within the Frame-Based model, orthogonal resource sharing is preferable for maximizing broadband throughput, while non-orthogonal sharing significantly improves energy efficiency.

title: CSI-Driven Physical Layer Secret Key Generation for FDD Systems
authors: Ehsan Olyaei Torshizi, Anas Alashqar, Werner Henkel
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Physical Layer Secret Key Generation (PLSKG), which utilizes wireless channel reciprocity, is increasingly adopted to secure wireless communications. In Time Division Duplexing (TDD) systems, the inherent channel reciprocity facilitates the generation of cryptographic keys without requiring a key exchange process. Conversely, Frequency Division Duplexing (FDD) systems present greater challenges for key generation due to the use of distinct frequency bands for uplink and downlink, resulting in differing frequency responses. In this paper, we address this challenge by modeling the channel along with connecting cables as a two-port network and utilizing the reciprocity principles applicable to such networks within the same frequency range. For key generation, we construct the channel profile for each FDD band by utilizing the amplitude of the bidirectional scattering parameters S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">12</inf> and S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">21</inf> in two closely spaced FDD bands, thereby ensuring the required reciprocity in FDD systems. To assess the practicality of the proposed scheme, we analyze its performance across various indoor scenarios and compare it with other key generation schemes using multiple performance indicators. The comparative results confirm the feasibility and effectiveness of our scheme in terms of randomness and key disagreement ratio.

title: A Program of Physical Rehabilitation with Wearable SEPC Devices During Intradialytic Improves Inflammatory Markers and the Fitness in Chronic Kidney Disease Patients: A Randomized Clinical Trial
authors: ShuCheng Wu, ChuanChia Wang, Chen Han, ShuJen Lin, JwoShiun Sun, TungJing Fang
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Individuals with chronic kidney disease (CKD) and end-stage renal disease (ESRD) have a systemic inflammatory state. Regular exercise may have beneficial anti-inflammatory effects, but this is unclear in hemodialysis (HD) patients. We assessed the promoted effects of passive resistance exercise on inflammatory markers in ESRD with HD patients. Smart External Pulsatile Compression (SEPC) device on the lower leg, that is integrating sophisticated wearable biosensors, intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) for passive resistance muscle exercise and peripheral venous return enhancement. Fifty ESRD patients were randomly assigned to the SEPC exercise or the control group. Twenty-five HD patients from a center where intradialytic SEPC was offered thrice weekly and 25 HD patients received usual care HD. Passive exercising patients aimed to SEPC lower leg for 4 hours. After 6 months, the SEPC exercise group presented a significant reduction in measures of inflammation [C-reactive protein (CRP), tumor necrosis factor-a (TNF-a), classical monocytes; all P<0.01]. Six months of regular intradialytic SEPC exercise improved physical function (sit-to-stand 60) and functional capacity. These findings suggest that regular intradialytic SEPC exercise is associated with an anti-inflammatory effect at a circulating cellular level. SEPC improved physical function and functional capacity that is associated with chronic inflammation.

title: Measurement of tip movement of minimally invasive vibrator for ultrasonic growing rod
authors: Yudai Kitano, Koji Makino, Naofumi Taniguchi, Tetsuro Ohba, Takaaki Ishii, Yasumi Ito, Hirotaka Haro, Hidetsugu Terada
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In past research, we developed a growing rod system that expands and contracts inside the human body. This system can be used for spinal fusion, and by applying ultrasonic vibration, it can be expanded and contracted as the wearer grows and with changes in symptoms. In addition, a minimally invasive vibrator was developed to shift the system’s position with only simple surgery. In past research, the vibration exciter was evaluated using only ultrasonic measurements. This paper describes the measurement of the tip displacement for the developed vibrator using an optical fiber displacement meter. The experimental results confirmed that at the tip of the vibrator, there is a periodic amplitude that matched the results of previous frequency measurements, demonstrating the effectiveness of the vibrator.

title: A Note on Quantitative Evaluation Road Users’ Perceived Safety Based on Color Image Sequence
authors: Yuki Kitahashi, Chinami Fukui, Sho Takahashi, Masahiro Yagi, Toshio Yoshii
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In engineering systems, being able to understand a safe state is just as important as safety. However, in the field of street space design, a standardized method for the quantitative assessment of perceived safety has not yet been established. This paper aims to quantitatively evaluate variations in drivers’ perception of safety within a VR road simulation, assuming that the level of relaxation is a major contributing factor to perceived safety. Therefore, we try a noncontact heart rate (HR) measurement method known as remote photoplethysmography (rPPG), which estimates HR through video analysis. Using HR variations, we evaluate road users’ perceived safety.

title: Creating a Rich Indoor Multi-Path Environment for Terahertz using Random Phase Reflectors
authors: Suresh Singh, Thanh Le
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: In order to support emerging wireless applications, it is critical to provide users with ubiquitous high data rate connections. The emerging 6G standards are considering utilizing part of the terahertz spectrum for this purpose. However, this part of the spectrum suffers from significant distance based attenuation as well as blockage by most materials including foliage, paper, walls, etc. The challenge therefore is to ensure coverage in complex indoor environments. A second factor that needs to be considered is that for line of sight connections, MIMO capacity is lower than in a rich multi-path environment. Unfortunately, due to propagation limitations, multi-path propagation is mostly absent at this frequency.This paper proposes a novel design for a reflector that satisfies the need for coverage planning as well as providing a multi-path environment which can support high data rate MIMO links. The reflectors consist of multiple passive elements that add a random phase to the reflected signal. We build such reflectors and characterize their performance in a terahertz testbed for frequencies in the range 325 - 500 GHz. We use the channel impulse response to estimate the maximum possible capacity. We show that our reflectors do indeed provide a channel for high capacity MIMO links as compared to polished reflectors that are commonly used for coverage planning.

title: Multimodal Approach in Analyzing Topic Trends from Vietnamese Newspapers
authors: Hoan Huu Le, Ryosuke Harakawa, Masahiro Iwahashi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This research proposes a topic extraction method by time-series processing (TSP) and natural language processing (NLP). Most of the previous methods used an NLP approach (semantic characteristics) to extract topics from the vast amount of documents. These previous methods do not take advantage of time-series characteristics that can find the relationship between real events and the extracted topics. Unlike previous methods, we utilized GLIPCA (TSP method) and BERT (NLP method) for the topic extraction task. This approach could not only explore the latent topics from documents by using semantic features, but also improve the interpretability of topics based on the dynamics of trends. We conducted experiments on Vietnamese newspapers with different approaches. As a result, our method outperforms the other methods. These results indicate the potential of a combination of TSP and NLP in exploring the important pattern of trend-topics.

title: GFlowNets for Active Learning Based Resource Allocation in Next Generation Wireless Networks
authors: Charbel Bou Chaaya, Mehdi Bennis
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: In this work, we consider the radio resource allocation problem in a wireless system with various integrated functionalities, such as communication, sensing and computing. We design suitable resource management techniques that can simultaneously cater to those heterogeneous requirements, and scale appropriately with the high-dimensional and discrete nature of the problem. We propose a novel active learning framework where resource allocation patterns are drawn sequentially, evaluated in the environment, and then used to iteratively update a surrogate model of the environment. Our method leverages a generative flow network (GFlowNet) to sample favorable solutions, as such models are trained to generate compositional objects proportionally to their training reward, hence providing an appropriate coverage of its modes. As such, GFlowNet generates diverse and high return resource management designs that update the surrogate model and swiftly discover suitable solutions. We provide simulation results showing that our method can allocate radio resources achieving 20% performance gains against benchmarks, while requiring less than half of the number of acquisition rounds.

title: Design and Implementation of Sensor Modules and Gateway System Using ESP32 for RAS Pond Monitoring
authors: Juan Manuel Betancourth-García, Alvaro Navarro-Pérez, Ramiro Arango, Jose Bestier Padilla Bejerano
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Colombian BioCAS Workshop
abstract: The design and implementation of a fixed, hardware-centric monitoring system for Recirculating Aquaculture Systems (RAS) is presented in this paper. Focusing exclusively on edge data acquisition and transmission to an MQTT broker. The architecture consists of distributed sensor nodes—each based on an ATmega328P microcontroller interfaced with different probes to measure dissolved oxygen, pH, water temperature, ambient humidity, nitrates, and turbidity. The sysmtem is networked via Zigbee (XBee S2) to a central ESP32 coordinator running FreeRTOS. Sensor readings are sampled at configurable intervals, serialized as JSON packets, and relayed over MQTT to a remote server for downstream processing. Emphasis is placed on reliable Zigbee mesh communication, which has been verified to guarantee the connectivity between the modules over time. Also, the system uses a real-time tasks scheduling on FreeRTOS, as well as, employs “last will” messages to detect a communication fault. By isolating the hardware layer and MQTT uplink, this work lays the foundation for scalable, lowcost RAS monitoring deployments without addressing cloud-side visualization or analytics.

title: Optimization of PK/PD Models for Remifentanil Using Genetic Algorithms
authors: Lina María Rodríguez Romero, Juan Carlos Beltrán Gasca, Alvaro D. Orjuela-Cañón
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Colombian BioCAS Workshop
abstract: This study investigates the application of genetic algorithms (GAs) for the optimization of pharmacokinetic/pharmacodynamic (PK/PD) models of Remifentanil, with the goal of improving the selection of relevant covariates and their impact on drug clearance prediction. Two clearance functions were compared-one population-based and the other normalized-using a GA minimization model. The results indicated that a simpler, parallelized GA model outperformed more complex models that included penalties such as parsimony and elitism. The final model selection was based on an analysis that combined mathematical accuracy and the clinical relevance of the covariates.

title: Trustworthy Privacy-Preserving Federated Large Language Models for the Internet of Medical Things
authors: Selma Bououdina
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) devices has led to an unprecedented volume of sensitive health data generated at the edge. Leveraging this data for intelligent healthcare solutions necessitates models that are both powerful and privacy-conscious. This paper introduces a federated learning framework employing Large Language Models (LLMs) tailored for IoMT environments. By decentralizing training across edge devices, our approach ensures data privacy while harnessing the contextual understanding capabilities of LLMs. We address challenges unique to IoMT, including heterogeneous data distributions, limited computational resources, and stringent latency requirements. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that our federated LLM approach achieves competitive performance compared to centralized models, with significant improvements in data privacy and communication efficiency. This work underscores the potential of integrating federated LLMs into IoMT ecosystems, paving the way for advanced, privacy-preserving healthcare applications at the edge.

title: Sound Source Localization at Long Distances Using a Compact Microphone Array on an Edge Computing Platform
authors: Rintaro Sakiyama, Keito Ishikawa, Yoshikazu Koike
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In this study, we investigate the feasibility of accurate sound source localization using an edge computing platform equipped with two microphone arrays. Localization is achieved using a minimal setup consisting of two digital MEMS microphone arrays connected to an edge device. In general, when the sound source is located at a distance much greater than the spacing between the arrays, the localization accuracy tends to deteriorate. Specifically, we evaluate the performance of the Sony Spresense board under such conditions.
