title: Influence of Ni and Zn coatings on the microstructure of steel electrodes
authors: Christoph Kenel, Pierre Corfdir, Luca Sulmoni, Patrick Sütterlin
publish: 2025 IEEE 70th Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts (HLM)
abstract: Splitter plates are a key component in the arcing chamber of low voltage switchgear to cool down the arc and build up voltage for current limitation. During breaking, the arc enters the stack of plates and burns in between the plates, melting their surfaces. In this work, we analyze the effect that the arcing has on the steel microstructure and on the affected material depth. Coatings with Zn and Ni are compared to uncoated steel during controlled arcing experiments on test electrodes (steel, Zn) and splitter plate stacks (Ni). Surface imaging and cross-section analysis are combined with elemental mapping and crystal orientation measurements to study the alloying and removal of the coatings from the steel base. These experiments allow to estimate the depth at which splitter plates are affected during arcing and the effect of alloying of base and coating.

title: Torque Transfer for Handling Enhancement with Optimal Distribution and Adaptive Control Strategy in Real-Vehicle Implementation
authors: Heping Ling, Chao Li
publish: 2025 21st IEEE International Conference on Mechatronic and Embedded Systems and Applications (MESA)
abstract: The electric powertrain operates in many kinds of driving forms. The core principle is to make the most of the special traits of separately controllable torque and quick response. By reasonably distributing driving torques to the wheels or transferring torque between axles, the wheels can obtain greater adhesion, ensure the longitudinal driving ability and greater adhesion margin. To broaden the boundary capacity of dynamic handling for a four-wheel-drive electric vehicle, emphasis should be placed on the torque distribution strategy. This research introduces a DP(Dynamic Programming)-based optimal torque allocation and an adaptive RBFNN(Radial Basis Function Neural Network)-PID(Proportional-Integral-Derivative) control strategy for enhancing electric vehicle handling and stability. DP is utilized to obtain the optimal torque distribution coefficient: when oversteering, the coefficient drops from 100% to 0% for stability; during understeer, it rises from 0% to 100% to improve yaw rate response. Co-simulation shows the strategy can pre-emptively control the vehicle and extend its steady-state speed range. Real vehicle tests reveal a 2.7 km/h increase in maximum stable speed relative to front-wheel drive under steady state turns. At 55 km/h yaw with ESP off, it averts instability compared to rear-wheel drive, validating the practical feasibility and effectiveness of proposed control strategy.

title: Clinching - Creating an electrical model
authors: Max Huter, Christian Hildmann, Stephan Schlegel, Maria Kosse
publish: 2025 IEEE 70th Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts (HLM)
abstract: For reasons of sustainability and cost-effectiveness, efficient joining processes should be applied to manufacture components for electrical applications. A suitable joining technology for this purpose is clinching. This joining technology is already being used for mechanical applications such as joining car body parts or housings. Only in a few applications, clinching is used for current-carrying connections so far. In order to exploit the possible potential of electrical applications, the design of clinch joints and the evaluation criteria must be evolved. For defining the designs of clinch joints for electrical applications, it is necessary to gain a deeper understanding of the contact behavior. Therefore, FE-Models were built considering a detailed geometric description of the characteristic areas of the clinch joints. For these areas, a specific Electrical-Contact-Conductance (ECC) was assigned, which maps the contact behavior. The parameterization was validated experimentally. With the FE-Models, the portions of bulk resistance and contact resistance as part of the joint resistance could be determined as well as the relevant current paths in the clinch joints. The results of this study lead to a better understanding of the contact behavior and is a basis for optimization of clinch joints. For the investigated clinch joints, it was found that the highest ECC values have to be set in the bottom-area, in which, in some cases, only a small percentage of the current commutates between the contact partners.

title: An Electroencephalogram Based Neural Networks for Enhancing anti-Interference Capability
authors: Deng-Ying Liu, Tin-Yu Wu, Shin-Lung Yang, Yi-Zhen Liu, Yu-Xiu Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: An electroencephalography (EEG) is typically used to detect brain diseases and sleep disorders. Nevertheless, EEG signals are easily interfered by either external interferences, like magnetic field or metal interferences, or internal interferences, like eye blinks or head movements. For this reason, it is challenging to identity if a signal comes from a brainwave or an artifact. At present, for signal correction, we can use software or hardware, including Wavelet Transform, Fourier Transform and Filters. Based on the existing studies, some use BP and RBF neural networks for EEG signal recognition, and four types of brainwaves, including δ wave, θ wave, α wave and β wave, are used to recognize each signal's source. This paper proposes to use the Rectified Linear Unit (ReLu) function because its formula is simple and focuses on the maximum value only. Our proposed method replaces the transfer function in the hidden layer of BP neural network with a ReLU function. Through "training" in the experiment, the initial weight can be adjusted to reduce bias in neural networks and improve convergence performance for enhancement of anti-interference capability.

title: Evaluating the Effectiveness of Adding Support Structures to 3D-Printed Oboe Reeds
authors: Fumihiko Kurosawa, Naoto Wakatsuki, Tadashi Ebihara
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study addresses the challenge of replicating the acoustic properties of natural cane in 3D-printed oboe reeds, given the significant differences in material stiffness. We propose and evaluate a method for tuning the reed’s response by integrating an internal support structure, focusing on geometric modification rather than material alteration. Reeds with and without this structure were fabricated using stereolithography (SLA) and their acoustic performance and mechanical compliance were compared against traditional cane reeds. Acoustic analysis revealed that while the supported reed exhibited harmonic profiles similar to cane in the low and high registers, it produced significant harmonic amplification in the mid-register (C5-G5). This amplification is attributed to a 15% decrease in mechanical compliance, confirmed via static load tests, which lowered the reed’s natural frequency and caused resonance. This research demonstrates that geometric design is an effective strategy for controlling the resonance of synthetic reeds, offering a promising pathway to compensate for material property disparities and tune acoustic characteristics.

title: In-situ monitoring of electrode wear during arcing
authors: Pierre Corfdir, Luca Sulmoni, Christoph Kenel, Patrick Sütterlin
publish: 2025 IEEE 70th Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts (HLM)
abstract: The wear of electric contacts, arc runners and splitter plates during arcing in electromechanical switchgear represents a major challenge for the electric life of the device. Here, we use laser shadowgraphy to monitor in-situ the wear of copper, aluminum and steel surfaces during arcing at currents up to 1 kA. During arcing, a pool of molten metal forms at the arc attachment region. We observe bubbles that develop and burst, leading to the emission of molten metal drops. Using image processing techniques, we track the evolution of the contour of the electrode’s surface and evaluate the evolution of the wear with varying current, material, and current flow direction. When going from copper to aluminum and steel, bubbling during arcing gets stronger, which we attribute to the respective micro-structure, thermal properties and surface tension of these metals. Finally, cathodes and anodes exhibit different bubbling behavior, which we discuss in terms of arc root diameter and motion, current density and temperature at the arc root location.

title: RAG based Question Answering of Accounting Knowledge
authors: Takashi Mitadera, Shohei Iida, Kuta Takahashi, Rikuto Tsuchida, Ryo Hasegawa, Takehito Utsuro, Youchao Lin, Rie Shishido
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In this paper, we introduce the Yayoi QA v1.1 dataset, a comprehensive resource tailored for question answering in accounting domain, and evaluate responses generated within a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) framework. The dataset is derived from systematically curated tutorial pages published by Yayoi Co., Ltd., a leading accounting software company in Japan, covering a breadth of content from fundamental knowledge about accounting laws and procedures to detailed instructions on using accounting applications. It is designed to answer a wide range of questions posed by non-expert users performing accounting tasks. Employing an embedding-based search mechanism, we retrieve the top five documents most similar to each query, and then propose multiple methods for using large language models (LLMs) to generate contextually accurate answers grounded in the retrieved information. We conduct evaluation experiments with various LLMs for each proposed method. Human assessments of our experimental results indicate that the proposed methods achieve a high accuracy rate of 90.00% when handling specialized accounting questions.

title: Automated Detection and Quantification of Midline Shift in Traumatic Brain Injury Using CT Images
authors: Qing Ouyang, Wuxiu Zhang, Yuan Ma, Yunzhe Zou, Bing Sun, Zhonglan Tang, Jing Zhang, Ling He
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: Midline shift is a critical biomarker of mass effect in traumatic brain injury, directly influencing neurosurgical decisions and patient prognosis. Current MLS quantification relies heavily on manual measurements, which are timeconsuming, subjective, and prone to inter-observer variability. This study presents a fully automated, training-free geometric pipeline for robust MLS detection from CT images. The framework avoids manual annotation or machine learning by using principal component analysis to define the brain's symmetry axis and operates in three stages: selecting the optimal slice, identifying ventricles to establish the reference axis, and detecting the midline shift magnitude and direction. Tested on 20 TBI patient datasets comprising 420 CT slices, the method showed strong correlation with expert annotations (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{r}=0.869$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}<$</tex> 0.001) and clinically acceptable mean absolute error (2.25 mm). It achieved 80% accuracy in classifying clinical severity (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<5 ~\text{mm}$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5-10 ~\text{mm},>10 ~\text{mm}$</tex>). These results demonstrate the feasibility of accurate, reproducible, and training-free MLS quantification for TBI assessment.

title: The Design of Single-Bit Fully Parallel Pipeline FFT
authors: Wei Li, Shuo Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: With the ongoing convergence of radar, electronic warfare, and communications, receivers demand real-time spectral analysis that is ultra-wideband, low-latency, and highthroughput. To meet these requirements under low-cost and small-form-factor constraints, we propose a real-time frequencymeasurement scheme that combines RFSoC direct sampling and 1-bit quantization with a fully parallel, pipelined FFT. The RF signal is directly sampled by the high-speed ADC integrated in the RFSoC, while a 256 -point, fully parallel, pipelined FFT is implemented on the PL side, yielding one spectrum per clock cycle. With 1-bit inputs, the core computation avoids DSP multipliers and is implemented primarily using LUT resources. The consistency verification based on MATLAB and Verilog shows that the main peak localization and spectral morphology are consistent with the reference spectrum. The platform adopts Zynq UltraScale+RFSoC. Under experimental conditions, the maximum sampling rate can reach <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.9 \text{GS} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>. After steady state, it can output the spectrum by beat and measure the frequency in real time. The scheme is suitable for instantaneous wideband frequency measurement, rapid signal-presence detection, and superheterodyne-assisted receiver front ends, among other scenarios.

title: Exploring Ultra-Low-Dimensional End-to-End Neural Vocoder Using Primary Speech Parameters
authors: Sumiharu Kobayashi, Tetsuo Kosaka, Takashi Nose, Akinori Ito
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper explores ultra-low-dimensional neural vocoders in an end-to-end manner. In our previous work, we proposed a controllable and high-fidelity end-to-end neural vocoder to improve the quality and controllability of speech synthesis. Nine parameters, including formants and fundamental frequency (F0), were used as the input of the vocoder. In this paper, we further examine reducing the number of parameters by focusing on primary speech parameters. The experimental results demonstrate that high-quality speech waveforms can be synthesized with low character error rate (CER) and speaker similarity using only four primary speech parameters.

title: Learning to Detect Fake News Early: A Multi-Task Approach with Generalized Distillation and Dynamic Graph
authors: Tomoki Abe, Soh Yoshida, Mitsuji Muneyasu
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Fake news on social media represents a serious societal challenge. While detection methods based on propagation patterns show high accuracy, they face the limitation of only being effective after significant diffusion has occurred. This paper proposes a novel approach combining generalized distillation and multi-task learning with dynamic graph representations to improve detection accuracy during the early stages of information spread. Building upon our previously proposed dynamic graph convolutional network that incorporates temporal information, we introduce knowledge distillation from a full-time model and a diffusion prediction auxiliary task specifically for limited data within the first hour of propagation. Experiments conducted on the FakeNewsNet and PHEME datasets demonstrate improved classification accuracy compared to baseline models, confirming the effectiveness of our approach for early detection of fake news.

title: Robotic Surveillance with Channel State Information for Object Tracking and Counting
authors: Rojin Zandi, Kian Behzad, Maral Mordad, Hojjat Salehinejad, Milad Siami
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Accurate detection and enumeration of mobile robots in indoor environments is a fundamental requirement for applications such as smart warehouses, collaborative robotics, and automated logistics systems. Conventional vision-based approaches for localization and object counting are often constrained by occlusions, illumination variations, and high computational overhead. Channel State Information (CSI) derived from commodity Wi-Fi signals provides a robust alternative, enabling passive, device-free sensing and reliable localization in GPS-denied environments. This paper introduces a CSI-driven framework for estimating the number of mobile robots in a controlled indoor setting and for localizing an individual robot within predefined spatial zones. By exploiting fine-grained channel measurements from existing Wi-Fi infrastructure, the proposed method offers a scalable, low-cost, and real-time solution that effectively mitigates the limitations of traditional vision-based sensing techniques.

title: On the Feasibility of Distributed Phase Synchronization for Coherent Signal Superposition
authors: Alphan Şahin
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: In this study, we analyze the feasibility of distributed phase synchronization for coherent signal superposition, a fundamental enabler for paradigms like coherent over-the-air computation (OAC), distributed beamforming, and interference alignment, under mobility and hardware impairments. With the focus on coherent OAC, we introduce phase-coded pilots (PCPs), a strategy where the radios communicate with each other to eliminate the round-trip phase change in the uplink (UL) and downlink (DL) to align the phase of the received symbol at a desired angle. In this study, considering a carrier frequency offset (CFO)-resilient multi-user procedure, we derive the statistics of the phase deviations to assess how fast the phase coherency degrades. Our results show that residual CFO is a major factor determining the duration of phase coherency, in addition to the non-negligible effects of mobility and the number of nodes in the network. We also provide a proof-of-concept demonstration for coherent signal superposition by using off-the-shelf radios to demonstrate the feasibility of PCPs in practice.

title: A Scalable Video Analysis Framework for Character Identification and Statistical Profiling
authors: Chin-Chia Liu, Qing-Feng Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This research presents a flexible, scalable framework for automated video character analysis, designed to efficiently process large-scale video datasets. The framework integrates a multi-stage pipeline of preprocessing, feature extraction, unsupervised clustering, and statistical profiling to address detection, motion tracking, and density-based clustering. Implemented in a distributed environment, it leverages MediaPipe, YOLOv3, FaceNet, UMAP, and HDBSCAN to achieve robust character identification and generate insightful statistical outputs, including appearance timelines, co-occurrence mappings, and clothing color trends. Evaluated on the VoxCeleb dataset with 10,545 frames, the framework achieves 74.56% identification accuracy, outperforming baselines like MTCNN + VGGFace and OpenFace. Challenges in complex scenarios are addressed with mitigation strategies, enhancing applicability in media analytics, surveillance, and recommendation systems.

title: Submodular Optimization Based Co-Inference in Space-Air-Ground Integrated Vehicular Networks
authors: Suyao Huang, Bo Xu, Guijin Tang, Haotong Cao, Linghao Zhang, Haitao Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Space-air-ground integrated vehicular networks (SAGVN) play a crucial role in the 6G system, offering global coverage and ultra-wide-area broadband access. Meanwhile, advancements in artificial intelligence (AI) have led to a significant increase in model inference demands, which come with stringent latency requirements. In this paper, considering the intelligent services in SAGVN, we explore the co-inference problem and improve the inference efficiency by performing model splitting, vehicle association, and resource allocation. This problem is solved iteratively by decomposing it into multiple sub-problems. In particular, the model splitting problem is addressed by systematically searching for the optimal split points. Besides, the joint vehicle association and resource allocation problem are reformulated into a monotone submodular function without satellites, and then a low-complexity submodular optimization algorithm is proposed. To further utilize the computing power of the satellite, we further introduce a resource reallocation algorithm based on the existing optimization results. These two subproblems can iterate alternately until the optimization goal converges. Simulation results show that the proposed algorithm can achieve better latency performance in several inference tasks.

title: Multi-Head Reinforcement Learning Based Resource Allocation for Integrated Sensing and Communications
authors: Po-Chen Wu, Ting-Hui Wang, Li-Hsiang Shen, Kai-Ten Feng
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) enables the simultaneous operation of communication and sensing functionalities, leading to improved efficiency and performance. Furthermore, multi-AP coordination (MAP-Co), which provides higher transmission coverage and capacity, has attracted significant attention. Therefore, in this paper, we propose an indoor ISAC scenario assisted by the MAP-Co scheme. By jointly optimizing transmit power, bandwidth, and subchannel selection, we aim to maximize transmission throughput while guaranteeing a minimum required human presence detection accuracy. To effectively solve the complicated task, we propose a novel multi-head self-attention-assisted reinforcement learning (MH-SARL) algorithm. In our algorithm, the communication head is designed to search for the optimal resource allocation policy to maximize transmission throughput, whilst the sensing head focuses on suggesting adequate spectrum utilization to satisfy the predefined sensing quality. Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed MH-SARL algorithm under different scenarios and parameter settings. Compared to other benchmarks in the open literature, MH-SARL can achieve the highest transmission rate of at least 5% increase with guaranteed sensing accuracy.

title: Multi-Agent Interior-Point Policy Optimization Algorithm for Multi-Objective Resource Allocation Problem
authors: Shuo Sun, Xuesi Zhao, Yangchen Li, Yujie Chen, Tao Yang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: This paper focuses on the multi-objective resource allocation problem in multi-agent systems, where the objective is to find an optimal allocation policy. To solve this problem, we propose the multi-agent interior-point policy optimization (MAIPO) algorithm. Firstly, by introducing the weighted <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$L_{p}$</tex> preference index, the multi-objective resource allocation problem is transformed into a constrained single-objective problem, where the weight of each objective is determined by relative importance. Next, a multi-agent interior point policy optimization reinforcement learning algorithm is designed to solve the transformed problem. Finally, we demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms by simulations.

title: Optimizing TinyML: User-oriented Trade-offs in Accuracy and Energy Consumption
authors: Tobiasz Puslecki, Krzysztof Walkowiak
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: This paper proposes a user-configurable approach to energy-efficient machine learning inference in TinyML devices. TinyML is the deployment of machine learning models on lowpower, resource-constrained devices at the edge. Rather than relying on a single monolithic model, our method allows switching between classification models of varying complexity based on user preferences or system conditions. Inspired by power-saving modes in consumer electronics, we introduce a method where users can select between a high-accuracy or energy-saving mode. Using a Random Forest classifier on the HAR, WISDM and PAMAP2 datasets and deploying models to STM32MP257F MPU, we demonstrate that varying the number of decision trees allows a balance between prediction accuracy and energy consumption. Experimental results show that energy savings (depending on the mode) can be achieved with minimal loss of classification quality. This flexible model-switching approach offers a promising direction for future adaptive TinyML systems, especially in battery-constrained environments.

title: Experimental Studies of Near-Field Beamfocusing with Extra-Large Antenna Array Prototype
authors: Matthew Mora, Yuanzhe Gong, Robert Morawski, Tho Le-Ngoc
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: An extra-large antenna array prototype operating between 3.35 GHz and 3.6 GHz was developed to experimentally study near-field beamfocusing and its distance-dependent radiation patterns. Using a 1×24 uniform linear sub-array, a 3 dB beam depth of 0.6 m was achieved at a beamfocusing distance of 0.8 m from the array. When transmitting a 64QAM 20 MHz modulated signal, the near-field beamfocusing approach yielded 9.6 dB higher received in-band power and improved error vector magnitude by 6.4 dB compared to the conventional far-field beamforming vector, resulting in high-quality constellation diagrams. Extensive measurements were conducted in the anechoic chamber to evaluate the distance-dependent radiation patterns and beam depth of uniform linear arrays with varying aperture sizes. Simulation results incorporating spherical wavefront characteristics demonstrated good agreement with the experimental observations.

title: Adaptive Working-Memory Allocation Driven by Static and Dynamic Fatigue Indices
authors: Qian Wu, Atsushi Kanai
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Resource-rational working memory (WM) models typically assume stable cognitive capacity, failing to account for fatigue effects that progressively degrade performance. We present a theoretical framework that captures both immediate and cumulative fatigue impacts on WM allocation. Our approach (i) constructs a static fatigue index from physiological signals including heart-rate variability, EEG patterns, eye metrics, and cortisol levels to identify immediate cognitive overload; (ii) transforms these measurements into a dynamic index using an exponentially weighted moving average to monitor fatigue accumulation; and (iii) incorporates fatigue directly into resource-rational WM modeling through cost-sensitivity modulation. This integration enables adaptive resource allocation strategies that respond to varying fatigue states. We provide a comprehensive validation framework in the appendix, with empirical testing left for future work.

title: Transforming Electricity Safety Training and Culture using active methodologies
authors: Alan Gustavo Magalhães, Emerson Franco
publish: 2025 IEEE ESW Brazil – Electrical Safety Workshop Brazil (ESW Brazil)
abstract: SUMMARYThis article aims to present the benefits of adopting active methodologies in electrical safety training, revolutionizing the way electrical professionals assimilate and apply knowledge by making the process more dynamic, practical and engaging. It will show details of the active methodologies used, such as virtual reality simulations, gamification, prototyping, and problem-solving. This means that training ceases to be passive and becomes more engaging, making it easier to understand and retain relevant content.This change in the training model directly contributes to reducing accidents, increasing risk perception, and strengthening a preventive safety culture in which each employee becomes a protagonist in ensuring their own safety and that of their colleagues

title: Deep Learning–Based Depression Screening Using Augmented Tongue Images Under Various Lighting Conditions
authors: Jiann-Der Lee, Pin-Yu Lin, Chien-Ho Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study proposes a deep learning–based method for depression screening using tongue images, a core diagnostic element in traditional Chinese medicine (TCM). Tongue images were collected from 68 participants (mean age: 25 years) under three distinct lighting conditions and augmented to 7,956 samples to improve model generalization. A ResNet-34 convolutional neural network, trained with a weighted cross-entropy loss to address class imbalance, achieved an overall accuracy of 97%, with a precision of 0.93 and a recall of 0.88 for the depression class. These results show the effectiveness of the proposed model in noninvasive mental health assessment and demonstrate the potential of integrating visual TCM features into AI-assisted diagnostic systems.

title: Ethics of AI in Technological Interruption: Discomfort on Employee Job Insecurity and Turnover
authors: M. Sneha, A. Mohamed Ibrahim, Sam D Sathyaseelan, Leena Jenefa, M. Jayakumar, S Ashok Kumar
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: AI-based knowledge carries considerable risks for handlers, designers, and humans owing to data biases, safety, secrecy, and ethical issues. To avoid prejudice and ensure data privacy, AI must be used ethically. This article focused on the ethical issues associated with AI structures as substances. It includes an integrative literature analysis as well as a process architecture that explains how to face and ease employee resistance to artificial intelligence (AI) in enterprises. The rapid addition of AI into HR procedures is noticeable, ushering in automation, enhanced decision-making, and a better employee experience. It is critical that the organization and HR grasp the balance between using technology to assist them and the human subtleties of dealing with others. Predictors may be examined as employees go through their careers and positions. These predictors or indications might tell us whether the employee intends to depart or is dissatisfied. This study seeks to analyze and determine the function of artificial intelligence in employee engagement and, as a result, staff retention.

title: Image Reconstruction Algorithm of Quantum Intensity Correlation Imaging Based on the Spatial Light Modulator
authors: Ying Zhao, Changwei Jie
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: Traditional point-to-point multispectral imaging methods have high processing and storage costs, so how to use new imaging methods to achieve efficient image demodulation has become a hot research issue. This paper introduces a spectral image imaging method based on SLM, which uses TV-RANK compressed sensing image reconstruction algorithm to achieve spectral image reconstruction of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$590 ~\text{nm} \sim 630 ~\text{nm}$</tex> with wavelength resolution of 10 nm. The image quality evaluation standard is also given. The experimental results show that when the sampling rate increases from 30 % to 100 %, the PSNR increases from 600 nm to 640 nm by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$17.9267,16.8618,16.7643$</tex>, 17.0431, 16.7845, respectively, which verifies the correctness of the image reconstruction algorithm. The research results have the advantages of high energy utilization, fast information acquisition efficiency, and 3D data can be obtained with a single exposure.

title: Energy Efficiency Optimization for CR-Enabled Integrated Terrestrial and NTNs with BD-RIS
authors: Wali Ullah Khan, Chandan Kumar Sheemar, Syed Tariq Shah, Symeon Chatzinotas
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper presents a novel framework for cognitive radio (CR)-enabled integrated terrestrial and non-terrestrial networks (ITNTNs), comprising a primary low-Earth-orbit (LEO) satellite network and a secondary terrestrial network. In particular, a beyond-diagonal reconfigurable intelligent surface (BD-RIS) mounted secondary base station (BS) reuses the same spectrum to communicate with the secondary user. The proposed framework improves the energy efficiency of the secondary network while ensuring that the interference temperature threshold of the primary LEO network is not violated. The joint optimization of BS power allocation and BD-RIS phase shifts is considered, which results in a highly nonconvex problem. To address this challenge, the Dinkelbach method is first employed to transform the fractional objective function, followed by the development of an alternating optimization strategy. Specifically, the BS power allocation is optimized using the Lagrangian method with Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions, while the BD-RIS phase shifts are updated through manifold optimization techniques. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed BD-RIS framework performs better than conventional diagonal RIS (D-RIS) configurations in terms of energy and spectral efficiency, highlighting its potential to enable green, adaptive, and high-capacity 6G ITNTN deployments.

title: BioNexus Defense: The Myco-Barrier Mechanism for Adaptive IoT Security
authors: Vaishali Ravi, Mohd Anuaruddin Ahmadon, Shuhaida Shuhidan, Shingo Yamaguchi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: The increasing prevalence of botnet attacks on Internet of Things networks presents a critical challenge that demands innovative and adaptive solutions. This paper proposes a novel architecture, inspired by the decentralized collaboration of fungal mycorrhizal networks and the selective protection of the blood-brain barrier. The design is a plug-and-play shield that integrates with current IoT networks without modifying their structure, dynamically responding to different levels of attack severity with exceptional resilience and adaptability. AI-driven decision-making enables real-time detection, containment, and recovery, while essential features such as sandbox analysis, resource redistribution, and dynamic restructuring through the addition of nodes and layers ensure scalability and continued functionality. This architecture offers a revolutionary approach to IoT security by drawing concepts from natural systems and incorporating cutting-edge technologies to create a strong framework that can adapt to cyberthreats.

title: Merge-Countering Dynamic Multi-Channel Masking for Text-Based Video Tuning
authors: Chunzhi Gu, Yue Zhuo, Shigeru Kuriyama
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Text-to-video (T2V) methods have witnessed considerable success using diffusion-based text-to-image (T2I) generative paradigms. More recently, these models have also enabled the achievement of one-shot video tuning with pre-trained T2I models. Despite the feasibility, prior techniques still struggle to handle the scenarios with multiple moving objects, leading to less consistent motions and object merging. To mitigate this issue, we propose to leverage multi-channel mask guidance to dynamically navigate frame-wise object location. Specifically, we perform object segmentation for each moving object in the video to prepare a multi-channel mask image sequence. By incorporating such a mask sequence into the cross-attention-based T2I diffusion pipeline, the frame-wise location of multiple objects can be explicitly guided to combat the tendency of object merging. Experimental results show that our approach improves the video quality and realism against existing T2V methods.

title: Affine Frequency Division Multiplexing with Practical DAC and ADC Filters
authors: Yuqing Liu, Yanqun Tang, Haoran Yin, Ruiqi Cao, Miaowen Wen
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper investigates affine frequency division multiplexing (AFDM) with practical digital-to-analog conversion (DAC) and analog-to-digital conversion (ADC) filters over doubly-dispersive channels. Firstly, we derive the input-output relationship for AFDM with practical DAC and ADC filters, thereby characterizing the discrete affine Fourier transform (DAFT) domain channel. Subsequently, the equivalent sampled DAFT channel matrix is visualized. Additionally, an analysis of the auto-ambiguity function of the AFDM pilot signal is conducted, focusing on the impact of various DAC and ADC filters. The selection of these filters exerts a significant influence on the sidelobe behavior in the time-delay domain of the sub-ambiguity function. Simulations demonstrate that AFDM with practical DAC/ADC outperforms OFDM and OCDM in bit error rate under identical conditions, while the root-raised cosine filter enhances spectral efficiency.

title: Corner Case Detection in Autonomous Driving with Deep Learning
authors: Kunming Hong, Yunchi Wu, Yunpeng Xin, Qixiu Cheng, Kai Huang, Zhiyuan Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Object detection serves as the fundamental cornerstone of autonomous driving perception technology. By precisely and promptly identifying traffic participants in the vicinity of the vehicle, the object detection model delivers safety warnings and protection to the driver. Corner case detection in autonomous driving remains a critical and challenging area of research due to the complex environmental conditions and irregular object shapes involved, such as a self-driving car dealing with sudden pedestrians, non-standard traffic signs, road works, and animals crossing the road. These scenarios demand higher robustness and accuracy from object detection algorithms. Existing research often inadequately addresses these complexities, resulting in suboptimal performance in real-world applications. This study delves into corner case detection in autonomous driving and proposes an improved objective detection model based on You Only Look Once version 10 (YOLOv10). In this paper, the Depth-Wise Convolution (DWConv) and Omni-Dimensional Convolution (ODConv) are integrated into the backbone and head modules of the original YOLOv10 algorithm. Comparative experiments demonstrate that these improvements significantly enhance the original YOLOv10's ability to detect complex corner cases, achieving a 2.9% average precision (AP) improvement and a 24.5% mean average recall (mAR) improvement on the widely-used Corner Case Dataset (CODA). The results indicate that the modified YOLOv10 maintains competitive inference speed while providing higher precision, showcasing the potential of targeted architectural enhancements in improving corner case detection for autonomous driving. This advancement contributes to improving the efficiency and safety of self-driving vehicle operations.

title: Spectral-temporal stretching and bandwidth scaling in soliton fiber lasers induced by large lumped attenuation
authors: Siqi Fan, Xintong Zhang, Qi Huang, Xiaogang Tang, Xiaocong Wang, Benhai Wang, Haochen Lin, Jinxin Zhan, Xin Jiang, Wenbin He, Meng Pang
publish: IEEE Photonics Journal
abstract: Soliton fiber laser is widely regarded as the paradigm for ultrafast fiber lasers due to its simple and flexible configuration. Meanwhile, to overcome its limitation in pulse energy and bandwidth, dispersion-management and spectral filtering effects are routinely used to mitigate nonlinearity induced instabilities through temporal and spectral stretching in the cavity. In this work, we demonstrate that, by simply introducing a large lumped attenuation in a soliton fiber laser, significant temporal and spectral stretching can be achieved despite the dominant anomalous dispersion of the fiber cavity, allowing for a stretched-pulse-like operation without using dispersion-compensation fibers and bandpass filters. In experiment, we achieved prominent pulse energy and bandwidth scaling by applying a lumped 13-dB attenuation before the gain section, which leads to 8-nm pulse bandwidth. Numerical simulations were performed to reveal the dramatic oscillation of the pulse chirp in the cavity in the all-anomalous fiber sections. This work revealed the critical role of lump attenuation in mode-locked cavity in manipulating the intra cavity dynamics of soliton laser, and may serve as a simple and useful degree of freedom for optimization of mode-locked fiber lasers

title: Reducing Cross-Cultural Risk Perception Gaps in Cycling Through Auditory Warnings
authors: Kai Takahashi, Yukiko Nishizaki
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: With the recent increase in inbound tourists to Japan, the use of bicycles as a mode of transportation has been promoted. Consequently, there is a growing demand for improving cycling environments and enhancing safety measures to prevent traffic accidents. Especially, a warning system at hazardous locations for foreign visitors to Japan, aimed at adapting to Japanese traffic rules and environment, is considered effective, and its proper implementation is crucial. On the other hand, it has been reported that cultural background can influence risk perception on the road. This study investigated the impact of cultural differences on the risk perception of pedestrians during cycling and the effect of warning system on the difference in risk perception. The results showed that Japanese participants felt pedestrians were more dangerous compared to non-Japanese participants. Additionally, it was suggested that this difference in risk perception could be controlled through auditory warning systems.

title: Hybrid Neural/Traditional OFDM Receiver with Learnable Decider
authors: Mohanad Obeed, Ming Jian
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Deep learning (DL) methods have emerged as promising solutions for enhancing receiver performance in wireless orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) systems, offering significant improvements over traditional estimation and detection techniques. However, DL-based receivers often face challenges such as poor generalization to unseen channel conditions and difficulty in effectively tracking rapid channel fluctuations. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a hybrid receiver architecture that integrates the strengths of both traditional and neural receivers. The core innovation is a discriminator neural network trained to dynamically select the optimal receiver whether it is the traditional or DL-based receiver according on the received OFDM block characteristics. This discriminator is trained using labeled pilot signals that encode the comparative performance of both receivers. By including anomalous channel scenarios in training, the proposed hybrid receiver achieves robust performance, effectively overcoming the generalization issues inherent in standalone DL approaches.

title: Transparent Intrusion Detection Using ML: Integrating Explainable Models for Cybersecurity
authors: Mohammad Abdussami, Sri Pranav N, Madhu Sudan Rao Ramani, Krishna Manikanta Singothu, Sai Krishna Gurram, Aswani Devi Aguru, Md Muzakkir Hussain, Firoj Gazi
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: In today’s world of connected systems, protecting those systems is imperative. Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) have an important function to perform to protect these systems by detecting and monitoring malicious activity and policy breaches. This project develops an intelligent IDS based on Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) to identify potential security threats online. The system applies sound ML methods to examine the traffic on a system and separate benign and malicious behavior. A variety of ML methods / Algorithms exist to differentiate bad and good data, and among those methods are supervised and unsupervised learning models to enhance known and unknown threat detection. Benchmark data sets are used to train the system so that it can detect a variety of attacks, including distributed denial of service (DDoS), probing, and remote-to-local (R2L) attacks efficiently. There is also use of feature selection and dimensionality reduction methods to achieve maximum computational performance and efficiency. The suggested AI and ML-based IDS provides scalable and flexible security through continuous learning to respond to emerging threats. It is a potent choice for securing networks of today because it supports scalability and real-time analytics.

title: Transformer-Driven Neural Beamforming with Imperfect CSI in Urban Macro Wireless Channels
authors: Cemil Vahapoglu, Timothy J. O’Shea, Wan Liu, Tamoghna Roy, Sennur Ulukus
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: The literature is abundant with methodologies focusing on using transformer architectures due to their prominence in wireless signal processing and their capability to capture long-range dependencies via attention mechanisms. In particular, separable convolutions enhance parameter efficiency for the process of high-dimensional data characteristics of MIMO systems. In this work, we introduce a novel unsupervised deep learning framework that integrates separable convolutions and transformers to generate beamforming weights under imperfect channel state information (CSI) for a multi-user single-input multiple-output (MU-SIMO) system in dense urban environments. The primary goal is to enhance throughput by maximizing sum-rate while ensuring reliable communication. Spectral efficiency and block error rate (BLER) are considered as performance metrics. Experiments are carried out under various conditions to compare the performance of the proposed NNBF framework against baseline methods zero-forcing beamforming (ZFBF) and minimum mean square error (MMSE) beamforming. Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed framework over the baseline techniques.

title: Applying PIBT to LA-MAPF and Proposing Priority Assignment Strategies
authors: Yosei Hotta, Takahiro Uchiya, Yuichiro Tateiwa
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In recent years, there has been growing interest in path planning technologies that can move multiple agents safely and efficiently, particularly in fields such as warehouse robotics and autonomous vehicles. The problem formalized as Multi-Agent Path Finding (MAPF) traditionally assumes uniform agent sizes, which limits its applicability to real-world scenarios. To address this issue, MAPF for Large Agents (LA-MAPF), which considers the physical size of agents, has been proposed. In this study, we apply Priority Inheritance with Backtracking (PIBT)―a MAPF algorithm based on dynamic priority inheritance and backtracking―to the LA-MAPF setting and evaluate its effectiveness. Specifically, we propose two priority assignment strategies that adjust agent priorities according to their sizes, and compare their performance across various map configurations and number of agents. Experimental results demonstrate that the strategy assigning higher priorities to smaller agents achieves superior performance, especially in densely populated environments and complex terrains, thereby enhancing overall path planning efficiency.

title: Large Language Models for Free-to-Air TV Program Content Analysis and Complementation
authors: Haydê Machado, Edson Weslley Almeida do Nascimento, Sergillam Barroso Oliveira, Tiago Souza, Petrina de Assis da Silva Kimura, Eddie B de Lima Filho, Lucas Cordeiro, Romulo Fabricio
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This work proposes an innovative approach based on large language models for TV program content analysis and complementation. The latter is performed with relevant web content delivered across devices, in real time, thus enhancing user experience through information enrichment. It fosters greater interactivity, personalization, and engagement, bridging the gap between linear television and digital platforms.

title: Calculation and Analysis of Temperature Fields for Critical Stator and Rotor Components Under Control System Faults in Large-Capacity Offshore Wind Generator
authors: Xiaoke Liu, Junci Cao, Peng Zuo, Weili Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Reliability
abstract: When operating in marine environments, the power conversion link of direct-drive grid-connected permanent magnet synchronous generator (PMSG) units may be subject to various types of faults, such as short-circuit faults in the generator windings and open-circuit faults in the converter. Due to the high maintenance cost, once a generator fault occurs, it will cause huge economic losses. For this reason, it is significant to investigate the impact of different faults of grid-connected wind power units on the generator. In this article, the coupled electromagnetic–thermal converter calculation model is established for a direct-drive offshore PMSG with a rated power of 5 MW and a rated speed of 15 r/min. In addition, the generator loss distributions under four types of machine-side converter open-circuit faults and four types of grid-side inverter open-circuit faults are calculated. Particular attention is given to the distribution of the eddy-current loss of the rotor magnet box. On this basis, the transient effects of different faults on the temperatures of the generator windings and permanent magnets are investigated. The dimensionless number global rise time is used as the evaluation index in this research. The index reveals the impact of different faults on the generator stability by indicating the time it takes for the generator’s key components to reach the temperature tolerance limit. The findings provide a basis for enhancing the transient operation capability of wind generators under extreme fault conditions.

title: Depth-Wise Federated Learning Based on Model Parameter Reliability
authors: Ryosuke Nutaba, Hiroshi Watanabe
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) enables collaborative model training across multiple clients without sharing their local data. However, its performance degrades when data distributions are non-identical among clients. To address this challenge, we propose a depth-wise model aggregation method. This method uses Fisher Information Matrix (FIM) to evaluate parameter reliability and dynamically adjusts client contributions, reducing the influence of unreliable parameters. Experimental results demonstrate that our method consistently outperforms the existing approach in terms of local and global classification accuracy under various conditions.

title: Dynamic Beyond 5G and 6G Connectivity: Leveraging NTN and RIS Synergies for Optimized Coverage and Capacity in High-Density Environments
authors: Valdemar Farré, Juan Estrada, David Vega, Luis F Urquiza-Aguiar, Juan A. Vásquez Peralvo, Symeon Chatzinotas
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: The increasing demand for reliable, high-capacity communication during large-scale outdoor events poses significant challenges for traditional Terrestrial Networks (TNs), which often struggle to provide consistent coverage in high-density environments. This paper presents a novel Sixth Generation (6G) radio network planning framework that integrates Non-Terrestrial Networks (NTNs) with Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RISs) to deliver ubiquitous coverage and enhanced network capacity. Our framework overcomes the limitations of conventional deployable base stations by leveraging NTN architectures, including Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellites—and passive RIS platforms seamlessly integrated with Beyond 5G (B5G) TNs. By incorporating advanced B5G technologies such as Massive Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (mMIMO) and beamforming, and by optimizing spectrum utilization across the C, S, and Ka bands, we implement a rigorous interference management strategy based on a dynamic SINR model. Comprehensive calculations and simulations validate the proposed framework, demonstrating significant improvements in connectivity, reliability, and cost-efficiency in crowded scenarios. This integration strategy represents a promising solution for meeting the evolving demands of future 6G networks.

title: Electromagnetic Parameters-assisted Propagation Modeling and Reconstruction for Complex Space Targets at FR3 Upper-Mid Band
authors: Xi Liao, Xiaolong Hu, Baichang Sun, Xiangquan Zheng, Yu Shao
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: This paper presents an electromagnetic parameters assisted (EPA) propagation model and structure reconstruction approach for space targets at frequency range 3 (FR3) upper mid band. First, the material type is classified as either reflective or transmissive by inverting the electromagnetic parameters and analyzing the propagation characteristics of single-layer space material. Second, the Fresnel model was modified using the Debye model to develop an EPA propagation model for space targets. Finally, the full-wave simulator (FEKO) is used to simulate the reflection and transmission behavior of multi-layer materials to reconstruct the space target structure. The results demonstrate that the proposed propagation model achieves higher accuracy than the traditional Fresnel model. This paper provides valuable insights into space target perception under unknown target conditions for 6G air-space-ground integrated communication.

title: Risk Assessment of Electrical Infrastructure Assets by a Multi-Objective Fine-Tuned Fuzzy Inference System
authors: Yunyang Zou, Yan Xu, Ziming Yan, Sungin Cho, Terence Tik Lam Yip
publish: IEEE Transactions on Power Delivery
abstract: Risk assessment of aging electrical infrastructure assets aims to provide informed asset management decision support, such as asset renewal and maintenance. To this end, this letter proposes a systematical and practical method incorporating multiple inputs from utilities and regulators. Specifically, the probability of asset failure (asset health index) and the consequence of asset failure (criticality index) are combined into a Takagi-Sugeno-Kang fuzzy inference system (TSK-FIS) for risk quantification. To ensure the monotonicity of TSK-FIS, sufficient conditions are first derived and modeled as constraints. Then, the TSK-FIS parameters are optimized for three objectives: 1) the optimality objective enables the TSK-FIS to learn the expert knowledge from existing tools, ensuring alignment with established utility practices; 2) the robustness objective enhances its ability to prevent minor input changes from causing drastic output deviations; 3) to ensure such small input variations can still be reflected in the output to a meaningful extent, the differentiation objective is formulated to improve output resolution and mitigate over-concentration. Case studies on real-world power asset data of Singapore power grid have validated the proposed method.

title: Nonintrusive Watermarking for CycleGAN
authors: Yebin Zheng, Haonan An, Guang Hua, Yongming Chen, Zhiping Lin
publish: IEEE Signal Processing Letters
abstract: Generative adversarial networks (GANs) are a set of powerful generative models, among which CycleGAN, featuring the unique cycle-consistency loss, has gained special popularity. However, this unique structure and the cycle-consistency loss make watermarking CycleGAN particularly challenging, rendering existing deep neural network (DNN) watermarking methods, whether model-agnostic or GAN-specific, inapplicable. Meanwhile, existing DNN watermarking methods are intrusive in nature, requiring direct or indirect modification of model parameters for watermark embedding, which raises fidelity concerns. To solve the above problems, we propose the first nonintrusive and robust watermarking method for CycleGAN. We empirically show that without modifying the CycleGAN model, a user-defined watermark image can still be extracted from model outputs using a dedicated watermark decoder. Extensive experimental results verify that while achieving the so-called absolute fidelity, the proposed method is robust to various attacks, from image post-processing to model stealing.

title: SGE-GLoc: Semantic Gaussian Ellipsoid Scene Graphs for Efficient LiDAR Global Localization_supp1-3643266.mp4
authors: Huai Yu
publish: N/A
abstract: Global localization, encompassing robust place recognition and precise transformation estimation, is crucial for mobile robot navigation when the global navigation satellite system (GNSS) is unavailable. While LiDAR-based approaches are favored for their accuracy in 3D perception and resilience to illumination changes, existing methods often suffer from complex scene representations or computationally intensive processes, hindering scalability in large-scale applications. This paper introduces SGE-GLoc, a novel LiDAR-based global localization framework, which utilizes a compact scene graph representation where individual objects are modeled as Semantic Gaussian Ellipsoids (SGEs), encapsulating both geometric and semantic attributes. For efficient place recognition, we encode SGE features into histograms and employ a Graph Neural Network (GNN) to learn local and global topological information, generating a discriminative two-stage descriptor for scene similarity scoring. For accurate 6-DoF transformation estimation, we first establish initial correspondences based on SGE matching and subsequently refine the transformation by exploiting geometric constraints between SGEs. Extensive evaluations on four public datasets, including KITTI, KITTI-360, Apollo, and HeLiPR, demonstrate that SGE-GLoc achieves high place recognition accuracy and low localization error, while maintaining a highly compact scene graph representation with an average storage of only 1.28 KB per scene. Furthermore, the integration of SGE-GLoc into a SLAM system showcases its practical efficacy in real-world scenarios.

title: I've Changed My Mind: Robots Adapting to Changing Human Goals During Collaboration
authors: Debasmita Ghose, Oz Gitelson, Ryan Jin, Grace Abawe, Marynel Vázquez, Brian Scassellati
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: For effective human-robot collaboration, a robot must align its actions with human goals, even as they change mid-task. Prior approaches often assume fixed goals, reducing goal prediction to a one-time inference. However, in real-world scenarios, humans frequently shift goals, making it challenging for robots to adapt without explicit communication. We propose a method for detecting goal changes by tracking multiple candidate action sequences and verifying their plausibility against a policy bank. Upon detecting a change, the robot refines its belief in relevant past actions and constructs Receding Horizon Planning (RHP) trees to actively select actions that assist the human while encouraging Differentiating Actions to reveal their updated goal. We evaluate our approach in a collaborative cooking environment with up to 30 unique recipes and compare it to three comparable human goal prediction algorithms. Our method outperforms all baselines, quickly converging to the correct goal after a switch, reducing task completion time and improving collaboration efficiency.

title: Automated Generation of MDPs Using Logic Programming and LLMs for Robotic Applications_supp1-3643276.mp4
authors: Enrico Saccon
publish: N/A
abstract: We present a novel framework that integrates Large Language Models (LLMs) with automated planning and formal verification to streamline the creation and use of Markov Decision Processes (MDP). Our system leverages LLMs to extract structured knowledge in the form of a Prolog knowledge base from natural language (NL) descriptions. It then automatically constructs an MDP through reachability analysis, and synthesises optimal policies using the Storm model checker. The resulting policy is exported as a state-action table for execution. We validate the framework in three human-robot interaction scenarios, demonstrating its ability to produce executable policies with minimal manual effort. This work highlights the potential of combining language models with formal methods to enable more accessible and scalable probabilistic planning in robotics.

title: A Photometrically Scaled Secondary Illumination Model for Lunar Permanently Shadowed Regions_supp1-3642808.pdf
authors: Prasun Mahanti
publish: N/A
abstract: Images of permanently shadowed regions (PSRs) acquired from lunar orbit are challenging to model and interpret because of the diffuse secondary illumination. In this work, we propose, implement, and evaluate a novel technique to model the radiance of PSRs with diffuse secondary illumination based on the Lommel-Seeliger law. We compare our results based on Lambert’s law and show that while both models reproduce details of Shoemaker crater PSR images observed by ShadowCam, the new technique is dramatically more accurate in scale.

title: Prompt-Enabled Large AI Models for CSI Feedback
authors: Jiajia Guo, Yiming Cui, Chao-Kai Wen, Shi Jin
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) has emerged as a promising tool for channel state information (CSI) feedback. While recent research primarily focuses on improving feedback accuracy on a specific dataset through novel architectures, the underlying mechanism of AI-based CSI feedback remains unclear. This study explores the mechanism through analyzing performance across diverse datasets, with findings suggesting that superior feedback performance stems from AI models’ strong fitting capabilities and their ability to leverage environmental knowledge. Building on these findings, we propose a prompt-enabled large AI model (LAM) for CSI feedback. The LAM employs powerful Transformer blocks and is trained on extensive datasets from various scenarios. Meanwhile, the channel distribution (environmental knowledge), represented as the mean of channel magnitude in the angular-delay domain, is incorporated as a scenario-specific prompt within the decoder to further enhance reconstruction quality. Simulation results confirm that the proposed prompt-enabled LAM significantly improves feedback accuracy and generalization performance while reducing data collection requirements in new scenarios.

title: A Spatio-Temporal Feature Distribution Network for Device-Free Power Inspection Activity Using WiFi CSI
authors: Cunyi Yin, Zhaoke Huang, Hao Jiang, Jing Chen, Zhida WANG, Chenwei Wang, Zhenghua Chen, Zhiwen Chen, Hong Yan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: Ensuring personnel safety during power station inspections is a critical yet challenging task due to inherent hazards in such environments. Traditional monitoring methods, including wearable devices and video surveillance, suffer from user discomfort, limited visibility, and high deployment costs. To overcome these limitations, this article proposes PowerHAR, a device-free framework for recognizing power inspection activities based on WiFi channel state information (CSI) acquired from custom-designed ESP32 internet of things (IoT) sensors. PowerHAR introduces a spatio-temporal feature distribution-based power operation recognition network, comprising a transformer-based preprocessing module capable of effectively handling variable-length CSI sequences, and a spatio-temporal extraction module that integrates convolutional operations with multihead self-attention mechanisms for comprehensive feature fusion. By leveraging mutual CSI sensing among distributed sensors, PowerHAR provides robust and accurate recognition of power inspection activities without requiring additional hardware infrastructure. Experimental validation demonstrates that PowerHAR significantly surpasses existing baseline methods, confirming its high reliability and practicality in safety-critical industrial scenarios.

title: A hybrid machine learning and blockchain framework for wireless sensor networks
authors: Maryam Raeiszadeh, Mohammad Zaroudi, Marjan Raeiszadeh, Amin Zarei
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: This study proposes an enhanced method for detecting malicious nodes in wireless sensor networks (WSNs) by extending security measures based on least square-support vector machine (LS-SVM). Specifically, a Pearson correlation coefficient-based enhanced LS-SVM (ELS-SVM) is employed for identifying malicious nodes. Detection of such nodes through machine learning (ML) algorithms establishes a robust defense mechanism, enabling the monitoring of node behavior and the mitigation of potential threats. In this context, effective anomaly detection in WSNs utilizing ELS-SVM fosters a secure environment, further strengthened by transparent logging and secure data storage (SDS) via blockchain technology. SDS in WSNs is critical, and this research achieves it through a hybrid approach combining ELS-SVM and blockchain technology for malicious node detection (MND). By ensuring network reliability and data immutability, this hybrid mechanism offers enhanced protection against potential attacks.

title: Indoor Benchmark of 3D LiDAR SLAM at iilab – Industry and Innovation Laboratory
authors: Jorge Diogo Ribeiro, Ricardo B. Sousa, João G. Martins, André S. Aguiar, Filipe N. Santos, Héber Miguel Sobreira
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: This paper presents an indoor benchmarking study of state-of-the-art 3D LiDAR-based Simultaneous Localization and Mapping (SLAM) algorithms using the newly developed IILABS 3D – iilab Indoor LiDAR-based SLAM 3D dataset. Existing SLAM datasets often focus on outdoor environments, rely on a single type of LiDAR sensor, or lack additional sensor data such as wheel odometry in ground-based robotic platforms. Consequently, the existing datasets lack data diversity required to comprehensively evaluate performance under diverse indoor conditions. The IILABS 3D dataset fills this gap by providing a sensor-rich, indoor-exclusive dataset recorded in a controlled laboratory environment using a wheeled mobile robot platform. It includes four heterogeneous 3D LiDAR sensors – Velodyne VLP-16, Ouster OS1-64, RoboSense RS-Helios-5515, and Livox Mid-360 – featuring both mechanical spinning and non-repetitive scanning patterns, as well as an IMU and wheel odometry for sensor fusion. The dataset also contains calibration sequences, challenging benchmark trajectories, and high-precision ground-truth poses captured with a motion capture system. Using this dataset, we benchmark nine representative LiDAR-based SLAM algorithms across multiple sequences, analyzing their performance in terms of accuracy and consistency under varying sensor configurations. The results provide a comprehensive performance comparison and valuable insights into the strengths and limitations of current SLAM algorithms in indoor environments. The dataset, benchmark results, and related tools are publicly available at https://jorgedfr.github.io/3d_lidar_slam_benchmark_at_iilab/.

title: Interval Type-2 T-S Fuzzy Braking Torque Finite-Time Consensus Control of Electro-Mechanical Brake System
authors: Linfeng Lv, Wanzhong Zhao, Chunyan Wang, Wei Li, Zhiyang Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Transportation Electrification
abstract: The Electro-mechanical Brake (EMB) system achieves fast and precise braking force through the coordinated operation of multiple motors. However, non-uniform parameter uncertainties in EMB motors weaken braking torque consensus, thereby compromising braking safety. To address this problem, this paper proposes a finite-time (FT) braking torque consensus control strategy based on interval type-2 Takagi-Sugeno (IT2 T-S) fuzzy theory. First, a heterogeneous EMB multi-agent system framework is established to describe the communication topology among EMB units, providing a more accurate representation under non-uniform parameter uncertainties. Second, a distributed IT2 T-S fuzzy braking torque FT H∞ consensus controller is designed. The EMB system is linearized using IT2 T-S fuzzy theory, and an augmented membership function is introduced, which enhances the capability of the model and controller in handling parameter uncertainties and external disturbances. Then, a fuzzy Lyapunov function reduced the conservatism of the consensus control, thereby effectively minimizing the braking torque error between left and right wheels, and FT constraints achieved rapid convergence. Finally, simulation and experimental results demonstrate that the proposed strategy significantly improves the braking torque consensus of the four-wheel EMB system under different braking conditions with non-uniform parameter uncertainties, thus ensuring braking safety.

title: Niagara: Normal-Integrated Geometric Affine Field for Scene Reconstruction from a Single View
authors: Xianzu Wu, Zhenxin Ai, Harry Yang, Sernam Lim, Jun Liu, Huan Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Recent advances in single-view 3D scene reconstruction have highlighted the challenges in capturing fine geometric details and ensuring structural consistency, particularly in high-fidelity outdoor scene modeling. This paper presents Niagara, a new single-view 3D scene reconstruction framework that can faithfully reconstruct challenging outdoor scenes from a single input image for the first time. Our approach integrates monocular depth and normal estimation as input, which substantially improves its ability to capture fine details, mitigating common issues like geometric detail loss and deformation. Additionally, we introduce a geometric affine field (GAF) and 3D self-attention as geometry-constraint, which combines the structural properties of explicit geometry with the adaptability of implicit feature fields, striking a balance between efficient rendering and high-fidelity reconstruction. Our framework finally proposes a specialized encoder-decoder architecture, where a depth-based 3D Gaussian decoder is proposed to predict 3D Gaussian parameters, which can be used for novel view synthesis. Extensive results and analyses suggest that our Niagara surpasses prior SoTA approaches such as Flash3D in both single-view and dual-view settings, significantly enhancing the geometric accuracy and visual fidelity, especially in outdoor scenes. Webpage: https://ai-kunkun.github.io/Niagara page/.

title: TUNA: A Target-aware Unified Network for Protein-Ligand Binding Affinity Prediction via Multi-Modal Feature Integration
authors: Jaesuk Yoon, Yeojin Kim, Hyunju Lee
publish: IEEE Journal of Biomedical and Health Informatics
abstract: The accurate prediction of protein–ligand binding affinity is crucial for early-stage drug discovery. Sequence-based deep learning models offer scalability and broader applicability than structure-based methods, but typically ignore the local binding site context, limiting predictive power. Recent advances in protein structure prediction and binding pocket detection have enabled for the integration of pocket-level information into sequence-based models. We present TUNA, a novel deep learning model that integrates multi-modal features to predict binding affinity. The TUNA integrates global protein sequences, localized pocket representations, ligand features derived from the SMILES, and molecular graph structures. We used three dimensional structure inference and pocket detection tools for proteins lacking experimentally determined binding sites. The pocket and protein sequences were encoded using embeddings from pre-trained models, including a model pretrained specifically on pocket-derived sequences. Ligands were represented through a fusion of Chemformer encoded SMILES and graph diffusion-based features, then unified via an alignment strategy to preserve both symbolic and structural information. TUNA achieved consistent improvements over sequence-based models across the PDB bind and BindingDB datasets while remaining competitive with structure-based methods for the PDBbind dataset. Its interpretable cross-modal attention mechanism enables the inference of potential binding sites, thus enhancing biological interpretation. These results demonstrate that TUNA is an effective affinity prediction method, especially for targets without known structures.

title: Deep Unfolding for MIMO Signal Detection
authors: Hangli Ge, Noboru Koshizuka
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a deep unfolding neural network-based MIMO detector that incorporates complex-valued computations using Wirtinger calculus. The method, referred as Dynamic Partially Shrinkage Thresholding (DPST), enables efficient, interpretable, and low-complexity MIMO signal detection. Unlike prior approaches that rely on real-valued approximations, our method operates natively in the complex domain, aligning with the fundamental nature of signal processing tasks. The proposed algorithm requires only a small number of trainable parameters, allowing for simplified training. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior detection performance with fewer iterations and lower computational complexity, making it a practical solution for next-generation massive MIMO systems.

title: Dual-Layer Optimization for Furnace Temperature Optimized Setpoint and Its Tracking Control
authors: Yicong Wu, Wei Wang, Jian Tang, Zenan Li, Yongqi Zhang, Yan Liu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: The emission concentrations of pollutants during municipal solid waste incineration (MSWI) are closely related to the furnace temperature, which is influenced by numerous control variables. However, domain experts find it difficult to optimize the furnace temperature setpoint and ensure its tracking under manual control mode to minimize typical pollutant emission concentrations. This article proposes a double-layer optimization control strategy for furnace temperature optimized setpoint and tracking control. First, a genetic algorithm is used in the upper layer to determine the furnace temperature setpoint aimed at minimizing pollutant emissions of NOx and C02. Then, the fitness function for the lower-layer optimization process is defined as the integral of time-weighted absolute error (IT AE) of a multi-loop PID controller, and a genetic algorithm is employed to find the optimal PID parameters for the controller. Finally, the control variables output by the PID controller are fed into the controlled object, and the actual temperature values are fed back to form a closed-loop optimization control. Experimental results demonstrate that this strategy dynamically determines the optimal FT setpoint and concurrently identifies optimal multi-loop PID controller parameters that are best suited for the optimal FT setpoint.

title: NearLink: Emerging Short Range Wireless Standard with Ultra-Low Latency and Ultra-High Reliability
authors: Zhan Yu, ZiChen Xie, Qian Yu, Kang Wang, Hang Fang, Weihua Li, Zhan Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: NearLink (formerly SparkLink) is an emerging international short range wireless standard in recent years. Because of its advantages in ultra-low latency and ultra-high reliability, NearLink has been quickly recognized as an enabling wireless technology for new communication and positioning applications at consumer electronics, Internet of Things (IoT), smart home and many other industries. In this paper, we presented the key features of NearLink Low Energy (SLE) communication and NearLink Positioning (SLP). We analyzed both the physical layer (PHY) and media access control layer (MAC) of SLE and SLP to show how these technical designs can meet the challenges of ultra-low latency and ultra-high reliability.

title: Generation of bioinspired asymmetric topographic structures on silver connectors via Direct Laser Interference Patterning
authors: Silas Schütz, Philipp Leonhard-Trautmann, Lena Hinsberger, Sebastian Suarez, Frank Mücklich
publish: 2025 IEEE 70th Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts (HLM)
abstract: The development of asymmetric structures for anisotropic friction behavior presents significant advantages for the connector industry, offering enhanced performance and reliability. This study explores a bioinspired, chemistry-free approach utilizing picosecond-pulsed Direct Laser Interference Patterning (ps-DLIP) as a promising technique. Ps-DLIP has demonstrated efficacy on materials such as copper and tin, and intriguingly, due to the short pulse duration, it is also applicable to silver materials despite the 532 nm wavelength, which typically does not absorb well in pure silver. Silver is of particular interest as it is commonly used in the connector industry. With DLIP, surface topographies can be reproducibly manufactured with high precision. Several periodicities and tilt angles were investigated to optimize the frictional properties. At first, the topography of the structured samples was studied thoroughly, a measurement routine was developed and different surface parameters were investigated. Subsequent tribo-electric characterization, i.e. insertion/removal tests, were conducted to evaluate the performance of the treated surfaces. The results indicate that ps-DLIP is a viable method for adapting the frictional behavior of silver and other materials, with potential applications in the connector industry.
