title: Model-Based Deep Learning Tuning of Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface for OFDM Radar Interference Mitigation
authors: Ali Parchekani, Milad Johnny, Shahrokh Valaee
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper proposes a model-based deep learning framework for Reconfigurable Intelligent Surface (RIS)-aided Orthogonal Frequency-Division Multiplexing (OFDM) radar interference mitigation without any assumption on the transmitted waveform. First, a modified Multiple Signal Classification (MUSIC) algorithm generates coarse estimates of target and interferer angles. These estimates feed a lightweight MLP that jointly optimizes RIS amplitude–phase settings via a custom loss balancing SINR enhancement with angle-estimation fidelity. A convolutional notch filtering step then deepens the null at the interference direction, and a subcarrier-pooling strategy fuses per-frequency spectra to ensure uniform suppression across the band. Simulation results under automotive radar conditions demonstrate robust interference mitigation, high angular resolution, and precise angle recovery in dense environments.

title: Self-Loop Effects in Graph-Modeled Mel-Spectrogram for Acoustic Anomaly Detection
authors: Ryota Kakinoki, Yosuke Kobayashi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study proposes a method for abnormal sound detection using graph-structured mel-spectrograms and Variational Graph Auto-Encoder (VGAE) models. Each time frame is represented as a node, with edges defined using the k-nearest neighbors algorithm. We compare two VGAE models—with and without self-loops—against a baseline Variational Convolutional Auto-Encoder (VCAE). Self-loops allow nodes to retain intrinsic acoustic features, which can enhance detection performance. Experiments on the ToyADMOS dataset show that VGAE achieves accuracy and AUC of up to 0.98 and 0.99, surpassing VCAE. Notably, self-loops improve detection for complex and subtle anomalies.

title: Full-Duplex Communications for Cellular-Connected UAVs: Distributed Beamforming and Power Control
authors: Lifeng Lai, Fu-Chun Zheng, Daquan Feng
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: In this paper, we investigate the beamforming and power control issue in cellular-connected unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) communications under full-duplex (FD). To mitigate the self-interference (SI), we adopt a decoupled uplink (UL)-downlink (DL) association for UAVs to spatially separate the transmit and receive beams. Then, we formulate a joint beamforming and power control problem to maximize the system’s spectral efficiency (SE) while ensuring each UAV meets its UL transmission rate and DL latency requirements. To solve this problem, we design a novel distributed heterogeneous graph neural network (HGNN) architecture for beamforming and power control with a low signaling overhead. Simulation results demonstrate that our proposed scheme outperforms the existing schemes in terms of the total SE, UL transmission rate and DL latency.

title: Frame-Agnostic Adaptive Causal Topology Inference for Non-Cooperative UAV Swarm Network
authors: Jiawen Zhu, Zhuo Sun, Ying Wang, Hao Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: In the field of non-cooperative network topology inference for unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) swarm networks, current causality discovery-based methodologies typically depend on critical assumptions that the data and acknowledgment (ACK) frames can be reliably distinguished and that the prior knowledge of transmission configurations, such as packet size, is available. However, in real-world scenarios, due to feature variations stemming from heterogeneous device configurations and undisclosed protocols, such assumptions are difficult to be satisfied. This paper proposes Frame-Agnostic Adaptive Causal Topology Inference (FAAC-TI), a novel network topology inference framework that overcomes the above limitations through two innovations. First, we propose Self-Informed Transfer Entropy (SITE) utilized as causality metric in FAAC-TI, which integrates the source node’s own past history contribution with cross-node causal influence, eliminating the conventional dependence on pre-classification of Data/ACK frames. Second, FAAC-TI contains a data-driven adaptive parameter selection scheme which determines parameters through run-length statistical characterization of binary time series when calculating causality metric, obviating the need for prior knowledge as previously mentioned. Experimental results show that the SITE metric achieves significantly higher topology inference accuracy on average than transfer entropy (TE) baselines across varying network scales and dynamics, while the adaptive parameter selection scheme maintains close deviation from the conventional parameter presetting scheme based on prior knowledge.

title: Digital Zero-Voltage Switching Flyback Converter Without Galvanic Isolation
authors: Wei-Tao Lo, Yi-Jing Lee, Chun-Han Yang, Shang-Chien Yang, Chien-Hung Tsai
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper presents a digitally controlled secondary-side regulated flyback converter without galvanic isolation. By using auxiliary winding sensing and a pair of low-voltage comparators, the system detects ZVS events without high-voltage analog circuits. A digital state machine determines valid ZVS conditions based on dv/dt timing. The design also incorporates synchronous rectification and variable-frequency constant on-time (COT) control for improved efficiency. Experimental results validate the proposed architecture’s ability to achieve high efficiency and low component count, making it suitable for compact, cost-sensitive AC-DC applications.

title: Thermofluid Analysis for Prototype Development of Energy Harvesting System Using Thermoelectric Devices for Small Engines
authors: Tomoya Fukuyama, Kazuyuki Kojima
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In the internal combustion engines of vehicles, the thermal energy after gasoline combustion is lost as waste heat without effective utilisation. With the introduction of more and more electronic devices in vehicles, these devices need to be powered, and efficient recovery and utilisation of the waste heat is required. Thermoelectric power generation is a promising method for converting exhaust heat into effective energy. In this study, a thermoelectric collector for waste heat recovery from the exhaust pipe of an internal combustion engine was investigated. Numerical simulations were carried out to analyse the heat transfer characteristics from the exhaust gases to the thermoelectric module in order to optimise the heat recovery during engine start-up. These results are intended to improve the efficiency of heat recovery, predict the amount of electricity generated and contribute to improved energy utilisation in vehicles with internal combustion engines.

title: Prediction Model and Behavioral Intervention Strategies for Adult Myopia Progression
authors: Qingxin Yang, Yao Wang, Jingling Qu, Renyuan Zhang, Guang Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study aims to develop a machine learning framework for predicting adult myopia progression by integrating behavioral factors with clinical measurements. The dual-model architecture put forward integrates the polynomial regression employed for the reconstruction of baseline refraction with interpretable classification algorithms. These classification algorithms, which are utilized for risk stratification, encompass eXtreme Gradient Boosting, Support Vector Machine, Random Forest, and Adaptive Boosting. Validation through 5-fold cross-validation demonstrates RF’s superior performance, achieving an area under the curve of 0.789, while regression achieves a Mean Absolute Error of 0.085D and Root Mean Square Error of 0.115D. Experimental results confirm the model’s clinical utility and highlight behavioral interventions, such as optimal sleep duration, as modifiable protective factors against myopia progression.

title: Communication-Aware Visual Navigation for Multi-AMR Systems via Federated Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Ai Jian, Hui Tian, Ruyu Luo, Jiawei Wang, Hao Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Autonomous mobile robot (AMR) systems in indoor environments face challenges in jointly optimizing visual navigation and communication efficiency. Existing methods often decouple path planning from communication allocation or rely on simplified 2D models, limiting adaptability to 3D environments.. To address these limitations, we introduce the non-orthogonal multiple access technology to enhance spectral efficiency and ensure real-time control during AMR movement. We formulate a joint optimization problem to maximize the long-term average data rate via coordinated planning of AMR trajectories, transmit power, and precoding matrix. To handle wireless fading and localization inaccuracy, we propose a vision-enhanced federated deep reinforcement learning framework, where AMRs independently learn policies while engaging in privacy-preserving model aggregation. Leveraging RGB-D visual features, object detection, and egocentric pose estimation, our approach enables robust decision-making in 3D environments under imprecise localization. Extensive experiments on the RoboThor simulator demonstrate that our proposed framework accelerates training convergence, improves navigation and communication efficiency, and outperforms baselines in reward accumulation.

title: Emotion-Driven Music Curation Using CNN and Dynamic Data Source Integration
authors: B S Jayasri, C Prathik, Srivathsa Batni, Sreekhar Srivatsa, Samanyu K
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: The changing times in the music recommendation systems have constituted great advances on an AI-powered dynamic data sourcing. The proposed work called “Emotion-driven Music Recommendation Using CNN and Dynamic Data Source Integration” gives personalized music recommendations based on real-time user emotions, age, and gender. The system uses Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) to ascertain facial expressions through activating the camera light for detecting the user’s emotional state and demographic profile. Attributes such as energy, valence, and other music features are then dynamically mapped around the user’s emotional disposition and thereby join forces to create recommendations with a ray of their current mood. This system will be high on personalization by including the smart deep learning models and scalable database solutions that keep the user experience interesting and satisfying. Real-time emotion detection and integration of external APIs could generally contrive the system to radical change the thinking of music recommendation. This paper discusses the architectural features and case study instances of this system in clarifying how it provides emotion-driven curation of music while considering their age and gender.

title: Qualitative analysis of video streamed from smartphones to TV using SSIM, PSNR and KMeans
authors: Walter Seiffert Simoes, Marcia de Sá
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: The increasing consumption of streaming content on mobile devices and its transmission to secondary screens, such as televisions, reinforces the need for reliable methods to assess the quality of the video consumed. The central challenge of this work lies in the ability to perform a reliable analysis, capable of detecting subtle variations between the original and received content, which can be introduced by factors such as compression and losses in the wireless network. The methodology uses the Android Debug Bridge (ADB) to capture frames from the mobile device, OpenCV for image processing, Peak Signal-toNoise Ratio (PSNR) to indicate the noise level of the wireless network, K-Means to partition the data into K clusters, where each data point belongs to the cluster with the closest centroid and Structural Similarity Index Measure (SSIM) to assess the similarity between the transmitted and received data. The results demonstrate that the quality of the transmitted video reaches levels above $98 \%$ similarity with the original content, indicating that the main degradation factor is the compression intrinsic to the transmission process via the Wi-Fi network. This finding gives high reliability to the proposed method, even in potentially noisy scenarios, consolidating it as an effective tool for evaluating the quality of video transmission between mobile devices and secondary screens.

title: Mini-ResNet-Based Early Screening of Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder Using EEG Signals
authors: Seung Ho Lee, Ha Il Kim, Hyeong Jun Jin, Seung Yoon Yang, So Hui Kim, Seung Won Bang, Ga Eun Song, Jae Young Im, Dong Seog Han
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: In this paper, we propose Mini-ResNet, an ultralightweight deep learning model designed for the early diagnosis of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). This model processes raw electroencephalogram (EEG) data, input through stride-based slicing and augmentation, which circumvents the need for complex preprocessing. We successfully reduced the size of the conventional ResNet18 model from 42 MB to approximately 333 KB through architectural optimization. Experiments were performed on a publicly available ADHD dataset, employing 5-fold crossvalidation and exploring various optimizer configurations. Our Mini-ResNet exhibited superior performance over MobileNetV2, achieving an average accuracy of up to $84.3 \%$ and a higher F1-score. The model’s real-time applicability in mobile environments underscores its potential as an economical ADHD screening solution for both domestic and public health settings.

title: Interactive Visual Analytics Approach for Heavy-Plate Production Schedule Recommendation
authors: Wenju Liu, Tongkang Zhang, Jinliang Ding
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: Heavy plate production faces persistent challenges in thickness control due to complex, multi-stage processes and frequent specification changes. This paper presents an interactive visual analytics system that integrates human-computer interaction with data-driven analysis to support intelligent production scheduling. The proposed method extracts key multi-dimensional variables from industrial data, applies density-based clustering to classify specifications, and employs principal-component analysis for anomaly diagnosis and root cause identification. Based on historical patterns, the system recommends optimal production sequences with improved quality consistency. A case study using real-world data from a domestic steel manufacturer demonstrates the effectiveness of the approach in both anomaly detection and schedule optimization.

title: Error Control for Content-Adaptive Block Compressive Sensing with Polar Codes and Unequal Protection Concepts
authors: Hsiang-Cheh Huang, Feng-Cheng Chang, Po-Liang Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Block compressive sensing (BCS) is one of the new compression techniques in recent years. In addition to looking for compression performances, protection of BCS plays another key role for robust data transmission. In our scenario, original image can be classified into smooth and active blocks, and then different measurement rates in BCS can be applied. BCS compressed data would be presented with the binary format to form bitstreams for transmitting over binary channels. Considering the concept of unequal error protection, different level of protection can be accomplished with the polar codes. Compressed bistreams protected with polar codes can be transmitted over the binary symmetric channel (BSC), and errors may be induced during transmission. After reception, polar decoding and BCS reconstruction can be utilized subsequently to obtain reconstructed image. Simulations have shown the advantages of using the inherent characteristics of original image and the concept of unequal error protection over conventional settings.

title: Generative AI Powered Modern Education Tool to Enhance Teaching Learning Experience
authors: Babitha Ganesh, Nagaraja Thamankar, B K Pratheek Nayak, B H Skanda, V Suraksha Pai, A S Shivani
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: This article proposes an innovative educational tool that combines virtual canvas with cutting-edge technologies like generative AI, natural language processing (NLP), and gesture detection to improve the teaching and learning experience. The tool’s core component is an air canvas system that converts hand gestures into digital text, providing instructors with an intuitive and interactive medium for teaching. A predictive text module, trained on a dataset specifically designed for teaching contexts, simplifies content delivery by providing accurate, context-aware suggestions. This reduces cognitive strain on educators and ensures that instructional content aligns with learning objectives. One of the most notable features of the tool is its integration with Gemini AI, a state-of-the-art generative AI system. Gemini AI enables the tool to instantly respond to educators’ queries, providing contextually relevant answers that enhance class discussions and help address student concerns. Additionally, the tool’s voice recognition functionality allows teachers to control applications, play multimedia, and navigate slides hands-free, further improving ease of use. By integrating these AI-powered elements, the tool creates a dynamic and responsive learning environment that adapts to the varied needs of both teachers and students. While the auto correction module of the system is currently optimized for mathematics alone, it holds potential for expansion to diverse educational domains. Overall, this tool bridges the gap between pedagogy and technology, promoting inclusion and participation, and supporting Sustainable Development Goal 4 (SDG 4) by fostering a more engaging, customized, and effective learning experience.

title: Extension of CNN-Based Demodulation from Single-Color to Multi-Color in Image Sensor-Based Visible Light Communication
authors: Yuki Iyoda, Kentaro Kobayashi, Chedlia Ben Naila, Hiraku Okada
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper proposes an extension of CNN-based demodulation in image sensor-based visible light communication from single-color to multi-color processing. Conventional CNN-based demodulation methods mainly focus on a single color space, limiting the utilization of chromatic information. In this study, we introduce a multiplexed chromatic modulation by incorporating both Cr and Cb components into the demodulation process. To evaluate the proposed method, we conducted fundamental experiments using 24 different monochromatic backgrounds. The performance of our approach was compared with the conventional cell averaging method in terms of bit error rate (BER). Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed CNN-based demodulation with multi-color processing achieves a lower BER than conventional methods, indicating improved communication quality in image sensor-based visible light communication.

title: Multidirectional Capture: A Synthetic Dataset Strategy Through the Blender Software
authors: Chang Liu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: This paper discusses the challenges and advancements in animal pose estimation, a critical task in computer vision that identifies keypoints such as joints or features on animals, similar to human pose estimation. While human pose estimation has benefited from large-scale annotated datasets and deep learning techniques, animal pose estimation faces unique challenges, primarily due to the scarcity of annotated datasets. The importance of animal pose estimation is emphasized in understanding animal behavior, physiology, and neurological conditions, particularly in small animals where precise tracking of movements is crucial for studying neurological diseases, pain, and behavioral disorders. Despite progress with datasets like ImageNet and AP-10K, existing resources lack the comprehensive pose information required for high-performance neural networks. This paper highlights these challenges through a Sim-to-Real strategy, synthesizing an annotated dataset in Blender software, followed by the training of the YOLOV5 detection model and HRNet pose estimation model on it. Finally, the evaluation of these models is discussed throughout the training process. This presents possible solutions and innovations in the field to improve the accuracy and applicability of animal pose estimation systems.

title: A Study on Indoor Positioning Method Based on Neural Network by Using Array Antenna
authors: Haruki Shimizu, Masahiro Fujii
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: The fingerprinting method using received signals from array antenna has demonstrated higher accuracy than conventional method relying on RSSI (Received Signal Strength Indicator). However, the method has a problem with the lack of robustness to changes in the radio propagation environment. In this method, the database must be manually reconstructed each time the radio propagation environment changes to maintain positioning accuracy. Reconstructing the database is impractical because of the time and effort required. To address this problem, we propose a positioning method based on neural network using array antenna. In this paper, we conduct the numerical experiment using ray tracing method to compare the positioning accuracy of the proposed neural network approach with that of the conventional fingerprinting method under a stable radio propagation condition.

title: AI as a Service: Exposing the Functionalities of AI-Native 6G Networks
authors: Merve Saimler, Mustafa Riza Akdeniz, Dinand Roeland, Ajay Kattepur, Sultan Ertas, Mukesh Thakur, Igor Pastushok, Mirko D’Angelo, Jing Yue, Arif Ahmed, Mehmet Yunus Donmez
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: The transition to AI-native 6G networks embeds artificial intelligence (AI) across all network functions, enabling automation, efficiency, and advanced services. The AI-native approach is more than just a technical enhancement; it is a fundamental shift that drives the evolution toward autonomous networks, unlocking new advancements in network capabilities and user experience. A key enabler is AI as a Service (AIaaS), which allows Communication Service Providers (CSPs) to expose AI capabilities via standardized APIs. Built on Machine Learning Operations (MLOps), AIaaS streamlines AI model lifecycle management, reducing complexity for developers and optimizing AI-driven workflows.This paper investigates the integration of AIaaS into network exposure frameworks such as the 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) Network Exposure Function (NEF), Service Enabler Architecture Layer (SEAL), and the open-source CAMARA interface emphasizing the interacting and collaborating robots (cobots) use case in the context of industrial automation. We discuss how AIaaS enables CSPs to offer AI-powered services with guaranteed Quality of Service (QoS), driving innovation across industries and shaping the future of AI-native 6G networks.

title: Stream Voice Diffusion: Real-Time Image Generation from Speech
authors: Hideo Kodama, Masaki Yoshida, Ren Togo, Takahiro Ogawa, Miki Haseyama
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study proposes a high-speed image generation pipeline that uses speech as the prompt input. While conventional image generation methods have focused on high quality and controllability, they face limitations in real-time performance and are constrained in their applicability to interactive applications due to reliance on text-based prompts. Existing speech-to-image models, though interactive in nature, also suffer from low throughput, limiting their practical usability. To address these challenges, we introduce a lightweight pipeline capable of rapid image generation, combined with a speech-based input interface that enables more intuitive and hands-free interaction. The proposed method offers an effective solution for real-time Speech-to-Image tasks, where low latency and interactivity are essential.

title: Consideration of Automatic Garbage Detection System Using Camera and Low-Power Edge Device
authors: Tatsuya Abe, Shota Homma, Hirotake Tomita, Hidekazu Suzuki
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In Japan, data on the status of garbage accumulation at garbage collection points for household garbage collection can be utilized by the municipalities and garbage collection companies in various ways, such as improving the efficiency of garbage collection operations. Previously, the authors have proposed a system that dynamically collects data on garbage discharge and collection times at garbage collection points by installing IoT devices equipped with a camera. This paper proposes a system for detecting garbage bags using low-power edge devices and a lightweight object detection algorithm.

title: Receding-Horizon Diffusion Policy for Dynamic Robotic Trajectory Planning
authors: Chengzhi Yuan, Jinghan Cui, Jinwu Gao, Yuqi Liu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: Safe and responsive motion planning in dynamic, uncertain environments remains challenging. Traditional planners balance real-time adaptability, smoothness and safety, whereas diffusion models capture rich action distributions but cannot adapt online. To bridge this gap, we propose the receding-horizon diffusion policy, which embeds a pretrained diffusion model within a rolling horizon. A novel dual-mode endpoint strategy applies hard terminal constraints during the initial and final planning phases, whereas intermediate iterations remain unconstrained to maintain trajectory diversity. A cost function then evaluates and selects among multiple candidate plans to ensure safety and efficiency at each step. In the D3IL benchmark, our policy outperforms the enhanced RRT* baseline in all performance metrics. Ablation studies confirm the efficacy of its endpoint and cost-selection strategies.

title: A New Vector Indexing Algorithm for Embedded AI Systems
authors: You Shan, Tomoyuki Nagase, Tsutomu Zeniya, Toshiki Kanamoto
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: To address the efficiency of degradation and declining recall in traditional high-dimensional vector indexing methods, this paper proposes an innovative Vector Partition Tree (VPT) algorithm that leverages vector-space symmetry. The main contributions of this work are as follows: presenting a novel hierarchical VPT data structure for efficient high-dimensional indexing; designing a new interface methods that enable dynamic tree management; and introducing an adaptive node-expansion model to mitigate sparsity, allowing the VPT to recursively construct hierarchical partition structures that adaptively counteract high-dimensional sparsity. Experiments demonstrate VPT’s significant superiority over k-dimensional (K-D) tree and Locality-Sensitive Hashing (LSH) in sparse high-dimensional scenarios, reducing index construction time by up to 61% and achieving a 90% Top-100 recall rate. However, VPT’s retrieval performance becomes unstable in dense low-dimensional environments due to static partition-boundary effects and leaf-node overload. Future research will focus on partition-boundary optimization, dynamic node splitting, and hybrid storage architectures to enhance the adaptability of dense vectors and overcome memory bottlenecks. This work provides an efficient and precise solution for high-dimensional vector retrieval.

title: Duration Estimation Based on a Time-Lag Model in End-to-End Singing Voice Synthesis
authors: Tomoki Oono, Takashi Nose, Akinori Ito
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study proposes an end-to-end singing voice synthesis method that enhances rhythmic accuracy by integrating a time-lag model into the VISinger 2 framework. The proposed method predicts the temporal offset between each note’s score-defined and actual onset, and adjusts phoneme durations accordingly. This enables the synthesis of singing voices that are both natural and faithful to the score-defined musical rhythm. Experimental results show that the proposed method reduces the RMSE of phoneme start timing by approximately 80% compared to VISinger 2, and improves the RMSE of phoneme duration.

title: Novel Codebook Design and Performance Analysis for Time-Varying Spatial Channels With FDD MIMO
authors: Jinho Kang, Gyeongrae Im
publish: IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
abstract: Codebook design utilizing channel statistics is an effective solution to reduce feedback overhead in frequency-division duplexing (FDD) multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems. In this paper, we propose a novel codebook designed for time-varying spatial channels and analyze its quantization error (QErr). To this end, we first develop a new analysis on the average QErr of the channel statistics-rotated (CSR) codebook in a time-invariant spatial channel. The developed analysis is expressed as a function of the eigenvalue profiles of the channel statistics matrix, even when its rank remains constant. Next, by leveraging our newly developed analysis for the CSR codebook, we propose a novel time-varying adaptive CSR (TACSR) codebook in a time-varying spatial channel and derive the average QErr to characterize its performance from the channel statistics. Simulation results show that our new analysis for the CSR codebook provides much tighter bounds, while the proposed TACSR codebook significantly outperforms the existing codebooks in time-varying spatial channels.

title: Recent Advances in Discrete Speech Tokens: A Review
authors: Yiwei Guo, Zhihan Li, Hankun Wang, Bohan Li, Chongtian Shao, Hanglei Zhang, Chenpeng Du, Xie Chen, Shujie Liu, Kai Yu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: The rapid advancement of speech generation technologies in the era of large language models (LLMs) has established discrete speech tokens as a foundational paradigm for speech representation. These tokens, characterized by their discrete, compact, and concise nature, are not only advantageous for efficient transmission and storage, but also inherently compatible with the language modeling framework, enabling seamless integration of speech into text-dominated LLM architectures. Current research categorizes discrete speech tokens into two principal classes: acoustic tokens and semantic tokens, each of which has evolved into a rich research domain characterized by unique design philosophies and methodological approaches. This survey systematically synthesizes the existing taxonomy and recent innovations in discrete speech tokenization, conducts a critical examination of the strengths and limitations of each paradigm, and presents systematic experimental comparisons across token types. Furthermore, we identify persistent challenges in the field and propose potential research directions, aiming to offer actionable insights to inspire future advancements in the development and application of discrete speech tokens.

title: ISAC Channel Models from ETSI and 3GPP
authors: Mohammad Heggo, Arman Shojaeifard, Alain Mourad, Chuangxin Jiang, Ruiqi Liu, Junchen Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Integrated Sensing and Communications (ISAC) is a new usage scenario for 6G. To enable studying ISAC solutions, standardization bodies such as European Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI) and Third Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) require specified ISAC channel models. 3GPP has been studying changes to the existing TR 38.901 channel models to model radio-frequency (RF) signal interactions between the transmitter, sensing target, receiver, and surrounding environment. In parallel, ETSI has been working on additional features to further support channel modelling for the rich variety of ISAC use cases envisioned in 6G. In this paper, we present an outline of the latest developments from industry and further provide an evaluation framework for assessing the models.

title: Blind Matched Filter Design for Communication Chains Involving Frequency Multipliers: LSTM-based Approach
authors: Ahmet Alperen Oznam, Mohaned Chraiti, Ali Ghrayeb, Korkut Kaan Tokgöz
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Frequency multipliers are increasingly utilized for signal up-conversion in modern wireless communication systems, particularly in millimeter-wave (mmWave) and sub-terahertz (sub-THz) bands, owning to their simplicity and ease of integration. However, their inherent nonlinearity causes distortions, fundamentally altering the temporal and spectral characteristics of transmitted signals. This distortion transforms well-defined baseband pulses (e.g., sinc, raised cosine) into complex, hardware-dependent waveforms, where the matched-filter depends both on the multiplication order and the specific hardware implementation. Notably, the spectral occupancy of the transmitted signal expands after frequency multiplication. Without accurate knowledge of the multiplier-induced distortions at the receiver, applying a mismatched filter can cause severe inter-symbol interference and loss of critical frequency components, signal-to-noise ratio degradation thereby degrading detection performance. In this paper, we propose a blind, adaptive matched-filter estimation approach leveraging a Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) neural network. Our method directly estimates the matched filter from sampled segments of the noisy modulated received signal without requiring pilot symbols. The proposed model adapts to dynamic pulse shapes and amplitudes by implicitly learning the spectral transformations introduced by hardware-induced nonlinearities. Simulation results demonstrate high accuracy of the matched filter estimation, with a mean-square error precision of four decimal places.

title: 3D Camera-Based Estimation of Cattle Body Weight
authors: Shunsuke Araki, Kazuhisa Shiiya, Thi Thi Zin, Ikuo Kobayashi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Traditional methods for measuring cattle weight require special equipment and often involve physical contact with the animals, increasing the risk of accidents. As the workload for dairy farmers grows due to a decreasing workforce, there is a strong need for safer and more efficient solutions. In this study, we propose a contactless method to estimate cattle weight using a depth camera. This study differentiates itself from other studies by placing the camera above the cow, making it more versatile. We extracted depth images and calculated key body measurements: height, body length, and belly width. Based on these values, we created a regression formula to estimate weight. Our results show that it is possible to estimate cattle weight roughly using only the values obtained from depth images. This method reduces the risk of injuries during measurement and offers a more efficient way to manage cattle health and nutrition.

title: Exploring the Impact of HAPS-RIS on UAV-Based Networks: a Novel Network Architecture
authors: Arman Azizi, Mustafa A. Kishk, Arman Farhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a novel network architecture where two types of aerial infrastructures together with a ground station provide connectivity to a remote area. A high altitude platform station (HAPS) is equipped with reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS), called HAPS-RIS, to be exploited to assist the unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-based wireless networks. A key challenge in such networks is the restricted number of UAVs, which limits full coverage and leaves some users unsupported. To tackle this issue, we propose a hierarchical bilevel optimization framework including a leader and a follower problem. The users served by HAPS-RIS are in a zone called the HAPS-RIS zone and the users served by the UAVs are in another zone called the UAV zone. In the leader problem, the goal is to establish the zone boundary and practical RIS phase shift design that maximizes the number of users covered by HAPS-RIS while ensuring that users in this zone meet their rate requirements. This is achieved through our proposed practical relaxation method and the proposed dynamic radius-based zone association with RIS clustering (DyRaZARC) technique. The follower problem focuses on minimizing the number of UAVs required, ensuring that the rate requirements of the users in the UAV zone are met. This is addressed through our proposed novel geometry-informed machine learning method, called k-means adaptive dynamic UAV selection (KADUS) technique. Our study reveals that increasing the number of RIS elements significantly decreases the number of required UAVs.

title: A Pressing Sensation Rendering System with Semi-constrained Finger
authors: Yuki Takeda, Wataru Wakita
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: We propose a system that allows users to perceive a pressing sensation at low cost by changing the movement of an object in a virtual space according to the force measured by a load cell sensor with a semi-constrained finger. In this work, we reproduce the sensation of pressing buttons with various mechanical properties. The results of the evaluation experiment indicated that the system effectively simulated the mechanical characteristics of a keyboard or mouse, allowing users to perceive the sensation of pressing mechanical buttons.

title: A DNA-Based Computing Framework for Image Signal Encoding and Pattern Recognition
authors: Sharifu Ura
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In this study, DNA is modeled as a finite string over the alphabet {A, C, G, T}. A protein is similarly represented as a finite string over a 20-letter alphabet, with each letter corresponding to one of the standard amino acids (e.g., A for alanine, R for arginine, N for asparagine, and so on). Translation from DNA to protein is defined by a function that maps every three-letter substring (codon) from the DNA alphabet to a single letter in the protein alphabet. For example, GCT maps to alanine (A), CGT to arginine (R), AAT to asparagine (N), and so on. Building on this principle, a DNA-Based Computing (DBC) algorithm is developed to address machine learning tasks. In this work, a DBC-based framework is proposed for pattern recognition in images. The framework extracts a time series signal from a given image, encodes it into multiple DNA sequences, and translates them into a protein-like string. The entropy of n-grams within this string is used as a numerical index for quantifying the image. In a case study involving two visually different images of the same object, the framework successfully indexed them as equivalent, demonstrating DBC’s potential for robust, image-based inference in smart manufacturing.

title: Impact of AlGaN Superlattices on the Thermal Stability of Al-Rich AlGaN Channel HEMTs
authors: Shyam Mohan, Joocheol Jeong, Jooyong Park, Joonhyuk Lee, Jaejin Heo, Okhyun Nam
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: This work presents a comprehensive study on the temperature-dependent and high-field electrical performance of Al ${}_{{0}.{60}}$ Ga ${}_{{0}.{40}}$ N channel high-electron-mobility transistors (HEMTs) incorporating AlN/Al ${}_{{0}.{70}}$ Ga ${}_{{0}.{30}}$ N superlattices (SLs) with total thicknesses of 150 and 300 nm, grown on AlN/4H–SiC substrates with an Al ${}_{{0}.{95}}$ Ga ${}_{\text {0. 0. 05}}$ N barrier. The SLs are engineered to modulate strain relaxation and reduce dislocation density in the AlGaN channel. Devices were characterized between $25~^{\circ }$ C and $200~^{\circ }$ C using capacitance–voltage (CV) and dc measurements to analyze interface trap dynamics, threshold-voltage stability, and thermal reliability. The SLs-150 nm device exhibits superior thermal and electrical stability, with minimal CV hysteresis and negligible threshold-voltage shift ( $\Delta \textit{V}_{\text {th}} \approx ~0.1$ V) up to $200~^{\circ }$ C, achieving the lowest on-resistance ( $\sim 650~\Omega \cdot $ mm) and sharpest subthreshold swing (SS) (~225 mV/dec). The off-state breakdown measurements show that the SLs-300 nm device sustains electric fields exceeding 2.6 kV at ${L}_{\text {gd}} =25$ $\mu $ m—among the highest reported for Al-rich AlGaN-channel HEMTs without field plates and passivation. These results demonstrate that optimized SLs engineering simultaneously enhances thermal stability and breakdown strength, highlighting Al-rich AlGaN-channel HEMTs as promising candidates for next-generation power and RF electronics in extreme environments.

title: Weld Defect Identification and Quality Evaluation for Modular Steel Construction Via YOLO with Loss Analysis
authors: Sorrathan Wongsuwan, Anek Siripanichgorn, Yuttapong Jirasaksopakun, Punnarai Siricharoen
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: Modular steel construction is gaining widespread adoption due to its efficiency, cost-effectiveness, and reduced construction time compared to traditional methods. However, ensuring weld quality remains a critical challenge for structural integrity. This study presents a defect detection system for modular steel welds using the YOLOv10 object detection model. A publicly available dataset from Roboflow Universe, enriched with augmentation techniques, is used to enhance model training. To address class imbalance, a Weighted Dataloader framework is implemented. In addition, the impact of multiple IoU-based loss functions, including Generalized IoU (GIoU), Distance IoU (DIoU), Complete IoU (CIoU), Efficient IoU (EIoU), SCYLLA IoU (SIoU), Minimum-Point-Distance IoU (MPDIoU), and Focal-EIoU, is investigated. Experimental results show that integrating the Focal-EIoU loss with YOLOv10s significantly improves performance, achieving a precision of 77.8 % and a mean Average Precision (mAP) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{8 0. 4 \%}$</tex>. The proposed system outperforms YOLOv8 and YOLOv9 in ablation studies. This work advances automated weld inspection and supports future application development for weld quality assessment in modular steel structures.

title: Grid-Based 3D Position Estimation in RFID Systems Using Directional Antennas
authors: Rena Koura, Yukina Miwa, Ayano Naito, Masaki Ehara
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) technology has garnered significant attention in various domains, particularly in inventory tracking and anti-theft applications. However, conventional RFID-based systems typically perform position estimation in two dimensions, limiting their ability to determine vertical positions or distinguish overlapping items. This paper introduces a three-dimensional positioning system that arranges RFID antennas in a spatial configuration. The system employs four directional antennas—two oriented horizontally and two vertically―to receive signals from multiple angles. By adjusting the tilt of each antenna, the system induces position-dependent variations in Received Signal Strength Indicator (RSSI) and phase values, resulting in distinctive spatial signal patterns. The proposed configuration captures vertical information and extends positioning capabilities beyond traditional two-dimensional methods. Experimental validation using a prototype system confirms the feasibility of accurate three-dimensional localization. A comparative evaluation using grid-based classification and multiple machine learning algorithms further demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Reproducing Developmental Features and Preserving Semantics in Child-Style Text Generation Using LLM
authors: Keito Inoshita, Rushia Harada, Keisuke Motomura
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: A Large Language Model (LLM) has advanced natural language processing but primarily relies on adult-oriented texts, creating gaps in modeling child-style writing, particularly in Japanese with its unique developmental script shifts. This study explores whether an LLM can regenerate Japanese adult texts into child-style texts across 16 educational stages. Using high-difficulty base texts covering ten themes, we generated outputs in both zero-shot and few-shot settings, evaluating readability with jReadability and semantic similarity with BERT-based cosine metrics. The results demonstrate that the LLM effectively reproduces developmental linguistic features and maintains high semantic fidelity, indicating its potential for ethical child-style data augmentation.

title: Emulating Industrial 5G-Edge Networks
authors: Suleyman Sadikhov, Mehrdad Salimnejad, William Tärneberg, Christian Nyberg, Nikolaos Pappas
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Despite extensive research on Quality-of-Services (QoS) analysis of 5G networks, practical applications remain limited. This gap may be attributed to the lack of available tools and the complexity of developing or configuring technical systems to implement theoretical approaches. To address this, we developed an edge control system within a private 5G base station, utilizing Precision Time Protocol (PTP) to enable accurate Age of Information (AoI) measurements. Through analysis using AoI and Age of Actuation (AoA) metrics, we demonstrate the accomplishment of comparable results in an emulated Local Area Network (LAN), which offers greater accessibility and reduced complexity. We also test the reliability of network emulation application on system performance analysis.

title: Edge-AI Based WiFi Sensing for Aerosol Detection
authors: Yirui Deng, Taoran Ye, Deepak Mishra, Shaghik Atakaramians, Aruna Seneviratne
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: With the accelerated global urbanization and industrialization, air pollution due to aerosol has become one of the main challenges facing society. The aim of this work is to explore the use of artificial intelligence (AI) and WiFi-based wireless sensing technologies to enable the detection of aerosols and to assess their potential application in environmental monitoring. We proposed a framework that detects the aerosol concentration levels via the channel state information (CSI) of the ambient WiFi signal with the help of low-complexity machine learning (ML) classifiers that can process CSI data on the embedded devices. We experimentally validated the feasibility of the proposed framework with a prototype system implemented with wide-deployable commodity hardware. We demonstrated empirically that the proposed framework can predict aerosol concentration levels with 99% average accuracy via edge computing on an embedded system with tailored pre-processing. We evaluated the robustness of our proposed technology with practical aerosol materials and achieved more than 97% accuracy for both graffiti paint and air refresher. Overall, our edge-AI-based wireless sensing offers a low-cost, low-complexity, non-invasive solution to practical aerosol monitoring applications, such as indoor air quality monitoring and autonomous graffiti vandalism alerting.

title: Dynamic Challenge Based Federated Learning Scenario for Network Digital Twin Aided O-RAN
authors: Ayşe Sayın
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper provides a robust and privacy-preserved federated learning (FL) framework in the open radio access network (O-RAN). The proposed solution uses the network digital twin (NDT) as an rApp in O-RAN to generate dynamic challenge scenarios specific to the network configuration prior to the local model training process in FL. The generated challenge scenario and a predetermined model success threshold are made available to the FL clients to prompt them to subsequently join the model aggregation process. The solution prevents free-riding and issues with global model accuracy in FL, while preserving local data privacy and improving compliance in a multi-vendor environment. This study enables fair and robust FL in a heterogeneous O-RAN environment and makes O-RAN networks effective and adaptive.

title: Improvement Strategies for Few-Shot Learning in OCT Image Classification of Rare Retinal Diseases
authors: Cheng-Yu Tai, Ching-Wen Chen, Chi-Chin Wu, Bo-Chen Chiu, Cheng-Hung Dixson Lin, Cheng-Kai Lu, Jia-Kang Wang, Tzu-Lun Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper focuses on using few-shot learning to improve the accuracy of classifying OCT diagnosis images with major and rare classes. We used the GAN-based augmentation strategy as a baseline and introduced several novel methods to further enhance our model. The proposed strategy contains U-GAT-IT for improving the generative part and uses the data balance technique to narrow down the skew of accuracy between all categories. The best model obtained was built with CBAM attention mechanism and fine-tuned InceptionV3, and achieved an overall accuracy of 97.85%, representing a significant improvement over the original baseline.

title: Efficient Fault Diagnosis in Industrial Systems Using Enhanced PolyKAN Techniques
authors: Majdi Mansouri, Khadija Attouri, Abdelmalek Kouadri
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: This article introduces and evaluates adaptive polynomial Kolmogorov–Arnold network (AdaptPolyKAN) architectures for intelligent fault diagnosis, addressing limitations of classical KANs in dynamic and nonlinear industrial systems. While classical KANs offer interpretability, their fixed univariate mappings lack the flexibility needed for evolving operating conditions. The proposed AdaptPolyKAN uses adaptive polynomial expansions that adjust the degree of each basis according to local reconstruction errors, enabling real-time adaptation, improved accuracy, and efficient handling of complex nonstationary fault patterns. Three variants are examined-Standard PolyKAN, SplineKAN, and Online PolyKAN-alongside the proposed AdaptPolyKAN. Their performance is benchmarked against classical KAN, artificial neural networks, support vector machines, and random forest models in both real and simulated fault scenarios. The evaluation uses datasets from a cement rotary kiln at the Ain El Kebira plant, consisting of 768 normal samples, multiple simulated sensor faults, and one real fault. Monitored variables include temperatures, pressures, motor currents, and rotational speeds from 44 sensors recorded at 20-s intervals. The dataset contains noise, class imbalance, and limited duration, reflecting realistic industrial conditions. Comprehensive metrics—including accuracy, precision, recall, F1- score, false alarm rate (FAR), and missed detection rate (MDR)—demonstrate the superiority of the proposed approach. AdaptPolyKAN achieves 98.4% accuracy, balanced precision and recall (98.3% and 98.4%), and the lowest FAR (0.0060), while maintaining competitive MDR (0.178). Online PolyKAN adapts effectively to changing fault patterns, whereas classical KAN suffers from elevated false alarms. Overall, AdaptPolyKAN provides reliable detection in nonlinear and time-varying processes, offering a practical and interpretable solution for safety-critical industrial environments.

title: Automatic Photo Selection Method for Graduation Albums
authors: Masashi Oda, Naoki Kotani, Satoshi Sugikawa, Yuta Muraki
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Graduation albums are used to store the many events and memories experienced throughout the students' school life. However, the production of graduation albums requires a large amount of time and effort to select appropriate images from a huge collection of images, and there is a growing demand for an automatic graduation album photo selection system. Conventional image selection systems are not practical for graduation album production because of problems such as false detection of face blurring. In this study, face blur detection using frequency components of the face region and blink detection using feature points of the eyes are applied to a group of main subjects determined from depth values and areas. Then, we propose an appropriate automatic selection method for graduation album photos.

title: CNN and Transfer Learning-Based Classification of Alzheimer's Disease Stages from 2D Brain MRI: Model Performance and Interface Integration
authors: Alejandra Bolaños Aldana, Valentina Canaval Dicue, Nicoll D. Castillo Estacio, Cristian A. Torres Valencia
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Colombian BioCAS Workshop
abstract: Alzheimer's disease is one of the leading causes of dementia worldwide, posing a major challenge for its early and accurate diagnosis. Although conventional techniques are useful, they rely heavily on clinical judgment and may be limited in early stages. In this context, convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have emerged as an effective alternative for the automated analysis of medical images. This work presents the development and implementation of two CNN-based models for the classification of 2D brain MRI images across different stages of Alzheimer's disease, a custom model built from scratch, and a transfer learning model using the pre-trained VGG16 architecture. The models were trained and evaluated using a public dataset from Kaggle, with images categorized into four clinical stages. Results show that the custom model achieved <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{9 6. 5 \%}$</tex> accuracy, significantly outperforming the transfer learning model, which reached 70 %. Additionally, a graphical user interface was designed to allow users to visualize the predictions from both models, enhancing their potential clinical application. The findings highlight the effectiveness of CNNs for assisted diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease and emphasize the importance of adapting architectures to medical data.

title: A Battery Degradation Model for Cost-Optimized PV-BESS Design in Telecom Base Stations
authors: Mohammad Reza Jokar, Michela Meo, Greta Vallero, Daniela Renga
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Telecom base stations increasingly rely on solar power and battery storage to achieve sustainable, cost-effective energy solutions, but battery degradation poses a significant challenge to system reliability and longevity. This paper introduces an innovative optimization framework that accounts for lithium-ion battery aging, modeling both calendar and cycle degradation with a novel segment-based approach. Designed for seamless integration into cost-effective energy planning, the framework optimizes photovoltaic (PV) panel and battery sizing to minimize costs and extend system lifespan. Validated using real-world base station power consumption data, our approach outperforms traditional rainflow-based aging models, reducing battery cycle wear by up to 65.5% compared to aging-unaware methods and by an additional 10% over rainflow-based methods. By enabling real-time battery health tracking, it supports dynamic energy management, offering a practical solution for sustainable telecom networks.

title: Delay and Packet Loss in Wireless Networks with Finite Queue Length
authors: Jiaji Tian, Yi Zhong
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper studies the performance of large-scale wireless networks with finite queue lengths, an aspect that has been largely overlooked in previous studies focusing on single-link or single-queue models. By modeling packet transmission in networks with finite-length queues and employing meta distribution analysis, we derive precise expressions for delay and packet loss probability. Our findings show that when queue capacities are limited, the transmission success probability significantly influences packet loss behavior. Specifically, a sharp increase in packet loss occurs when the transmission success probability drops below a critical threshold. While increasing queue length does not mitigate packet loss in suboptimal transmission conditions, it can notably enhance network performance under typical scenarios. This study provides important insights for optimizing resource allocation in large-scale wireless networks, emphasizing the need to balance queue length and transmission success probability for better efficiency.

title: Prescribed Performance Control of Marine Surface Vessels with Dead-Zone Inputs
authors: Hong-Wei Jia, Jin-Xi Zhang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: This paper investigates the problem of dynamic positioning (DP) for the marine surface vessels with unknown dynamics and dead-zone input as well as unknown disturbances. In order to resolve this problem, we put forward a prescribed performance control approach. It ensures DP with predefined speed and precision, meaning that DP errors remain confined within the specified performance bounds even in the presence of nonsymmetric dead-zone input. It is naturally resilient to unknown vessel dynamics and marine disturbances. Moreover, the proposed control preserves the simplicity of the controller, without identification, approximation, estimation, or derivation. At last, a simulation study is given to demonstrate the aforementioned theoretical finding.

title: A Sequential Transfer Optimization Framework for Expensive Optimization Problems
authors: Wangpeng Huang, Cuie Yang, Jinliang Ding
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: In recent years, evolutionary transfer optimization has attracted extensive attention due to its capability to enhance the optimization efficiency of expensive optimization problems (EOPs) and reduce the number of expensive function evaluations (FEs). However, most existing studies primarily focus on transferring elite individual knowledge from source tasks, while paying less attention to other aspects of knowledge such as landscape knowledge. In view of the above, this paper proposes a novel evolutionary sequential transfer optimization framework (ESTOF) for addressing EOPs. First, farthest point sampling (FPS) is utilized to filter out the data in each source task that best reflects landscape information. Subsequently, to maximize the integration of source task information, a source task screening mechanism (STSM) is designed to screen out source tasks with the highest feature similarity and data transferability to the target task. Finally, the selected source task data and target task data are used to construct a dual-task transfer gaussian process (DTGP), thereby significantly reducing the computational burden of surrogate models and the calculation of redundant parameters. Since landscape knowledge integrates both topological features and predictive information of elite individuals, ESTOF facilitates more comprehensive knowledge transfer. Experimental results further confirm that ESTOF significantly improves the optimization efficiency of EOPs while reducing the number of expensive FEs.

title: Drone Rider: Enhancing VR Flight Experience with Dynamic Wind Feedback
authors: Hanyi Yang, Shogo Okamoto, Kazuya Shimato, Hong Shen
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Wind stimulation has been shown to enhance self-motion perception in virtual reality (VR). Building on our previous work with the Drone Rider simulator, this study investigates how four types of wind feedback—no wind, constant wind, naturally fluctuating wind, and velocity-adaptive wind— affect the VR flight experience. Seven participants experienced all conditions and rated four aspects: sense of flight, sense of being on a flying drone, sense of control, and wind naturalness. Within-participant analysis revealed that velocity-adaptive wind significantly enhanced the sense of flight and wind naturalness compared to no-wind or constant wind conditions. These findings suggest that both the presence of wind and its dynamic modulation are critical for achieving realistic and immersive VR flight experiences.

title: Blockchain Simulator for Consensus Algorithms and Security Testing in Future IoT
authors: Yunus Kareem, Djamel Djenouri, Essam Ghadafi
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Blockchain is expected to play a key role in securing next generation communication systems, i.e., B5G and 6G, which will be highly decentralised, with high integration of edge computing, device-to-device (D2D) communications, and notably IoT networks. This paper addresses a fundamental bottleneck of blockchain; the simulation of consensus algorithms. State-of-the-art blockchain consensus algorithm simulators are built on general data that do not consider resource-constrained devices. These simulators have limitations in performance measurement (energy, latency, and throughput) and testing of security attacks, including DoS, Sybil, and 34% or 51% attacks). This paper introduces a blockchain Internet of Things consensus algorithm (BICA) simulator, which offers a framework for testing consensus algorithms with adaptable IoT data in various attack scenarios. It evaluates metrics such as latency, throughput, and attack resilience, providing insights into their capabilities under diverse network conditions. A case study involving Proof of Stake (PoS), Delegated Proof of Stake (DPoS), Proof of Elapse Time (PoET), Proof of Authority (PoA) and Practical Byzantine Fault Tolerance (PBFT) showed PBFT’s superior performance and security against vulnerabilities such as Sybil, DoS, and 34-51% attacks. BICA’s block-creation speed surpasses that of the existing simulators.

title: A Topology-Based Approach for Energy Consumption Mitigation in Video CDN
authors: Hamid Zargariasl, Christian Herglotz
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: A Video Content Delivery Network (VCDN) is a distributed system specifically designed to deliver video content and live streams to consumer electronics. Given the large scale of these networks, energy consumption has become a key area of research in recent years. Our contribution is to demonstrate that graph theory offers a promising approach to addressing energy-efficiency challenges in VCDNs. We aim to show how previous VCDN network can be enhanced using graph theory. This study also evaluates the effectiveness of graph-based analysis for optimizing the placement of origin servers and edge servers (surrogates). In our research, we compare the traditional random placement of servers with an approach driven by network analysis. Our findings reveal that applying graph theory can lead to significant improvements in energy consumption. These results are valuable both for addressing energy challenges during the deployment phase and for optimizing energy efficiency in existing VCDN networks.

title: Development and Implementation of a High-Efficiency Solar-Powered Cooling System for Smart Industrial and Commercial Buildings
authors: Yong-Dong Chang, Ching-Chih Chang, Jun-Hao Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study presents the development and implementation of a high-efficiency solar-powered cooling system designed for smart industrial and commercial buildings. The system integrates a 3000 W photovoltaic array, a 48 V lithium-ion battery storage system, and a DC inverter air conditioning unit, ensuring sustainable cooling operations with minimal reliance on the power grid. A dual-mode energy management strategy dynamically optimizes power distribution between solar power, battery storage, and grid electricity to ensure stable cooling operation. The controller module is a key system feature, offering programmable digital control for greater monitoring flexibility, enhanced control freedom, and UPS functionality. Additionally, an IoT-based wireless monitoring system provides real-time performance tracking and remote control. Experimental results demonstrate that the system maintains stable cooling operation for over 9 hours while being powered entirely by 100% green energy. These findings verify the feasibility of the system for energy-efficient cooling applications in industrial and commercial settings.

title: Stability Analysis and Anti-Windup Design of Uncertain Switched Fuzzy Systems with Actuator Saturation
authors: Bihe Wu, Xinquan Zhang, Chao Yuan, Xinyu Du
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: This paper investigates the stability analysis and anti-windup design problem for a class of switched fuzzy systems with actuator saturation. By designing switching strategies and anti-windup compensators, the asymptotic stability of the closed-loop system is ensured. Based on the multiple Lyapunov functions method, several sufficient conditions for the existence of anti-windup compensators are derived. Furthermore, an anti-windup control strategy is developed by solving an optimization problem constrained by linear matrix inequalities (LMI) to maximize the estimated domain of attraction. Finally, numerical examples are provided to validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Infrared Thermography for Incident Energy Measurement in Arc Flashes under VOA Configuration Supported by Statistical Analysis
authors: Pedro Bacin, Vitor Bender, Márcio Bottaro, Marina Camponogara, Tiago Marchesan, Rafael Beltrame, Gilnei José Santos, Carlos Simões, Bowen Zheng, Bo Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE ESW Brazil – Electrical Safety Workshop Brazil (ESW Brazil)
abstract: Accurate estimation of incident energy (IE) in arc flash events is essential for improving electrical safety. This study explores the application of infrared thermography as a thermal sensing technique for calorimetric measurements, offering a non-contact alternative to conventional methods. Tests were performed in a high-current laboratory using a vertical open-air (VOA) three-phase electrode configuration, as defined in IEEE Std 1584-2018. A total of 20 paired measurements were collected under similar arc current and duration conditions, with IE values ranging from 0.91 to 1.02 cal/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. These values were compared to estimates obtained from the IEEE Std 1584-2018 model. Statistical analysis included a paired t-test and the two one-sided tests (TOST), which assess statistical equivalence within predefined acceptance margins. The observed differences remained within acceptable limits, suggesting consistent behavior between thermographic measurements and standard-based estimations. Additional exploratory analysis was conducted to examine distribution characteristics and support interpretation. While not intended to replace conventional instrumentation, the thermographic approach demonstrated feasibility as a complementary method for IE estimation. Broader studies under diverse conditions are recommended to further evaluate its applicability.

title: Multi-objective optimization using few-shot hybridization network for numerical control machining
authors: Xinyi Jie, Yangyang Li, Fanlge Chang, Weipeng Liu, Lei Xie, Hongye Su
publish: 2025 21st IEEE International Conference on Mechatronic and Embedded Systems and Applications (MESA)
abstract: Optimizing the machining parameters can improve the product quality and reduce processing costs.This work proposes a hybrid network (PPO-XGB) integrating reinforcement learning (PPO) and machine learning (XGBoost) for multiobjective optimization of machining parameters in numerical control (NC) machining. Addressing the poor generalization of traditional models in few-shot samples data environment, the PPO algorithm dynamically optimizes XGBoost hyperparameters to enhance prediction accuracy for surface roughness (Ra) and cutting force. Results indicate that PPO-XGB offers the best predictive performance in respect of all accuracy metrics: root-mean-squared-error (RMSE), mean-absolute-error (MAE), and coefficient of determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>).In addition,a hybridization of non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm (NSGA-II) and PPO-XGB is implemented to find the optimal solutions for machining parameters. It balances the multi-objective conflict of minimizing Ra and cutting force. Experiments demonstrate: PPO-XGB’s predictive performance (test set RMSE=0.2000 for Ra, 0.0153 for Force) significantly outperforms baseline models; two Pareto solutions optimized by NSGA-II reduce Ra by 12.7% and cutting force by 9.3% compared to empirical solution. This method provides a high-accuracy, low-computation-cost optimization framework for numerical control machining.
