title: Drone Rider: Virtual Flight Meets Exergaming
authors: Hong Shen, Kazuya Shimato, Hanyi Yang, Shogo Okamoto
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: We developed Drone Rider, an extended reality (XR) system designed to simulate a flying experience. The system enhances immersion through multisensory feedback, including lower-body vibration stimuli, passive tilting of the foot platform, wind feedback proportional to flying speed, and real-time projection of the user’s arms into the virtual environment. This study explores the potential of Drone Rider as an exergame— a form of interactive entertainment that integrates gameplay with physical activity. In a user study, 10 participants tracked virtual flight targets for 90 s. The average heart rate increased by 10.4 bpm, indicating moderate physical engagement. Reports of cybersickness were minimal (mean = 2.3 on a 0–9 scale), and participants positively evaluated its potential as an e-sports platform (mean = 5.0). These findings support the potential of Drone Rider as a fitness-oriented XR system involving moderate physical engagement.

title: Data-Driven Gait Phenotyping in Older Adults via Clustering of Raw Signals: Links to Fall History
authors: Ryusei Sato, Takashi Watanabe
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study applies unsupervised clustering to foot-mounted inertial-sensor data to delineate discrete gait phenotypes in older adults and explore how fall history modifies gait within each phenotype. Using a publicly available dataset of adults aged ≥ 70 years who completed continuous walking task, sagittal-plane acceleration and angular-velocity waveforms for every stride were summarized by Dynamic Time Warping distances and partitioned with K-medoids++ clustering. A four-cluster solution optimally balanced compactness and separation, yielding: (0) high-cadence, (1) cautious, (2) intermediate, and (3) robust patterns. Fall prevalence ranged from 27 % in Cluster 3 to 68 % in Cluster 1. Within each cluster, fallers still displayed slower speed, shorter steps, and poorer functional scores than non-fallers despite otherwise similar global gait signatures; for example, Cluster 3 fallers walked 31 % slower and covered roughly half the distance of their non-falling counterparts. Fear of falling and clinical measures discriminated against fallers only in phenotypes characterized by faster gait velocity, suggesting phenotype-specific risk mechanisms. The findings highlight that gait phenotyping sharpens clinical stratification beyond binary faller/non-faller labels and that preventive thresholds for metrics such as gait velocity should be calibrated based on phenotype.

title: Distributed Mixture-of-Agents for Edge Inference with Large Language Models
authors: Purbesh Mitra, Priyanka Kaswan, Sennur Ulukus
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Mixture-of-Agents (MoA) has recently been proposed as a method to enhance performance of large language models (LLMs), enabling multiple individual LLMs to work together for collaborative inference. This collaborative approach results in improved responses to user prompts compared to relying on a single LLM. In this paper, we consider such an MoA architecture in a distributed setting, where LLMs operate on individual edge devices, each uniquely associated with a user and equipped with its own distributed computing power. These devices exchange information using decentralized gossip algorithms, allowing different device nodes to talk without the supervision of a centralized server. In the considered setup, different users have their own LLM models to address user prompts. Additionally, the devices gossip either their own user-specific prompts or augmented prompts to generate more refined answers to certain queries. User prompts are temporarily stored in the device queues when their corresponding LLMs are busy. Given the memory limitations of edge devices, it is crucial to ensure that the average queue sizes in the system remain bounded. In this paper, we address this by theoretically calculating the queuing stability conditions for the device queues under reasonable assumptions, which we validate experimentally as well. Further, we demonstrate through experiments, leveraging open-source LLMs for the implementation of distributed MoA, that certain MoA configurations produce higher-quality responses compared to others, as evaluated on AlpacaEval 2.0 benchmark. The implementation is available at: https://github.com/purbeshmitra/distributed_moa.

title: Cortisol Estimation using Wearable Wristbands: Comparing Multilevel Modelling and Machine Learning
authors: Marina Saskovets, Mykhailo Lohachov, Zilu Liang
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Non-invasive monitoring of cortisol is an emerging focus in stress research, driven by advances in wearable sensing and data-driven modeling approaches. However, small sample sizes and multimodal signal variability pose significant challenges. This study compares random forest (RF) and multivariate multilevel modeling (MMM) to predict cortisol levels from physiological features, including heart rate, heart rate variability, electrodermal activity, acceleration, and skin temperature. Our dataset consists of 175 cortisol samples collected across five experimental stages. Using 3-fold cross-validation, RF achieved an average R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.510, outperforming MMM (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> = 0.433), while identifying heart rate and electrodermal activity as top predictors. However, MMM provided deeper insight into inter-individual variability and stage-dependent effects. This comparative analysis highlights trade-offs between predictive accuracy and model interpretability, supporting a hybrid modeling strategy for stress monitoring applications in health technology and personalized interventions.

title: AR-Independent DCP Read-Only Mode for Secure Configuration in PROFINET Networks
authors: İhsan Gökhun Önel, Can Çağdaş Yeşildağ, Ömer Korçak
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper addresses a critical yet overlooked security gap in PROFINET Security Class 1: the inability of the Discovery and Configuration Protocol (DCP) Read-only mode to persist when no Application Relationship (AR) exists between a PROFINET IO Device and its Controller. In current implementations, this protection is deactivated once the AR terminates—such as during maintenance or controller failures—leaving devices vulnerable to unauthorized configuration changes. To close this gap, we propose a lightweight and backward-compatible extension that enables persistent DCP Read-only protection independent of AR state. The proposed mechanism stores the protection flag in non-volatile memory and supports secure activation or deactivation via standard engineering tools. We implement and validate our solution using the Siemens PROFINET Driver and SIMATIC S7-1500 hardware. Experimental results show that our enhancement reliably blocks unauthorized DCP modifications, even after AR loss—thus significantly improving the configuration security of mission-critical industrial networks.

title: Transferable DRL for Robust Digital Predistortion Under Dynamic Transmission Conditions
authors: Arash Rabiepoor, Leslie Rusch, Ming Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper presents a novel digital pre-distortion technique leveraging deep reinforcement learning (DRL) to address memoryless nonlinearities caused by nonideal electrical components in communication systems. The proposed DRL based method is shown to outperform traditional approaches—including Volterra series, look-up tables, and machine learning-based indirect learning algorithms—in terms of bit-error rate (BER) and effective signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) improvement. Additionally, the study demonstrates the superior robustness of DRL compared to direct learning architectures (DLA) under abrupt input power variations in power amplifiers. Notably, this work is the first to incorporate transfer learning into the DRL training process, effectively stabilizing performance across varying operating conditions.

title: Dual Attention and Discrete Wavelet Transform Network for Image Dehazing
authors: Tianqi Zhou, Jinhui Fan, Weizhe Gao, Yikang Yang, Shiping Guo, Haoqi Xu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: As a pivotal technique for enhancing the interpretability of images degraded by poor visibility, image dehazing is indispensable for ensuring the reliability and accuracy of various visual systems, particularly in the domains of autonomous driving, video surveillance, and remote sensing. Addressing this issues of blurred images, loss of details, and insufficient brightness in current defogging models during nonuniform defogging processes, this study proposes a defogging network, which combines dual attention and discrete wavelet transform (2D-DWT). First, a 2D-DWT defogging network is introduced into the model structure, which retains more highfrequency information and significantly improves the restoration of details and textures; Second, a histogram self-attention mechanism is incorporated into the 2D-DWT defogging network to effectively focus on dynamic range spatial features, thereby achieving global efficient defogging; Finally, a half wavelet attention block is introduced into the transfer learning-based defogging branch to further enrich the feature representation in the image wavelet domain. To validate the model's effectiveness, we constructed a dataset closely resembling real-world scenarios by integrating multiple databases and conducted comparative experiments with state-of-the-art algorithms. The experimental evaluation demonstrates the exceptional effectiveness of the proposed framework, which excels in producing high-quality, haze-free images. This study provides new research insights for de-hazing technology and holds significant theoretical and practical value for unsupervised model-based dehazing.

title: Graph-based Pass Receiver Prediction in Soccer with Consideration of Passer’s Body Orientation
authors: Riku Yoshida, Ryota Goka, Keisuke Maeda, Takahiro Ogawa, Miki Haseyama
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Passes account for most of the on-ball actions in a soccer match, and thus accurately predicting pass receivers is informative to reveal the action value of multiple players. Although tracking data is commonly used for prediction in existing methods, it is derived from a bird’s-eye view and fails to consider the passer’s perceptual cues. We tackle this problem with the passer’s body orientation, which is estimated from the broadcast image. Specifically, we construct a player graph that reflects the spatial relationships among players and adapt its structure according to the body orientation of the passer. The proposed method then predicts pass receivers by applying a graph attention network to the player graph. Experimental results show the effectiveness of our method.

title: Behavior-Driven Mealworm Harvest Prediction System
authors: Daiki Togawa, Reona Yamawaki, Fukuyoshi Kimura, Kai Hashizume, Mitsuru Hattori, Tetsuo Imai, Toru Kobayashi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: We have been studying the Worm Pod system, which automatically grows mealworms (larvae of Tenebrio molitor) as an alternative to fishmeal feed. To optimize mealworm production with Worm Pod, it is crucial to predict the ideal harvest time. In this paper, we clarify the ecological characteristics observed during mealworm growth stages and propose a method to predict total production maximization based on these characteristics. This method corrects the typical mealworm growth curve for each Worm Pod's growth environment, maintaining prediction accuracy in different environments.

title: A Consumer-Grade IMU-Based System for Visualizing and Quantifying Finger Independence in Piano Training
authors: Tsen-Fang Lin, Kuang-Hung Cheng, Liang-Bi Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper presents a low-cost consumer-grade sensor-based system to visualize and quantify involuntary finger motion during piano training. We use five 6-axis IMU sensors with an ESP32 microcontroller on each finger to collect motion data while trained users press keys with either the thumb or pinky. We calculate the total angular velocity to analyze and detect crosstalk between fingers. Our results show that even experienced pianists exhibit subtle involuntary finger movements, which can now be visualized and used for learning and corrective feedback.

title: AI ARMORS: An Experimental C-V2X Framework for Road Safety over 5G SA with Computer Vision
authors: George T. Karetsos, Dimitris Moutafidis, Konstantinos Gonidakis
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Road safety is one of the most critical aspects of everyday living and related accidents have serious psychological and economic side effects. In this work we present the AI ARMORS framework which aims to enhance safety leveraging 5G connectivity and the capabilities of the respective end devices. In particular we study, develop, set-up and carry out experiments related to C-V2X (Cellular Vehicle-to-Everything) communications for road safety by enabling the involved stakeholders in road traffic environments to communicate and synchronize so as to avoid accidents or manage them in the best possible way using on site information from cameras and AI based detection. This type of communications is time critical and has stringent requirements regarding latency, throughput and reliability. We present experimental performance results which pinpoint that 5G networking infrastructures and AI pre-processing can lead to enhanced road safety by fulfilling the associated requirements.

title: Enhancing Appliance Classification in NILM by Power-Theoretic Color-Coding V-I Trajectory Visualization
authors: Fanju Meng, Zile Feng, Lingxia Lu, Zhejing Bao, Miao Yu
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper presents a power-theoretic color-encoding method for visualizing voltage-current (V-I) trajectories in Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring (NILM). Based on Fryze's power decomposition, the approach encodes electrical characteristics into RGB images that distinguish enclosed and boundary-connected regions. These images, combined with a compact ResNet18 classifier, enable accurate load identification. Experiments conducted on the PLAID dataset demonstrate a classification accuracy of 97.71%, with strong visual interpretability and significantly reduced model complexity. These results highlight the effectiveness of embedding physical semantics into input representations, offering a lightweight solution for appliance classification in NILM systems.

title: An Investigation of Data Augmentation for Image Classification Network Based on Graph Convolution
authors: Ryusei Mikami, Koshi Watanabe, Keisuke Maeda, Takahiro Ogawa, Miki Haseyama
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Vision GNN (ViG) is a convolutional architecture capable of capturing global image structures by dynamically determining the features to be convolved via graph convolution. Although ViG has been proposed as an alternative to CNNs and Vision Transformers (ViTs), it has not yet demonstrated a clear performance advantage over these architectures. This paper empirically investigates the impact of existing data augmentation methods on ViG. The results reveal that ViG exhibits different behavior compared to a representative CNN, ResNet, under various augmentation techniques.

title: Low-Power and Accurate IoT Monitoring Under Radio Resource Constraint
authors: Takaho Shimokasa, Hiroyuki Yomo, Federico Chiariotti, Junya Shiraishi, Petar Popovski
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper investigates how to achieve both low-power operations of sensor nodes and accurate state estimation using Kalman filter for internet of things (IoT) monitoring employing wireless sensor networks under radio resource constraint. We consider two policies used by the base station to collect observations from the sensor nodes: (i) an oblivious policy, based on statistics of the observations, and (ii) a decentralized policy, based on autonomous decision of each sensor based on its instantaneous observation. This work introduces a wake-up receiver and wake-up signaling to both policies to improve the energy efficiency of the sensor nodes. The decentralized policy designed with random access prioritizes transmissions of instantaneous observations that are highly likely to contribute to the improvement of state estimation. Our numerical results show that the decentralized policy improves the accuracy of the estimation in comparison to the oblivious policy under the constraint on the radio resource and consumed energy when the correlation between the processes observed by the sensor nodes is low. We also clarify the degree of correlation in which the superiority of two policies changes.

title: Multi-Dimensional Maturity Framework for Consumer ECG Devices
authors: Nina Pearl Doe, Kurt J. G. Schmailzl, Florian Rokohl, Marc Reichenbach, Christian Herglotz
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: The influx of smart consumer devices equipped with sensors and high computational capabilities has enabled various important health monitoring applications to be placed in the hands of the consumer. This evolution is potentially transforming the healthcare delivery practice, which is still mainly located in clinical environments. This paper investigates comprehensively electrocardiogram (ECG) vital sign monitoring technologies in consumer medical devices with the goal of assessing and analyzing the maturity of the hardware. The analysis is focused on the evaluation of 12 consumer ECG devices from four manufacturers. We define five maturity dimensions (Technical, Validation, Regulatory, Market, and Clinical Integration) with corresponding scoring scale of 1-5. Based on information gathered from an extensive literature review, we evaluate the scores for each dimension for all considered devices. Based on these scores, we perform a detailed statistical analysis and identify development pathways: Technical-Led, Regulatory-Led, and Market-Driven approaches.

title: Research on APIOBPCS Closed-loop Supply Chain Based on Distributed Predictive Control under Data-Driven
authors: Haifeng Guo, Weize Sun
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: This paper establishes a multi-level closed-loop supply chain model based on the APIOBPCS strategy for a forward logistics system-comprising a single supplier, manufacturer, and retailer-and incorporating returns and remanufacturing. The model is formulated via differential equations. A data-driven distributed predictive control algorithm is then designed, and its general implementation steps are detailed. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed control strategy effectively regulates inventory levels toward their targets and significantly mitigates the bullwhip effect.

title: Online Optimization of Pickup and Delivery Problems Considering Traffic Congestion Prediction
authors: Soma Nakagawa, Koichi Kobayashi, Yuh Yamashita
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: In this paper, online optimization of the pickup and delivery problem is studied. In particular, we focus on incorporating traffic congestion prediction. First, the target area is modeled by a set of graphs. Next, constraints and cost functions are introduced. Then, the pickup and delivery problem is rewritten as a mixed integer linear programming problem. Finally, we provide numerical examples about congestion scenarios with the incorporation of traffic congestion prediction.

title: Design an AI-Assisted PC Building Interface to Promote User Understanding Through Guided Assembly and Monitoring
authors: Yu-Lin Liao, Hsiao-Yue Tsao
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study proposes an intelligent graphical interface to assist users in assembling personal computers with greater clarity and confidence. This system integrates compatibility checks, configuration suggestions, and real-time monitoring via digital twin technology. Users can input their computing needs, such as gaming, content creation, or AI, then receive AI-generated suggestions that match their performance and budget expectations. Through interactive visualization and AI analysis, this interface helps users avoid issues such as hardware mismatches. After assembly, the system continues to support users by visualizing real-time data to maintain stability and performance. This research aims to lower the barrier to PC building, enhance hardware literacy, and demonstrate how AI and digital twins can improve personal computing experiences.

title: Estimating Subjective Intelligibility of Deaf and Hard-of-Hearing Speech with Neural Networks
authors: Akio Kobayashi, Keiichi Yasu
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Frictionless speech communication between individuals with normal hearing and those who are deaf or hard of hearing (DHH) requires not only ensuring accessibility for DHH speakers but also addressing the challenges that hearing listeners face due to reduced speech intelligibility. Accurately estimating the intelligibility of DHH speech is therefore valuable for the development of assistive technologies. In this study, we collected subjective intelligibility ratings for speech produced by DHH individuals with varying articulatory abilities. Neural networks were then trained using MFCC and HuBERT features to predict these ratings. Notably, the HuBERT-based models achieved accurate predictions across utterances from a diverse set of DHH speakers, highlighting their potential for assistive applications such as voice conversion.

title: Electric-thermal long-term behavior of compression connections with transmission line conductors at realistic outdoor conditions
authors: Christian Hildmann, Markus Gödicke, Stephan Schlegel, Maria Kosse, Jérémy Unterfinger
publish: 2025 IEEE 70th Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts (HLM)
abstract: Current-carrying compression connections, among other applications widely used to join transmission line conductors, are important components that fulfill crucial functions in an overhead line. In practical application, electric-thermal, mechanical and ambient loads act on the connections and influence their long-term behavior depending on the initial joint resistance. Recently, thermal irregularities of current-carrying connections are increasingly diagnosed especially for high-utilized overhead lines. In particular, the interaction of relevant aging mechanisms and deterioration mechanisms that accelerate reaching the end of lifetime is still not fully understood. In order to determine factors that can limit the service life of compression connections, long-term tests for several thousand hours were carried out under realistic outdoor operating conditions. Electric-thermal and mechanical loads were therefore applied to the tested connections. The resistance behavior and the thermal operating behavior of typical compression fittings were evaluated. It was found that mechanical tensile loads can deteriorate compression connections, especially if they were made with service-aged transmission line conductors. Connections made with the same connectors and brand-new conductors were not affected. Hence, the paper summarizes the results and the found correlations for unstable thermal operating behavior of compression connections and presents some recommendations for practice, diagnosing and testing.

title: Semisupervised High-Order Graph Diffusion Network for Cross-Domain Fault Diagnosis of Rotating Machinery_supp1-3638241.pdf
authors: Jiande Wu
publish: N/A
abstract: In recent years, the superiority of graph neural networks (GNNs) in the aspect of relational modeling has been confirmed in rotating machinery fault diagnosis field. However, most GNNs based intelligent diagnostic methods struggle to construct high-precision and low-complexity graph and perform poorly without efficient graph update strategies. To solve these problems, a semisupervised high-order graph diffusion network (SHGDN) for cross domain fault diagnosis is proposed in this study. First, the discriminative subsequences called Shapelets are sufficiently extracted by diffusion model. Thereafter, fast dynamic time warping and sparse strategy are leveraged to construct dynamic graph with semantic perception ability. Second, a high-order graph diffusion network based on approximate personalized propagation of neural predictions is put forward, which can implement dual-stream aggregation modeling for local first-order neighbors and global high-order neighbors. Then, the pseudolabel guided dynamic graph optimization and Leiden algorithm-based subgraph exchange enhancement is developed to reduce the cumulative propagation of pseudolabel errors. Finally, the explicit theoretical connection between graph construction and graph update is established, which can break the limitation of parameter isolation and provide a unified framework for model optimization. The proposed method is demonstrated on datasets from three types, and the experimental results indicate the SHGDN achieves the average accuracy of 97.29<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\%$</tex-math></inline-formula>, surpassing other state-of-the-art methods.

title: DuaDiff: Dual-Conditional Diffusion Model for Guided Thermal Image Super-Resolution_supp1-3640168.pdf
authors: Gaochang Wu
publish: N/A
abstract: Thermal imaging offers valuable properties, but suffers from inherently low spatial resolution, which can be enhanced using a high-resolution (HR) visible image as guidance. However, the substantial modality differences between thermal and visible images, coupled with significant resolution gaps, pose challenges to existing guided super-resolution (SR) approaches. In this article, we present dual-conditional diffusion (DuaDiff), an innovative diffusion model featuring a dual-conditioning mechanism to enhance guided thermal image SR. Unlike typical conditional diffusion models, DuaDiff integrates a learnable Laplacian pyramid to extract high-frequency details from the visible image, serving as one of the conditioning inputs. By capturing multiscale high-frequency components, DuaDiff effectively focuses on intricate textures and edges in the HR visible images, significantly enhancing thermal image fidelity. Furthermore, we project both thermal and visible images into a semantic latent space, constructing another conditioning input. Leveraging these complementary conditions, DuaDiff employs a multimodal latent feature cross-attention module to facilitate effective interaction between noise, thermal, and visible latent representations. Extensive experiments on the FLIR-ADAS and CATS datasets for <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$4\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$8\times $</tex-math> </inline-formula> guided SR demonstrate that combining learnable Laplacian conditioning with semantic latent conditioning enables DuaDiff to surpass state-of-the-art methods in both visual quality and metric evaluation, particularly in scenarios with a large resolution gap. Besides, the applications to downstream tasks further confirm the capability of DuaDiff to recover high-fidelity semantic information. The code will be released.

title: Hardware Trojan Object Detection Based on Bidirectional Graph Neural Networks
authors: Dong Cheng, Xuanwei Lin, Chen Don, Ximeng Liu, Kun Guo, Yirui Huang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computers
abstract: The rapid growth of Internet of Things (IoT) devices has heightened hardware security concerns, particularly with the emergence of hardware Trojans (HTs) as malicious components in integrated circuits. These HTs pose significant threats to information privacy and system performance. The early detection methods rely on golden references and domain knowledge, limiting their implementation in large-scale integrated circuits. Traditional machine learning-based HT detections can effectively identify infected circuits without golden chips. However, locating and evaluating the specific behavior of HTs in vast and complex circuits is challenging. To address these challenges, this paper presents an HT Object Detection (HTOD) problem, which involves two primary tasks: identifying the boundaries and sizes of HTs within circuits and distinguishing between different HT behaviors. We have developed a two-stage HT object detection framework based on a bidirectional jumping knowledge network called HTOD-BGNN to solve the HTOD problem, which enables progressive refinement of localized regions. It incorporates enhanced base-type features to ensure scalability and information retention during modeling. Additionally, the implementation of sample augmentation alleviates the challenges of sample imbalance and scarcity. The proposed method enables more intelligent circuit detection, achieving 100% and 87.5% detection rates for Trojan triggering and payload behaviors, respectively. It demonstrates superior localization performance and effective generalization to unseen circuit scenarios via its region refinement mechanism, achieving F1-scores of 54.01% on TrustHub and 90.04% on TRIT datasets.

title: Community-Aware Multi-View Representation Learning With Incomplete Information
authors: Haobin Li, Yijie Lin, Peng Hu, Mouxing Yang, Xi Peng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Due to the complexity of data collection in the real world, Multi-view Representation Learning (MvRL) always encounters the incomplete information challenge, typically manifested as the Sample-missing Problem (SP) and the View-unaligned Problem (VP). Although several methods have been proposed, they fail to find a good trade-off among sample restoration, view alignment, and data diversity preservation. To address this issue, we take and mathematically formulate two sociological concepts for MvRL, i.e., community commonality and community versatility, where the former refers to the identical custom shared within the same community, and the latter refers to the similar but non-identical custom within communities of the same minority. One could find that the community commonality can enhance the compactness of view-specific clusters, and the community versatility can preserve the view diversity. Moreover, combining both of them could facilitate achieving robust MvRL with incomplete information. With the formulations, we propose a novel method dubbed Community-Aware Multi-viEw RepresentAtion learning with incomplete information (CAMERA). In brief, CAMERA employs a novel dual-stream network and an elaborate objective function that theoretically and empirically embraces community commonality and versatility. Extensive experimental results on seven datasets demonstrate that CAMERA remarkably outperforms 24 competitive multi-view learning methods on clustering, classification, and human action recognition tasks.

title: Lightweight AI-Driven Model for Phishing Detection with Hash-Augmented Feature Embeddings
authors: Akshat Gaurav, Brij B Gupta, Jinsong Wu, Varsha Arya, Kwok Tai Chui
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper proposes a lightweight AI-driven model for phishing detection based on a hybrid embedding architecture. The model integrates standard embeddings for categorical features with a hash-augmented embedding mechanism for continuous features, enabling efficient representation with reduced computational overhead. Experimental results demonstrate a high detection accuracy of 95%, along with strong precision and recall scores. Compared to traditional models, the proposed approach achieves up to 81% fewer trainable parameters while maintaining superior convergence and classification performance, making it highly suitable for real-time and resource-constrained cybersecurity environments.

title: Small Obstacle-Aware Person-Following for Mobile Robots Using Vision-Based Segmentation
authors: Jiahao Sim, Yoshinobu Hagiwara, Yongwoon Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study presents a novel person-following system for mobile robots equipped with a small obstacle avoidance mechanism. The system integrates Grounding DINO for open-vocabulary object detection and SAM 2 for pixel-level segmentation to detect travelable regions and small obstacles that are typically undetectable by conventional 2D LiDAR sensors. By projecting non-travelable regions into 2D point clouds and incorporating them into path planning, the robot achieves robust navigation while maintaining continuous visual tracking of the target individual. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly improves the success rate of person-following tasks in environments containing small obstacles, outperforming conventional 2D LiDAR-based systems.

title: Cost-Efficient Wideband Beam Training: A 3D Controllable Beam Squint Approach
authors: Ruihuan Wang, Qimei Chen, Yongcheng Li, Qipeng Zheng, Dingzhu Wen, Muhammad Kaleem Awan
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: The widely adopted extremely large-scale multiple-input multiple-output (XL-MIMO) wideband systems are fundamentally constrained by their two-dimensional planar coverage, primarily due to the conventional use of uniform linear arrays (ULAs). This limitation significantly degrades the quality of service in practical three-dimensional (3D) deployment scenarios. Furthermore, XL-MIMO wideband systems inherently suffer from severe beam squint effects caused by non-negligible signal propagation delays, and the narrow beamwidth results in substantial beam training overhead. To address these challenges, we propose a novel cost-efficient frequency-dependent beamforming framework capable of supporting 3D spatially distributed users by leveraging a full-dimensional uniform planar array (UPA) architecture. Based on this design, we introduce a controllable 3D beam squint scheme via a partially-connected time-delay network, alongside a low-dimensional user-centric spatial-frequency scanning codebook to enable rapid and robust beam training. Numerical results demonstrate that the proposed scheme achieves accurate 3D angle estimation with significantly reduced training overhead during the initial access phase. Additionally, the proposed method can maintain high angle estimation accuracy in poor channel conditions.

title: Optimization of H264 and 5G QoS parameters for a multi-agent live video streaming service
authors: J.-C. Sibel, A. Bechihi
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper formulates an optimization problem to extract the best QoS parameters as well as the best H264 parameters embodied by the video bitrates in a context of a near real-time multi-agent system deployed within a public network. The principle is to interface H264 with the 5G QoS to construct measurable objective functions in terms of the latency and in terms of the rendering quality that reflect the requirements of an end-user using the said multi-agent system. Once the optimization problem is built, we make it a linear optimization problem that allows for many solvers, e.g., the simplex algorithm. Through numerical evaluations, we show examples of combined QoS requests for the multi-agent system that ensure the video streaming service to well operate regarding the end-user requirements.

title: Improving Motion Classification in Electric Prosthetics with Feature Selection and Piezoelectric Wire Sensors
authors: Yuki Hamada, Yuhi Asanuma, Jun Inoue
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: The development of prosthetic hands for upperlimb amputees aims to improve quality of life. Despite advancements, rejection rates of current prosthetic hands remain high, emphasizing the need for prosthetic hands that better meet user requirements. We aim to develop an electric prosthesis suitable for long-term use and resistant to factors, such as perspiration. This design will depend on muscle vibrations (MVs) measured using a piezoelectric wire sensor, which is easy to install, non-invasive, lightweight, and robust. Previously, we classified six movements using MVs, achieving an average classification accuracy exceeded 90%. However, the model required 35 training datasets and 1000 ms of data length, rendering data collection time-consuming and reducing responsiveness. Reducing training datasets and shortening the data length led to a significant drop in average motion classification accuracy, falling below 65%. To address this, we applied Shapley additive explanations (SHAP) for feature selection method, improving motion classification accuracy under reduced datasets and shorter data lengths. With two training datasets and a data length of 300 ms, the average motion classification accuracy reached 87.4%. Furthermore, we optimized model parameters to improve the minimum classification accuracy. This approach reduces data collection demands and improves the responsiveness of motion classification using MVs.

title: 3D Gaussian Splatting With Semantic Information Based on Semantic Class Labels
authors: Masaya Takabe, Taiju Watanabe, Hiroshi Watanabe
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: 3D Gaussian Splatting has recently emerged as a promising method for real-time 3D reconstruction. However, it does not leverage semantic information, limiting its utility in tasks such as editing and segmentation. We propose an efficient approach that incorporates semantic class labels directly into each 3D Gaussian by learning from segmentation results. This reduces memory and training time compared to prior methods relying on high-dimensional feature maps. Experiments show that our method maintains competitive rendering and segmentation performance while greatly reducing computational complexity.

title: Improving Speech-to-Speech Translation with Word-Level Data Augmentation
authors: Rui Zhou, Takashi Nose, Akinori Ito
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: End-to-end speech-to-speech translation (S2ST) suffers from data scarcity, often leading to out-of-vocabulary (OOV) issues that limit performance. We propose a simple word-level data augmentation strategy that constructs synthetic speech-unit pairs using frequent bilingual word pairs, avoiding the variability and alignment errors of sentence-level synthesis. Evaluated on the CVSS-C French–English dataset, our method improves BLEU by over 3 points compared to a Transformer baseline. While effective under moderate-resource conditions, it remains limited in extremely low-resource settings due to insufficient semantic learning. This highlights the need for future work on context-aware or semantic-level augmentation.

title: A4FN: an Agentic AI Architecture for Autonomous Flying Networks
authors: André Coelho, Pedro Ribeiro, Helder Fontes, Rui Campos
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This position paper presents A4FN, an Agentic Artificial Intelligence (AI) architecture for intent-driven automation in Flying Networks (FNs) using Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) as access nodes. A4FN leverages Generative AI and Large Language Models (LLMs) to enable real-time, context-aware network control via a distributed agentic system. It comprises two components: the Perception Agent (PA), which semantically interprets multimodal input – including imagery, audio, and telemetry data – from UAV-mounted sensors to derive Service Level Specifications (SLSs); and the Decision-and-Action Agent (DAA), which reconfigures the network based on inferred intents. A4FN embodies key properties of Agentic AI, including autonomy, goal-driven reasoning, and continuous perception-action cycles. Designed for mission-critical, infrastructure-limited scenarios such as disaster response, it supports adaptive reconfiguration, dynamic resource management, and interoperability with emerging wireless technologies. The paper details the A4FN architecture, its core innovations, and open research challenges in multi-agent coordination and Agentic AI integration in next-generation FNs.

title: Gentle Object Retraction in Dense Clutter Using Multimodal Force Sensing and Imitation Learning_supp1-3643332.mp4
authors: Dane Brouwer
publish: N/A
abstract: Dense collections of movable objects are common in everyday spaces-from cabinets in a home to shelves in a warehouse. Safely retracting objects from such collections is difficult for robots, yet people do it frequently, leveraging learned experience in tandem with vision and non-prehensile tactile sensing on the sides and backs of their hands and arms. We investigate the role of contact force sensing for training robots to gently reach into constrained clutter and extract objects. The available sensing modalities are (1) “eye-in-hand” vision, (2) proprioception, (3) non-prehensile triaxial tactile sensing, (4) contact wrenches estimated from joint torques, and (5) a measure of object acquisition obtained by monitoring the vacuum line of a suction cup. We use imitation learning to train policies from a set of demonstrations on randomly generated scenes, then conduct an ablation study of wrench and tactile information. We evaluate each policy's performance across 40 unseen environment configurations. Policies employing any force sensing show fewer excessive force failures, an increased overall success rate, and faster completion times. The best performance is achieved using both tactile and wrench information, producing an 80% improvement above the baseline without force information.

title: VEHFSL: Hybrid Federated Split Learning for Resource-Constrained Vehicular Networks
authors: Changsheng Li, Zichao Zhao, Haixia Zhang, Dongfeng Yuan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
abstract: Collaborative machine learning has been a key technology to enhance the development of intelligent transportation systems with the advantage of privacy protection and communication efficiency. However, model training on vehicles requires a large amount of computation resource especially that the machine learning (ML) models are massive nowadays. In this paper, we shed light on the situation that a part of the vehicles may have low computational capability and not able to participate in the training process. To address this problem, we propose a Vehicular Edge Hybrid Federated Split Learning (VEHFSL) paradigm considering the data privacy protection and resource constraints in Internet of Vehicles (IoV). Firstly, we select the vehicles to participate in the training process by sorting the weighted sum of the expected sojourn time and training data volume of each vehicle. Then, we formulate a joint optimization problem to minimize the training latency of one round by jointly optimizing the training mode selection, computation frequency and transmit power allocation. Given that the formulated optimization problem is mixed-integer nonlinear programming (MINLP), which is typically NP-hard, we design a joint mode selection and resource allocation algorithm (JMSRA) by performing block coordinate descent (BCD) technique to decompose it into three sub-problems and iteratively solving them to achieve a near-optimal solution efficiently with the balance of the computational complexity and optimality of the solution. Finally, extensive simulations are performed to validate the superiority of our proposed VEHFSL paradigm in resource-constrained vehicular networks.

title: Efficient Transformed Gaussian Process State-Space Models for Non-Stationary High-Dimensional Dynamical Systems
authors: Zhidi Lin, Ying Li, Feng Yin, Juan Maroñas, Alexandre H. Thiéry
publish: IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing
abstract: Gaussian process state-space models (GPSSMs) offer a principled framework for learning and inference in nonlinear dynamical systems with uncertainty quantification. However, existing GPSSMs are limited by the use of multiple independent stationary Gaussian processes (GPs), leading to prohibitive computational and parametric complexity in high-dimensional settings and restricted modeling capacity for nonstationary dynamics. To address these challenges, we propose an efficient transformed Gaussian process state-space model (ETG-PSSM) for scalable and flexible modeling of high-dimensional, non-stationary dynamical systems. Specifically, our ETGPSSM integrates a single shared GP with input-dependent normalizing flows, yielding an expressive non-stationary implicit process prior that can capture complex transition dynamics while significantly reducing model complexity. For the inference of the implicit process, we develop a variational inference algorithm that jointly approximates the posterior over the underlying GP and the neural network parameters defining the normalizing flows. To avoid explicit variational parameterization of the latent states, we further incorporate the ensemble Kalman filter (EnKF) into the variational framework, enabling accurate and efficient state estimation. Extensive empirical evaluations on synthetic and real-world datasets demonstrate the superior performance of our ETGPSSM in system dynamics learning, high-dimensional state estimation, and time-series forecasting, outperforming existing GPSSMs and neural network-based SSMs in terms of computational efficiency and accuracy.

title: Cascaded Neural Network-based Assessment of Voltage Stability Margin in a Renewable-rich Indian Power System
authors: Karuppasamy Anthony, Venkadesan Arunachalam
publish: IEEE Transactions on Artificial Intelligence
abstract: Voltage stability is critical in managing power systems with significant use of renewable power. As wind and solar energy adoption increases, precise estimation of voltage stability margins becomes increasingly crucial. This paper proposes a novel approach to predict voltage stability margins (VSM) in wind and solar-integrated real-time practical grid systems using a cascaded neural network (CNN), one of the machine learning (ML) models. The CNN method provides a computationally less complex NN model with the required accuracy to predict the VSM under diverse operating conditions in renewable-rich systems, which forms a major contribution of the paper. The performance of the CNN is compared against a Multilayer feedforward neural network and other ML techniques, with testing conducted on the Indian utility's 62-bus system. The proposed method offers an effective operational tool for system operators to monitor and maintain voltage stability in environments with high renewable energy penetration.
