title: Challenges and Opportunities in Signal Processing for Radar-Based Vital Sign Monitoring in Home Care Scenarios: A Scoping Review
authors: Mario Henao-Rosero, Víctor Quintero
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Colombian BioCAS Workshop
abstract: Continuous monitoring of vital signs with radars has become a topic of interest in recent years because of its contactless nature, and because privacy is preserved during measurement. To be categorized as a Passive Mode Interaction system applied to Ambient Assisted Living environments, a radar-based vital signs measurement system needs to deal with scenarios where multiple moving users perform daily activities in the presence of clutter. In this document, a literature mapping focused on describing the signal processing techniques required to deal with such scenarios is developed. Studies from IEEE Xplore, ScienceDirect, Web of Science, and Scopus databases were obtained, and a final set of 31 documents that met the inclusion criteria were analyzed. A maximum of three users in the experimental setup were found within the analyzed studies, and only in three of them body orientation was considered besides motion. Finally, a signal processing chain is proposed for scenarios with multiple moving users, and further research opportunities within each chain step are listed.

title: A Probabilistic Diffusion Framework for Detecting Academic Stress-Induced Abnormalities in ECG Signals
authors: Weimar A. Arenas-Gonzalez, Hernan F. Garcia, Alejandro Hernández-Arango
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Colombian BioCAS Workshop
abstract: Academic stress exerts measurable physiological effects that can be captured noninvasively using wearable electrocardiogram (ECG) sensors. However, existing stress-detection methods rely heavily on supervised learning with annotated labels, which are costly to obtain and often fail to generalize to real-world academic settings. In this work, we propose a fully unsupervised diffusion-probabilistic framework for detecting stress-induced anomalies in ECG recordings. Our approach trains a score-based U-Net model exclusively on resting-state cardiac beats, learning to approximate the gradient of the log density of noisy ECG samples under a forward Itô diffusion process. At inference, we compute beat-level anomaly scores via time-integrated score residuals and employ one-class support vector machines and isolation forests to flag outliers without any stress annotations. We evaluate the pipeline on data from twenty undergraduate students during resting and mock exam sessions. Beat-level detection achieves AUCs of 0.563 (one-class SVM) and 0.521 (isolation forest), while segment-level aggregation over 30second windows improves discrimination to AUCs of 0.528 and 0.556, respectively. Subject-level shifts in mean anomaly scores (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta A_{s}$</tex>) correlate significantly with self-reported stress (Escala de Estresores Académicos), confirming the framework's sensitivity to individual physiological responses. UMAP visualizations of the U-Net bottleneck features reveal a compact resting manifold distinct from stress embeddings, highlighting the model's capacity to internalize baseline morphology and detect deviations. These results validate the potential of diffusion-probabilistic score modeling for continuous, personalized stress monitoring in academic environments.

title: A Convolutional Vision Transformer with Channel Attention for Multi-Class Alzheimer's Disease Classification Using MRI
authors: Mario Alejandro Bravo-Ortiz, Sergio Alejandro Holguín-García, Ernesto Guevara-Navarro, Luis Miguel Cardona-Perez, Rafael Medina-López, Isabel Sofia Benitez Duque, Reinel Tabares-Soto, Gonzalo A. Ruz
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Colombian BioCAS Workshop
abstract: Alzheimer's disease is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder and the primary cause of dementia globally. Early and accurate diagnosis is essential for improving patient outcomes. This paper proposes a novel deep learning architecture that integrates a Convolutional Vision Transformer with Squeeze-and-Excitation blocks to classify different stages of Alzheimer's disease from MRI images. Unlike prior studies, which often merge moderate and mild dementia classes, this work evaluates the model in binary, three-class (excluding the minority class), and full four-class settings. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed model achieves an accuracy of 99.36 %, outperforming or matching state-of-the-art approaches even without data balancing. These results underscore the potential of combining attention mechanisms with transformer-based architectures for enhancing automated AD diagnosis and provide a promising step toward more clinically robust solutions.

title: Positioning Error Bound Analysis for Wireless System Using Bidirectional Leaky Coaxial Cable
authors: Yafei Hou, Ziying Ji, Junjie Zhu, Satoshi Denno
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Leaky CoaXial (LCX) cable is a line-shaped cable used as antenna for wireless system. Due to its stable and uniform radiation characteristics with changeable shape, LCX cable is largely used for wireless coverage over many linear-cell environments such as shopping mall, tunnel, underground mall or walkway etc. These scenarios usually require location-aware services for many applications. We have investigated many localization methods for wireless system using the proposed bidirectional LCX. The bidirectional LCX can be used as two antennas by input the signal from both sides of the cable. We have investigated the theoretical positioning error bound (PEB) of the conventional LCX. However, for bidirectional LCX, its theoretical PEB and the advantage over conventional LCX are still unknown. This paper will analyze the PEB property and compare it with the conventional LCX usage based on the LCX channel model developed from the Geometrically-Based Single-Bounce (GBSB) model. We give a brief Fisher Information analysis for wireless system using bidirectional LCX-based localization. Then the impact of different LCX configurations on the PEB is evaluated through the Cramér-Rao lower bound.

title: Time-Domain Sound Field Estimation Using 3D-CNN for Sound Field Reproduction*
authors: Koki Horikoshi, Gen Sato, Izumi Tsunokuni, Yusuke Ikeda
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Sound field reproduction requires measurements using multiple microphones, which is difficult to implement due to physical constraints and cost challenges. Recently, deep learning-based methods have been proposed to reproduce sound fields by estimating them at specific frequencies from a limited number of measurement points. In this study, we propose a time-domain sound field estimation method using a 3D-convolutional neural network with the aim of reproducing wideband sound fields such as music and speech. Through simulation experiments, we evaluate the accuracy of sound field estimation and the accuracy of the reproduced sound field using the proposed time-domain model.

title: Integrated Web Based Augmented Reality (AR) and AI for Immersive Booking Experience
authors: Chandan Prakash, M Akshatha, B H Anil Kumar, B S Lakshmi, P Ashwini
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: As artificial intelligence (AI) and augmented reality (AR) hold significant potential to transform various sectors, such as e-commerce, tourism, and hospitality and event Industry. This study examines how web-based AR and AI can be integrated to create a more engaging and user-friendly booking experience. AR enables users to visualize products and spaces in real-time, while AI personalizes the booking process by analyzing user preferences. Traditional booking platforms often depend on static images and text descriptions, which can lead to uncertainty when making decisions. By merging AI-driven personalization with real-time AR visualization, this research suggests a framework that enables users to explore accommodations, event venues, and travel destinations interactively before finalizing their reservations. Imagine being able to dive into an immersive experience straight from your web browser—no app downloads, no compatibility issues, just instant access. That’s exactly what web-based AR offers. It makes things simpler for users while opening up exciting new opportunities for businesses. Instead of static images or generic descriptions, customers can interact with lifelike previews of hotels, event spaces, or travel destinations before making a booking. AI-powered recommendation systems take personalization to the next level by learning from user preferences, past searches, and browsing habits to suggest options that genuinely match their interests. And when customers have questions or need guidance, AI-driven chatbots step in, providing real-time assistance to make the booking process smooth and hassle-free.

title: Low-Complexity Determination of Downlink Timing Offset and Doppler Shift in LEO Satellite Channels
authors: Muhammad Nabeel, Thomas Wagner, Rainer Bachl, Naveed Iqbal, Zhibin Yu, Xiaofeng Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Low earth orbit (LEO) satellites periodically broadcast ephemeris data that describes satellite position and orbit. A ground user equipment (UE) utilizes the ephemeris data using an orbit propagator model, and combines it with its own position information to determine downlink timing offset and Doppler shift at any given time. In this work, first we analytically show that relying upon even the simplest orbit propagator model, i.e., Two Body Keplerian, the process involves huge computational complexity when applied over the entire duration that the satellite is connected to the UE. To reduce the computational overhead, we then propose to decrease the number of data points computed using the orbit propagator model. This is achieved by introducing two low-complexity interpolation methods. The first method exploits polynomial based non-linear sliding interpolation. Whereas, the second method uses a unique set of finite impulse response (FIR) polyphase filter coefficients that are computed and stored offline at the UE. We show that proposed methods reduce the computational complexity more than 8 times when compared to the baseline approach without compromising the required performance, hence, making them feasible to realize in the UE.

title: A Parallel System Framework and Practice for the Magnetic Levitation Rotary Machinery
authors: Honglei Sha, Zhen Shen, Yuqi Sun, Yuxin Ren
publish: 2025 21st IEEE International Conference on Mechatronic and Embedded Systems and Applications (MESA)
abstract: In this paper we discuss future development trends of magnetic levitation rotating machinery, and propose that its development directions will mainly focus on digitalization, intelligence, and high efficiency. As a core component, magnetic levitation bearings provide a foundation for the disruptive transformation of rotating machinery by eliminating mechanical friction and integrating self-perception and control capabilities. Parallel systems theory forms the theoretical basis for the digital and intelligent transformation of magnetic levitation rotating machinery, enabling continuous improvement across its full life cycle — from design and manufacturing to testing, operation, and maintenance. In the design phase, magnetic levitation rotating machinery needs to achieve integrated modeling and digital inheritance of design experience. In the manufacturing phase, virtual simulation and quality control become key elements. In the testing phase, virtual testing technology will enhance efficiency and accuracy. In the operation and maintenance phase, predictive maintenance, intelligent optimization, and process adaptability emerge as core requirements. The digital system of magnetic levitation rotating machinery consists of physical equipment, digital devices, parallel data, and parallel control systems, with capabilities of self-perception, self-learning, self-evolution, and self-scheduling. In the future, magnetic levitation rotating machinery will gradually realize multi-level digital capabilities from basic functions to cluster intelligence, promoting the optimization and collaboration of equipment in process systems. In particular, a study is conducted with the example of predictive maintenance for backup bearings during the operation and maintenance phase.

title: Risk Analysis of Vehicle Rollover Accidents Caused by Wind Using Digital Twin Technology
authors: Keisuke Takada, Hideki Yaginuma, Shintaro Terabe
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In recent years, traffic regulations have been implemented to ensure safety due to the frequent occurrence of extreme weather events. However, weather-related regulations are based on past experience, resulting in accidents due to delays and traffic congestion due to excessive regulations. In this study, we focus on wind-induced vehicle rollovers in urban spaces and identify wind directions and speeds that have a high risk of causing vehicle rollovers. Specifically, we utilize the 3D urban model PLATEAU and perform efficient wind simulations using PINNs, a neural network-based physics calculation method, to clarify the risk of vehicle rollover under various scenarios.

title: Mobility Enhancements in 3GPP: Toward Rel-20 and Beyond
authors: Evren Tuna, Aydanur Kayalar, Murat Faruk Aydin, Huseyin Arslan
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Mobility management remains a cornerstone of network evolution, yet ever-tighter latency and reliability targets, heterogeneous deployments, and AI-driven network intelligence demand continual refinement of handover mechanisms. Tracking and understanding recent developments in mobility management is essential to support the integrated, intelligent, and ubiquitous connectivity envisioned for 6G networks. This paper delivers a 3GPP-centric review of progressive mobility enhancements from Rel-15 through Rel-20 and offers insight into the emerging roadmap for 5G-Advanced and early 6G networks. After summarizing baseline measurement procedures and event-triggered reporting, we analyze three principal handover paradigms—Baseline Handover, Conditional Handover, and the recent Lower-Layer Triggered Mobility—highlighting their respective trade-offs in signaling overhead, interruption time, and robustness. We then examine how AI/ML techniques are positioned within 3GPP to predict optimal handover parameters, adapt to dynamic radio conditions, and reduce failure rates. The paper synthesizes Rel-20 hot topics, including mobility enhancements and AI/ML-based mobility use cases, and distills key contributions from 6G standardization meetings. By aligning ongoing 3GPP efforts with performance goals, this work highlights key challenges and outlines directions for future standardization beyond Rel-20.

title: Construction and Validation of a Slip Ring Test Bench Using 50 Years of Data
authors: Grant G. Justice, Patrick K. Bowen
publish: 2025 IEEE 70th Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts (HLM)
abstract: Design and validation of a modernized slip ring test bench at Deringer-Ney Inc. was performed, enabling simultaneous measurement of electrical noise, contact resistance, wear rate, and friction under controlled conditions. Validation against 1970s archival data confirmed reliable replication of historical performance metrics using Neyoro G and Neyoro 28A alloy rings and Paliney 7 brushes, while extended testing successfully captured cyclical variations in electrical performance closely correlated with environmental humidity. Interrupted rotation testing revealed significant stick-slip phenomena with load variations up to 20%, and optimization determined 100 kHz as the ideal sampling rate for characterizing electrical noise. The system establishes a foundation for comprehensive characterization of sliding electrical contacts while providing new insights into the complex interplay between mechanical wear, environmental factors, and electrical performance.

title: Clutter Suppression in Bistatic ISAC with Joint Angle and Doppler Estimation
authors: M. Ertug Pihtili, Julia Equi, Ossi Kaltiokallio, Jukka Talvitie, Elena Simona Lohan, Ertugrul Basar, Mikko Valkama
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: The coexistence of radar and communications in wireless systems marks a paradigm shift for the sixth-generation (6G) networks. As 6G systems are expected to operate at higher frequencies and employ larger antenna arrays than fifth-generation (5G) systems, they can also enable more accurate sensing capabilities. To this end, the integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) paradigm aims to unify the physical and radio frequency (RF) domains by introducing the sensing functionality into the communication network. However, the clutter poses a challenge, as it can significantly degrade the sensing accuracy in ISAC systems. This paper presents a novel two-dimensional root multiple signal classification (2D-rootMUSIC)-based algorithm for static background clutter suppression. Computer simulation results indicate that the proposed method effectively mitigates the strong background clutter, yields accurate parameter estimation performance, and offers a notable improvement in the signal-to-clutter-and-noise ratio (SCNR), while outperforming the prior-art benchmark methods.

title: Efficient Dynamic Beamforming Activation for UAV-Enabled Vehicular Networks
authors: Leonardo Spampinato, Lorenzo Mario Amorosa, Marco Skocaj, Greta Vallero, Daniela Renga, Chiara Buratti
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Unmanned aerial base stations (UABSs) are a promising solution for improving coverage and capacity in vehicle-to-everything (V2X) communications, particularly in dense urban areas. However, their operation is constrained by onboard energy consumption, required for both flight and communication. Beamforming, while enhancing network performance, adds to this challenge due to its energy-intensive nature.This paper proposes a sequential and hierarchical decision-making framework for UABS operations, considering trajectory planning, dynamic beamforming, and radio resource assignment (RRA). While heuristic and optimal solutions are employed for trajectory planning and RRA respectively, the beamforming model is modeled as Markov decision process (MDP) to maximize served user demand, weighted by time-varying priorities, under strict energy constraints. Leveraging a dueling double deep q-network (3DQN) algorithm that penalizes energy budget violations, an agent policy for the beamformer is then trained. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms static beamforming benchmarks and closely matches an ideal step-wise oracle, achieving a balance between energy efficiency and served user demand while adapting to dynamic V2X traffic conditions.

title: Subspace Aware Multi-Target Detection and Parameter Estimation for Hybrid MIMO Based ISAC
authors: Baran Kırdar, Gökhan M. Güvensen
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Accurate signal detection in wireless communication systems is heavily influenced by temporal and spatial channel variations, particularly in the presence of angular spread and Doppler effects. These challenges necessitate advanced signal processing strategies to achieve robust channel estimation. This paper presents an Angular and Doppler Spread Aware Orthogonal Matching Pursuit (OMP) algorithm tailored for Integrated Sensing and Communication (ISAC) systems. By employing basis decomposition in the angular domain and directly modeling Doppler-induced phase variations, the proposed method efficiently estimates channel coefficients while addressing the complexities introduced by channel dynamics. The approach improves the reliability of both sensing and communication functionalities, offering a more seamless integration of these tasks within ISAC frameworks.

title: Application of Principal Component Analysis in Hyperspectral Analysis of Rubber Materials
authors: Kentaro Oishi, Ren Togo, Takahiro Ogawa, Miki Haseyama
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper presents a method for quantitatively evaluating spectral differences obtained from rubber materials. Spectra of rubber reflect their chemical structure, and obtaining a detailed understanding of these spectra is crucial for material development. Since hyperspectral imaging (HSI) provides a spectrum for each pixel, a large amount of spectral data can be obtained from a single measurement compared to conventional spectroscopic analysis. We use HSI to quantitatively evaluate differences in chemical structure between samples by a statistical method. Specifically, we perform dimensionality reduction with principal component analysis (PCA) to deal with the high dimensional data. After reducing the pixel level spectra to two dimensions, we quantify the differences between samples by comparing their distributions in the latent space. Our method realizes quantitative evaluation of the differences between rubber samples exposed to different conditions.

title: Sentiment and User-interaction Analysis on YouTube Comments of Trending Videos Using DistilBERT and TF-IDF
authors: Yuanyong Yu, Wataru Kameyama
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper analyzes the impact of sentiment polarity and resonant words in YouTube comments on user interactions such as likes and replies. We classify comments using a fine-tuned DistilBERT model and examine the interaction patterns through resonant words identified by the Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) algorithm. Our findings reveal that while sentiment polarity alone has limited predictive power, resonant words strongly correlate with higher user interaction.

title: Comparative Study of Gradient-Based Massive MIMO Linear Detection Algorithms
authors: Lin Li, Jianhao Hu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: In the development of next-generation wireless systems, massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) is widely recognized as a key enabler. Although minimum mean square error (MMSE) detection delivers ideal performance, its implementation is often prohibitively complex due to the significant computational resources required. To address the matrix inversion involved, gradient-based detection algorithms have been widely studied. Through theoretical discussion and simulation results, this paper undertakes a comparative analysis of the steepest descent algorithm (SD), conjugate gradient algorithm (CG), Barzilai-Borwein algorithm (BB) and Broyden-Fletcher-Goldfarb-Shannon algorithm (BFGS), focusing on their detection performance and computational demands. Furthermore, under the condition of an acceptable increase in complexity, a hybrid SDBB-BFGS detection algorithm with significantly improved performance is proposed.

title: CYPHONIC Adapter Enhancement for Supporting Multiple General Nodes
authors: Mitsuki Sugihara, Ren Goto, Michiyo Suda, Hidekazu Suzuki, Ayano Naito
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper presents an enhanced architecture of the CYber PHysical Overlay Network over Internet Communication (CYPHONIC) adapter, a gateway system that enables unmodifiable or resource-constrained IoT devices to participate in secure overlay network communication. The original CYPHONIC adapter assumes a one-to-one mapping between a general node and an adapter, which limits scalability in real-world IoT environments where multiple devices are often colocated. To address this limitation, the proposed system extends the signaling protocol to allow the CYPHONIC cloud to configure and manage general node metadata, thereby eliminating the need for adapter-side configuration. In addition, the system introduces a structured data model to maintain the state and session information of multiple general nodes concurrently. To support parallel processing, the communication engine adopts a multithreaded design, assigning independent worker threads to handle each node’s traffic. Experimental evaluations confirm that the enhanced adapter achieves stable throughput and moderate resource usage under concurrent node communication. These enhancements significantly improve the scalability, flexibility, and practicality of CYPHONIC in heterogeneous IoT deployments without requiring modifications to the end devices.

title: Integrated Navigation and Communication: OFDM-MIMO Signal Frame Design with NOMA and Adaptive Power Allocation
authors: Yiming Ma, Chao Zhang, Jian Song
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper presents a novel integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) system based on multiple input multiple output (MIMO) and orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) technologies with a non-orthogonal signal design that refines spectrum efficiency. Inspired by non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) scheme, we superimpose pseudo-random noise (PN) sequences and OFDM symbols in the power domain to enable simultaneous decimeter-level ranging and broadband communication over shared spectrum. A genetic algorithm optimizes power allocation to jointly achieve high-precision ranging and data throughput in the proposed frame. MIMO-based spatial processing can support high performance joint ranging and data detection. Experimental results demonstrate that the ranging precision of better than 1% of the actual distance and the data rate of over 1 Mbps can be achieved at a 6km distance under the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) below -8dB, which confirm the system’s dual functionality and compatibility with legacy OFDM, offering a new direction for future integrated networks.

title: STAMP-NET: A Spatio-Temporal Attention Network with Multi-Modal Price Integration for Electric Vehicle Charging Load Forecasting
authors: Chao Mei, Ming Chen, Jiangbing Mao, Wenliang Liu
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: The increasing adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) presents significant challenges for power grid management, necessitating accurate forecasting of charging station loads. Accurate multi-step prediction of EV charging demand is crucial for efficient grid operation, resource allocation, and maintaining stability. However, this task is complex due to the inherent spatiotemporal dependencies of charging behavior across different locations and times, as well as the influence of external factors like dynamic electricity pricing. This paper introduces STAMP-Net (Spatio-Temporal Attention Network with Multi-modal Price Integration), a novel deep learning architecture specifically designed for precise, multi-step EV charging load forecasting. STAMPNet uniquely integrates historical load data with corresponding historical price information to enhance prediction accuracy over multiple future time horizons (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3}, 6$</tex>, and 12 steps). The model architecture employs a sequence of specialized layers, including feature embedding, 2D positional encoding to capture spatial and temporal contexts, a node-wise cross-attention mechanism to effectively fuse load and price information, a time-wise spatial self-attention layer to model inter-station dependencies, and a Temporal Convolutional Network (TCN) to capture long-range temporal patterns. Using the past 12 time steps of load and price data as input, STAMP-Net predicts future load profiles. The model's effectiveness is evaluated using standard metrics (MAE, RMSE, MAPE) on benchmark datasets, demonstrating its capability to accurately forecast charging loads at various future horizons. By effectively capturing complex spatio-temporal dependencies and integrating multi-modal price data through tailored attention mechanisms, STAMP-Net offers a promising approach for improving the reliability and accuracy of EV charging load forecasts, contributing to more robust grid management and planning in the era of electrified transportation.

title: Distributed Beamforming with Incomplete Channel State Information in MISO Networks via GNNs
authors: Lorenzo Mario Amorosa, Tony Chahoud, Zhan Gao, Roberto Verdone, Deniz Gündüz
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Beamforming is a crucial component in modern large-scale multiple-input single-output (MISO) wireless networks. However, its practical deployment is often constrained by the incomplete channel state information (CSI) and the overhead associated with centralized optimization methods, such as the weighted minimum mean-square error (WMMSE) algorithm. In this work, we propose the problem of distributed beamforming with varying degrees of CSI incompleteness and develop a graph neural network (GNN)-based approach, which enables transmitters to collaboratively optimize their beamforming strategies using only local and partial CSI. Our approach combines imitation learning with unsupervised learning for model training, where the former provides a warm start and the latter allows for superior performance beyond the "expert" strategy, while leveraging the GNN for a distributed implementation. We evaluate the proposed approach using ray tracing-based simulations in both indoor and outdoor scenarios, demonstrating that it outperforms WMMSE, particularly in environments with noisy or incomplete CSI. These results highlight the potential of our GNN-based solution for scalable, robust, and distributed beamforming strategies in future wireless networks.

title: Hyperparameter Tuning of LSTM Load Forecasting Model Based on Segmented Bayesian Optimization
authors: Junjie Xu, Yu Feng, MD Alauddin, Wenmin Fan
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: As a key link in power system operation and planning, the prediction accuracy of power load forecasting is directly related to the economy, security and power supply reliability of power grid operation. Aiming at the low efficiency of hyperparameter tuning of current load forecasting model, this paper proposes a hyperparameter tuning of LSTM load forecasting model based on segmented Bayesian optimization. The method takes the category of hyperparameters as the segmentation condition on the basis of LSTM model, which is divided into the first segment of network structure parameter tuning and the second segment of training parameter tuning, which mainly involves the number of neurons, Dropout ratio, initial learning rate, batch size, and L2 regularization parameter, and carries out the hyperparameter tuning comparison experiments under different dimensions. The experimental results show that the training speed of the piecewise Bayesian optimization method is shortened by 35.7<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">%</sup>, 35.3%, and 65.9% respectively compared with random search in the optimization of 3, 4, and 5-dimensional hyperparameters. Compared with the traditional Bayesian optimization method, the acceleration ratio is increased by 34.2%, 36.9%, and 61.6% respectively. However, the accuracy remains basically unchanged. When the dimension is increased from four to five, the training time of random search increases by 100.1 %, that of the traditional Bayesian optimization method increases by 72.6%, while that of the piecewise Bayesian optimization method only increases by 5%, achieving a balance between accuracy and speed in high-dimensional parameter optimization.

title: Measurement of Arc Flash Incident Energy in Low-Voltage Three-Phase Panels Using an Optical Calorimeter
authors: Fernanda Cristina Salvador Soares, Márcio Bottaro, Josemir Coelho Santos, Luis Eduardo Caires, Paulo Futoshi Obase, Rogério Masaro
publish: 2025 IEEE ESW Brazil – Electrical Safety Workshop Brazil (ESW Brazil)
abstract: Calculating incident energy is essential for assessing the risk to which professionals involved in the operation and maintenance of electrical installations are exposed, allowing the definition of appropriate control measures and aiming at protecting workers, preserving the environment and ensuring the operational continuity of the system. The IEEE 1584 Standard is a calculation guide globally adopted by the industry for arc-flash hazard calculations and uses an empirical model updated in 2018. It was developed based on approximately 1860 tests, covering open-air and enclosed configurations, performed with different parameters, such as: operating voltage, fault currents, fault clearing time, working distances and conductor’s gap. During the IEEE 1584 development process, incident energy measurements were performed using calorimeters such as those specified in ASTM F1959, consisting of copper discs instrumented with an inserted thermocouple wire sensor. However, thermocouple-based measurements are susceptible to electromagnetic noise, requiring mathematical signal filtering techniques that may affect accuracy. ASTM F1959 allows the use of alternative calorimeters provided they are calibrated and have a similar response to the calorimeter with a thermocouple sensor. This study proposes the use of an optical calorimeter for measuring the incident energy of electric arcs produced in a three-phase panel in IEEE 1584 VCBB configuration. The calorimeter is equipped with an optical sensor and a thermocouple for simultaneous assessment of measuring systems. The results show that calorimeters with optical sensors demonstrates key advantages as immunity to electromagnetic noise and faster response times. It was evidenced that incident energy measured is higher when compared to that measured with the thermocouple sensor. These findings suggest that the choice of sensor technology can significantly impact the calculated incident energy and, consequently, influence the specification of protective measures in electrical systems, especially given that IEEE 1584 equations are based on data derived from thermocouple measurements.

title: Vulnerability Analysis for Explosion and Fire Scenarios in Power Transformers
authors: Edmilson José de Castro, Camila Cunha Toledo Guerald, Marcos Ferreira Lopes Júnior, Thallis Henrique Felipe, Raphael Alasia
publish: 2025 IEEE ESW Brazil – Electrical Safety Workshop Brazil (ESW Brazil)
abstract: Power transformers are essential equipment in any electrical installation for the transportation or distribution of electricity, whether in systems with power plants associated with transmission systems, or in large industrial installations.Transformers adapt voltage levels to the different points in the system, enabling efficient and safe transportation of electricity. A feature of power transformers is the use of liquid insulating fluid, which has two main functions: to maintain the temperature at adequate levels for operation and to guarantee the electrical insulation of its components.The point to watch out for is that this fluid has a fire point temperature that is not very high, and in the event of some failures can cause loss of tank integrity, where an explosion or fire scenario can occur. If this type of event occurs, the consequences can be catastrophic depending on the transformer’s operating context.

title: Independent Low-Rank Matrix Analysis for Fast Joint Blind Source Extraction and Dereverberation in Diffuse Noise Environments
authors: Shuo Feng, Liyuan Zhang, Shoji Makino
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper addresses a blind source extraction (BSE) problem in reverberant and diffuse noise environments. Although traditional Diffuse-Noise-Aware Independent Low-Rank Matrix Analysis (NoisyILRMA) achieves efficient extraction in diffuse noise scenarios, the performance degrades in reverberant environments. To address this limitation, we propose NoisyILRMA-conv, which extends NoisyILRMA by integrating a Weighted Prediction Error dereverberation module under a unified optimization scheme. Our proposed method enables joint source extraction and dereverberation while maintaining the computational efficiency of NoisyILRMA.

title: An Efficient Blended Staggered Double Vane Slow Wave Structure for 1 THz TWT
authors: Patibandla Anilkumar, Shaomeng Wang, Atif Jameel, Bilawal Ali, Jibran Latif, Muhammad Khawar Nadeem, Tasir Ullah, Yubin Gong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices
abstract: This article presents a novel blended staggered double vane slow wave structure (BSDV-SWS) for a 0.98–1.1THz frequency traveling-wave tube (TWT). The proposed structure is designed to overcome key limitations at terahertz frequencies by enhancing electric field distribution for improved interaction efficiency, simplifying fabrication through the elimination of sharp edges that cause field singularities, and reducing RF losses. Dispersion and transmission analyses confirm minimal reflection and strong energy transfer. Beam–wave interaction provides 1.155 W output power, 25.85dB gain, and 0.25% electronic efficiency when 25.7kV beam voltage and 18.2mA beam current is applied using CST Studio Suite. The close alignment between the measured S-parameters of the nano-computer numerical control (CNC)-fabricated device and the simulated performance confirms the practical feasibility of the proposed design.

title: A rapid temperature rise testing scheme and device for low-voltage switchgear
authors: Bin Xiang, Hu Xiong, Jiayuan Li, Xiaoguang Jiang, Zhixiong Liu, Jiarui Yang
publish: IEEE Instrumentation & Measurement Magazine
abstract: Low-voltage switchgear is widely used in power distribution networks. The temperature rise test for switchgear is a critical step in verifying the safety and reliability of electrical equipment [1]. This test ensures safe operation: when current flows through the switchgear, heat is generated. Poor heat dissipation design or excessive contact resistance in components may lead to overheating during long-term operation, potentially causing accidents due to insulation aging, contact burnout, or short-circuit faults. Excessive temperature may also trigger partial discharge or thermal runaway, leading to cascading failures. For example, excessive temperature rise at cable joints may cause insulation breakdown, affecting the stability of the entire power distribution system [2][3][4][5]. Currently, during material procurement, China State Grid mandates temperature rise testing for low-voltage switchgear.

title: Smart camera-based real-time 2D arm gesture detection: A fuzzy logic and CNN approach
authors: Boulbaba Guedri, Naji Guedri, Rached Gharbi
publish: IEEE Instrumentation & Measurement Magazine
abstract: In today's technological era, natural remote control of devices is essential for effortless system management from a distance. However, many current solutions are complex and require advanced skills, limiting user accessibility. This study presents Smart Camera Two (SCT), an advanced system enabling precise real-time recognition of upward and downward arm gestures on both arms, with a minimum angular resolution of 15°. SCT allows seamless control of connected devices anytime, anywhere, enhancing operational flexibility. The system uses a camera facing the user to capture simple arm movements, enabling intuitive interaction without technical expertise. This natural gesture control streamlines tasks and significantly reduces completion times. Real-time data acquisition facilitates prompt decision-making and adaptive system monitoring, boosting productivity. SCT achieves an overall accuracy of 99.937%, with low latency and robustness against lighting changes and occlusions. It combines two versions: SCT-O employing Fuzzy Logic (F<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Lo</inf>) and SCT-T based on convolutional neural networks (CNNs), each suited to different project needs. This article presents a detailed comparative analysis of both versions, supported by extensive experiments validating their performance. Extensive experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the versions. The video can be found here: https://sites.google.com/view/smart-camera-two-sct/accueil.

title: Practical evaluation of the time drift of measurement standards in calibration laboratory
authors: Oleh Velychko, Tetyana Gordiyenko, Sergii Kursin
publish: IEEE Instrumentation & Measurement Magazine
abstract: According to the international standard ISO/IEC 17025, a calibration laboratory (CL) must take into account the change in the characteristics of the standards used to ensure the reliability of the calibration results. The CLs must monitor the stability and change in the characteristics of the standards over time, in particular the drift of their readings. Changes in these readings should be taken into account when evaluation the measurement uncertainty of during calibration. Determining the long-term drift of standards, which characterizes the change in the nominal value of a standard over time, is important for obtaining accurate and reliable results in precision measurements. The most common statistical method used to determine such drift is regression. With its help, it is possible to predict the values according to a certain time trend (drift), which can be estimated based on the regression line. The results of the evaluation of long-term drifts of precision capacitance standards using polynomial approximation are presented. Various control charts are used to monitor the long-term drift of standards in a real calibration data set. The exponentially weighted moving average (EWMA) chart can be applied to absolute data, not just relative data, as in Cumulative sum (CUSUM) charts. The EWMA chart uses an exponentially weighted moving average derived from a time series of data that has a cumulative value. All received data contributes to the result, but the contribution factor decreases when calculating the next period of the EWMA chart. Such a chart can be used to capture small deviations of average values over time, which allows you to obtain and analyze the long-term drift of standards. The results of the long-term drift assessment of capacitance standards using EWMA are shown. Accredited CLs should always include the component of the total measurement uncertainty due to standard drift in their calibration uncertainty budgets. Failure to do so may result in an underestimation of the calibration uncertainty. A procedure for predicting the future value and uncertainty during calibration, taking into account the real drift of the standard used, is proposed. Examples of predicting the of standard values taking into account the drift component of the total standard uncertainty are presented. Interpretation of the results regarding the prediction of future calibration results was carried out using special software “DDrift 1.0”, for which appropriate verification and validation were carried out. The predicted values of the standards were simulated using the Monte Carlo method for 3<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">rd</sup> order polynomial regression. Those values obtained using software “DDrift v.1.0” differ slightly from the modulated data using the Monte Carlo method, but are within the established confidence interval.

title: Improved Knowledge Distillation Based on Global Latent Workspace With Multimodal Knowledge Fusion for Understanding Topological Guidance on Wearable Sensor Data
authors: Jinyung Hong, Eun Som Jeon, Matthew P. Buman, Pavan Turaga, Theodore P. Pavlic
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: Wearable sensors have found numerous applications in health and wellness promotion and have achieved great success leveraging advancements in deep learning. However, the development of robust continues to be hindered by issues related to sensor noise, inconsistent sampling rates, and individual differences. Topological data analysis (TDA) has emerged as a viable solution to extract robust features from such time-series data by converting them into persistence images (PIs), which capture intrinsic characteristics and demonstrate resilience to noise and signal variations. However, the computational costs of TDA pose significant challenges for small devices with limited resources. To more efficiently incorporate topological features, we utilize knowledge distillation (KD), which is a promising way to generate a smaller model using larger models. Multiple teachers can be adopted to enrich features in KD. However, this approach has presented two key challenges: 1) differences in feature dimensions from multimodal data and 2) conflicting knowledge provided by the different teachers, both of which can degrade the student model’s performance. To address these issues, we propose a novel KD framework called multimodal global latent workspace-based KD (mGLW-KD) that is motivated by global workspace theory (GTW) from cognitive neuroscience. GWT models how the brain integrates and distributes relevant information across different neural modules through a shared workspace, and it includes attentional control and working memory to prioritize and retain key information. Inspired by this theory, mGLW-KD incorporates a working memory module to unify diverse knowledge from multiple teacher models into a shared latent workspace, facilitating efficient knowledge transfer to the student model. By integrating topological insights with cognitive principles, mGLW-KD addresses the challenges posed by wearable sensor data and enables the student model to achieve superior performance using only time-series input during inference.

title: Parameter-Optimal Adaptive Layer Mapping: A Transferability-Guided View for Cross-Domain Fault Diagnosis
authors: Yansong Zhang, Xianfeng Yuan, Xinxin Yao, Jianjie Liu, Bao Pang, Yong Song, Xiaoru Niu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Cross-domain fault diagnosis based on unsupervised domain adaptation has gained much attention. However, current methods face key challenges due to the limited consideration of transferability. Specifically, they primarily align fault features exclusively within identical-depth layers in the diagnostic model, assuming that these features share same transferability, leading to feature dislocation and reduced diagnostic accuracy. In reality, fault features with similar transferability often emerge across distinct-depth layers, especially under complex conditions where fault signal spectral characteristics shift significantly. Moreover, conventional methods usually treat all parameters with uniform transferability, failing to distinguish domain-specific fault features from transferable ones. This indiscriminate treatment risks negative transfer and poor diagnosis ability under diverse conditions. To address these limitations, a novel parameter-optimal adaptive layer mapping network (ParALM) guided by transferability is proposed. ParALM establishes inter-layer mapping pairs to capture distinct-level fault features across layers, aligning signal characteristics that vary with conditions. In parallel, ParALM adaptively categorizes model parameters into transfer-wise and transfer-limited ones, updating only the former to selectively preserve transferable diagnostic information. Comprehensive experiments on a dataset and a real-world diagnostic system demonstrate that ParALM outperforms state-of-the-art methods. ParALM yields diagnostic performance improvements of 2.89% and 1.99% over the best-performing competitor on two cases (p < 0.05), while exhibiting the lowest standard deviations of 1.13% and 1.22%, which verifies its superiority and stability.

title: A Foundation Model for Massive MIMO Precoding with an Adaptive Per-User Rate-Power Tradeoff
authors: Jérôme Emery, Ali Hasanzadeh Karkan, Jean-François Frigon, François Leduc-Primeau
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Deep learning (DL) has emerged as a solution for precoding in massive multiple-input multiple-output (mMIMO) systems due to its capacity to learn the characteristics of the propagation environment. However, training such a model requires high-quality, local datasets at the deployment site, which are often difficult to collect. We propose a transformer-based foundation model for mMIMO precoding that seeks to minimize the energy consumption of the transmitter while dynamically adapting to per-user rate requirements. At equal energy consumption, zero-shot deployment of the proposed foundation model significantly outperforms zero forcing, and approaches weighted minimum mean squared error performance with 8× less complexity. To address model adaptation in data-scarce settings, we introduce a data augmentation method that finds training samples similar to the target distribution by computing the cosine similarity between the outputs of the pre-trained feature extractor. Our work enables the implementation of DL-based solutions in practice by addressing challenges of data availability and training complexity. Moreover, the ability to dynamically configure per-user rate requirements can be leveraged by higher level resource allocation and scheduling algorithms for greater control over energy efficiency, spectral efficiency and fairness.

title: GMIML: Graph Multi-Instance Multi-Label Learning
authors: Yijun Duan, Xin Liu, Steven Lynden, Akiyoshi Matono, Qiang Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In this study, we discuss for the first time a novel and widely applicable weakly-supervised graph learning task: Graph Multi-Instance Multi-Label Learning (GMIML). We explore the definition and key challenges of GMIML, as well as its potential applications in the domain of large language models. We further propose a preliminary cascaded model and evaluate its performance on standard benchmark datasets.

title: Modular Interface Design for a Dual-Role sEMG Platform: A Usability-Oriented Study
authors: Wang-Yu Lee, Min-Yun Liou, Yi-Mo Lin, Chun-Chun Wei, Yang-Cheng Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study presents a modular sEMG interface prototype designed to support dual-role collaboration between caregivers and family members in rehabilitation settings. The platform integrates role-specific modules for health assessment, visual feedback, and task engagement, aiming to enhance user comprehension and participation. A preliminary user study (N=10) was conducted using the SUS and PSSUQ questionnaires. Results showed high usability, clarity, and acceptance across both user groups, supporting the system’s feasibility for user-centered co-care applications. Future development will incorporate real-time sEMG classification via deep learning. The modular design enables flexible adaptation across care settings and supports role-specific user interaction.

title: Dynamic Real-time Learning of Electromagnetic Interference Parameters for Drone Crashing Attack
authors: Yasser El-Alfy, Ehab Al-Shaer, Uthman Baroudi, Umar Johar
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Drones are increasingly used in mission-critical environments such as border surveillance, military logistics, and infrastructure inspection. However, their flexibility also introduces cybersecurity risks, as adversaries can exploit them for malicious purposes. A promising defense technique involves using electromagnetic interference to selectively neutralize rogue drones—provided their communication parameters can be precisely identified.In this work, we propose a reinforcement learning agent based on Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO) to autonomously identify the frequency–power pair susceptible to interference for an unknown drone-controller system. The agent operates in a large search space, guided by an environment modeled with dynamic hot zones. It is designed to minimize probing steps and energy consumption, making it suitable for time- and resource-constrained defensive scenarios. Experimental results in a simulated environment show that the agent achieves 90% accuracy in identifying effective jamming parameters, demonstrating its potential as a real-time, adaptive cybersecurity countermeasure for drone-based threats.

title: Harmonizing Flexibility and Intelligence: RIS-Aided Flexible Intelligent Metasurface Systems
authors: Hosein Zarini, S. Mohsen Kazemi, Mehdi Sookhak, Ali Ghrayeb, Marco Di Renzo
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Composed of an array of low-cost radiating elements, flexible intelligent metasurfaces (FIMs) can adaptively morph their surface shapes by adjusting the positions of elements along the direction perpendicular to the surface. This adaptive morphing, not only enhances wireless channel conditions, but also significantly curtails power consumption. This paper conducts an adaptive performance analysis of a wireless system, in which a FIM-equipped base station (BS) leverages the presence of a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) to facilitate downlink transmission. To rigorously evaluate the system’s efficiency, we formulate an optimization problem centered on resource allocation, with the primary objective of maximizing the network achievable data rate. This maximization is subject to multiple constraints, especially on stringent quality-of-service (QoS) requirements of users and the BS finite power budget. Due to the highly intricate interdependencies among optimization variables and the inherent non-convexity of the problem, we strategically reformulate it as a Markov decision process (MDP), encapsulating its dynamic characteristics. To derive an optimal solution, we train a deep deterministic policy gradient (DDPG) agent, relying on MDP, which simultaneously optimizes the decision variables: the BS transmit beamforming, the morphology of the FIM and the reflection coefficient matrix of the RIS. Furthermore, to accommodate the real-world challenges imposed by user mobility, we enhance the generalization of the DDPG model through the integration of meta-learning technique, thereby significantly improving its adaptability to system variations. Numerical evaluations affirm that incorporating an RIS yields a pronounced improvement in achievable network data rate, particularly when the BS transmit power budget is maintained within a moderate operational range.

title: Effects of Surface Texture and Grasping Force of a Myoelectric Prosthetic Hand on Others
authors: Takumi Nagai, Taro Shibanoki
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a myoelectric prosthetic hand with flexible surface texture, aiming to realize a human-like prosthetic hand. The proposed prosthetic hand is equipped with a pseudo-skin made of a plastic bag filled with liquid in the palm portion. A Peltier element and a temperature sensor are also installed to control the surface temperature. In addition, pressure sensors are attached to the fingertips to adjust the gripping force. By controlling the joint angle of the fingers, an appropriate gripping force for the person can be achieved. The effects of changing the palm temperature and gripping force on others were evaluated through experiments.

title: Suggestion of Pseudo-3D Video Learning Materials Using MR Technology and Omnidirectional Camera
authors: Kaoru Mitsuhashi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: When learning sports or occupational movements, three-dimensional (3D) video resources, which allow observation of movements from all directions, are essential for understanding the actions of learners and instructors. However, the creation of 3D videos predominantly relies on computer graphics (CG) animation generated through motion capture, which typically requires specialized technical expertise. This research proposes a pseudo-3D video teaching material viewable on smartphones, created by capturing the subject from multiple directions using several omnidirectional cameras and stitching the videos together using Mixed Reality (MR) technology. As these pseudo-3D video materials can be viewed from a full 360-degree perspective, they enable focused observation of specific body movements that are crucial for understanding. Subsequently, this research will investigate the improvement in learning comprehension achieved through the use of these pseudo-3D video materials for sports and occupational movements.

title: Data Market Sustainability: An Agent-Based Simulation of Trust and Resale
authors: Jun Sashihara, Teruaki Hayashi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Data marketplaces enable exchange and monetization of data, but balancing price efficiency and partner reliability remains challenging. We develop an agent-based simulation that explicitly captures data’s non-rivalrous resale and dynamic trust among trading agents. Buyers and sellers interact over Barabási–Albert, Watts–Strogatz, and Erdős–Rényi networks, employing three strategies: Price (minimize cost), Trust (maximize reputation), and Hybrid (trust filter then lowest price). Price-only agents quickly exhaust low-cost supply, collapsing transactions; Trust-only agents concentrate demand, inflating prices, and excluding budget-sensitive buyers. Hybrid agents sustain volume and stabilize prices by balancing cost and reputation. Our findings suggest that combining trust-based selection with price optimization fosters a resilient, efficient data marketplace, guiding the design of future data-exchange platforms.

title: A Study on Improving the Accuracy of Person Identification by Using Learning Methods
authors: Rynosuke Tanaka, Tomio Goto
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Person identification is used in a variety of locations, and improving its performance is an important issue. In this study, we proposed a person identification system using YOLO, an object recognition algorithm, and improved its performance.

title: Development and Initial Evaluation of a Food Intake Ratio Estimation System for Welfare Facilities
authors: Kazuyuki Kaned, Kanta Yamaguchi, Yuji Teshima, Osamu Shiku, Tadahiro Nanri
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: To alleviate the burden of monitoring dietary intake in welfare facilities, this paper proposes an automatic dietary intake ratio estimation system using machine learning and image processing. First, we identified individual IDs by scanning 2D barcodes placed on meal trays. Next, to evaluate the dietary intake ratio for each individual, we estimated the leftover food regions on the meal trays using segmentation techniques. Furthermore, to improve usability, we developed a user interface to confirm acquired images and dietary intake ratios. Initial evaluations showed that although minor errors existed, the dietary intake ratios estimated by this system were generally consistent with visual assessments.

title: Failure Tolerant Phase-Only Indoor Positioning via Deep Learning
authors: Fatih Ayten, Mehmet C. Ilter, Akshay Jain, Ossi Kaltiokallio, Jukka Talvitie, Elena Simona Lohan, Henk Wymeersch, Mikko Valkama
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: High-Precision localization turns into a crucial added value and asset for next-generation wireless systems. Carrier phase positioning (CPP) enables sub-meter to centimeter-level accuracy and is gaining interest in 5G-Advanced standardization. While CPP typically complements time-of-arrival (ToA) measurements, recent literature has introduced a phase-only positioning approach in a distributed antenna/MIMO system context with minimal bandwidth requirements, using deep learning (DL) when operating under ideal hardware assumptions. In more practical scenarios, however, antenna failures can largely degrade the performance. In this paper, we address the challenging phase-only positioning task, and propose a new DL-based localization approach harnessing the so-called hyperbola intersection principle, clearly outperforming the previous methods. Additionally, we consider and propose a processing and learning mechanism that is robust to antenna element failures. Our results show that the proposed DL model achieves robust and accurate positioning despite antenna impairments, demonstrating the viability of data-driven, impairment-tolerant phase-only positioning mechanisms. Comprehensive set of numerical results demonstrates large improvements in localization accuracy against the prior art methods.

title: Movable Antenna Aided ISAC with Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access: Joint Power Allocation, Beamforming and Antenna Position Design
authors: Wanting Lyu, Baojuan Liu, Yue Xiu, Zhongpei Zhang, Jiahe Guo, Chadi Assi, Chau Yuen
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper investigates a movable antenna (MA)-aided integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) system using non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA). A base station (BS) configured with a two-dimensional MA array simultaneously serves multiple communication users and sensing multiple targets. To enhance system capacity, superimposed symbols are transmitted to communication users, with successive interference cancellation (SIC) employed for signal decoding. Our objective is to maximize the total illumination power at the targets while satisfying the minimum signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) requirements for communication users. To achieve this goal, we propose an alternating optimization (AO)-based algorithm that jointly optimizes the transmit power allocation, beamforming, sensing covariance matrix, and antenna positions. Numerical results show that the MA system achieves significant improvement in illumination power compared to fixed-position antennas (FPAs), with particularly significant gains under high SINR requirements.

title: Embedded AI for WiFi Sensing of Surface Hotness
authors: Yirui Deng, Wanqiu Ding, Jiacheng Zhu, Ziyang Wang, Deepak Mishra, Aruna Seneviratne
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: With the rapid growth of Lithium-ion (Li-ion) battery usage in modern lifestyles, the increasing risk of fire hazards demands practical temperature monitoring techniques that are massively deployable. The goal of this work is to explore the use of wireless sensing in conjunction with Artificial Intelligence (AI) to enable the detection of the surface temperature of a target object. Our framework for detecting the target surface temperature based on the channel state information (CSI) of WiFi signals utilises a low-complexity classifier algorithm, specifically the linear support vector machine. With a prototype constructed with commodity embedded systems, we experimentally validated the feasibility of our proposed framework for detecting surface temperature levels with more than 93% accuracy at a resolution of 2°C. In addition, we evaluated the robustness of our embedded AI-based WiFI sensing technology. We identified that accuracy is subject to degradation with deployment conditions such as over-range, imbalanced positioning, and inadequate transmit power. Overall, with adequate accuracy, our WiFi CSI-based surface temperature detection framework provides a low-cost, massively deployable, and non-invasive solution for practical temperature surveillance applications involving heat-sensitive products.

title: Service Continuity in Mobile Non-Terrestrial Networks under Line-of-Sight Loss
authors: Marius Corici, Fabian Eichhorn, Eric Troudt, Hauke Buhr, Thomas Magedanz
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: To enable seamless 5G service continuity for mobile ground users traversing infrastructure-limited or obstructed regions, the integration of Non-Terrestrial Networks based on Low Earth Orbit satellite constellations is being actively pursued. However, the mobility dynamics of ground terminals frequently result in sudden Line-of-Sight loss, which undermines the feasibility of conventional handover preparation involving context transfer, synchronization, and identity continuity. Without pre-coordination, such transitions lead to uplink blindness, session interruption, and degraded performance. This paper addresses the handover problem under Non-Terrestrial Network-specific constraints by (i) defining a structured taxonomy of service continuity mechanisms suited for impaired Line-of-Sight conditions, (ii) introducing an analytical model that captures handover delay, authentication feasibility, and buffer dimensioning under varying visibility regimes, and (iii) quantitatively evaluating these mechanisms in a high-mobility highway scenario. The results underline that while context mirroring ensures superior continuity under full coordination, handover with reactive preparation emerges as the most practical and resilient fallback under constrained Non-Terrestrial-Networks conditions.

title: Benchmarking Vector, Graph and Hybrid Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) Pipelines for Open Radio Access Networks (ORAN)
authors: Sarat Ahmad, Zeinab Nezami, Maryam Hafeez, Syed Ali Raza Zaidi
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Generative AI (GenAI) is expected to play a pivotal role in enabling autonomous optimization in future wireless networks. Within the ORAN architecture, Large Language Models (LLMs) can be specialized to generate xApps and rApps by leveraging specifications and API definitions from the RAN Intelligent Controller (RIC) platform. However, fine-tuning base LLMs for telecom-specific tasks remains expensive and resource-intensive. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) offers a practical alternative through in-context learning, enabling domain adaptation without full retraining. While traditional RAG systems rely on vector-based retrieval, emerging variants such as GraphRAG and Hybrid GraphRAG incorporate knowledge graphs or dual retrieval strategies to support multi-hop reasoning and improve factual grounding. Despite their promise, these methods lack systematic, metric-driven evaluations, particularly in high-stakes domains such as ORAN. In this study, we conduct a comparative evaluation of Vector RAG, GraphRAG, and Hybrid GraphRAG using ORAN specifications. We assess performance across varying question complexities using established generation metrics: faithfulness, answer relevance, context relevance, and factual correctness. Results show that both GraphRAG and Hybrid GraphRAG outperform traditional RAG. Hybrid GraphRAG improves factual correctness by 8%, while GraphRAG improves context relevance by 11%.

title: Prototype of Coffee Maker Considering User Experience and Skilled Barista Movements
authors: Yuuki Nakamura, Kazuyuki Kojima
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: As global coffee consumption continues to increase, a new trend known as the third wave of coffee has emerged. This trend emphasizes not only the origin and quality of coffee beans but also the enjoyment of the brewing process itself. Consequently, there has been a rise in coffee shops that focus on providing an immersive brewing experience. In recent years, barista robots have been developed to replicate this experience, however, these robots are typically large and designed for installation in commercial or public spaces. To address this gap, this study proposes the development of a compact, barista-style coffee maker designed for home use, enabling users to enjoy the coffee brewing process in a domestic setting.

title: Energy Landscape Analysis for Road Congestion Dynamics
authors: Kaibin Huang, Hideki Yaginuma, Shintaro Terabe
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study proposes an interpretable framework for analysing urban expressway congestion dynamics using energy landscape analysis based on a pairwise maximum-entropy (Ising) model. Probe-vehicle speed data are binarised, with each road section represented as a spin variable. Model parameters are estimated via exact likelihood maximisation, and the resulting energy landscape captures both probabilistic and interaction structures. We evaluate model performance using two metrics and confirm its robustness across settings. The model not only reproduces the static distribution of traffic states and captures the main asymmetric transitions between metastable states, but also highlights potential transitions not observed empirically, offering enhanced explanatory power that may inform future traffic management strategies.

title: An Enhanced Lightweight Framework with Selective Kernel and Attention for FER using Modified Bottleneck
authors: Shahzad Ali, Pisit Vanichchanunt, Charnchai Pluempitiwiriyawej, Kosuke Takano, Naveed Sultan, Ratchatin Chancharoen, Lunchakorn Wuttisittikulkij
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: Facial Expression Recognition (FER) plays an important role in enabling machines to interpret human emotions. While recent advances have led to high-performing models and many of these remain too computationally demanding for use on resource-limited devices. In this work, we introduce a compact yet effective FER model based on modified inverted residual blocks, augmented with two well known key modules: the Coordinate Attention (CA) for enhance spatial attention by encoding directional relationships across facial regions and a depthwise convolution-based Selective Kernel (SK) module for dynamically adjusts receptive fields by selecting from multiple kernel sizes. We have evaluated on the RAF-DB and FER2013 benchmarks, it achieves accuracies of 86.83 % and 70.25 %, respectively, with a model size of only 1.17 million parameters compared to the lightweight state-of-the-art-models. These results highlight the model's ability to making it well-suited for deployment on edge devices.

title: Learning-Based Selective Use of Appearance Features for Efficient Multi-Object Tracking
authors: Koki Kanazawa, Shuhei Tarashima, Toru Abe
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In Multi-Object Tracking (MOT) based on trackingby-detection, appearance features as well as position features of objects detected in each frame are used to associate objects across frames, but using appearance features is computationally expensive. We propose a method to speed up MOT by selectively using appearance features only in necessary situations. This method evaluates the states of objects, and applies a supervised decision tree to efficiently select the situations where appearance features need to be used. Experiments on MOT20 dataset confirmed that our method can speed up MOT by 1.2 times while achieving tracking accuracy equal to or better than the existing method.

title: Soft Sensor Modeling Based on Exponential-LSTM and Spatiotemporal Feature Fusion
authors: Xiaoyue Liu, Danya Xu, Jingfei Wang, Yujie Chen, Tao Yang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: Key quality variables in industrial processes are usually difficult to measure directly. Soft sensing technology predicts hard-to-measure key parameters using easily obtained process variables. This improves process monitoring and control accuracy, reduces reliance on costly equipment, and lowers production costs. As industrial processes become more complex, process data tend to be complex, nonlinear, and multivariate. Therefore, it is very necessary to capture the temporal and spatial correlations between process data. In this paper, a new soft sensing model based on exponential long short-term memory and spatiotemporal feature fusion (STG-eLSTM) is proposed. The spatiotemporal convolution is introduced to initially capture the temporal and spatial dependencies in the data. In order to further learn the dependencies over a long period of time and remember important historical information, an LSTM network improved with exponential gating (eLSTM) is introduced. The introduction of exponential gating can provide more dynamic information filtering capabilities and help improve the memory and forgetting process. At the same time, in order to deepen the understanding of the graph structure, the application of GNN allows the model to directly operate on the data of the graph structure and deeply explore the complex interaction patterns between variables. In addition, the gated neurons are used to weight the prediction results of each layer and output the final value. Finally, the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed method are verified by the industrial case of debutanizer.

title: Channel Estimation via Digital Twins with Limited a Priori Knowledge
authors: Lorenzo Del Moro, Francesco Linsalata, Marouan Mizmizi, Damiano Badini, Umberto Spagnolini, Maurizio Magarini
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Digital Twin (DT) has emerged as a promising solution for channel estimation. By leveraging high-resolution 3D models of the scenario and ray-tracing simulations, DT could provide valuable site-specific prior knowledge on the channel’s space-time (ST) invariant features of the multipath environment, such as angles of arrival, angles of departure, and propagation delays. However, the real-time characterization of these features imposes computational constraints on ray-tracing simulations, hence limiting the prior knowledge of the multipath environment and corresponding ST features, and degrading estimation accuracy. In this paper, we propose and investigate, for the first time, three distinct DT-empowered low-rank methods for channel estimation, under different degrees of prior knowledge corresponding to limited number of paths provided by DT. Specifically, these methods perform modal projection onto a joint space-time, a spatial, and a temporal subspace. We compare our proposed methods with state-of-the-art techniques, and evaluate their performance in a synthetic scenario. Numerical results show that robustness, when prior knowledge is limited to few paths, is achieved when exploiting only temporal features, while estimation accuracy is attained when joint space-time features are considered.

title: Data-Oriented Transmission Under Jamming Attack
authors: Mehmet Can, Mehmet C. Ilter, Ibrahim Altunbas, Mikko Valkama
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: As wireless systems move toward 6G, ensuring ultra-reliable low-latency communication (URLLC) securely is a key design challenge. Addressing the strict latency and reliability demands requires a shift in performance evaluation. The delay-outage rate (DOR) has recently emerged as a data-oriented metric that captures the probability of transmission time exceeding a threshold under ideal conditions. This work extends the data-oriented framework to include physical layer security, focusing on jamming and eavesdropping threats. We analyze how constant and random jamming affect DOR in the multi-antenna systems, highlighting the role of spatial and spectral resources in mitigation. Our analysis, supported by empirical simulations, offers new insights for designing secure, low-latency systems resilient to jamming—supporting robust ultra- or hyper-reliable low-latency communications in future 6G networks.
