authors: Hung Tran-Huy, Tu Le-Tuan, Phuong Kim-Thi, Niamat Hussain, Truong Khang Nguyen, Nghia Nguyen-Trong
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: This paper proposes an approach to improve performance of a dual-circularly polarized (CP) patch using non uniform parasitic elements. To overcome the limited operating bandwidth and poor isolation of the conventional dual-CP patch, multiple parasitic elements are used to produce additional resonance to improve the operating bandwidth. Interestingly, the capacitive couple between the patch and the parasitic elements also introduces a new coupling path flowing on the parasitic elements, which is opposite to the original coupling path between two ports. A weak-field area is therefore generated, and the isolation is improved. It is also worth noting that by using non-uniform parasitic elements, wide isolation bandwidth can be attained. The fabricated antenna prototype with overall dimensions of 0.83 λ × 0.83 λ × 0.03 λ has measured operating bandwidth of 17.8% (5.1– 6.1 GHz). Across this band, the isolation is always higher than 20 dB, and the broadside gain is from 5.2 to 7.6 dBi.

title: A Near-Time-Optimal Trajectory Planning under Torque and Jerk Constraints for Industrial Robots on Fixed Paths_supp1-3642937.mp4
authors: Tianjiao Zheng
publish: N/A
abstract: Trajectory planning plays a pivotal role in robotic motion planning, particularly in achieving time-optimal motion under complex dynamic constraints. Although the Time-Optimal Path Parameterization (TOPP) algorithm effectively addresses trajectory generation under joint torque constraints, classical methods often overlook third-order constraints. As a result, the generated trajectories, while torque-feasible, exhibit excessive jerk and poor dynamic stability, which limits their practical applicability. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a trajectory planning framework that simultaneously enforces torque and jerk constraints. Building upon torque-constrained TOPP, the method integrates a shooting-based strategy to identify switching points through bidirectional integration under jerk constraints and employs a Sigmoid-based fusion scheme to eliminate integration errors and ensure smooth transitions. The proposed approach is experimentally validated on a six-degree-of-freedom industrial robot. Comparative evaluations with the TOPP-RA algorithm demonstrate that the method significantly reduces both high-frequency vibrations during high-speed execution and residual oscillations after motion termination. Feedback from torque rate measurements, vibration sensors, and laser tracker data confirms faster settling and improved compliance, making the approach well-suited for complex industrial scenarios.

title: Fixed-time adaptive deferred constrained control for a flexible manipulator with saturation and variable learning rate
authors: Zhijia Zhao, Rourou Xu, Shouyan Chen, Zhijie Liu, Xuefeng Zhou, Keum-Shik Hong, Chenguang Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: In this paper, a fixed-time adaptive deferred constrained control strategy is proposed for a flexible single-link manipulator system with input saturation. Fuzzy Neural Networks are utilized to estimate the unknown dynamics of the flexible manipulator system as well as the errors caused by input saturation. To address output constraints imposed within a prescribed time period, a time-shift function and an adjusted barrier function are introduced. The system’s stability is rigorously proven using the direct Lyapunov method. Finally, numerical simulations and experimental results are presented to validate the effectiveness and superiority of the proposed control approach.

title: Dynamic Trajectory Planning for a Group of Unmanned Aerial Vehicles in Unknown Environments
authors: Fan Yang, Qiang Lu, Botao Zhang, Na Huang, Youngjin Choi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: This paper deals with the problem of dynamic trajectory planning for a group of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) in unknown environments. The existing methods often suffer from excessive computational burden, which creates the gap between theoretical approaches and practical swarm deployment. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a distributed cooperative planning system (DCPS). The system consists of two levels: a trajectory planning level and a cooperative trajectory planning level. On the trajectory planning level, a kinodynamic Gaussian potential B-spline (KGPB) approach is designed by combining the local kinodynamic-A-star method and the Gaussian potential field B-spline method. Specifically, in the front-end, a trajectory is first generated by using the local kinodynamic-A-star method based on kinematics-dynamics constraints. And then, in the back-end, the trajectory is further optimized by using the Gaussian potential B-spline (GPB) method. On the cooperative trajectory planning level, a back field neighbor replanning (BFNP) approach is proposed, where each UAV only needs to communicate with the nearest neighbors. According to the potential collision region of the front UAV, the trajectory of the current UAV is dynamically improved to ensure safe and stable flight such that communication costs are significantly improved. Finally, the simulation results demonstrate that the proposed DCPS achieves at least a 27% increase in average velocity and a 24% reduction in traversal time for the UAV swarm compared to prior methods. The experimental outcomes provide further validation that the proposed DCPS can generate efficient and safe trajectories. For particular cases, the UAV operates at 97% of its maximum possible velocity. The proposed DCPS provides a reliable solution for a group of unmanned aerial vehicles in unknown environments.

title: Swooper: Learning High-Speed Aerial Grasping with a Simple Gripper_supp1-3643298.mp4
authors: Danping Zou
publish: N/A
abstract: High-speed aerial grasping presents significant challenges due to the high demands on precise, responsive flight control and coordinated gripper manipulation. In this work, we propose Swooper, a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) based approach that achieves both precise flight control and active gripper control using a single lightweight neural network policy. Training such a policy directly via DRL is nontrivial due to the complexity of coordinating flight and grasping. To address this, we adopt a two-stage learning strategy: we first pre-train a flight control policy, and then fine-tune it to acquire grasping skills. With the carefully designed reward functions and training framework, the entire training process completes in under 60 minutes on a standard desktop with an Nvidia RTX 3060 GPU. To validate the trained policy in the real world, we develop a lightweight quadrotor grasping platform equipped with a simple off-the-shelf gripper, and deploy the policy in a zero-shot manner on the onboard Raspberry Pi 4B computer, where each inference takes only about 1.0 ms. In 25 real-world trials, our policy achieves an 84% grasp success rate and grasping speeds of up to 1.5 m/s without any fine-tuning. This matches the robustness and agility of state-of-the-art classical systems with sophisticated grippers, highlighting the capability of DRL for learning a robust control policy that seamlessly integrates high-speed flight and grasping.

title: An IEEE 802.15.4z/ab-Compatible IR-UWB MIMO Radar System for in-Cabin Monitoring
authors: Amirashkan Farsaei, Gururaja Kasanadi Ramachandra, Sharada Prasad Shantharam, Alireza Sheikh, Utku Kumbul, Mohieddine El Soussi, Peng Zhang, Anoop Narayan Bhat
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper demonstrates an IEEE 802.15.4z/ab compatible Impulse Radio Ultra-Wideband (IR-UWB) time-division-duplexing (TDD) multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) radar system for in-cabin monitoring for automotive applications. The proposed system supports two in-cabin use cases running in real-time: occupancy detection and breathing rate estimation. The IR-UWB TDD MIMO radar system detects if the driver and/or front passenger seats are occupied. Furthermore, the our system estimates the breathing rates of persons sitting in a car’s driver and/or front passenger seat. The experimental results confirm achieving a high precision for estimating the angle-of-arrival (AoA) and breathing rate. Particularly, for a measurement scenario where both passenger and driver seats are occupied, our system achieves a standard deviation of less than 1.90 degree and 2.95 bpm, for AoA and breathing rate estimations, respectively.

title: Spiking Neural Networks for Resource Allocation in UAV-Enabled Wireless Networks
authors: Vasileios Kouvakis, Stylianos E. Trevlakis, Ioannis Arapakis, Alexandros-Apostolos A. Boulogeorgos
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This work presents a new spiking neural network (SNN)-based approach for user equipment-base station (UE-BS) association in non-terrestrial networks (NTNs). With the introduction of UAV’s in wireless networks, the system architecture becomes heterogeneous, resulting in the need for dynamic and efficient management to avoid congestion and sustain overall performance. The presented framework compares two SNN-based optimization strategies. Specifically, a top-down centralized approach with complete network visibility and a bottom-up distributed approach for individual network nodes. The SNN is based on leak integrate-and-fire neurons with temporal components, which can perform fast and efficient event-driven inference. Realistic ray-tracing simulations are conducted, which showcase that the bottom-up model attains over 90% accuracy, while the top-down model maintains 80-100% accuracy. Both approaches reveal a trade-off between individually optimal solutions and UE-BS association feasibility, thus revealing the effectiveness of both approaches depending on deployment scenarios.

title: Data-Driven Simulation System for Industrial Fused Magnesia Furnaces
authors: Bin Wang, Shaowen Lu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: This paper presents the design and implementation of a data-driven simulation system for fused magnesia furnaces, aiming to enhance the intelligence level and energy efficiency optimization in fused magnesia production. The system specifically models and predicts the short-term variation trends of electrode current, and real-time calculates and displays key performance parameters such as power, energy consumption, and demand. By employing a Radial Basis Function (RBF) neural network model, the system effectively addresses the nonlinear, strongly coupled, and time-varying characteristics of electrode current during the operation of the fused magnesia furnace. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed RBF model exhibits good fitting accuracy and stability on both the training and testing datasets, validating its effectiveness in online prediction and rapid response capability. In addition, the system achieves deep integration from front-end to back-end, providing functionalities including real-time data acquisition, predictive analysis, and interactive visualization, thereby supporting production decision-making and contributing to the advancement of fused magnesia furnaces toward intelligent and efficient operations.

title: Lightining Protection for Lifelines - Considerations
authors: Jobson Modena, Hélio E. Sueta, Luiz C. Ferraro
publish: 2025 IEEE ESW Brazil – Electrical Safety Workshop Brazil (ESW Brazil)
abstract: Lifelines are critical components for fall protection, specifically used in work-at-height activities. However, when exposed to adverse weather conditions, such as lightning strikes, they may suffer structural damage that compromises their safety.This study analyzes the impacts of lightning discharges on lifelines, discusses damage mechanisms, presents experimental evidence regarding the vulnerability of the materials used, and proposes practical protection measures.

title: Weather Predictions Using Fuzzy TOPSIS & Fuzzy AHP
authors: P Harshitha, R Lekhana, Trupthi Rao, Ashwini Kodipalli
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: Precise weather forecasting is deemed to be extremely important for several sectors like agriculture, aviation, and disaster management. The present research focuses on the fusion of Fuzzy Analytic Hierarchy Process (Fuzzy AHP) and Fuzzy Technique for Order of Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (Fuzzy TOPSIS) and FUZZY AHP Geometric Mean approaches in order to maximize the reliability and precision of weather forecasting models. Fuzzy AHP was utilized to rank important meteorological variables-like atmospheric pressure, temperature, humidity, wind velocity, and cloud cover—by decomposing the sophisticated decision process into a formal hierarchy of attributes. This method successfully addressed and overcame inherent uncertainty and subjectivity in weather forecasting. Fuzzy TOPSIS was then applied for ranking and evaluating different weather forecasting scenarios with an overall evaluation by taking both best and worst possible outcomes into account. The research concludes that although Fuzzy AHP always points to atmospheric pressure as the most important indicator, Fuzzy TOPSIS indicates cloud cover can also be critical. The results highlight the complementary effects of these methodologies in enhancing the precision of weather forecasting, particularly under the scenario of evermore erratic climate trends.

title: Digital Twin-Based Reinforcement Learning for Beam Selection in Cell-Free Networks
authors: Yifeng Yang, Wen Wang, Cheng Zhang, Wanli Ni, Yongming Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Cell-free massive multiple-input multiple-output (CF-mMIMO) networks improve spectral efficiency via coordinated transmission and flexible beam selection. However, the resource allocation in such networks presents a high-dimensional optimization challenge due to the distributed architecture with multiple access points and antennas. To address this, we first formulate a beam selection problem, and then propose an efficient Q-value mixing (QMIX)-based algorithm. Furthermore, recognizing the inherent limitations of deep reinforcement learning (DRL) in practical applications, such as costly training, risky exploration phases, and suboptimal convergence speeds, we design a data-driven digital twin (DT) framework to optimize the DRL training phase. Simulation results show that our approach achieves accelerated convergence and enhanced stability compared to conventional methods. DT-based pre-training establishes a robust performance lower bound prior to real-system deployment.

title: Evaluation of Packaging Printing Quality Defects Based on Linear Array CCD
authors: Yong Sun, Xinhan Yang, Ruijun Deng, Jing Jin, Jianfeng Zhang, Yushu Gong
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: To address the issue of finished product appearance defects caused by quality defects in boxed packaging printing, this paper proposes a packaging printing quality defect evaluation method based on linear array image sensors (Charge-Coupled Device, CCD) and three-dimensional reconstruction. The method involves acquiring images of boxed packaging through an image sensor scanning device, extracting the edge lines of printing patterns via algorithms such as Sobel and Hough transform, reconstructing the packaging geometric model based on measurement data, and constructing a printing quality defect evaluation method and control thresholds from two dimensions: the positional accuracy and alignment accuracy of printing patterns. Mixed sampling test results show that this method can effectively and objectively evaluate the positional and alignment status of patterns, has a high degree of consistency with actual production results, and possesses engineering application value.

title: Development of Grafana-Based Dashboard in Garbage Collection Visualization System
authors: Shota Homma, Tatsuya Abe, Hidekazu Suzuki
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In Japanese municipalities, staff are frequently burdened by numerous resident inquiries regarding garbage collection. To address this issue, a system for visualizing the status of garbage collection has been developed, and a web application for residents was previously implemented. This paper presents a dashboard for operation managers, developed using Grafana, which enables detailed visualization of garbage collection operations. By integrating Grafana with MongoDB, which stores data on garbage collection status and is deployed in an AWS environment, the system enables centralized management and monitoring of the collection status of smart garbage trucks and garbage collection points. This integrated management approach is expected to reduce the time required to respond to resident inquiries.

title: Risk Analysis and Safety Measures in the Use of Temporary Grounding in Electrical Networks
authors: Emanuel Filipe Galdino Alves, Larissa Andrade de Almeida, Paula Silva Duarte Pinto, Rodrigo Souza Rossi
publish: 2025 IEEE ESW Brazil – Electrical Safety Workshop Brazil (ESW Brazil)
abstract: Temporary grounding is a critical safety measure for electricians and field technicians during maintenance activities on electrical networks. As mandated by NR-10 (Regulatory Standard for Safety in Electrical Installations and Services), grounding is compulsory in de-energized circuits that are susceptible to accidental re-energization, serving as a primary protective mechanism against electric shock and arc flash hazards. This study investigates the risks associated with the absence or failure of temporary grounding systems, drawing upon real-world incidents and the lessons learned from them. Non-compliance with this safety protocol not only endangers worker safety but also exposes organizations to serious legal consequences and regulatory penalties. Best practices aligned with NR-10 are presented, including technical criteria for selecting grounding equipment, routine inspections, and comprehensive training programs to ensure proper implementation by qualified personnel. The research also underscores the importance of standardized procedures and safety checklists to ensure that the installation and removal of temporary grounding are conducted safely and efficiently. By emphasizing the necessity of compliance with NR-10, this study aims to foster an organizational culture centered on electrical safety, thereby mitigating risks and reducing the incidence of workplace accidents. The adoption of safe temporary grounding practices not only safeguards operational integrity but also ensures the protection of personnel and adherence to regulatory standards.

title: A Three-stage Detector for Massive MIMO System with Mixed ADCs
authors: Ziqing Zhen, Jin Xu, Shumei Wei, Jincong Peng, Xiaofeng Tao
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: The balance between system performance and power consumption has always been a top priority, particularly in massive multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) system. Besides, as one of the most critical modules in the radio-frequency (RF) chain, analog-to-digital converters (ADCs) hold significant importance. To find that tradeoff, mixed-ADC architecture, combining high-resolution ADCs and low-resolution ADCs, emerges as an effective approach. In this paper, we propose a novel three-stage near maximum likelihood (nML) detector to perform signal detection for the mixed architecture. In the first step, high-resolution ADCs are exploited to roughly find the transmitted signal vector. Subsequently, a convex optimization problem is further constructed based on the rough vector and projection gradient method is used to estimate the more likely one. An approximate expression for the cumulative distribution function is derived to simplify the optimization problem. Finally, the size of the transmitted signal vector collection is effectively minimized on the basis of the most possible vector and exhaustive search is carried out on the collection. Numerical results show that the proposed three-stage nML detector is efficient enough to simultaneously obtain high accuracy and low complexity.

title: Multiple-objective Coordinated Steering Control of the Corner Module Electric Vehicle
authors: Shenghan Zhang, Lu Xiong, Sonki Prasetya, Cetengfei Zhang, Quan Zhou
publish: 2025 21st IEEE International Conference on Mechatronic and Embedded Systems and Applications (MESA)
abstract: Corner module vehicle, characterized by being equipped with four-wheel-independent-drive and four-wheel-independent-steering (4WID-4WIS) system, is at the forefront of automotive development. With more steering control degrees of freedom, corner module vehicles meet the high-precision requirements of unmanned vehicles for path tracking. This paper proposes a control structure to improve the performance of corner module vehicle path tracking through rear-wheel steering and differential steering, which can realize the switching and cooperation of these two functions. By analyzing the energy cost and the trajectory costs, the Pareto optimal solution of the controller parameter is found to realize the multiple objective optimization in the steering process. The simulation results of CarSim/Simulink show that the coordinated steering method performs better than rear steering and differential steering in energy saving while achieving satisfying trajectory performance.

title: Matching Under Uncertainty: Toward Robust and Communication-Efficient Perception in Embedded Multi-Agent Systems
authors: Tiange Fu, Shijie Feng, Guiyang Luo, Hui Zhang, Yonglin Tian
publish: 2025 21st IEEE International Conference on Mechatronic and Embedded Systems and Applications (MESA)
abstract: Collaborative perception (CP) plays a central role in enabling embedded intelligent systems, such as autonomous vehicles and robotic collectives, to operate effectively in dynamic and uncertain environments. However, CP often suffers from misaligned observations caused by localization inaccuracies and detection uncertainties, especially under bandwidth-constrained conditions. To address these challenges, we propose UA-MCS, an uncertainty-aware maximum common subgraph extraction framework for robust multi-agent perception. UA-MCS selectively transmits high-confidence detections while attaching compact features to low-confidence ones. By formulating the matching task as a min-max quadratic assignment problem (MM-QAP) and solving it with concave-convex optimization, UA-MCS achieves reliable alignment of detection results across agents, greatly enhancing perception accuracy under uncertainty. Meanwhile, the selective transmission mechanism substantially reduces communication overhead. Experiments on simulated and real-world datasets show that UA-MCS achieves state-of-the-art accuracy under varying localization noise, while outperforming prior methods in perception-communication trade-offs.

title: SSP-SAM: SAM with Semantic-Spatial Prompt for Referring Expression Segmentation
authors: Wei Tang, Xuejing Liu, Yanpeng Sun, Zechao Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: The Segment Anything Model (SAM) excels at general image segmentation but has limited ability to understand natural language, which restricts its direct application in Referring Expression Segmentation (RES). Toward this end, we propose SSP-SAM, a framework that fully utilizes SAM’s segmentation capabilities by integrating a Semantic-Spatial Prompt (SSP) encoder. Specifically, we incorporate both visual and linguistic attention adapters into the SSP encoder, which highlight salient objects within the visual features and discriminative phrases within the linguistic features. This design enhances the referent representation for the prompt generator, resulting in high-quality SSPs that enable SAM to generate precise masks guided by language. Although not specifically designed for Generalized RES (GRES), where the referent may correspond to zero, one, or multiple objects, SSP-SAM naturally supports this more flexible setting without additional modifications. Extensive experiments on widely used RES and GRES benchmarks confirm the superiority of our method. Notably, our approach generates segmentation masks of high quality, achieving strong precision even at strict thresholds such as Pr@0.9. Further evaluation on the PhraseCut dataset demonstrates improved performance in open-vocabulary scenarios compared to existing state-of-the-art RES methods. The code and checkpoints are available at: https://github.com/WayneTomas/SSP-SAM.

title: AI-Driven Inverse Antenna Design in UWB Band: Embedding Forward Consistency into Deep Learning Architectures
authors: Olaoluwa Adegboye, Taoreed Akinola, Xiangfang Li, Lijun Qian
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This work presents a deep learning-based inverse design framework for rapid prototyping of fork antennas operating within the ultra-wideband (UWB) frequency. By integrating a pre-trained frozen forward model into the inverse training process, the proposed method with forward consistency loss ensures that predicted antenna geometries yield physically valid performance metrics. Three models were trained: Deep Neural Network (DNN), Long Short Term Memory (LSTM), and Echo State Network (ESN), to map performance targets to antenna dimensions. The results show that the models trained with forward consistency loss achieve a lower error in return loss, bandwidth, and frequency metrics. The proposed framework considering both forward loss and reverse loss outperforms inverse-only models, especially in complex high-frequency wideband scenarios. DNN and LSTM models demonstrated the best generalization at 3.5 GHz and 8 GHz, while all models significantly reduced the computational cost of antenna design compared to conventional simulation sweeps.

title: A Lightweight Transfer Learning-Based State-of-Health Monitoring With Application to Lithium-Ion Batteries in Autonomous Air Vehicles
authors: Jiang Liu, Yan Qin, Wei Dai, Chau Yuen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
abstract: Accurate and rapid state-of-health (SOH) monitoring plays an important role in indicating energy information for lithium-ion battery-powered portable mobile devices. To confront their variable working conditions, transfer learning (TL) emerges as a promising technique for leveraging knowledge from data-rich source working conditions, significantly reducing the training data required for SOH monitoring from target working conditions. However, traditional TL-based SOH monitoring is infeasible when applied in portable mobile devices since substantial computational resources are consumed during the TL stage and unexpectedly reduce the working endurance. To address these challenges, this article proposes a lightweight TL-based SOH monitoring approach with constructive incremental transfer learning (CITL). First, taking advantage of the unlabeled data in the target domain, a semisupervised TL mechanism is proposed to minimize the monitoring residual in a constructive way, through iteratively adding network nodes in the CITL. Second, the cross-domain learning ability of node parameters for CITL is comprehensively guaranteed through structural risk minimization, transfer mismatching minimization, and manifold consistency maximization. Moreover, the convergence analysis of the CITL is given, theoretically guaranteeing the efficacy of TL performance and network compactness. Finally, the proposed approach is verified through extensive experiments with a realistic autonomous air vehicles (AAVs) battery dataset collected from dozens of flight missions. Specifically, the CITL outperforms SS-TCA, MMD-LSTM-DA, DDAN, BO-CNN-TL, and AS <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$^{3}$</tex-math></inline-formula> LSTM, in SOH estimation by 83.73%, 61.15%, 28.24%, 87.70%, and 57.34%, respectively, as evaluated using the index root-mean-square error.

title: An Expectation Maximization Sample Transfer Identification Method for Dynamic Systems Under Non-ideal Data
authors: Yan Huang, Xiaoli Luan, Shuang Gao, Xiaojing Ping, Fei Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: This paper proposes an expectation maximization sample transfer identification (EM-STI) algorithm to address the parameter identification problem in dynamic systems with non-ideal data. Traditional identification methods usually require a large amount of high-quality ideal data that follows the same distribution. However, in industrial measurement scenarios, challenges such as sensor noise, environmental complexity, and sensor data loss often make such datasets difficult to obtain. To solve the above problems, the EM-STI algorithm constructs a transfer identification framework, and models the distribution discrepancy between the source and target systems as latent variables, and iteratively optimizes parameters using the expectation maximization algorithm to improve the reliability and accuracy of the model. The core of the algorithm includes establishing a unified probabilistic framework, explicitly modeling distribution differences as latent variables, inferring the latent variable relationships through the expectation step, calculating the log-likelihood expectation, and updating the parameters in the maximization step to reduce distribution discrepancy. The algorithm also provides a theoretical guarantee of convergence. The simulation experiments on the mass-spring-damping system and the pH process system, as well as the industrial case study on the demand prediction of magnesium furnaces, have proved that this algorithm has excellent estimation accuracy under non-ideal data conditions such as high noise and data scarcity, and has strong robustness against non-Gaussian noise.

title: ICDM: Interference Cancellation Diffusion Models for Wireless Semantic Communications
authors: Tong Wu, Zhiyong Chen, Dazhi He, Feng Yang, Meixia Tao, Xiaodong Xu, Wenjun Zhang, Ping Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Diffusion models (DMs) have recently achieved significant success in wireless communications systems due to their denoising capabilities. The broadcast nature of wireless signals makes them susceptible not only to Gaussian noise, but also to unaware interference. This raises the question of whether DMs can effectively mitigate interference in wireless semantic communication systems. In this paper, we model the interference cancellation problem as a maximum a posteriori (MAP) problem over the joint posterior probability of the signal and interference, and theoretically prove that the solution provides excellent estimates for the signal and interference. To solve this problem, we develop an interference cancellation diffusion model (ICDM), which decomposes the joint posterior into independent prior probabilities of the signal and interference, along with the channel transition probability. The log-gradients of these distributions at each time step are learned separately by DMs and accurately estimated through deriving. ICDM further integrates these gradients with advanced numerical iteration method, achieving accurate and rapid interference cancellation. Extensive experiments demonstrate that ICDM significantly reduces the mean square error (MSE) and enhances perceptual quality compared to schemes without ICDM. For example, on the CelebA dataset under the Rayleigh fading channel with a signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of 20 dB and signal to interference plus noise ratio (SINR) of 0 dB, ICDM reduces the MSE by 4.54 dB and improves the learned perceptual image patch similarity (LPIPS) by 2.47 dB. The code is available at https://github.com/Wireless3C-SJTU/ICDM.

title: Burning Reality: Experiencing Climate Change through Virtual Reality
authors: Federico Calà, Mariana Magalhães, António Coelho, Antonio Lanata
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study proposes a virtual reality (VR) experience that aims at raising awareness toward climate change through the simulation of a wildfire, a natural disaster that is becoming increasingly frequent in Portugal, and promote the adoption of sustainable behaviours and mitigation strategies. Here, the feasibility of such an approach is tested implementing both subjective, with the Igroup Presence Questionnaire (IPQ) to evaluate the senses of presence, involvement and realism, and objective measures, i.e., a set of features extracted from the in-VR movement trajectories. The mean scores of IPQ items demonstrated that such devastating event is particularly effective in enhancing participants’ involvement and sense of presence within the virtual environment, reinforcing the potential of VR to foster pro-environmental attitudes. Results also highlighted that these feelings were not altered by VR familiarity, whereas presence ratings were higher for participants who visited the actual location that the virtual environment replicated. Correlation analysis also discovered significant relationships between subjective and objective parameters.

title: Construction and Utilization of a Partial Scale Map for Navigation on Distorted Indoor Maps
authors: Ryo Takeyama, Yoshihiro Sugaya
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study proposes a robust indoor navigation method using partial scale information to mitigate the effects of map distortions. Pedestrian turning points are detected via PDR, and local scales are estimated by matching these to known map corners. Scale values, calculated from walking distance and pixel distance, are refined using RANSAC and stored in a Partial Scale Map (PSM). During navigation, the PSM is referenced to update particle scales, improving map matching accuracy. Experiments on distorted floor maps show that the proposed method achieves more stable and accurate position estimation compared to conventional approaches, without requiring a globally accurate floor map.

title: Moisture Prediction in Tobacco Drying Process Based on the NRBO-GRU Algorithm
authors: Hongjing Li, Ming Wang, Shangrong Wang, Tao Wang, Weitao Liu, Chuancan Liu, Songyan Li, Qian Shang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: During the drying process of tobacco shreds, the moisture content of tobacco shreds is an important factor affecting product quality. Aiming at the nonlinearity, uncertainty and hysteresis of the drying process itself, it is difficult to achieve precise control of the moisture content of tobacco shreds. Accurately predicting the moisture content helps to control product quality. Therefore, this paper proposes a prediction model that combines the NRBO algorithm and the GRU algorithm neural network. NRBO is used to optimize the initial learning rate, hidden nodes, and regularization coefficient of the GRU model. Then, the optimized network hyperparameters are substituted into the GRU for learning and training. Finally, the moisture content of tobacco shreds at the outlet in the future is predicted. The model is experimentally compared with the LSTM, GRU, and NRBO-LSTM models, and the root mean square error (RMSE), mean absolute error (MAE), mean absolute percentage error (MAPE), and coefficient of determination (R2) are used as evaluation criteria. The results show that the NRBO-GRU model has a smaller error, higher precision, and more stable numerical fluctuations.

title: Leveraging ISAC for Adaptive Cell Zooming in Mixed FSO-RF Networks
authors: Muhammad Nafees, Mohammadamin Baniasadi, James R. Hopgood, Majid Safari, John S. Thompson
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) is set to transform data transmission and real-time sensing in sixth-generation (6G) networks. By offering high capacity, free-space optical (FSO) links can play a vital role as a backhaul solution, complementing radio frequency (RF) technologies such as millimeter wave (mmWave) to enhance 6G reliability. While adverse weather conditions such as fog can reduce the reliability of FSO links due to atmospheric attenuation, the back-scattered light it generates may also enable real-time sensing of atmospheric channel gain at the transmitter. This paper proposes a novel user offloading scheme utilizing an optical ISAC (O-ISAC) framework within a single-cell network, supported by a ground base station (GBS) and enhanced by an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV). The UAV connects to the gateway via an FSO backhaul link, estimating the channel gain based on back-scattered light and dynamically optimizing its position to efficiently offload users in the downlink. Numerical results demonstrate the UAV’s effectiveness in optimizing its position under various weather conditions and show that the proposed deployment scheme outperforms existing UAV offloading methods. The framework is evaluated using a real dataset of hourly visibility measurements in Edinburgh, underscoring the significance of optical channel sensing for overall system performance and providing insights into how sensing impacts communication efficiency.

title: A Dual-hop Uplink IM-OFDMA System with Decode-and-Forward Relays
authors: Saud Althunibat, Mazen Hasna, Khalid Qaraqe
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Due to the expected exploitation of high frequency bands to meet increasing demands on high data rates, multi-hop links are being under investigation as a solution for limited transmission distances over these bands. As such, many of recent transmission schemes are analyzed over multi-hop scenarios. To this end, in this paper, we design a dual-hop system of Index Modulation based Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiple Access (IM-OFDMA) with the help of decode-and-forward relays. Two different scenarios are considered, with single and multiple DF relays. Moreover, the average error rate is analyzed for the proposed system considering the two different scenarios. Our results indicate that the overall performance in the case of a single DF relay is governed by the performance of the second hop. Also, results reveal that a significant gain can be attained if a single relay is assigned to each user rather than one relay for all users.

title: Animal Intrusion Detection in Agriculture Fields Using IoT and Machine Learning
authors: C Venkatesh Prasad, Gayana J Kumar, S N Vinayashree, B S Lakshmi, H A Chaya Kumari, D N Kavitha
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: Animal intrusion in agricultural fields is a major challenge that leads to significant crop damage and financial losses for farmers. Traditional protective measures such as manual monitoring, fencing, and scare devices are ineffective and labor-intensive. To address this issue, we propose an AI-powered Animal Intrusion Detection System, which integrates YOLOv8 object detection with an IoT-based alert mechanism. The system is trained using a dataset collected from Roboflow.com, recognizing six classes: Boar, Deer, Elephant, Fire, Smoke, and Peacock. The YOLOv8 model is trained with an image resolution, and the AdamW optimizer achieves with a detection accuracy reaching $99.2 \%$ for elephants and $96.2 \%$ for boars. Performance evaluation using a confusion matrix and F1-confidence curve analysis validates the system’s reliability. The trained model is deployed on an Arduino Uno-based IoT system, where a buzzer is triggered instantly upon detecting an animal. In addition, the system is combined with Telegram API, letting real-time alerts be sent to farmers’ mobile devices. The low-latency reply, high detection accuracy, and cost-effective hardware make it an ideal solution for real-time smart agriculture safety.

title: A Conceptual Framework for Neonatal Motor Activity Monitoring Using Digital Twin Technology and Computer Vision: A Preliminary Study
authors: Remon Nakashima, Hiroki Matsumoto, Thi Thi Zin, Yuki Kodama
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Continuous non-contact monitoring of neonatal motor activity in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) is crucial for early detection of neurological disorders and for guiding timely clinical interventions. We introduce an infrared-driven skeleton-estimation prototype designed for real-time operation that generates a live virtual "digital twin" of the infant’s posture to support clinician assessment. A deep-learning pose model was fine-tuned on a bespoke infrared key-point dataset, and three motion-quantification filters were evaluated: raw differencing (Method A), center-aligned suppression (Method B), and a newly proposed skeleton template-matching filter (Method C). Tests on a life-sized neonatal mannequin confirmed centimetric joint-localization accuracy, reliable detection of 50-pixel hand displacements, and reduction of simulated camera-shake artifacts to within five pixels. Building on these results, a follow-up evaluation on pre-term neonates showed that Method C suppressed static key-point noise by 78 % while preserving physiological motion. This combined mannequin and in-vivo evidence demonstrates the clinical feasibility of our infrared digital-twin framework and establishes a foundation for automated assessment of pre-term motor development.

title: Online Prediction of Oxygen Content in Municipal Solid Waste Incineration Process Based on Improved Random Weight Neural Network
authors: Qiumei Cong, Huan Li, Mengyuan Zhang, Jian Tang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: Municipal solid waste incineration (MSWI) process emits various conventional pollutants such as nitrogen oxides (NOx) and carbon dioxide (C02), as well as trace toxic pollutants such as dioxins (DXN). The oxygen content in flue gas is one of the key process parameters that affect the emission concentration of these pollutants. To achieve the sustainable development of ecological environment, it is necessary to predict oxygen content concentration and take control measures in advance. Aiming at the above problems, this article proposes an online prediction model of oxygen content based on improved random weight neural network (RWNN). First, based on the mechanism analysis for the oxygen content, the related auxiliary variables are determined. Then, the IRWNN algorithm based on binary division for dynamic structural adjustment has been proposed, which solves the problem that it is time-consuming and inefficient to adjust the number of hidden layer nodes by trial and error method. Finally, the improved sparrow search algorithm (ISSA) is use to optimize the initial parameters of IRWNN. The experimental results based on the actual data set of an actual MSWI power plant in Beijing show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

title: Expanding Access to Science Participation: A FAIR Framework for Petascale Data Visualization and Analytics_supp2-3642878.mp4
authors: Aashish Panta
publish: N/A
abstract: The massive data generated by scientists daily serve as both a major catalyst for new discoveries and innovations, as well as a significant roadblock that restricts access to the data. Our paper introduces a new approach to removing big data barriers and democratizing access to petascale data for the broader scientific community. Our novel data fabric abstraction layer allows user-friendly querying of scientific information while hiding the complexities of dealing with file systems or cloud services. We enable FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) access to datasets such as NASA's petascale climate datasets. Our paper presents an approach to managing, visualizing, and analyzing petabytes of data within a browser on equipment ranging from the top NASA supercomputer to commodity hardware like a laptop. Our novel data fabric abstraction utilizes state-of-the art progressive compression algorithms and machinelearning insights to power scalable visualization dashboards for petascale data. The result provides users with the ability to identify extreme events or trends dynamically, expanding access to scientific data and further enabling discoveries. We validate our approach by improving the ability of climate scientists to visually explore their data via three fully interactive dashboards. We further validate our approach by deploying the dashboards and simplified training materials in the classroom at a minorityserving institution. These dashboards, released in simplified form to the general public, contribute significantly to a broader push to democratize the access and use of climate data.

title: Experimental Study on the Influence of Design Parameters on 1500V DC Circuit Breaker Interruption Performance
authors: Dongkyu Shin, Dongyoel Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE 70th Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts (HLM)
abstract: The demand for DC distribution networks has been steadily increasing due to their superior energy efficiency and expanding applicability across various sectors, including DC buildings, electric ships, and high-power charging systems. Unlike AC systems, DC networks inherently lack a natural current zero-crossing, making current interruption significantly more challengingThis study presents an experimental investigation into the characteristics of DC arc interruption and explores the influence of key design parameters on the interruption performance of DC circuit breakers. Several phenomena unique to DC interruption are identified, and practical design strategies are proposed to enhance the performance and reliability of DC switching devicesFirst, a sufficient number of splitter plates is necessary to generate an arc voltage that exceeds the system voltage, thereby enabling effective current interruption. Second, enhanced insulation, particularly around the arc quenching chamber, is crucial to prevent dielectric breakdown, especially under conditions of elevated arc voltage and the emission of high-temperature gases from the chamber. Third, minimizing both the opening time and contact rebound is essential to improve the current-limiting effect and accelerate arc extinction. Furthermore, under low-current operating conditions, increasing the number of arcing contacts enhances interruption reliability by forming multiple parallel arc branches, which help distribute arc energy more effectively.

title: Remote Estimation of Spatial Sound Energy Distribution for Real-Time Sound Source Localization
authors: Taiki Kanbayashi, Toru Takahashi, Masato Nakayama
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: We propose a method for real-time estimation of spatial sound energy distribution for monitoring multi-person dialogue activities in a wide space. We apply frame processing to our previously proposed method to achieve real-time processing. And then we demonstrate that dialogue activities can be monitored in real-time by creating a movie of the estimated spatial sound energy distribution. In the subjective evaluation, five types of analysis frame lengths are tested. Our experimental results suggest that the appropriate frame lengths are 0.2 s and 0.4 s.

title: sEMG-based Arm Movement Prediction by LSTM for Realtime Teleoperation
authors: Yurika Machida, Yutaka Katsuyama, Wataru Kameyama
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper aims to compensate for control latency in robot arm teleoperation by predicting arm movement 0.5 seconds ahead using surface electromyography (sEMG) signals and a long short-term memory (LSTM) model. To establish this prediction method, two experiments are conducted. First, we investigate the effect of varying the number of sEMG channels on prediction accuracy during a right-to-left unidirectional arm movement, aiming to achieve stable and high-accuracy predictions independent of subjects and datasets. Second, we assess the generalizability of the proposed method by conducting within-subject validation and cross-subject validation using models trained on the data from multiple subjects. The results indicate that increasing the number of the channels generally improves prediction performance, and the trained model of multiple subjects can compensate for lack of data per individual to achieve feasible prediction accuracy. These findings indicate that the proposed method has strong potential for realtime teleoperation applications to minimize the control latency.

title: Intelligent Document Camera for Enhancing Writing Instruction and Demonstration
authors: Nobuyuki Umezu, Haruto Oyagi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Document cameras are widely used for instruction and demonstration, as online lectures have become more common. Their functionality, however, is very limited to capturing frames and retaining sophisticated built-in features. The purpose of this study is to improve the usability of document cameras by developing intelligent functions. Our "transparent hand" feature solves the problem of text and diagrams being blocked by the instructor’s hand while writing, and "frame pauses" allows us to display a still frame and proceed with writing without showing viewers temporary-hidden content, such as the answers to exercises. The "restore frames" displays saved frames of the transparent hand and the current one, allowing us to switch between saved frames and reducing the time the instructor waits for all students to finish taking notes before changing pages. From the results of user experiments, the system was found to be effective in reducing the time required for viewers to finish taking notes by 33–42%. The proposed method was positively rated by the participants in terms of the hand transparency function and system usability.

title: Secure UAV Relay under Jamming and Eavesdropping via Trajectory-Power Optimization
authors: Shuo Yu, Ahmed Shaharyar Khwaja, Alagan Anpalagan, Waleed Ejaz
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are emerging as key enablers for adaptive connectivity in future sixth-generation (6G) networks, offering high mobility, flexible deployment, and enhanced line-of-sight coverage. However, the open nature of wireless communication and the elevated positioning of UAVs as a relay expose them to severe security threats, including jamming and eavesdropping. In this work, we propose a secure downlink communication framework where a UAV relay flying at a fixed altitude serves multiple ground users while contending with an active jammer and a passive eavesdropper. To enhance physical layer security, we jointly optimize the UAV’s trajectory and transmit power over a discrete time horizon to maximize the cumulative secrecy rate. The resulting non-convex optimization problem is solved using both a successive convex approximation (SCA) method and deep reinforcement learning (DRL). Simulation results demonstrate the optimized trajectories in various user topologies and shed light on the relationship between secrecy energy efficiency and maximal transmit power of the UAV relay as well as the number of users.

title: Adaptation to Non-Individualized Head-Related Transfer Functions by Imparting Visual Spatial Characteristics with Virtual Reality
authors: Tatsufumi Yamamoto, Ken’Ichi Furuya
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Binaural synthesis is a signal processing technique used to represent spatial audio. The head-related transfer function (HRTF) is convolved with a sound source to provide distance and direction cues and reproduce stereophonic sounds. Non-individualized HRTFs may cause perceptual incongruity in some listeners; however, such incongruity can be overcome through training that leverages human adaptability. This study aims to improve adaptation to non-individualized HRTFs and proposes a new training method that combines auditory and visual information. The experimental results confirmed a tendency for reduced confusion rates when training with visual information in both anechoic and short-reverberant environments.

title: Basic Evaluation of a Distributed Processing Platform with Reconfigurable Software Module Composition
authors: Ginga Nishimiya, Mutsuki Sato, Tatsuya Nakafuji, Atsunori Aoki, Naoya Chujo, Tadanori Mizuno, Katsuhiko Kaji, Ayano Naito
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Edge computing has attracted attention in the field of industrial IoT as a technology that enables real-time processing at the network edge, thereby reducing dependence on cloud services. However, in smart factories, conventional systems often tightly couple hardware and software, resulting in limited scalability and inefficient resource utilization. In this study, we propose SPHERE (Service-oriented Platform with High-performance, Elastic, and Resilient Edge-enabled solutions), a reconfigurable edge-distributed processing platform based on container virtualization technology. SPHERE decouples software from hardware, enabling flexible deployment and efficient use of heterogeneous edge resources. We implemented a prototype system consisting of seven components and constructed three types of services: scratch detection, shape validation, and motion detection. Experimental validation demonstrated that modules can be shared across multiple services and dynamically recomposed to form different services. These results highlight the modularity and flexibility of SPHERE in dynamic factory environments.

title: Design of Acoustic Metadata on Object-Based Audio Utilizing Estimated 3D-Position of Sound Source in Video
authors: Subaru Kato, Masato Nakayama, Takanobu Nishiura, Yoshiharu Soeta
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Object-based audio is a playback method for multichannel audio that can reproduce a highly realistic sound space. However, a significant challenge with object-based audio is that increasing the number of sound images imposes a greater production burden on audio engineers. In this paper, we propose a method to reduce the production burden by estimating the 3D-position of objects in a video image and using these estimated positions for sound image construction. Evaluation experiments confirmed that the sound images constructed by the proposed method were aligned with the video image, which caused no perceptual inconsistencies.

title: Multi-Class Brain Computer Interface Using Electrical and Mechanical Stimuli
authors: Keijiro Ito, Shunya Nakata, Atsushi Matsubara, Shota Nakashima, Seiji Nishifuji
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Steady-State somatosensory evoked potentials (SSSEPs) are event-related potentials in brain elicited by periodic vibrotactile stimulation to various body sites such as fingers and knees. Brain-Computer interfaces based on SSSEP (SSSEP-BCIs) use amplitude modulation of SSSEP elicited by selective attention to tactile stimuli with different frequencies to decode user intent for the interaction with external environment. Conventional SSSEP-BCIs have typically relied solely on mechanical stimulation. However, the limited perceptual distinctiveness among these stimuli reduces the attentional engagement in the selective attention task, resulting in insufficient amplitude modulation and degrading classification performance. To address this limitation, we propose a novel SSSEP-BCI paradigm that combines mechanical and electrical stimulation to enhance the stimulus discriminability. Eight healthy participants were instructed to selectively attend to one of three stimuli--two mechanical stimuli applied to the index finger and the back of the knee and one electrical stimulus to the contralateral index finger to elicit the amplitude modulation of SSSEP. Using the common spatial pattern (CSP) for feature extraction and the support vector machine (SVM) for classification of the feature extracted, the proposed BCI achieved the maximum classification accuracy of 86.7% for three-class tasks and 76.3% for four-class tasks, demonstrating significant improvement over conventional SSSEP-BCI approaches.

title: Contract-based Incentive Mechanism for AI-Generated Content Services in Vehicle Edge Computing
authors: Runchen Xu, Lu Yu, Zheng Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Artificial Intelligence Generated Content (AIGC) is a paradigm that utilizes AI models to automatically generate content. Within the framework of Internet of Vehicles (IoV) networks, mobile AIGC services present numerous advantages over conventional cloud-based solutions, notably enhanced network efficiency and enhanced data security and privacy. However, the implementation of AIGC services often demands significant resources, leading to challenges for Roadside Units (RSUs) in managing information uncertainty and effectively addressing all user service requests without compromising overall system performance. To address these challenges, in this paper, we propose a multi-to-multi contract-based incentive mechanism for AIGC services within vehicle edge computing. This approach leverages contract theory to design an optimal contractual framework between Mobile AIGC Service Providers (MASPs) and vehicles. We present the necessary and sufficient conditions for achieving an optimal contract and explore the simplification of the associated constraints. The simulation results demonstrate that our proposed method effectively provides incentives and outperforms existing benchmark schemes.

title: Development of a VR-based fitness game designed for individuals living with Parkinson's disease
authors: Yuto Nitta, Takayuki Sawada, Ryoichi Suzuki
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: The research objective is to develop a VR-based fitness game for patients with Parkinson’s disease. Continued daily exercise is necessary to prevent muscle weakness. The proposed fitness game consists of tennis and basketball. To verify the effectiveness of the game content, the fitness game has been tested and evaluated through experiments involving Parkinson's disease patients.

title: Goal-oriented Semantic Communication for the Metaverse Application
authors: Zhe Wang, Nan Li, Yansha Deng, Hamid Aghvami
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: With the emergence of the metaverse and its role in enabling real-time simulation and analysis of real-world counterparts, an increasing number of personalized metaverse scenarios are being created to influence entertainment experiences and social behaviors. However, compared to traditional image and video entertainment applications, the exact transmission of the vast amount of metaverse-associated information significantly challenges the capacity of existing bit-oriented communication networks. Moreover, the current metaverse also witnesses a growing goal shift for transmitting the meaning behind custom-designed content, such as user-designed buildings and avatars, rather than exact copies of physical objects. To meet this growing goal shift and bandwidth challenge, this paper proposes a goal-oriented semantic communication framework for metaverse application (GSCM) to explore and define semantic information through the goal levels. Specifically, we first analyze the traditional image communication framework in metaverse construction and then detail our proposed semantic information along with the end-to-end wireless communication. We then describe the designed modules of the GSCM framework, including goal-oriented semantic information extraction, base knowledge definition, and neural radiance field (NeRF) based metaverse construction. Finally, numerous experiments have been conducted to demonstrate that, compared to image communication, our proposed GSCM framework decreases transmission latency by up to 92.6% and enhances the virtual object operation accuracy and metaverse construction clearance by up to 45.6% and 44.7%, respectively.

title: A Novel Water-Substrate-Based Dual-UWB Conformal Antenna with Radiation Stability for Diverse IIoMT Applications
authors: Naeem Abbas, Zain Ul Abdin, Hyoungsuk Yoo
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: This work presents a water-substrate-based conformal implantable antenna (WSCIA) designed for Industrial Internet of Medical Things (IIoMT) applications. The antenna exhibits ultra-wideband (UWB) characteristics across the Industrial, Scientific, and Medical bands at 915 MHz and 2400 MHz, enabling efficient wireless power transfer and high-data-rate biotelemetry. It achieves a bandwidth of 510 MHz (0.71–1.23 GHz) in the 915 MHz band and 1.30 GHz (1.80–3.10 GHz) in the 2400 MHz band. The antenna exhibits strong radiation stability in varying tissue environments, ensuring reliable performance under realistic implantation conditions. Measured peak realized gains are –24.87 dBi at 915 MHz and –22.03 dBi at 2400 MHz, with corresponding radiation efficiencies of 0.76% and 0.80%. The specific absorption rate (SAR) analysis using an anatomically realistic human model confirms compliance with safety guidelines. Link margin and received power analyses confirm reliable telemetric communication at distances beyond 10 m for 915 MHz and 5 m for 2400 MHz, supporting high data rates of up to 120 Mb/s. Owing to the dielectric similarity between water and human tissue, the proposed WSCIA enables efficient electromagnetic (EM) energy transfer and, through 3D printing, offers a lightweight and cost-effective alternative to traditional substrate-based antenna designs. Collectively, the dual-UWB performance, radiation stability, low SAR, compact design, and frequency tunability make the proposed WSCIA a promising solution for next-generation IIoMT-based implants. Furthermore, its structural flexibility and stable EM performance in diverse environments make it suitable for anatomically constrained regions, particularly the scalp, heart, and gastrointestinal tract, where reliable wireless communication and safe long-term implantation are critical.

title: A Radiative Transfer-Driven Deep Learning Framework for Accurate Estimation of Rice Growth Parameters Using Multi-Source UAV Data
authors: Yaopeng Zou, Jie Pei, Yibo Liu, Shaofeng Tan, Huajun Fang, Xiaopo Zheng, Tianxing Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Leaf area index (LAI) and leaf chlorophyll content (LCC) are key indicators for monitoring rice growth dynamics. While UAV-based hyperspectral data is widely used, its high redundancy poses challenges for efficient information extraction. To address this, we propose a two-step generic framework. First, synthetic spectra generated by a field-constrained PROSAIL model are used to train a one-dimensional convolutional neural network with a self-attention mechanism that derives Spectral Composite Variables (SCVs) from redundant hyperspectral data. Then, the SCVs are combined with canopy temperature (from thermal infrared sensors) and crop height (derived from UAV-based LiDAR and RGB imagery) to develop a retrieval model, validated through both within-site and cross-site strategies. Results showed that the SCVs generated exhibited strong correlations with LAI and LCC, averaging 0.83 and 0.85, respectively. Moreover, the proposed framework achieved high retrieval accuracy across all growth stages (e.g., booting, heading, filling), with mean R² values of 0.76 for LAI and 0.71 for LCC. Specifically, both estimations reached peak performance during the heading stage, with an R² of 0.83 and RMSE of 0.47 m²/m² for LAI, and an R² of 0.77 and RMSE of 4.13 μg/cm² for LCC. Cross-site validation confirmed the model’s robustness and transferability, with the best performance consistently observed during the heading stage. Benefiting from this framework, spatial predictions of LAI and LCC at centimeter-level resolution closely aligned with observed patterns, enabling precise monitoring of rice growth. Overall, this study presents a robust and transferable solution for overcoming hyperspectral redundancy and enhancing crop growth estimation accuracy.
