title: Extended BPPM Signal Design for Frame Synchronization in Modified MPPM
authors: Riku Sakai, Yusuke Kozawa, Hiromasa Habuchi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In this paper, a synchronization method for a modified multi-pulse pulse position modulation system consisting of binary PPM and multi-pulse PPM is considered. In particular, a method to extend the binary PPM signal used as a synchronization signal is proposed. The mean retention time and mean recovery time characteristics against the average SNR per bit are clarified by theoretical analysis. Consequently, it is shown that the average retention time of the proposed system is almost equivalent to that of the conventional system. Furthermore, it is found that the proposed system is superior to the conventional system in average recovery time.

title: 3D Point Cloud Registration Based on Planes Extracted Using a Neural Network
authors: Koichi Urakami, Ryo Kato
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: 3D Point cloud registration is a critical technique in fields such as infrastructure maintenance, urban planning, and disaster response. Although the Iterative Closest Point (ICP) algorithm is widely used, its accuracy often degrades due to noise from non-overlapping regions. Recently, neural network-based methods have also been proposed, but their effectiveness drops significantly when the input point clouds are not nearly identical. In this study, we propose a novel registration method that uses a neural network to detect high-precision planar regions, followed by alignment based solely on these planes. Experimental results show that limiting the registration process to selected planes significantly reduces the impact of noise, improving accuracy in scenarios with partial overlap.

title: Effective Fine-Tuning of Vision Transformers with Low-Rank Adaptation for Privacy-Preserving Image Classification
authors: Haiwei Lin, Shoko Imaizumi, Hitoshi Kiya
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: We propose a low-rank adaptation method for training privacy-preserving vision transformer (ViT) models that efficiently freezes pre-trained ViT model weights. In the proposed method, trainable rank decomposition matrices are injected into each layer of the ViT architecture, and moreover, the patch embedding layer is not frozen, unlike in the case of the conventional low-rank adaptation methods. The proposed method allows us not only to reduce the number of trainable parameters but to also maintain almost the same accuracy as that of full-time tuning.

title: Enhancing Image Classifier Robustness via Prompt-Based Counterfactual Data-Augmentation with Intermediate Transitions
authors: Tomoya Mitsui, Ren Togo, Naoki Saito, Takahiro Ogawa, Miki Haseyama
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a counterfactual data-augmentation framework that generates factual, counterfactual, and intermediate images from class-level prompts—without requiring original data edits—and improves classifier robustness via semantically rich, smoothly interpolated augmentations. Conventional data-augmentation relies on visual transformations, while counterfactual generation introduces semantic changes but still edits original images. In contrast, our method probes for fragile concepts and generates continuous counterfactual images along concept axes without original data, enabling targeted robustness enhancement. We fine-tune only the classification head of a pretrained ResNet-50 with approximately 4k slider images. This achieves HardImageNet accuracy gains comparable to editing-based retraining, without original images or complex pipelines.

title: Towards Robust Prediction of Tobacco Box Logistics System Status: A Multi-Feature Framework with Dynamic Graph Learning
authors: Kaihua Yang, Songliang You, Zhouyi He, Wei Ding, Shubiao Li, Zhongmin Zhang, Cheng Xu, Dingtao Lu, Jianfeng Zhang, Chunhui Zhao
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: The process of tobacco blending and flavoring plays a decisive role in the quality of finished products and production efficiency in the tobacco shred process, and the fluctuation of blending flow is often closely related to the operati ng status of the logistics system. In view of the complex structure and significant dynamic changes of the tobacco box logistics system, this paper combines the track topology and transportation behavior of the tobacco box logistics system to design a multi-feature prediction framework that integrates dynamic graph structure learning, graph attention mechanism, and time series modeling. To address the challenge of limited and sparse source data, our model realizes the effective fusion of dynamic and static information by sharing the dynamic flow information with significant time series gradient changes and static distribution information, significantly improving the prediction performance and strengthening the representation and adaptability to complex working conditions. Experiments based on real production data show that the proposed method can achieve a refined prediction of future logistics status.

title: DRL-based Network Slicing for Unifying 5G and Wi-Fi Networks
authors: Ranyin Wang, Vasilis Friderikos, Toktam Mahmoodi
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: The growing complexity of next-generation telecommunication networks demands more intelligent and adaptive management approaches to address the diverse requirements of emerging services. This paper proposes a novel network slicing framework that integrates the Multi-Access Technology Real-Time Intelligent Controller (mATRIC) within the O-RAN system, enabling resource unification of 5G and Wi-Fi networks and efficient allocation. The framework dynamically adapts to unify the 5G and Wi-Fi access technologies. Specifically, we propose slice deployment policies based on two Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) algorithms: the on-policy Trust Region Policy Optimization (TRPO) and the off-policy Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) approaches, which aims to optimize slice deployments across varying service requirements. To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed policies, we compare them against the on-policy Advantage Actor-Critic (A2C) and off-policy Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) methods. Extensive simulations demonstrate that the on-policy algorithms achieve superior performance in terms of slice acceptance ratios and resource utilization, highlighting their potential to enhance slice deployment in future heterogeneous networks beyond 5G and into 6G.

title: Evaluating the Resilience of 2D Conferencing Platforms in VR Under Packet Loss: A Pilot Study
authors: A. Adeyemi-Ejeye, X. Dong
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: This preliminary study investigates the impact of packet loss on commercial 2D video conferencing systems, specifically Microsoft Teams and Google Meet, when used within a virtual reality (VR) workspace. These platforms, treated as black-box systems, were accessed through head-mounted displays (HMDs) via the Immersed VR application. Participants engaged in a gesture-based charade game under varying packet loss conditions, alternating between gesture-only (Mimer) and audioenabled (Guesser) roles. Early results from 28 sessions (14 per platform) indicate a noticeable degradation in audiovisual experience as packet loss increases, particularly for gesture-based users. Microsoft Teams demonstrated greater resilience compared to Google Meet, although these findings remain exploratory. The study lays the groundwork for a more comprehensive Quality of Experience (QoE) evaluation. Future work will include additional participants and integrate metrics such as Simulator Sickness (SSQ), NASA TLX, and Quality of Interaction (QoI) to support a fuller assessment of conferencing feasibility in immersive settings.

title: Performance Analysis of YOLO Models for Real-Time Surveillance Object Detection
authors: Lochana Balivada, Priyadharshini S
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: The task of object detection has become a crucial part of many video surveillance applications in real-time including security monitoring, anomaly detection, and traffic management. With advancements in deep learning, YOLObased models have established themselves as the benchmark for fast and accurate detection of object. However, the suitability of recent You Only Look Once (YOLO) architectures for real-time surveillance scenarios remains underexplored. In this work, we conduct a performance analysis of YOLOv9c and YOLOv10n architectures for object detection in surveillance videos in real-time. The models were evaluated on the VIRAT video surveillance dataset containing a diverse collection of surveillance footage, with objects ranging from pedestrians and vehicles to other moving entities. Quantitative and qualitative metrics, including mAP, precision, recall, and accuracy, were considered to assess their effectiveness. Our analysis reveals that YOLOv9c outperforms YOLOv10n in accuracy and detection robustness, while YOLOv10n demonstrates superior performance in terms of computational efficiency, making it a better choice for systems with hardware constraints. These findings provide valuable insights into selecting YOLO architectures tailored to real-time surveillance applications.

title: The next level of user experience for mobile devices with inertial MEMS sensors
authors: Gerhard Lammel, Ossi Mäenpää, Zhenrong Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: Inertial MEMS sensors have been integral to consumer electronics for over two decades, initially enabling functionalities like screen rotation and motion-based gaming. With the pervasive use of smartphones, earbuds, and smartwatches, new challenges arise regarding user experience. Specifically, many people suffer from motion sickness from reading or working on mobile screens (such as mobile phones, laptops, etc.) while travelling in a car or other vehicles. Displaying motion cues is a promising approach but needs more than accelerometer data to indicate the orientation to alleviate or even eliminate the symptoms of motion sickness. Another common user experience shortcoming is wind noise outdoors or while riding on a bike, which makes telephone communication almost impossible. Bone conduction microphones are known for harsh environments. The challenge for consumer electronics is the integration in miniaturized earables and with good audio capturing quality. This paper examines how advanced inertial MEMS sensors and sensor fusion techniques can address these challenges, presenting practical implementation examples.

title: Construction and Application of Multi-Layered Urban Digital Twin Platform Integrating Open Data and 3D Visualization
authors: Yasuo Kawai
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In this study, we developed a digital twin platform that enables the multilayered visualization of urban information by integrating Unity and Cesium with open 3D city models (PLATEAU and Photorealistic 3D Tiles). The platform incorporates external datasets with spatial attributes, such as flood inundation hazard zones, and allows for real-time control of visual mappings. Moreover, by linking spatial reproduction displays, the system facilitates intuitive understanding of multifaceted risks—including building heights—that are difficult to grasp using conventional 2D visualization methods.

title: AI-Driven Cross-Layer Modulation Towards 6G
authors: Ning Wei, Zhen Yang, Xingguang Wei, Xiaojing Xu, Ruiqi Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: A promising artificial intelligence (AI)-driven cross-layer modulation is proposed to perform the bit-symbol mapping for the multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) transmission mode in the next generation wireless communication system. Unlike the prior modulation technologies, multiple influence factors including he constellation mapping, the number of spatial layers, layer mapping and power allocation among spatial layers are simultaneously taken into account in the proposed method pursuing for spectral efficiency maximization via auto-encoder (AE) model. In this paper, a joint optimization subject to influence factors above for the cross-layer modulation is fulfilled based on the AE framework for simplifying the design complexity and achieving a better performance. Simulation results demonstrate that the block error rate (BLER) performance of the proposed cross-layer modulation is beyond the traditional scheme by around 1 dB as a result of the learned bit-symbol mapping for spatial layers.

title: Securing Task-Oriented Semantic Communications: A Physical-Layer Solution
authors: Zhengyang Li, Anbang Zhang, Ruidong Li, Jia Ye, Shuping Dang, Shuaishuai Guo
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Existing end-to-end task-oriented semantic communication (ToSC) systems rely on deep neural network-based joint source and channel coding (DeepJSCC) architecture, which can extract and transmit task-relevant information for remote task inference. Although this architecture provides an efficient communication method, it poses specific security issues. Since DeepJSCC delivers task-related data without encryption, the risks of signal interception and reverse inference increase. This paper provides a physical layer solution for security protection via precoding optimization. We compare the proposed method with the traditional physical layer security strategy, which aims to maximize secrecy capacity under different task classifiers. Simulation results show the superiority of the proposed method in securing the task-inference performance.

title: SSM-based Sequential Recommendation Considering Short-term Dependencies of Time and Adjacency
authors: Keito Kozaki, Keigo Sakurai, Ren Togo, Takahiro Ogawa, Miki Haseyama
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Sequential recommendation focuses on capturing user interests based on the chronological order of user’s interaction history. Recently, State-Space Model (SSM), a state-of-the-art time-series machine learning model, has attracted attention in sequential recommendation modeling. SSM-based sequential recommendation models can effectively capture long-term user preferences, but modeling short-term dependencies is difficult. In this paper, we propose a new sequential recommendation model, which complements the short-term dependencies of SSM-based models in two aspects: item adjacencies and time intervals. To capture the adjacency between items, a graph structure is constructed from the sequences, and the time interval between items is captured in the time-aware SSM layer. Extensive experiments on two real-world datasets show that our model consistently outperforms state-of-the-art recommendation models.

title: A Review of Mechanisms of Lightning Injuries
authors: Gabriel Simião Dos Santos, Walter Aguiar Martins Junior, Hélio Eiji Sueta, Ronald L. Holle, Mary Ann Cooper, Danilo Ferreira de Souza
publish: 2025 IEEE ESW Brazil – Electrical Safety Workshop Brazil (ESW Brazil)
abstract: Lightning represents a critical atmospheric hazard, with direct and indirect injury mechanisms well-established in the literature. Currently, six mechanisms are recognized (five direct and one indirect), to which all officially recorded fatalities are ascribed. However, this study highlights that additional deaths occur from secondary effects, such as fires, failures in essential services (e.g., electrical power), and panic in mass gatherings, triggered by electrical discharges. Such fatalities, although linked to lightning as a primary cause, remain underreported due to a lack of proper classification. The application of eligibility criteria in the Scopus database revealed 302 publications by the end of 2023. Of these, 57 fully satisfied the inclusion criteria. The analysis revealed significant underreporting of fatalities associated with secondary effects, reinforcing the gap in existing classifications. The absence of formal categorization for these cases compromises statistical accuracy, impacting risk assessment and public policy formulation. The results highlight the need to expand classification systems to include secondary effects, ensuring a more accurate representation of lightning’s societal impact. This restructuring will facilitate the development of more effective protection guidelines, safety standards, and prevention mechanisms. The study concludes that integrating these factors into official statistics is crucial for mitigating risks and saving lives, providing a technical basis for advancements in public safety and disaster management.

title: Distributionally Robust Model Predictive Control with Mixture of Gaussian Processes
authors: Jingyi Wu, Chao Ning
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: Despite the success of Gaussian process based Model Predictive Control (MPC), its applicability scope is greatly hindered by multimodal disturbances that are prevalent in real-world settings. Here we propose a novel Mixture of Gaussian Processes based Distributionally Robust MPC (MoGP-DR-MPC) framework for linear time-invariant systems subject to potentially multimodal state-dependent disturbances. This framework utilizes MoGP to automatically determine the number of modes from disturbance data. Using the mean and variance information provided by each mode-specific predictive distribution, it constructs a data-driven state-dependent ambiguity set, which allows for flexible and fine-grained disturbance modeling. Based on this ambiguity set, we impose Distributionally Robust Conditional Value-at-Risk (DR-CVaR) constraints to effectively achieve distributional robustness against errors in the predictive distributions. To address the computational challenge posed by these constraints in the resulting MPC problem, we equivalently reformulate the DR-CVaR constraints into tractable second-order cone constraints. Furthermore, we provide theoretical guarantees on the recursive feasibility and stability of the proposed framework. The enhanced control performance of MoGP-DR-MPC is validated through both numerical experiments and simulations on a quadrotor system, demonstrating notable reductions in closed-loop cost by 17% and 4% respectively compared against Gaussian process based MPC.

title: Global Funnel Control of Single-Link Manipulators With Flexible Loads
authors: Rui-Bo Gao, Jin-Xi Zhang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: This paper is dealt with the problem of global funnel control (FC) of the flexible single-Link manipulators with flexible loads. It is focused on the cases of unknown internal dynamics, nonlinear virtual control coefficients and completely unknown closed-loop dynamics, which render the existing solutions infeasible. To overcome these challenges, a flexible FC scheme is proposed in this paper. It achieves reference tracking with the predefined accuracy and settling time under any initial condition of the closed-loop system, despite the totally unknown nonlinearities and the unmatched disturbances. The strategy eliminates the requirements for parameter identification, function approximation, derivative calculation and disturbance estimation, and shows a control simplicity. The above theoretical results are verified by a experiment on a serial flexible link robotic manipulator.

title: Trust-Driven Multi-Criteria Optimization for UAV-Assisted IoT Networks
authors: Muhammad Omair Butt, Muhammad Naeem, Waleed Ejaz
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Trustworthy communication is essential for the success of sixth-generation (6G) networks, enabling seamless and reliable interactions across diverse connected Internet of things (IoT) devices and systems. Uncrewed aerial vehicles (UAVs) are expected to play a pivotal role in this ecosystem by facilitating low-latency communication and promoting efficient resource utilization through flexible deployment strategies. In this context, we propose a trust-driven framework for UAV-assisted mobile edge computing (MEC). Initially, UAVs are deployed using the K-means clustering algorithm to maximize coverage. We then formulate an optimization problem that simultaneously targets several conflicting objectives: (i) maximize the trust level of serving UAVs; (ii) minimize computational latency for IoT devices tasks; (iii) maximize the number of served IoT devices; and (iv) balance the trade-off between maximizing trust and minimizing service provisioning cost. UAV trustworthiness is modeled as a composite metric encompassing success rate, security score, communication stability, computational resource availability, and energy sufficiency. To solve this problem, we develop a penalty-guided optimization (PGO) algorithm that guides relaxed binary decision variables toward integer solutions, followed by refinement using sequential quadratic programming. Simulations demonstrate that the PGO algorithm outperforms baseline relaxation methods and achieves performance close to the optimal branch-and-bound approach, while significantly reducing computational complexity. Additionally, unequally weighted trust metrics yield better UAV trust levels as compared to equal weighting, highlighting the advantage of adaptive trust modeling. The proposed UAV trust evaluation framework and deployment strategy thus collectively lead to enhanced network accessibility, reliability, and utility in aerial IoT networks.

title: Federated Learning for UAV-based Spectrum Sensing: Enhancing Accuracy Through SNR-Weighted Model Aggregation
authors: Kürşat Tekbıyık, Güneş Karabulut Kurt, Antoine Lesage-Landry
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: The increasing demand for data usage in wireless communications requires using wider bands in the spectrum, especially for backhaul links. Yet, allocations in the spectrum for non-communication systems inhibit merging bands to achieve wider bandwidth. To overcome this issue, spectrum-sharing or opportunistic spectrum utilization by secondary users stands out as a promising solution. However, both approaches must minimize interference to primary users. Therefore, spectrum sensing becomes vital for such opportunistic usage, ensuring the proper operation of the primary users. Although this problem has been investigated for two-dimensional networks, unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) networks need different approaches concerning three-dimensional space, its challenges, and opportunities. For this purpose, we propose a federated learning (FL)-based method for spectrum sensing in UAV networks to account for their distributed nature and limited computational capacity. FL enables local training without sharing raw data while guaranteeing the privacy of local users, lowering communication overhead, and increasing data diversity. Furthermore, we develop a federated aggregation method, namely FedSNR, that considers the signal-to-noise ratio observed by UAVs to acquire a global model. The numerical results show that the proposed architecture and the aggregation method outperform traditional methods.

title: Interactive Brain Activity Enhancement Using Hand-Based Exercises: A Game for Alzheimer Patients
authors: A.R Dhedeep Reddy, M Hareni, Shamil Saidu Mohamed, Cj Harini, Suja Palaniswamy
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: This paper presents an intelligent, deep learningbased interactive rehabilitation platform designed to enhance cognitive and motor functions in individuals with neurological impairments such as Alzheimer’s disease. By leveraging MediaPipe for real-time hand tracking and a custom Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for gesture classification, the system translates hand movements into meaningful therapeutic exercises within a gamified environment. The adaptive nature of the game, powered by deep learning models, ensures personalized progression and sustained user engagement through real-time feedback, scoring, and challenge scaling. The platform promotes neuroplasticity by synchronizing motor tasks with cognitive stimuli, offering an accessible and cost-effective solution that can be deployed in clinical as well as home-based settings. This fusion of computer vision and deep learning represents a significant advancement in smart cognitive rehabilitation technologies.

title: Resource-Constrained OCT Classification via Adaptive Distillation and Optimized Training
authors: Yan-Ci Chen, Chia-I Su, Yi-Hong Yeh, Yi-Rui Chiu, Cheng-Hung Lin, Cheng-Kai Lu, Tzu-Lun Huang, Jia-Kang Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Clinical adoption of large deep learning models (e.g., ResNet-50) for optical coherence tomography (OCT) image classification is often limited by computational overhead. We present a lightweight, efficient MobileNetV2 Lite student model, distilled from a ResNet-50 teacher using an adaptive framework with dynamic loss weighting, OneCycleLR, and RandomAffine augmentation. Our model achieved 93.8% accuracy on the OCT-C8 dataset, comparable to ShuffleNetV2 (93.9%), yet boasts significantly reduced inference latency and model size. This demonstrates its suitability for real-time, resource-constrained clinical settings.

title: A Novel Approach to SME Security: Integrating Hardware Primitives on COTS Platforms
authors: Nico Mexis, Tolga Arul, Nikolaos Athanasios Anagnostopoulos, Stefan Katzenbeisser
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: The supply chain and other areas related to Operational Technology (OT) represent critical components of industrial operations. However, their security is often overlooked. Small and Medium-sized Enterprises (SMEs) in particular tend to avoid addressing OT security due to the associated costs, time, and effort. This inaction frequently results in inadequate OT security, leaving systems with highly attractive attack surfaces. To address this gap, especially within the SME framework, we build on the concept of IT/OT convergence, by proposing a novel security approach based on the integration of lightweight hardware security primitives into OT hardware. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to examine the feasibility of combining the use of Commercial Off-The-Shelf (COTS) Physical Unclonable Functions (PUFs) and True Random Number Generators (TRNGs) in the context of the Industrial Internet of Things (IIoT).

title: Improving the Recognition Probability of Image Based Text
authors: Hyeonggyu Sim, Changhyun Kim, Jihun Kim, Minseok Choi, Nayoung Jung, Woong Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Recent advances in optical character recognition (OCR) have demonstrated high accuracy in standard environments such as document scanning and smartphone camera usage. However, recognizing stylized or decorative text in images—such as those found on signboards or advertisements—remains a challenge. To address this issue, we propose a hybrid model that integrates a Transformer-based OCR architecture (TrOCR) with Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA), a parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT) method. By leveraging a custom dataset containing images of stylized text, our approach aims to enhance recognition accuracy while maintaining low computational cost. Although the performance improvements were limited, this study highlights the feasibility of applying PEFT strategies to lightweight OCR adaptation in real-world scenarios.

title: Jamming Detection in Cell-Free MIMO with Dynamic Graphs
authors: Ali Hossary, Laura Crosara, Stefano Tomasin
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Jamming attacks pose a critical threat to wireless networks, particularly in cell-free massive MIMO systems, where distributed access points and user equipment (UE) create complex, time-varying topologies. This paper proposes a novel jamming detection framework leveraging dynamic graphs and graph convolution neural networks (GCN) to address this challenge. By modeling the network as a dynamic graph, we capture evolving communication links and detect jamming attacks as anomalies in the graph evolution. A GCN-Transformers-based model, trained with supervised learning, learns graph embeddings to identify malicious interference. Performance evaluation in simulated scenarios with moving UEs, varying jamming conditions and channel fadings, demonstrates the method’s effectiveness, which is assessed through accuracy and F1 score metrics, achieving promising results for effective jamming detection.

title: AI-Driven Framework for Automating Infrastructure Provisioning and Compliance Validation in Cloud-Native Environments
authors: Hephzibah A. Igwe
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: As consumer-facing systems scale in complexity and regulation, ensuring security and compliance throughout the software development lifecycle becomes critical. This work introduces an intelligent, automated approach for continuous compliance monitoring and secure infrastructure deployment in cloud-native environments. Using Google’s Vertex AI as a secure orchestration layer and AWS Systems Manager (SSM) and EventBridge as control mechanisms, we enable continuous enforcement of security policies. The approach integrates Infrastructure as Code (IaC), cloud event triggers, and machine learning models to detect anomalies and enforce controls at deploy-time. Our experimental validation demonstrates 92.4% accuracy in detecting security misconfigurations, 45% reduction in deployment latency, and $78 \%$ decrease in manual security interventions. The framework successfully processed 3,250 deployment scenarios with an average response time of 3.1 seconds. Designed generically for regulated enterprise environments, this methodology minimizes manual error, accelerates secure deployments, and aligns with Zero Trust principles. We outline architecture elements, automation flows, and compatibility with services like GuardDuty and AWS Inspector, demonstrating that AI-orchestrated infrastructure security is not only feasible but increasingly necessary in future consumer ecosystems.

title: Real-Time Safe and Smooth Visual Servoing for Robot Manipulators via Reinforcement Learning_supp1-3634401.mp4
authors: Jianliang Mao
publish: N/A
abstract: Real-time collision avoidance is a critical challenge in visual servoing control for safe robot manipulation. This article presents a model-free framework that integrates reinforcement learning (RL) with real-time collision detection (RCD), enabling secure and smooth visual servoing in dynamic environments. The reward function in the RL framework is carefully designed to simultaneously minimize tracking errors, promote motion smoothness, and enforce collision avoidance. Beyond policy optimization through RL, a two-step real-time trajectory blending (RTB) scheme, consisting of a Butterworth filter (BF) and polynomial interpolation, is developed to further refine the generated trajectories and ensure smooth joint velocity profiles. Furthermore, the soft actor-critic (SAC) algorithm is employed for policy learning, and the performance is compared with two widely used methods, namely proximal policy optimization (PPO) and twin delayed deep deterministic policy gradient (TD3). Experimental results on a 6-degree-of-freedom (6-DoF) robot manipulator demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach in achieving safe and smooth visual servoing in real time.

title: Deploying UAVs and Surveillance Cameras for Continuous Omnidirectional Monitoring_supp1-3642129.pdf
authors: Haihan Zhang
publish: N/A
abstract: This paper addresses the <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">J</u>oint deployment of <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">U</u>nmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and surveillance ca<underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">M</u>eras with <underline xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">P</u>ath planning (JUMP), aiming to deploy a fixed number of UAVs and budget-limited surveillance cameras, to achieve continuous omnidirectional monitoring. Specifically, the objective is to maximize the monitoring durations of target objects in each of all horizontal directions within a given task duration. We propose an approach for JUMP, which is proved to be NP-hard. Our approach achieves a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\frac{1}{6}-\varepsilon _{1}$</tex-math></inline-formula> approximation ratio in general and <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\frac{1}{4}-\varepsilon _{1}$</tex-math></inline-formula> when camera costs are uniform. Firstly, we introduce spatio-temporal discretization to approximate JUMP. Secondly, we partition the solution space of JUMP from spatial perspective and refine the space by addressing a variant of obstacle-avoiding shortest path problem spatio-temporal perspective. Thirdly, we reformulate the problem as a classical problem of Monotone Submodular set function Maximization with one partition Matroid and two Knapsack constraints (MSMMK). To address MSMMK, we propose a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\frac{1}{6(1+\varepsilon )}$</tex-math></inline-formula> approximation algorithm, which outperforms the state-of-the-art with the same time complexity in general. Specifically, our algorithm achieves a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\frac{1}{4(1+\varepsilon )}$</tex-math></inline-formula> approximation ratio for special cases. Simulation results demonstrate our proposed approach outperforms five benchmark algorithms, yielding enhancements 13%-1446%. Moreover, field experiment results indicate that our approach surpasses comparison algorithms, achieving enhancements 23%-265%.

title: FlowMamba: Building Damage Assessment via Optics Flow-based State Space Model
authors: Xin Guo, Xudong Kang, Zihao Wang, Qiong Wu, Puhong Duan, Bin Yang, Shutao Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Natural disasters pose a threat to the safety of human life and buildings. Rapid and accurate building damage assessment (BDA) on remote sensing images is crucial for disaster response and recovery. However, most methods are constructed on the ideal co-registered bitemporal remote sensing images, neglecting the misalignment in practice. In this paper, we propose a novel building damage assessment method, termed FlowMamba, which can effectively handle the offset between the pre- and post-disaster images in BDA task. Specifically, a vision mamba backbone with four stages is utilized to extract multi scale features from the pre- and post-disaster images. Then, a differential optical flow alignment module is designed to estimate shift matrix to align pre- and post-disaster features. Furthermore, a category distance-aware loss function is tailored for the BDA task, which replaces fixed binary values of the penalty factors in to soft values of inter-class distance. Extensive experiments on the xBD dataset, the BRIGHT dataset and four out-of-distribution disaster scenarios validate the robustness and effectiveness of the proposed FlowMamba. Our code is available at https://github.com/flying318/FlowMamba.

title: Temporal Refinement of Muscle Synergies in Skilled Golf Swings_supp1-3642830.docx
authors: Hyung-Soon Park
publish: N/A
abstract: Muscle synergies, defined as coordinated activations of muscle groups, are thought to simplify motor control by reducing dimensionality and providing a repertoire of adaptable motor solutions. While prior research has investigated synergy adaptation in clinical populations and healthy individuals, most evidence stems from constrained or low-degree-of-freedom (DOF) tasks. A critical gap remains in understanding how synergies are refined in high-DOF, performance-driven contexts that demand full-body coordination. To address this, we examined neuromuscular strategies in professional and amateur golfers performing a 7-iron swing. Electromyographic recordings from 27 muscles, along with kinematic and kinetic data, were analyzed to identify kinematic predictors of clubhead speed and their associated muscle activation patterns. Muscle synergy and clustering analysis of these key muscles revealed two group-invariant synergies, pelvis rotation and plantarflexion, whose peak activation timings were significantly correlated with clubhead speed. A significant subject-specific synergy and a significant amateur-exclusive synergy further highlighted how adaptation involves both individualized tuning and filtering of suboptimal strategies. These findings suggest that expert performance in complex, high-DOF tasks relies on temporal refinement of existing synergies rather than structural reorganization, highlighting the importance of managing, rather than minimizing, motor complexity in the acquisition of advanced motor skills. Furthermore, our approach for identifying neuromuscular patterns linked to performance outcomes provides a foundation for targeted training interventions aimed at enhancing or restoring complex movement patterns.

title: Highly sensitive QCM humidity sensor based on Nafion/cellulose nanocrystal nanocomposite
authors: Weihang Zhang, Xiao Yong, Qing Zhou, Xingpeng Chen, Zuquan Wu
publish: IEEE Sensors Journal
abstract: In this paper, a novel Nafion/cellulose nanocrystal (CNC) nanocomposite was synthesized by mixing method, which has been fabricated onto Quartz Crystal Microbalance (QCM) as humidity sensor via drop-coating method. The humidity sensitive characteristic of the QCM sensor is investigated in various relative humidity (RH). The experimental result indicates that the Nafion/CNC exhibits excellent sensitivity, slight humidity hysteresis (ca. 4.3%), good repeatability and high stability. Among them, the sensitivity of Nafion/CNC (ca. 48.43 Hz/RH) is higher than that of CNC (ca. 1.31 times) and Nafion (ca. 1.43 times). The humidity sensitive mechanism of Nafion/CNC is also discussed by the Langmuir isothermal adsorption model. Meanwhile, the structure and morphology of the synthesized products are analyzed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM), respectively. Additionally, the Nafion/CNC humidity sensor has been applied for respiration monitoring, demonstrating good potential for application.

title: MAM: A zkSNARK-based Protocol for Privacy-Preserving Cross-Metaverse Asset Interoperability
authors: Fady R. Alkhateeb, Adib Habbal
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The rapid growth of the metaverse has led to a scattered ecosystem in which digital assets are deployed on different blockchain platforms. This disintegration creates significant challenges for interoperability, as users need secure, decentralized, and privacy-preserving protocols to enable interoperability between chains. Existing solutions typically depend on centralized exchanges or third-party relays, introducing a single point of failure and potential privacy risks. We propose MAM (Metaverse Asset Management), a novel user-centric protocol utilizing zkSNARK technology (Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-Interactive Argument of Knowledge) that enables seamless movement of metaverse assets across various blockchain platforms. MAM’s architecture ensures privacy by generating all zkSNARK proofs locally on the user’s machine, ensuring that sensitive data, including private keys and asset metadata, never leave the device. The protocol employs a secure one-time setup to distribute the global circuit-specific proving key, ensuring the permanent destruction of toxic-waste data. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that MAM achieves a constant and minimal proof size (192 bytes), low gas cost (281,107 Gas per verification), and an end-to-end asset transfer latency under 15 seconds, outperforming recent alternatives such as MetaOpera and MAP. Static security analysis confirms the robustness of MAM’s smart contracts against the most significant vulnerability types. This research enhances the state-of-the-art of privacy-preserving and scalable cross-metaverse interoperability, providing a practical approach for fully decentralized digital asset management and transfer across the Metaverse.

title: IDSE-YOLO: An Infrared Recognition Model for Substation Equipment
authors: Hongcheng Ding, Jianfeng Zheng
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: The issue of inadequate infrared recognition accuracy for substation equipment is addressed in this paper through the proposal of the IDSE-YOLO model, a high-precision infrared recognition model for substation equipment. The primary goal of this study is to improve recognition accuracy in complex backgrounds and low-resolution scenarios. It incorporates Dual Depthwise Convolution (DDConv) and Multi-scale Efficient Channel Attention (MECA) to enhance computational capabilities and feature extraction efficiency. Additionally, a multi-scale loss function is designed with optimised regression loss, enabling precise target identification. Experimental results, based on proprietary datasets, show that the enhanced model demonstrates substantial improvements in key performance metrics such as Precision (P), Recall (R), and Mean Average Precision (mAP), when compared to existing models. Notably, a comparison with the baseline YOLOv13 model reveals that the IDSE-YOLO model achieves an mAP of 95.3%, marking a 5.5% improvement, without a significant increase in computational load or parameter overhead. The model’s deployment on edge devices for on-site image recognition further demonstrates its efficacy and practicality. The findings validate the IDSE-YOLO model as a highly effective and viable solution for deploying infrared recognition systems for substation equipment on embedded devices, offering a significant boost in recognition accuracy.

title: Hybrid MRR-Assisted Long-Range SDMA for RO-ISAC Systems in Industry IoT Applications
authors: Xin Xiong, Haochuan Wang, Sihua Shao, Chen Chen
publish: Journal of Lightwave Technology
abstract: Retro-reflective optical wireless systems provide a compelling solution for passive uplink in integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) applications. However, supporting practical uplink concurrency is hindered by two fundamental challenges: the limited operational range of modulated retro reflectors (MRRs) and the severe inter-tag uplink interference which becomes particularly severe in near–far scenarios. To overcome these limitations, we propose a system that achieves spatial division multiple access (SDMA) by co-designing a hybrid retro-reflector architecture with a successive interference can cellation (SIC)-based signal processing framework. The hybrid design on each tag integrates an unmodulated retro-reflector (URR) for ranging with an MRR that embeds an on-off keying (OOK) ID. At the receiver, our SIC framework leverages the distinct time delays from spatially diverse tags to resolve signal superposition, successfully recovering weaker, previously masked signals. We validate this approach through high-fidelity simulations parameterized by experimental data from a custom built, high-power optical test bed. Simulation results validate the concept, demonstrating simultaneous ranging and communication for two concurrent tags; the system achieves centimeter level ranging accuracy at a 5-meter range while maintaining a communication uplink of several hundred hertz per tag at a bit-error rate below 10−3. Crucially, our analysis provides a comprehensive characterization of the system's performance bottlenecks, establishing the fundamental trade-off between light source bandwidth and the achievable tag concurrency.

title: AS-Level Topology Inference for Path-Aware Networking
authors: Yuxin Mao, Hongbin Luo, Zhiyuan Wang, Shan Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: As the frequency of cyber attacks (e.g., DDoS) continues to rise, it becomes increasingly crucial to trace malicious packets and identify which autonomous systems (ASes) they originate from and traverse through. Path-aware networking (PAN) architectures, forwarding packets based on in-packet path identifiers (PIDs), enable end-hosts to gain insights into the AS-level topology and facilitate AS-level path traceback. However, the study on AS-level topology inference and path traceback under PAN has been overlooked, primarily due to the diversity of path identification. Some PAN architectures (e.g., SCION) use deterministic PIDs to identify inter-domain paths, while others (e.g., CoLoR) adopt prefix-deterministic PIDs. In the latter, PID-Prefix is used to identify inter-domain paths, and PID-Suffix is reserved for additional security functions, making the inference problem complicated. This paper focuses on PAN with prefix-deterministic PIDs and investigates how to use in-packet PIDs to infer the AS-level topology. Our goal is to construct a tree-like AS-level topology with the corresponding PID-Prefixes based on in-packet PIDs. We first introduce two macro metrics (i.e., completion rate and precision rate) and two micro metrics (i.e., traceback division and traceback aggregation) to evaluate the inference accuracy. Furthermore, we propose an Alternating Expanding and Checking (AEC) algorithm for AS-level topology inference. AEC algorithm constructs the topology by iteratively expanding and checking the current topology. The expanding phase performs one-hop PID-Prefix inference and generates new child ASes, while the checking phase verifies the consistency of PID sequences with the current topology from the perspective of each new child AS. Experiments based on empirical Internet topology of 201 ASes show that the accuracy of AEC reaches 99.6% when the observer receives only 30 packets from each AS.

title: Robotic Double Patch Clamp Based on Interactive Mechanical Modeling for Functional Connectivity Measurement Between Neurons_supp2-3642790.mp4
authors: Qili Zhao
publish: N/A
abstract: Double patch clamp technique, using two micropipette electrodes to patch and measure electrophysiological signals of two neurons, is essential for investigating the functional connections between neurons in brain. However, the interactive mechanical disturbances from the dual-micropipette motions inside viscoelastic brain tissue cause dynamic drifts of neurons, making double patching low efficiency and challenging. In this paper, an interactive mechanical modeling of two micropipettes approaching two cells in elastic environment was established to estimate the dynamic drift of the cells. Based on that, a synchronous descent strategy, an appropriate relative position of two cells, and an online trajectory plan of two micropipettes were determined to improve double patch clamp efficiency. Finally, a robotic double patch clamp operation process was established for functional connectivity measurement between neurons in brain slice. The effectiveness of the proposed work is validated through both finite element modeling and experiments. The double patch clamp experiments on neurons in visual cortex demonstrate that our method achieves a 40% improvement in success rate and a 38% improvement in speed in comparison to the traditional manual method. With the above advantages, diverse functional connectivity activities between neurons were found using our system, paving a solid ground for further research.

title: Integrated Photoacoustic-Metabolomic Platform for Multimodal Assessment of Sepsis-Induced Brain Dysfunction_supp1-3637090.mp4
authors: Long Jin
publish: N/A
abstract: Sepsis-induced brain dysfunction (SIBD), a critical determinant of mortality and long-term neurological sequelae in sepsis patients. The mechanistic understanding of SIBD has been limited by conventional single-modality approaches, which fail to capture the complex oxygenation-metabolism interplay. Here, we present an integrated photoacoustic-metabolomic platform that combines high-resolution photoacoustic imaging with targeted metabolomics to comprehensively assess cerebral oxygenation and metabolic alterations during sepsis. Our imaging system provides high spatiotemporal resolution, enabling mapping of key parameters, including cerebral oxygen saturation (sO2), oxygen extraction fraction (OEF), and the spatial heterogeneity of oxygen metabolism. By integrating these imaging capabilities with region-specific metabolomic profiling, we uncover a dynamic relationship between sepsis-driven oxygenation disruptions and metabolic reprogramming. Specifically, we demonstrate that sepsis induces heterogeneous cortical hypoxia, dysregulated OEF dynamics, and a metabolic shift marked by enhanced glycolysis and suppressed pentose phosphate pathway activity in high-OEF regions. This multimodal platform not only advances our understanding of the pathophysiology of SIBD but also offers a powerful tool for early diagnosis, personalized therapeutic strategies, highlighting the promise in bedside monitoring and precision medicine applications in sepsis management.

title: Development of a Novel 7-DOF Position-Orientation Decoupled Microsurgical Robot with Motorized Instruments for Microvascular Anastomosis_supp1-3643333.mp4
authors: Chaoyang Shi
publish: N/A
abstract: This work introduces a novel compact 7-degree-of freedom (7-DOF) microsurgical robot with position-orientation decoupling capacity for microvascular anastomosis. The proposed system employs a modular architecture combining a proximal displacement platform for 3D small-stroke translation and a distal compact remote center of motion (RCM) mechanism for wide range orientation adjustment. This design meets the workspace requirements for microvascular anastomosis, requiring extensive orientation adjustments with minimal positional movement and reducing the system footprint. The parasitic motion reverse self-compensation method has been developed for motorized surgical instruments, effectively reducing operational resistance to improve precision. Theoretical analysis has been performed on both the RCM mechanism and motorized surgical instruments, and kinematics-based parameter optimization and data-driven calibration have been conducted to enhance superior performance. A prototype has been constructed, and its experimental validation demonstrated that the system achieved repeatability of 11.24 ± 2.31 μm (XY) and 12.46 ± 4.48 μm (YZ), and absolute positioning accuracy of 29.80 ± 12.27 μm (XY) and 37.02 ± 19.47 μm (YZ), meeting super-microsurgical requirements. Experiments that include needle-threading and stamen peeling tasks demonstrate the robot's superior dexterity and manipulation capabilities.

title: Novel Regular Hexagonal Six-Port Hybrid Couplers for Multibeam Applications
authors: Zhiwei Yin, He Zhu, Xiaojing Lv, Jiexin Lai, Yang Yang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article proposes a novel approach to implementing the 3-beam Nolen matrix (NM) using a compact planar six-port regular hexagonal coupler for multibeam applications. Compared to conventional NM designs, this design could significantly reduce the size of the matrix by using a regular hexagonal coupler. The six-port hybrid coupler is composed of two hexagons and a series of transmission lines connecting them. The power at each output port can be controlled by the impedance of the transmission lines. To verify this, two six-port couplers with the power division ratios of 1:1:1 and 1:2:1 are designed. The transmission coefficient of the first design is <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$5~\pm ~0.38$</tex-math> </inline-formula> dB. The return loss exceeds 20 dB, while the amplitude and phase fluctuations are within 0.9 dB and 14°, respectively, across 2.28–2.61 GHz. In addition, the return loss and isolation of the second design are better than 13.6 dB, while isolation is greater than 15.8 dB across 2.3–2.6 GHz. The size of these two six-port regular hexagonal couplers is both <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.59\times 0.37\lambda _{0}^{2}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, where <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$0.37\lambda _{0}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> represents the side length of this hexagonal shape, respectively. Furthermore, two prototypes are introduced to demonstrate the simplicity and effectiveness of the proposed approach in implementing both equal and unequal power division beamforming networks, while maintaining excellent RF performance in a compact design.

title: Enhancing Rogue-Emitter Rejection in Open-Set Specific Emitter Identification with Out-of-Distribution Signals
authors: Bowen Zhang, Fuhui Zhou, Rui Ding, Ming Xu, Chengda She, Qihui Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Consumer Electronics
abstract: With the rapid proliferation of consumer electronics, transmitter identification faces growing challenges in open-set wireless environments. Conventional deep learning-based open-set specific emitter identification (OS-SEI) methods rely solely on in-distribution(ID) emitter signals, often resulting in over-confident classifiers and limited rejection of rogue emitters. To address this, we propose an OS-SEI framework that first employs a residual shrinkage network (RSN) to robustly extract radio frequency fingerprints under noisy conditions. To alleviate classifier overconfidence, an adaptive energy-based regularization dynamically adjusts decision boundaries using class prototypes and energy statistics maintained via exponential moving averages. Furthermore, class-wise representative out-of-distribution (OOD) sampling is applied to select hard samples for each class. Finally, a dual-head deviation network (DHDN) with a soft deviation loss jointly models explicit and implicit deviations and aggregates their scores, enhancing detection of subtle distributional shifts. Experiments on the WiSig and the DroneDetect datasets demonstrate that our method outperforms existing methods in unknown transmitter rejection and overall robustness, making it well-suited for consumer electronics applications.

title: Detection of Model-based Planted Pseudo-cliques in Random Dot Product Graphs by the Adjacency Spectral Embedding and the Graph Encoder Embedding
authors: Tong Qi, Vince Lyzinski
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: In this paper, we explore the capability of both the Adjacency Spectral Embedding (ASE) and the Graph Encoder Embedding (GEE) for capturing an embedded pseudo-clique structure in the random dot product graph setting. In both theory and experiments, we demonstrate that, in the absence of additional clean (i.e., without the implanted pseudo-clique) network data, this pairing of model and methods can yield worse results than the best existing spectral clique detection methods. However, these methods can be used to asymptotically localize the pseudo-cliques if additional clean, independent network data is provided. This demonstrates at once the methods' potential ability/inability to capture modestly sized pseudo-cliques and the methods' robustness to the model contamination giving rise to the pseudo-clique structure. To further enrich our analysis, we also consider the Variational Graph Auto-Encoder (VGAE) model in our simulation and real data experiments.

title: GEXPNET: a Novel Gene EXPression NETwork for Tumor Classification Using the ResNet-based Deep Learning Approach
authors: Faezeh Sadeghi, Mohammadreza Pourfard, Maryam Talebi Rostami, Seyed Ahmad Motamedi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: Accurate classification of cancer subtypes from mi croarray gene expression data remains challenging due to high dimensionality, class imbalance, and limited sample sizes. To address these issues, we propose GexpNet, a novel deep learning architecture specifically designed for gene expression analysis. GexpNet integrates an initial convolutional layer with dynamic multi-head residual blocks that employ heterogeneous kernel sizes and activation functions. These are followed by an adaptive dense classifier, enabling effective multi-scale feature extraction and robust classification. To reduce noise and overfitting, a customized preprocessing pipeline is introduced, comprising me dian imputation, quantile normalization, and supervised feature selection based on logistic regression. Evaluated on four publicly available datasets, GexpNet achieves 98.99% accuracy (95% CI: 98.57–99.43%) and 98.26% F1-score (95% CI: 97.51–99.01%) on the Mendeley dataset, outperforming prior deep learning models by up to 1.99%. Across three additional datasets, GexpNet con sistently exceeds 99% accuracy with minimal variance in 10-fold cross-validation, confirming its robustness and generalizability. Overall, these results highlight GexpNet as a robust, scalable, and generalizable framework for precision oncology applications.
