title: A Generative AI Mentoring System for Cultivating Cybersecurity Skills
authors: Moe Yamanaka, Keishiro Watanabe, Haruhisa Hasegawa
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: We propose a virtual mentoring system utilizing generative AI to cultivate cybersecurity skills and critical thinking. The system guides learners by encouraging reasoning, prompting "why" questions, and offering credible hints, instead of promoting rote memorization. It leverages Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) to provide accurate information from authoritative sources, enhancing the applicability of large language models (LLMs) in specialized domains such as cybersecurity. Our evaluation demonstrates that retrieving high-credibility information enhances the quality of hints and support, leading to better guidance of thinking and deeper understanding. This study shows the substantial potential of generative AI, particularly when integrated with RAG, to support thinking-centered cybersecurity education.

title: RCAN Based OTFS Signal Detection in the Presence of Hardware Impairments
authors: Amit Singh, Sanjeev Sharma, Kuntal Deka, Mohit Sharma, Daniel B. da Costa
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Orthogonal time-frequency space (OTFS) modulation is a promising technique for next-generation wireless communication, particularly in high-mobility scenarios. However, the performance of the OTFS modulation is degraded by hardware impairments (HIs), particularly at high frequencies and mobility. Thus, efficient signal detection is essential for reliable OTFS-based communication. To overcome this, various detectors, including convolutional neural networks (CNN), minimum mean square error (MMSE), and message passing (MP), have been explored in the literature, with CNN-based detectors demonstrating superior performance over MMSE and MP. In this work, we propose a residual channel attention network (RCAN) to robustly detect OTFS signal in the presence of HIs. Using deep residual learning and channel attention mechanisms to improve detection accuracy under varying channel conditions. Extensive simulations, considering different OTFS frame sizes, user mobility levels, and HI parameters, confirm that the proposed RCAN consistently outperforms conventional detectors, including CNN, in all scenarios evaluated. This makes RCAN a highly effective solution for OTFS-based high-mobility wireless communication systems, both with and without HI.

title: Bearing Remaining Useful Life Prediction Method Based on Dynamic Feature Selection and LSTM-KAN Modeling
authors: Yanwei Ma, Jingjing Liu, Yefeng Liu, Zhi Wei Du, Zeyu Zhang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: Accurate bearing remaining useful life (RUL) prediction is vital for health management but challenged by feature redundancy and complex condition degradation modeling. We propose a dynamic feature selection strategy and an LSTM-KAN hybrid model. An initial multi-domain feature set is constructed. A dynamic strategy using random forest regression and quantile analysis selects robust feature subsets across conditions. An LSTM-KAN network combines LSTM's temporal modeling with KAN's nonlinear approximation. PHM2012 experiments show the dynamic features reduce prediction error. LSTM-KAN outperforms LSTM and TCN, demonstrating superior late-stage stability and generalization.

title: Iterative Bayesian Model for Ground Point Detection
authors: Chien-Chou Lin, Shu-Ping Chen, Risma Septiana
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: This paper presents an iterative Bayesian model designed to remove non-ground points from point clouds, effectively filtering out background data and reducing computational overhead. By processing continuous point cloud scenes, the iterative approach enhances classification performance compared to the application of the Bayesian theorem alone. The model’s effectiveness is evaluated using two primary datasets: campus scenes and KITTI scenes. The proposed method achieves an accuracy of up to $98.6 \%$, demonstrating strong stability across diverse datasets, environments, and complex scenarios.

title: A Study on Improving the Accuracy of Wearable Devices to Alleviate Harvesting Workload
authors: Shuya Yazawa, Kohei Yamaguchi, Minori Hikawa-Endo, Ryosuke Yamanaka, Takayoshi Yano, Kazuo Soeno, Hiroki Shigemune
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Strawberries are a type of fruit that requires significant time and labor to product. In this study, we have developed a wearable fruit sorting aid device that can estimate the weight and grade of fruits using only the picking action. An inertial measurement unit (IMU) sensor was employed to capture hand movements, aiming to improve accuracy. Additionally, based on feedback indicating visibility issues with the display, we incorporated an audio feedback function. Furthermore, we focused on the phenomenon where the output of the magnetic sensor changes with the tilt angle of the IMU, and investigated its impact. Based on these findings, we proposed methods for improving accuracy. This device is expected to contribute to the efficiency and labor-saving of agricultural work by enabling simultaneous harvesting and sorting.

title: Lightweight and Trusted Authentication for Cross-Domain Operation of UAV Swarm
authors: Mingyue Xie, Lu Yu, Zheng Chang, Zhiwei Zhao, Tao Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: With the high-speed and low-latency connection capabilities brought by the wireless communications, the performance of unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) swarm for executing tasks such as emergency response, smart farming, and aerial base station has been significantly improved. As the use of UAVs becomes more prevalent in various tasks, the demand for cross-domain task allocation and operations continues to grow. Cross-domain task allocation enables the UAVs to flexibly execute tasks over a wider range, work together in different task domains, thereby improving operation efficiency. However, due to variations in management policies, authentication protocols, and security standards across various domains, to ensure the secure and reliable interoperability of UAVs across diverse domains, cross-domain authentication has become the primary line of defense for UAVs. In this paper, we propose a lightweight and trusted blockchain-based cross-domain authentication scheme for UAV swarm. To achieve a lightweight authentication process, we apply certificateless authentication and avoid costly operations for resource-constrained UAVs. Additionally, the trustworthiness of UAVs and domains is evaluated through credibility, which is stored on blockchain. We analyze the theoretical security of the proposed scheme, and extensive experiments demonstrate its efficiency.

title: A Fatigue-Aware Bicycle Type Recommendation for Cycle Tourism
authors: Hayato Tomisu, Shota Morita, Naoto Kai, Tomoki Yoshihisa
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Cycle tourism is a growing global market; yet, novices often struggle to plan enjoyable rides, facing a mismatch between their bicycle choice, terrain difficulty, and personal fitness. To address this gap, we present a fatigue-aware bicycle route simulator. Our system integrates a physics-based speed model with rider-specific parameters and a Training Stress Score-based fatigue model to predict performance and automatically recommend rest points along any given GPX route. We evaluated the simulator in a factorial experiment comprising 54 scenarios across three real-world routes in Wakayama, Japan. The results demonstrate that rider ability is the primary determinant of performance. Moreover, our findings show that e-bikes significantly enhance accessibility, reducing travel time for tourists by up to 38% on challenging terrain. This work provides a practical decision-support tool that enables tourism stakeholders to optimize rental fleets and generate tailored itineraries, thereby better aligning their services with the diverse needs and abilities of visitors.

title: An Interactive Application for Real-Time Circuit Education
authors: ZhenLin Zhou, Yihsin Ho
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study presents an augmented reality (AR) education application that visualizes dynamic current-voltage relationships in electronic circuits. By using breadboards as marker-embedded factors, the AR-based application shows real-time animations of series and parallel circuits to reflect electrical parameter changes through smartphone. The application implements resistance-driven modulation so that the user can adjust resistor values to change speed and current path correlating follow Ohm's Law principles; the Voltage-controlled visualization permitting 5-10V input adjustments to demonstrate proportional current variations. This interface provides novice learners with intuitive perception of abstract electrical concepts.

title: BuffetAR: A Food Recognition System with Stereo Audio Cues for Blind Users in Conference Dining
authors: Chun-Nan Chi, Jia-Lien Hsu, Chi-Huang Hung
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: BuffetAR is an AI-powered system designed to assist visually impaired individuals in buffet settings. It combines YOLO-based food detection with monocular depth estimation to identify and localize dishes. Using spatially rendered stereo audio, detected items are announced in order of proximity, enabling users to perceive both identity and location without relying on vision. A preliminary study shows BuffetAR enhances food identification speed, spatial awareness, and user confidence, demonstrating the potential of combining computer vision and stereo audio for assistive dining.

title: A Goal-Oriented Effective Communication Scheme via Action Innovations
authors: Yigit Yildirim, Orhan Arikan
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: In future wireless communication, an exponential increase in connected devices and the need for safety-critical and data-intensive applications like Autonomous Vehicles (AVs) and eXtended Reality (XR) will render large-scale intelligent agent deployments infeasible. To address this, we propose a novel framework where a centralized Smart Service Provider (SSP) transmits actions to agents, balancing effectiveness and transmission costs. Our approach leverages the observation that both semantic information extraction from raw sensor data and action generation from semantic states are many-to-one mappings. We model action decisions using stochastic policies from Reinforcement Learning (RL) literature. A key novelty is our focus on when to transmit. Namely, the SSP, observing what an agent observes, estimates the agent’s likely action. Based on the weighted statistical distance between the SSP’s policy and the agent’s estimated policy, the SSP decides whether an "action innovation" has occurred, and if so, transmits an action to the agent. Simulations demonstrate that transmitting only 10% of the time is sufficient to satisfy goals with up to 1% deviation, and compression rates up to 8,108:1 are achievable compared to existing standards. This "effective communication" scheme significantly reduces transmission overhead while maintaining high performance.

title: Empathy Enhanced by Vibratory Biofeedback Triggered by Other’s Physiological Arousal
authors: Tatsuya Kitajima, Shogo Okamoto, Yuki Kosuge
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Previous studies have shown that bodily arousal enhances empathy toward others. Further, mechanical vibration stimuli applied to the upper body can amplify emotions during activities like video viewing or gameplay. This study aimed to promote empathy by delivering vibration stimuli triggered by a partner’s physiological arousal. Eleven participants formed pairs and played a cooperative game with different roles. Skin conductance responses (SCR) were measured, and vibration stimuli were presented when a partner’s SCR increased. Participants reported greater empathy when vibration stimuli were delivered compared to when they were not. These findings suggest a method for enhancing emotional connection between individuals in interactive settings.

title: An in-Situ Smartwatch-Assisted Approach to Emotional Eating and Dietary Self-Regulation
authors: Tzu-Ling Huang, Ko-Chiu Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Stress-induced emotional eating has become a critical issue in modern society, especially in the post-pandemic era. With advancements in smartwatch technology, real-time stress monitoring and user self-reporting have created new opportunities for behavioral adjustment. This study designs a system that integrates smartwatch-based automatic data collection and Ecological Momentary Assessment (EMA) with mindful eating principles and alternative behavior suggestions. The system aims to enhance users' awareness of their emotional and eating behaviors, interrupt the vicious cycle of emotional eating, and promote healthier dietary habits.

title: RIS-Assisted Covert ISAC via Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Fangtao Yang, Chengwen Xing, Haichao Wei, Minho Jo, Na Deng, Nan Zhao, Dusit Niyato
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: The combination of reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS) and integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) can improve the resource utilization in non-line-of-sight scenarios. However, the private information in this situation raises security concerns when the transmission behavior is detected by wardens. Against this background, we investigate a covert transmission problem in an RIS assisted ISAC system. Specifically, we obtain a tractable form of covertness constraint in terms of minimum detection error probability via the optimal detection threshold, paving the way for optimization process. Then, the sum covert transmission rate is maximized by jointly optimizing the beamforming of confidential signal and jamming signal as well as the RIS’s phase shift. To solve the above non-convex problem, we propose a joint covert beamforming and the phase shift of RIS optimization-based twins-deep deterministic policy gradient (CBP-TD3) algorithm. Finally, simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed CBP-TD3 algorithm in the covertness.

title: T2AgeNet: A Text-Guided Framework with Tissue Features for Brain Age Estimation
authors: Shengxian Chen, Wenxuan Wu, Xin Zhang, Jiakun Xu, Tong Xiong, Chaoxiang Yang, Xiangmin Xu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering
abstract: Brain age estimation from structural MRI is an effective approach for detecting abnormal neurodevel opment and neurodegeneration. However, most existing methods produce global biomarkers that lack tissue-level specificity and fail to leverage medical prior knowledge. To address these limitations, we propose T2AgeNet, a dual-path image–text framework for tissue-level brain age estimation that integrates anatomical features with clinical semantics. The framework first segments brain MRI to generate tissue-specific masks, forming the basis for localized age prediction. To further incorporate medical prior knowledge, the model first aligns visual features with personalized clinical descriptions to guide semantic understanding of tissue-level variation. In parallel, it transforms handcrafted aging-related features into textual representations through an auxiliary branch using a large language model, enabling enriched interpretation and representation. We evaluate T2AgeNet on five datasets spanning fetal development, preterm infants, Alzheimer's disease, and autism spectrum disorder. Results demonstrate accurate age estimation across diverse populations. On the OASIS-3 and ABIDE-I datasets, the model further identifies tissue specific structural abnormalities consistent with known neurological patterns.

title: UIB-Enhanced Micro-Pose Network for Multi-Target Workpiece Localization and Dimensional Measurement in Industrial Scenes
authors: Tianze Wei, Shutong Fu, Zhiwen Hu, Haoyue Zhang, Chi Zhang
publish: 2025 21st IEEE International Conference on Mechatronic and Embedded Systems and Applications (MESA)
abstract: Applying computer vision for workpiece-dimension measurement is a pivotal task in Industry 5.0. Existing pose-estimation models exhibit markedly degraded accuracy upon transfer to tiny-target metrology tasks such as inspection of industrial-parts. This paper introduces Micro-Pose, a two-stage RTMPose-m variant that replaces the CSPNext backbone with UIB search blocks. This redesign markedly boosts tiny-target detection accuracy while drastically compressing parameter count, achieving a superior accuracy-speed trade-off. Plugged into an industrial inspection framework, Micro-Pose enables end-to-end workpiece positioning and metrology in real time. Furthermore, we introduce an error-evaluation algorithm tailored to multi-target scenes, which employs a divide-and-conquer strategy to resolve spatial-constraint problems. To validate our model, we released a dataset comprising 7420 hex-bolt images annotated with keypoint labels. In the COCO AP metric, our method reduces the parameter count by 37% and outperforms the original RTMPose-s and RTMPose-m by 0.7% and 2.0%, respectively, while maintaining the same inference speed as RTMPose-s. Under multi-target conditions, the dimensional accuracy reaches 1mm.

title: Real-time Multilingual Video Subtitle Spotting on Resource-Constrained Devices
authors: Illya Degtyarenko, Olga Radyvonenko, Nazarii Tkach, Valerii Sielikhov, Kostiantyn Seliuk, Oleksandr Ivanov
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Accurate real-time on-device video subtitle spotting is essential for many applications, such as subtitle translation, text-to-speech conversion, video content comprehension. However, most video content providers encrypt or embed subtitles in ways that prevent direct text extraction, necessitating the use of Optical Character Recognition (OCR) for detection and recognition. Current state-of-the-art video text spotting methods are not optimized for real-time operation on edge devices. To address this challenge, this study introduces the specialized neural network architectures designed for on-device video content classification, subtitle tracking, detection and recognition. To enhance efficiency, the proposed neural network architectures employ advanced optimization techniques, including pruning and Quantization-Aware Training (QAT), significantly reducing memory and computational demands while maintaining high real-time performance on TV devices. Through rigorous testing and on-device end-to-end (E2E) evaluation, we achieved an impressive novel state-of-the-art E2E word recognition accuracy of over 97% across seven languages, with a low latency of under 150 ms per screen. The findings hold great potential for extending this technology to other platforms, including IoT devices and digital appliances.

title: A Gear Backlash Identification and Compensation Method to Enhance Industrial Robot Repeatability
authors: Jinxiang Yao, Lin Yang, Ran Ju, Xing Zhou, Meng Gao, You Xu, Haibin Yang, Gengcong Lin, Shifeng Huang
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Industrial robots are widely employed in machinery manufacturing due to multiple degrees of freedom (DoF) and flexibility. However, backlash not only degrades the bidirectional repeatability and multi-directional repeatability of the end-effector, but also complicates its identification and compensation compared with geometric errors. Existing backlash identification and compensation methods ignore the principle of backlash error transmission, which severely limits the improvement of both bidirectional repeatability and multi-directional repeatability of the robot end-effector. In contrast to existing studies, this article presents the first systematic discussion correlating backlash with bidirectional repeatability and multi-directional repeatability, and proposes a pipeline including modeling, identification and compensation methods. Based on the principle of backlash error transmission, a mathematical model incorporating the reduction ratio correction coefficient, backlash and joint rotation direction is developed and integrated into a robotic kinematic error model with higher-order joint-dependent error terms. Since the pose deviation between adjacent coordinate systems is a linear function incorporating backlash and kinematic errors, a Taylor expansion is performed on this function with higher-order error terms neglected, and the iterative reweighted least squares (IRLS) algorithm is employed to identify backlash and kinematic parameter errors. A compensation method that accounts for both backlash and compensation direction is also proposed, where the compensation direction is determined by the joint velocity before the joint arrives at the target point. Experiments were conducted to compare the single-axis rotation identification and compensation approach implemented on a 6-DoF robot with the innovative method proposed in this article. The experimental results indicate that the traditional single-axis method requires repeated single-axis movements for each joint, resulting in low efficiency in backlash identification and compensation, and it fails to consider the impact of backlash on multi-directional repeatability. In contrast, the proposed method rapidly identifies backlash in each joint and improves bidirectional repeatability and multi-directional repeatability by 47.97% and 53.44%, respectively.

title: TakeAD: Preference-based Post-optimization for End-to-end Autonomous Driving with Expert Takeover Data
authors: Deqing Liu, Yinfeng Gao, Deheng Qian, Qichao Zhang, Xiaoqing Ye, Junyu Han, Yupeng Zheng, Xueyi Liu, Zhongpu Xia, Dawei Ding, Yifeng Pan, Dongbin Zhao
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Existing end-to-end autonomous driving methods typically rely on imitation learning (IL) but face a key challenge: the misalignment between open-loop training and closed-loop deployment. This misalignment often triggers driver-initiated takeovers and system disengagements during closed-loop execution. How to leverage those expert takeover data from disengagement scenarios and effectively expand the IL policy's capability presents a valuable yet unexplored challenge. In this paper, we propose TakeAD, a novel preference-based post-optimization framework that fine-tunes the pre-trained IL policy with this disengagement data to enhance the closed-loop driving performance. First, we design an efficient expert takeover data collection pipeline inspired by human takeover mechanisms in real-world autonomous driving systems. Then, this post-optimization framework integrates iterative Dataset Aggregation (DAgger) for imitation learning with Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) for preference alignment. The DAgger stage equips the policy with fundamental capabilities to handle disengagement states through direct imitation of expert interventions. Subsequently, the DPO stage refines the policy's behavior to better align with expert preferences in disengagement scenarios. Through multiple iterations, the policy progressively learns recovery strategies for disengagement states, thereby mitigating the open-loop gap. Experiments on the closed-loop Bench2Drive benchmark demonstrate our method's effectiveness compared with pure IL methods, with comprehensive ablations confirming the contribution of each component.

title: Self-Supervised Spatial-Temporal Consistency for Source-Free Domain Adaptive Segmentation in Remote Sensing Images
authors: Zhihao Xi, Yu Meng, Yupeng Deng, Yuman Feng, Diyou Liu, Jingbo Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: In conventional Unsupervised domain adaptation (UDA), model knowledge is transferred to the target domain with access to annotated source data, which is an unsuitable strategy for cross-domain scenarios involving data privacy and confidentiality. In this paper, we focus on source-free domain adaptation (SFDA) for semantic segmentation tasks, which adapts source-trained models to unannotated target domains without relying on source data. Self-training paradigms dominate the existing approaches, but often suffer from significant performance degradation due to unreliable pseudolabels and knowledge forgetting. To address these challenges, we propose innovative self-supervised spatial–temporal consistency learning for source-free domain adaptive segmentation (S<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>T-SFDA). Specifically, to address pseudolabel ambiguity in various spatial contexts, a spatial multiview consistency (SMVC) mechanism is proposed to constrain the semantic consistency across different spatial views of the same image. To mitigate the knowledge forgetting problem caused by a lack of supervisory information, a temporal dynamic consistency (TDC) mechanism, which harnesses historical knowledge consistency to regularize the current model evolution direction, is proposed. Furthermore, to improve the category-discriminative representation capabilities under domain shifts, a spatial-temporal contrastive (STC) strategy is designed to promote the intrinsic semantic association of features belonging to different categories in the target domain. Extensive experiments conducted on two domain-adaptive remote sensing (RS) segmentation benchmarks. The results demonstrate the flexibility of the proposed method when integrated into various advanced segmentation architectures, as well as its excellent generalization performance across different cross-domain RS scenarios.

title: Remaining useful life prediction of rolling element bearings based on an advanced two-stage degradation model
authors: Tuan-Anh Nguyen, Duc-Thuan Nguyen, Jong-Myon Kim
publish: IEEE Access
abstract: Bearings are essential to rotating machinery, and malfunctioning might result in unscheduled downtime, significant financial losses, and serious safety risks. Thus, predictive maintenance depends on precisely estimating the bearings’ remaining useful life (RUL). This study introduces a novel approach for early-stage degradation detection and RUL estimation by integrating a Joseph-form Kalman filter for reliable health indicator denoising and the Akaike information criterion for precise detection of the first change point. The proposed method employs an advanced two-stage approach based on the Wiener process with drift to model degradation. The model parameters are iteratively estimated and updated using the least-squares method to accurately capture the degradation trajectory. Experimental validation on the Pronostia bearing dataset demonstrates that the proposed method achieves the lowest MAE, RMSE, and MAPE values under different operating conditions, confirming its superior prediction accuracy and reliability compared with traditional statistical and model-based methods.

title: A Novel Lightweight Electromagnetic Induction Sensor for Permafrost Detection and Mapping
authors: Michele Maxson, Benjamin Barrowes, David Lozano, Taylor Sullivan, Mikheil Prishvin, Fridon Shubitidze
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: This paper introduces a novel, lightweight, electronically bucked, high-frequency electromagnetic induction (EMI) system for detection and mapping of spatial freeze and thaw patterns in the near-surface of remote, Arctic and sub-Arctic regions. The system incorporates an electronically isolated transmitter and bucking coil and utilizes an electronically controlled cancelation approach to suppress the primary magnetic field at the receiver coil. This integrated hardware-software control architecture enables the system to effectively bridge the frequency gap between traditional EMI sensors (operating from a few hertz to several tens of kilohertz and primarily sensitive to eddy currents in the soil) and ground-penetrating radar (GPR) systems (operating from a few to several hundred megahertz and are sensitive to displacement currents). The instrument is designed for easy deployment from unmanned aerial systems (UAS) for collecting high-resolution data over the Earth’s surface in both horizontal and vertical directions. Operating within the intermediate frequency range of approximately 100 kHz to several megahertz, this newly developed UAS-deployable frequency-domain electromagnetic induction (FDEMI) sensor enables rapid, cost-effective, and high-resolution spatial and spectral non-invasive measurements, resulting detailed mapping of subsurface electromagnetic properties, including electrical conductivity, magnetic susceptibility and dielectric permittivity. The data presented in this study were collected over a freshwater lake in Lyme, NH, and in the discontinuous permafrost zone of Fox, AK, at 93 kHz and 330 kHz. Results from both locations demonstrate this new FDEMI sensor’s sensitivity to (i) low-conductivity soils and (ii) variations in depth to permafrost.

title: Low-Carbon Energy Scheduling for Hydrogen-based Steel Heating with Battery Storage
authors: Dafeng Zhu, Bo Yang, Yunyang Zou, Zhao Yang Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Sustainable Energy
abstract: To address rising carbon emissions and energy loads in industry, a hydrogen-integrated energy scheduling method based on enhanced Lyapunov optimization is proposed for low-carbon steel heating, which transforms original problems into online tractable subproblems and mitigates battery degradation from charge/discharge cycles. Case studies at an Ovako steel plant verify simultaneous cost and emission reductions while ensuring charge/discharge benefits and system stability without compromising steel heating demands.

title: Dynamic Digital Twin Development for PMSMs: A Real-Time Physics-Informed Framework for Condition Monitoring
authors: Abdullah Shawier, Shady Gadoue, Kamyar Mehran
publish: IEEE Transactions on Energy Conversion
abstract: A fundamental challenge in developing digital representations of physical systems is capturing their dynamic and nonlinear characteristics under varying operating conditions. This research work introduces an adaptive digital twin (DT) framework for condition monitoring of permanent magnet synchronous machines (PMSMs) used in wind turbine drivetrain applications. The proposed framework employs particle swarm optimization (PSO) to update the physics-informed model and enhance real-time state estimation. Unlike static models, which do not account for parameter changes, the proposed PSO-based DT model (PDTM) adapts to parameter variations, tracks power loss fluctuations, and interprets degradation as a fault indicator. This work introduces an innovative integration of a physics-informed DT with real-time parameter adaptation, providing accurate state estimation and abnormality detection capabilities not available with conventional datasheet models or purely data-driven approaches. The framework's effectiveness for fault diagnostics is further demonstrated through a digital-twin-assisted multi-layer diagnostic architecture. The proposed methodology is validated using a 1kW PMSM-based experimental setup that considers transient conditions, load changes, and fault scenarios. Results show that the PDTM outperforms traditional models by accurately tracking PMSM states, estimating power losses, and adapting in real-time to various fault scenarios.

title: Decentralized Many-to-One Resource Allocation: The Competing Bandit Approach_supp1-3641175.pdf
authors: Zhixuan Fang
publish: N/A
abstract: Two-sided matching is a foundational topic that traditionally assumes participants have perfect knowledge of their pReferences. However, in practice, many participants lack precise information about potential matches. The competing bandits model, based on the multi-armed bandit framework, addresses this uncertainty by enabling participants to learn through interactions. While most existing research has focused on one-to-one matching, real-world scenarios—such as resource allocation in wireless networks—often involve cases in which a single resource can accommodate multiple participants, making it essential to adapt the framework to better reflect practical applications. In this paper, we extend the analysis to many-to-one matching. To enhance practical relevance and reduce restrictive assumptions, we introduce four key properties: full decentralization, accommodation of arbitrary and private preferences, absence of winner observation, and regret minimization with respect to the optimal stable matching. These properties introduce challenges such as severe information scarcity and complex preference structures. To address the issue of limited information, we propose techniques such as random pulls and specialized communication protocols to facilitate information gathering by agents. We further conduct a detailed analysis of complex preference structures and identify a critical property that underpins the development of our algorithm, SUBMARINE. Our proposed algorithm achieves logarithmic regret, representing a notable advancement: it is the first to satisfy all the outlined properties while attaining the lowest known regret bound.

title: Physical Modeling of Pitch Bending in Accordions Involving Resonance Effects of Reed Box
authors: Hyuga Okada, Seiji Adachi, Toshiya Samejima, Kojiro Nishimiya
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Pitch bending in the accordion is achieved by lightly pressing a key, thereby narrowing the opening of the reed box valve. It is hypothesized that the resonance of the reed box plays an important role in this phenomenon. To investigate this, a physical model of the accordion has been developed that incorporates the acoustic resonance of the reed box. Time-domain simulations based on this model successfully reproduce pitch bending when the valve opening is narrowed.
