title: BER Prediction in Partially Blocked Rayleigh Channels for Distributed Antenna Systems
authors: Thibaut Rolland, Matthieu Crussière, Marie Le Bot
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper introduces the theoretical derivations for establishing the bit error rate (BER) expressions of distributed antenna systems (DAS) over partially blocked Rayleigh fading channels. Clustered delay line models from 3GPP are considered with a subset of blocked propagation components. Assuming the receiver cannot update its equalizer during blockage events, a statistical analysis of the erroneously equalized channel gains is performed to provide the probability density functions of the received symbols depending on the blockage. BER derivations are then obtained and validated through simulations. The provided expressions allow predicting the performance of DAS and accurately analyze the impact of various blockage scenarios.

title: Development of a Hydropneumatic Actuator for Supercritical Fluid Circuit Breakers
authors: Zhiyang Jin, Alfonso J. Cruz Feliciano, Samuel M. Neall, Yang Liu, Mohd. Sadeed Al Hossain, Mahitha Pothuri, Chanyeop Park, Lukas Graber
publish: 2025 IEEE 70th Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts (HLM)
abstract: A substation-grade circuit breaker based on supercritical CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> is currently being developed at Georgia Tech. One of the challenges is to develop an actuator system that moves the contact system sufficiently fast in the much denser environment compared to SF<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> circuit breakers. Furthermore, sealing the hydraulics against the high-pressure supercritical fluid adds challenges. In this paper, we describe the development of a highly power-dense, hydropneumatic actuator system for our substation-grade 72-kV circuit breaker, achieving a contact travel distance of 71.5 mm and a travel time of approximately 15.8 ms, including a travel curve measurement.

title: AEFL: Adaptive Encryption for Secure and Energy-efficient Federated Learning
authors: Ziad Almesleh, Ala Gouissem, Yacine Challal, Ridha Hamila
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: In federated learning (FL), achieving high model accuracy often comes at the cost of increased energy consumption, particularly when incorporating robust privacy-preserving techniques like homomorphic encryption (HE). While HE enhances security by enabling encrypted aggregation of local models—thus mitigating data leakage and inference attacks without requiring a trusted aggregator—it also introduces computational overhead that impacts energy efficiency.This paper presents a novel approach for Adaptive Encryption Federated Learning (AEFL). AEFL strategically tunes encryption complexity to achieve the best trade-off between model accuracy and energy efficiency without compromising security. When additional energy from harvested sources is available, AEFL enhances model accuracy by adjusting encryption parameters to support more intensive computations. During periods of limited energy, the system focuses on conserving resources while maintaining robust encryption to ensure data security. This adaptive approach maximizes energy efficiency without lowering the security threshold, allowing for improved model performance when energy conditions permit.Experimental results show that AEFL improves energy efficiency by over 35% and increases the pool of eligible clients for FL by approximately 18%, all while maintaining a security level above 128 bits. Importantly, these gains are achieved with minimal impact on model accuracy, demonstrating that significant energy savings are possible in FL environments without sacrificing data security or model performance.

title: Optimizing Fertilizer Application in Precision Agriculture Using Deep Learning and Soil Sensor Data
authors: P Kumar, S Senthil Pandi, L Bharath Kumar, R Karthick
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: Utilizing cutting-edge technologies, precision agriculture maximizes agricultural productivity while reducing environmental effects. By tackling the issues of rising food demand and environmental preservation, precision agriculture has emerged as a revolutionary method of sustainable farming. A crucial component of agriculture, fertilizer application frequently suffers from inefficiencies brought on by traditional uniform distribution techniques that disregard temporal and spatial variability in soil conditions. Overuse of nutrients, environmental damage, and financial losses for farmers are the outcomes of these inefficiencies. A promising answer to these problems is provided by the development of deep learning algorithms in conjunction with real-time soil sensor data. This study investigates how to optimize fertilizer application by combining real-time soil sensor data with deep learning algorithms. Real-time, detailed information on soil characteristics, such as pH, moisture content, and nutrient content, is provided via soil sensors. Our goal is to develop an accurate and scalable system that minimizes fertilizer waste, enhances plant health, and lessens environmental harm by integrating convolutional neural networks (CNNs) with temporal data processing from soil sensors. Recent developments in machine learning for precision agriculture, with an emphasis on soil nutrient prediction and application optimization, are highlighted in an extensive literature analysis. Decision tree methods are used by a recommendation engine to produce useful information for fertilizer distribution. Real-world experiments and datasets are used to further evaluate this system, guaranteeing its scalability and resilience. Real-world experiments and implementation using publicly accessible datasets show notable increases in crop productivity and fertilizer efficiency. The findings highlight how deep learning can revolutionize the adoption of sustainable farming methods. The results demonstrate how well the suggested strategy works to increase agricultural sustainability and resource efficiency. Prediction reliability and adaptability have significantly improved, according to accuracy measurements and comparisons with current techniques.

title: Evaluation of Dialogue Translation in a Self-made Game Using a Pre-trained BERT Model
authors: Kouichi Tasaka, Sakura Miyano, Masayuki Numao, Shun Nishide
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper investigates the effectiveness of using a pre-trained multilingual BERT model to translate in-game dialogue from Japanese to English in a custom-developed co-operative action game. In-game dialogues often contain informal expressions, character-specific tones, and emotional nuances that are critical for preserving narrative immersion. As a baseline, we use ChatGPT, which generally produces fluent and contextually appropriate translations. We qualitatively evaluate BERT’s translations against this baseline, focusing on style fidelity, speaker consistency, and conversational naturalness. While BERT provides structurally accurate and literal translations, it tends to lack contextual sensitivity and character-aware adaptation. These findings highlight the limitations of applying unadapted BERT models in narrative contexts. Based on the results, we propose future enhancements through character-specific fine-tuning and context-aware modeling. This study serves as a first step toward building an adaptive, character-sensitive translation system for dialogue-intensive game environments.

title: Low-Frequency Focused Learning Method for Active Noise Canceling in Headphones
authors: Ryo Matsuyama, Shun Muramatsu, Benedikt Bugl, Viola Isabella Schneider, Armin Sehr, Takahiro Yoshida
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Active noise control reduces unwanted sound by generating the anti-noise. Neural network-based approaches have shown superior noise reduction performance compared to the conventional filtered-x least mean squares algorithm in simulation environments. However, we observed that it generates excessive mid- and high-frequency components, which increase residual error. To address this, we propose a low-frequency focused learning, which applies a low-pass filter (LPF) during training and canceling to improve lower frequency reduction. We evaluate the proposed method using data that simulates the real environment of active noise canceling in headphones and includes the effects of the primary path obtained through measurement. Evaluated results showed the proposed method achieved improvements of 3.12 dB (41.4%) average noise reduction and a maximum of 6.03 dB over the previous method without LPF.

title: Brain State Discrimination Performance of Ensemble Learning Model Based on Spatiotemporal Features from Cerebral Blood Flow for Brain-Computer Interface
authors: Akira Masuo, Takuto Sakuma, Shohei Kato
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Brain-computer interface (BCI) is gaining attention as a new means of expression for patients with neurological disorders. This study evaluated the performance of brain state discrimination using near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) signals measured from a patient with neurological disorders to apply BCI. A single patient with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis participated in the study, and NIRS signals were measured during two tasks, mental arithmetic and music imagery, with 24 trials each. Time-domain features and spectral-domain features were extracted from the NIRS signals. A model was constructed by integrating weak learners created for each channel using majority voting, with cognitive tasks as teacher labels, and the classification accuracy was calculated using 24-fold cross-validation. The model correctly classified 39 out of 48 trials, achieving an average accuracy of 81%. This method demonstrates the potential for applying the technique to BCI to enable communication for patients with neurological disorders using residual brain function.

title: Foundational Models for Building Clinical Decision Support Systems: An Open-Source Models Comparison
authors: Giuseppe D’Aniello, Valeria Fraenza, Pierluigi Ritrovato
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) are driving significant advances across different domains, including the healthcare field. Recent studies highlight the existence of several foundational models capable to process and interpret Electronic Health Records (EHR), underscoring their potential in developing Clinical Decision Support Systems (CDSSs). This paper presents a comparative analysis of nine open-source LLMs organised over three macro categories: (a) general-purpose (3), (b) trained using medical-domain data only (1), and (c) general-purpose fine-tuned on medical-domains dataset (5). The models have been evaluated across four different Questions Answering (QA) medical datasets: two generic, iCliniq and LiveQA, and two specific for chronic disease, diabetes-QA-dataset-origin for diabetes, and Cardio-docs-qa for cardiology. The evaluation involves three different tokenizers (GPT2TokenizerFast, LlamaTokenizerFast and PreTrainedTokenizerFast) and three different fine-tuning strategies. Moreover, fine-tuning is performed using three specific datasets. Performance metrics are derived using the BERTScore. The achieved results show that all models have similar performance over all testing datasets, with the best performance achieved by a recent general-purpose model (DeepSeek): Fine-tuning activities slightly increase performance over all datasets for one model only. Additionally, Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) and Quantized LoRA (QLORA) are confirmed as the most effective fine-tuning techniques.

title: Intelligent Radio-Protocol Recognition Leveraging SDR and a Transformer Network
authors: Akimun Jannat Alvina, Yao Ma, Nadia P. Yoza-Mitsuishi, Susanna Mosleh
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Spectrum sharing enables multiple wireless technologies—either from different standards (e.g., 4G and 5G) or different protocols of the same standard (e.g., IEEE 802.11 family of protocols)—to operate within the same frequency band with minimal interference. A wireless system that shares spectrum with signal/protocol awareness can allocate more spectrum for dynamic channel access. This paper introduces a Transformer-Based algorithm developed specifically for Wireless Local Area Network (WLAN) radio protocol recognition, leveraging low-cost SDR-based spectrum sensing capabilities. Unlike traditional approaches that require gigabytes of training data, our method achieves satisfactory results using only 100k (approximately 100–400megabytes of data) samples in total. The paper makes three key contributions: First, the model is trained on only 33k samples per protocol using a customized Transformer tailored for protocol classification. Second, over-the-air test datasets demonstrated near-perfect detection accuracy (exceeding 99%) at 20 dB signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) and above, enabling SDR-based spectrum sensing. Third, experiments conducted with real WLAN traffic generated using development boards achieved detection accuracy of at least 96%. We compared our Transformer-Based model with CNN and MLP classifiers and found that it consistently outperformed them in protocol recognition, even with minimal training data. Our findings suggest that intelligent spectrum sensing is achievable using low-cost devices, and that algorithms trained on compact datasets can attain state-of-the-art detection accuracy.

title: INKOOYO Cube: An Interactive Charm with Electronic Paper Display for Everyday Use
authors: Kao-Hua Liu, Wei-Ting Lu, Hiroyuki Kajihara, Tomoya Sasaki, Chien-Hsu Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: The INKOOYO Cube is a portable charm embedding a 1.64-inch four-color electronic paper display (EPD) and an ESP32 microcontroller to enable low-power, infrequently updated personalized visuals. Drawing on the bistable, paper-like qualities of E ink, the Cube supports image updates via a built-in web server over USB-C power, eliminating app installation and ensuring cross-platform compatibility. Users connect through a browser to upload, dither, preview, and transmit images in real time, with LED indicators signaling connection and update status. Hardware considerations— display size, power method, and interaction design—optimize ergonomics, reliability, and usability. A formative study with E Ink employees unveiled unanticipated social interactions, transit-card and USB-drive uses, and highlighted opportunities for expansion into digital amulets and child-friendly e-wallets. The system architecture, spanning segmented display trade-offs, flexible backplane challenges, and NFC limitations, informs the Cube’s design rationale. Future work will involve extensive user interviews to refine features and integrate additional everyday functionalities.

title: Enhancing Pond Ecosystem Management with IoT-Based Water Quality Monitoring
authors: Revathy Ramalingam, Mohd Salleh Md Roslan, Abd Kadir Mahamad, Nagalena Narasiahramu, Sharifah Saon, Maisara Othman, Herdawatie Abdul Kadir, Mohd Anuaruddin Ahmadon, Shingo Yamaguchi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This project introduces a portable, real-time water quality monitoring system for pond environments. The system measures parameters of pH, turbidity, temperature, and water level. This system integrates advanced sensors with cloud platforms; ThingSpeak and Telegram, for real-time data visualization and alert notifications. An INA219 current sensor monitors power consumption for operational energy efficiency. The system's effectiveness was validated through deployments in three ponds at Universiti Tun Hussein Onn Malaysia (UTHM), Parit Lapis Semarang, and FPTV. Results showed the system's accuracy is approximatly 98%, to detect and address water quality deviations promptly. This project addresses traditional monitoring limitations by providing a cost-effective, portable, and scalable solution for real-time water quality management.

title: Reciprocity-Aware Convolutional Neural Networks for Map-Based Path Loss Prediction
authors: Ryan G. Dempsey, Jonathan Ethier, Halim Yanikomeroglu
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Path loss modeling is a widely used technique for estimating point-to-point losses along a communications link from transmitter (Tx) to receiver (Rx). Accurate path loss predictions can optimize use of the radio frequency spectrum and minimize unwanted interference. Modern path loss modeling often leverages data-driven approaches, using machine learning to train models on drive test measurement datasets. Drive tests primarily represent downlink scenarios, where the Tx is located on a building and the Rx is located on a moving vehicle. Consequently, trained models are frequently reserved for downlink coverage estimation, lacking representation of uplink scenarios. In this paper, we demonstrate that data augmentation can be used to train a path loss model that is generalized to uplink, downlink, and backhaul scenarios, training using only downlink drive test measurements. By adding a small number of synthetic samples representing uplink scenarios to the training set, root mean squared error is reduced by > 8 dB on uplink examples in the test set.

title: UMCA: Enhancing UNet with Multi-Scale Cross Attention for Semi-Supervised Medical Image Fusion
authors: Wencheng Mei, Kangjian He, Dan Xu, Jian Gong, Yiqiao Zhou, Qingxin Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Prior brain tumor detection relies on diverse imaging modalities and acquisition protocols, yet the generated images intrinsically convey limited and modality-specific information. To address this deficiency, medical image fusion techniques have been proposed. Nevertheless, existing fusion paradigms predominantly adopt unsupervised learning, necessitating the elaborate design of composite loss functions and sophisticated network architectures. In response, we introduce a semi-supervised training framework that dispenses with intricate losses and cumbersome architectures while still attaining state-of-the-art performance. Furthermore, to ensure model compactness, we integrate a novel multi-scale cross attention mechanism into the U-Net backbone, yielding the U-Net with Multi-scale Cross Attention (UMCA). Comprehensive experiments demonstrate that UMCA achieves the best performance across six quantitative metrics.

title: Low Frequency Laser Noise Model Based on Fourier Transform Methods
authors: Takahiro Uchida, Mitsuru Shinagawa, Jun Katsuyama, Yoshinori Matsumoto, Shinichiro Tezuka
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study reports a low frequency laser noise model of the spectra and phase based on Fourier transform methods. It was observed that a phase distribution of laser noise gathers at a certain value in the low-frequency region. As a result, a modeled laser noise waveform close to a measured noise waveform was obtained.

title: Prediction of Pedestrian Crossing Intentions Using Wearable Smart Glasses
authors: Yuka Hara, Yanlei Gu, Toru Higaki, Bisser Raytchev, Kazufumi Kaneda
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Accurate prediction of pedestrian movements is essential for collision avoidance for autonomous vehicles. Although research on pedestrian behavior prediction using in-vehicle cameras and sensors has progressed, environmental factors such as obstacles and poor weather can create blind spots, making it difficult to fully capture pedestrian behavior. To overcome this challenge, this study explores pedestrian intention prediction using wearable smart glasses, leveraging the concept of Vehicle-to-Infrastructure (V2I) communication. Our system uses first-person view (FPV) videos captured from pedestrians’ smart glasses, to predict whether they will cross an unsignalized crosswalk within a few seconds. We constructed a novel FPV video dataset and implemented three models—3D Convolutional Neural Network (3DCNN), a hybrid Convolutional Neural Network-Recurrent Neural Network (CNN-RNN), and a Transformer-based model—for binary classification. Performance comparison revealed the most effective model, whose prediction results were further visualized to illustrate system accuracy.

title: On Reconstruction of Boolean Networks Using Input-Output Data Sets
authors: Xiaoniujin Chen, Koichi Kobayashi, Yuh Yamashita
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a reconstruction method of Boolean networks from input-output data sets. A Boolean network is a mathematical model where dynamics are modeled by Boolean functions. In the problem formulation, we suppose that the state is directly measured. We consider both the estimation of the initial state and the derivation of noisy dynamics.

title: Operational Optimal Control of Flotation Processes via Multi-Step Reinforcement Learning
authors: Wenbo Zhang, Jinna Li, Shaowen Lu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: This paper addresses the operational optimal control (OOC) problem in single-cell flotation processes, a critical step in mineral processing. A model-free, data-driven reinforcement learning (RL) algorithm is proposed to compute optimal control actions online without relying on accurate system dynamics. The algorithm employs a multi-step learning mechanism to improve convergence speed and tracking accuracy. To implement this control strategy, neural networks and an Actor-Critic architecture are introduced to approximate the iterative value functions and control policies. To ensure physical feasibility, control constraints are enforced through an embedded penalty mechanism. Simulation results validate the proposed method's effectiveness and demonstrate superior performance compared to standard one-step RL algorithms.

title: Management and Optimization of Electrical Energy in Greenhouses
authors: Tinghan Chueh, Deyang Liu, Joseph. K.H. Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: As highly energy-intensive systems, greenhouses utilize considerable electrical energy for supplemental heating and lighting to maintain optimal growing conditions, leading to high operational expenditures. Therefore, managing and optimizing energy use is crucial for cost reduction. This study introduces a greenhouse electrical energy management framework built upon the Volapu IIoT Suite. It employs smart meters for collecting device-specific power consumption data. Through the integration of these data with plant growth and greenhouse environment models, the framework facilitates an optimized scheduling strategy for supplemental heating and lighting, designed to lower the overall operational costs.

title: ASL Gesture Recognition and Speech Conversion
authors: R Suhas Bharadwaj, N Vedavathi, Harshitha Suresh, M Aishwarya
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: The Sign Language Recognition System fills the communication gap between signers and non-signers with deep learning that interprets ASL motions in real time. It recognizes and processes gestures with a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and OpenCV with static gesture accuracy of over $95 \%$. The system handles live videos, translating motions to text or sound with low latency, with consistent performance in healthcare, education, and customer service. Its scalable architecture allows for future upgrades like dynamic gesture detection and smartphone support. This research unveils the application of AI in accessibility through inclusivity for hearing or speech impaired.

title: Study on the Development of Wireless Gait Function Assessment Devices
authors: Konatsu Sakai, Kazuya Kato, Mizuki Uematsu, Hideyuki Natori, Tadasuke Onishi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: With the rapid increase in the elderly population, there is an urgent need to improve the quality of life (QOL) for older adults. One crucial aspect of QOL is the ability to maintain independence in activities of daily living (ADL). Gait function plays a vital role in the performance of ADL. The aim of this study is to develop a low-cost, wireless, compact sensor device capable of assessing gait function. The developed device was attached to both feet. Each device simultaneously measured the swing angle and swing speed in two directions of the foot, as well as the foot pressure at six points. The measurement results were sent wirelessly to a PC and compiled into a single data set.

title: A Pulse Radar System with UWB Antenna for Noncontact Respiration and Heartbeat Detection
authors: Meng-Ju Tsai, Ching-Hsiang Yang, Da-Huei Lee, Wei-Wen Hu, Chia-Hung Chang
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study presents a noncontact vital sign monitoring system based on pulse radar, designed to detect human respiration and heartbeat. The system employs a patch-fed wideband slot antenna to transmit pulsed signals toward the subject, and analyzes the reflected signals to extract physiological parameters such as thoracic respiratory activity, respiratory rate, and breathing depth. The antenna used in the system has dimensions of 100 mm × 150 mm × 0.8 mm (L×W×H) and operates in the 5G C-band (4.4–5 GHz) and WLAN bands at 5.2/5.8 GHz (5.15–5.825 GHz). The antenna exhibits a return loss below 10 dB and demonstrates reliable performance in both respiration and heart rate monitoring.

title: Driving Risks and Behavior by Speed Zone
authors: Yoshihiro Niimi, Akira Kawai
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study integrates driving data, abrupt maneuver records, and traffic accident information collected in Shiga Prefecture at a mesh level to quantitatively analyze the relationship between near-miss incidents and traffic accident counts. The analysis revealed a significant positive correlation between near-miss frequency and accident occurrence, suggesting that near-misses may serve as a useful indicator of traffic risk. Furthermore, the rate of near-miss events including sudden braking and acceleration was notably higher in low-speed zones, indicating clear behavioral differences depending on speed conditions.

title: Design of Interpretable and Enhanced Anomaly Detection xApp for Traffic Steering in O-RAN
authors: Seung-Eun Hong, Jungmo Moon, Jihyun Na
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: In this paper, we propose an improved anomaly detection algorithm for O-RAN Near-RT RIC environments by enhancing the Isolation Forest-based xApp deployed for traffic steering. Conventional implementations rely on arbitrary or correlation-based feature selection and (semi-)supervised-like hyperparameter tuning, which can result in suboptimal performance. To address these issues, we introduce a proxy label generation method grounded domain expertise, enabling evaluation-driven hyperparameter optimization. We further propose a three-step feature selection framework to produce interpretable and effective feature subsets. Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed method consistently improves F1-score performance, with Bayesian optimization showing the most robust results. Furthermore, our analysis highlights the value of retaining certain correlated features that may be beneficial for tree-based models like Isolation Forest, counter to common practices in feature selection. These findings validate the proposed framework’s applicability in O-RAN anomaly detection and offer new directions for interpretable xApp development.

title: Temporal Spectrum Analysis for Multi-Constellation Space Domain Awareness
authors: Mansour Naslcheraghi, Gunes Karabulut Kurt
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Space Domain Awareness (SDA) system has different major aspects including continuous and robust awareness from the network that is crucial for efficient control over all actors in space. The observability of the space assets, on the other hand, requires efficient analysis of when and how observed space objects can be controlled. This becomes crucial when real-world spatial dynamics are taken into account, as it introduces complexities into the system. The real-world dynamics can reveal the structure of the network, including isolated and dominant stations. We propose a Temporal Spectrum Analysis (TSA) scheme that takes into account a set of real-world parameters, including actual dynamics of the objects in space, to analyze the structure of a ground-space network that inherits temporal spectrum as the key element of design. We study the potential interactions between multiple constellations using TSA and conduct comprehensive real-world simulations to quantify the structure of the network. Numerical results show how the temporal spectrum of each satellite affects the intra- and inter-constellation network structure, including interactions between ground stations and constellations.

title: Exploratory Study of AR Hand Redirection using Augmented Virtual Hand
authors: Gu Jiaqi, Parinya Punpongsanon
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Hand Redirection (HR) techniques have been widely studied in virtual reality (VR) to accommodate the hand position relative to the user’s real hand. While such HR can be applied in a VR since the real hand does not appear to the user, in augmented reality (AR), the user’s real hand is visible alongside the virtual hand, which might reduce the HR illusion using the VR technique. To this challenge, we conducted two exploratory experiments to evaluate whether VR-based HR techniques can be applied in AR without disrupting user performance or whether there are different elements to be used before the HR in AR. Results indicate minimal impact on behavior, supporting HR’s potential as lightweight pseudo-haptic feedback in AR. Our results provided the potential to apply HR in the AR environment.

title: Mitigating Frequency-Dependent Mutual Coupling for Wideband Holographic MIMO Communications
authors: Yuqing Guo, Xufeng Guo, Ying Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Mutual coupling is essentially the physical phenomenon where the voltage on one antenna induces excitation currents on its surrounding antennas. Mutual coupling usually occurs in holographic MIMO (HMIMO) systems, distorting the intended radiation pattern of the array. Nevertheless, the impacts of mutual coupling on wideband HMIMO have not yet been fully investigated in the literature. To fill this knowledge gap, this paper initially unveils the frequency-dependent nature of mutual coupling, which emanates from frequency-dependent antenna impedance and mutual impedance. Subsequently, this paper proposes an innovative frequency-dependent coupling-aware beamforming methodology to mitigate frequency-dependent mutual coupling (FDMC). Upon this approach, both FDMC and frequency-dependent channels (FDC) can be simultaneously mitigated for wideband HMIMO communications. Simulation results validate the necessity of mitigating FDMC and substantiate the efficacy of our proposed beamforming-based mitigation in enhancing the wideband performance of HMIMO.

title: Development of Leader-Follower based Recording System for Ad-Hoc Microphone Arrays
authors: Atsuto Harada, Ryoichi Miyazaki
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: We propose a mobile recording system for ad-hoc microphone arrays using a leader-follower architecture and TSP-based post-hoc synchronization. A cross-platform application was developed for smartphones and tablets. Experiments with six iPad devices demonstrated synchronization accuracy better than 200 μs and microphone localization errors below 0.05 m. The system can provide a practical foundation for Ad-Hoc Microphone Array-Based applications, such as meeting transcription with spatial audio processing.

title: Late transaction settlement on PoA voting Blockchain for higher security crypto token transfer
authors: Hironao Takahashi, Muhammed Waqar, Muhammad Kamran
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: There are so many cryptocurrency transactions to taking place in today's token ecosystem. Secure transfers of FT and NFT tokens are becoming increasingly important. Users are at risk from incorrect wallet addresses, phishing, and hacking. To address this, propose a late transaction settlement model on a PoA-based blockchain that integrates 2FA and KBA verification before transactions are executed. An escrow account node evaluates the legitimacy of transactions, while REP nodes connected to user wallets perform a reconfirmation process. Our evaluation indicates improved transaction accuracy and significantly reduces the risk of unauthorized transfers.

title: Baby Safety Monitoring: Improving the CNN Model Using Batch Normalization and SGD
authors: Neda Khan, Peter H. J. Chong, Farhaan Mirza, Duaa Zuhair Al-Hamid
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: Nowadays, baby safety monitoring has become a growing trend in the research domain. Babies aged 12-24 months are highly active and undergo rapid developmental growth, which can sometimes lead to falls or other unsafe scenarios. As a result, various research initiatives and commercial products have been developed for the safety monitoring of babies using Artificial Intelligence (AI)/Machine Learning (ML) models and neural networks. However, these models, particularly Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) architecture, often encounter performance issues, primarily due to overfitting. Overfitting is a prevalent concern that can significantly challenge the model's efficacy, affect model generalization, prediction accuracy, and reliability. This paper has been tailored to address the causes for overfitting and explore techniques to reduce or prevent it by incorporating some techniques, improving the model performance. The Traditional Convolutional Neural Network (TCNN) model exhibited significant overfitting, with a loss of training and validation of 0.08 and 0.745, respectively. To address this, an improved CNN model, Benchmark CNN (BCNN-BGRDOS), is proposed based on Batch Normalization (B), Global (G) Average Pooling, Regularization (R), Dropout (DO), and Stochastic (S) Gradient Descent optimizer, is employed. The statistical analysis indicated the proposed BCNN-BGRDOS exhibited superior performance relative to TCNN, attaining high training (0.9947) and validation (0.9968) accuracies, alongside low training (0.0271) and validation (0.0193) losses. The improved CNN model, enhanced further with an attention mechanism, is used further in the baby safety monitoring system to predict falls.

title: A Neural Network-aided Low Complexity Chase Decoder for URLLC
authors: Enrico Testi, Enrico Paolini
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Ultra-reliable low-latency communications (URLLC) demand decoding algorithms that simultaneously offer high reliability and low complexity under stringent latency constraints. While iterative decoding schemes for LDPC and Polar codes offer a good compromise between performance and complexity, they fall short in approaching the theoretical performance limits in the typical URLLC short block length regime. Conversely, quasi-ML decoding schemes for algebraic codes, like Chase-II decoding, exhibit a smaller gap to optimum decoding but are computationally prohibitive for practical deployment in URLLC systems. To bridge this gap, we propose an enhanced Chase-II decoding algorithm that leverages a neural network (NN) to predict promising perturbation patterns, drastically reducing the number of required decoding trials. The proposed approach combines the reliability of quasi-ML decoding with the efficiency of NN inference, making it well-suited for time-sensitive and resource-constrained applications.

title: Surface Texture Display Combining Friction and Vibrotactile Stimuli for Realistic Natural Materials
authors: Mirai Azechi, Shogo Okamoto
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Surface tactile displays are touch panel interfaces capable of presenting tactile sensations. Typically, these systems implement either electrostatic friction stimuli or vibrotactile stimuli. In this study, we investigated the advantages of simultaneously presenting both types of stimuli using virtual textures modeled after natural materials. In the experiment, four types of natural material textures—fabric, wallpaper, woven straw, and artificial grass—were virtually rendered and presented to participants. Ten participants compared three virtual stimulation conditions presented in random order: electrostatic friction only, vibrotactile only, and a combined stimulation. The results showed that the combined stimulation was consistently rated as more realistic than either single modality alone. This finding contributes to the development of surface texture displays with high realism.

title: A Soft Sensor Method for Quality Prediction in Industrial Processes Based on Multi-Rate Autoencoder Regression
authors: Jingjing Wang, Qiang Liu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: To improve the precision of quality forecasting in industrial systems and to effectively handle missing data, this study proposes a novel soft sensor framework based on Multi-rate Autoencoder Regression for complex industrial systems. The proposed method improves modeling capability through multi-rate dynamic feature fusion and a data reconstruction mechanism. Specifically, a multi-rate data gating unit is designed to perform feature complementation and dynamic information filtering, enabling effective integration of process variables sam-pled at different rates. Furthermore, an autoencoder is utilized to reconstruct the original input, preserving critical dynamic information by minimizing reconstruction error and thereby mitigating the impact of missing features. This method is applied to a debutanizer column process to demonstrate its practicality and performance.

title: Leveraging Transfer Learning for Rapid Adaptation of ML-based Indoor Propagation Models
authors: Melina Geis, Nicolas Faust, Hendrik Schippers, Stefan Böcker, Christian Wietfeld
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Adaptive 6G networks are crucial for maintaining reliable communication in dynamically changing environments. To this end, accurate propagation models are essential for network adaptation, but developing real-time, high-fidelity models is a significant challenge. Machine Learning (ML)-based channel models have gained attention in recent years, yet their limited generalizability often necessitates extensive retraining to ensure applicability in unseen environments. In this paper, we propose a process chain for rapid network adaptation in dynamic environments. Our fully automated process encompasses network Key Performance Indicator collection, LiDAR-based environmental modeling, Transfer Learning (TL)-assisted refinement of the ML-based IndoorDRaGon propagation model, and network planning. We demonstrate that Artificial Neural Networks (ANNs) achieve comparable accuracy to Random Forest (RF)-based models while offering significantly faster adaptation to new environments. Unlike RFs, ANNs do not need to be retrained from scratch using all the source data, which reduces computational effort and improves data privacy as only the new data is required. This enables efficient and dynamic network reconfiguration in previously unseen scenarios with just a few new measurements.

title: PH-Mamba: Enhancing Mamba with Position Encoding and Harmonized Attention for Image Deraining and Beyond
authors: Kui Jiang, Junjun Jiang, Xianming Liu, Hongxun Yao, Chia-Wen Lin
publish: IEEE Transactions on Image Processing
abstract: Mamba and its variants excel at modeling long-range dependencies with linear computational complexity, making them effective for diverse vision tasks. However, Mamba’s reliance on unfolding 1D sequential representations necessitates multiple directional scans to recover lost spatial dependencies. This introduces significant computational overhead, redundant token traversal, and inefficiencies that compromise accuracy in real-world applications. To this end, we propose PH-Mamba, a novel framework integrating position encoding and harmonized attention for image deraining and beyond. PH-Mamba transforms Mamba’s scanning process into a position-guided, unidirectional scanning that selectively prioritizes degradation-relevant tokens. Specifically, we devise a position-guided hybrid Mamba module (PHMM) that jointly encodes perturbation features alongside their spatial coordinates and harmonized representation to model consistent degradation patterns. Within PHMM, a harmonized Transformer is developed to focus on uncertain regions while suppressing noise interference, thereby improving spatial modeling fidelity. Additionally, we employ a vector decomposition and synthesis strategy to enable the unified representation layout to global degradation by directional scanning while minimizing redundancy. By cascading multiple PHMM blocks, PH-Mamba combines global positional guidance with local differential features to strengthen contextual learning. Extensive experiments demonstrate the superiority of PH-Mamba across low-level image restoration benchmarks. For example, compared to NeRD, PH-Mamba achieves a 0.60 dB PSNR improvement while requiring 88.9% fewer parameters, 36.2% less computation, and 63.0% faster inference time.

title: Optimal Online Control Strategy for Differentially Private Federated Learning
authors: Xin Yuan, Andrey V. Savkin, Wei Ni, Minhui Xue, Ren Ping Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: While differential privacy (DP) contributes to pre serving data privacy during federated learning (FL), DP-FL suffers from either premature convergence or underutilized privacy budgets and subsequently degraded accuracy. Some recent studies heuristically adjusted the variance of the DP noises but offered no guarantee of optimality, little insight, and limited scalability. This paper presents a new control framework for (ε, δ)-DP FL to address the prevalent issues of DP-FL, i.e., premature convergence or underutilized privacy budgets. The key idea is to interpret the DP perturbation of DP-FL as a control process, where the DP noise variance and communication rounds are interdependent and jointly and adaptively determined. An optimal control framework is proposed to adjust the communication rounds and DP noise variance, adapting to the training accuracy of DP-FL. The optimality gap of (ε, δ)-DP FL is derived under the optimal control framework. The importance of joint orchestration of the DP noise and communication rounds is delineated. Experiments on MLP, CNN, and ResNet-9 models show that, given a privacy level, our control framework allows DP-FL to converge much faster with better accuracy than existing techniques, including those with persistent or heuristically reconfigurable DP noise variances.

title:
Numerical Modeling of Graphene Nanoribbons Salisbury Screen on CaF
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    Substrate for Near-Unity Mid-Infrared Absorption
authors: Vinod Sharma, Saurabh Kishen, Naresh Kumar Emani
publish: IEEE Sensors Letters
abstract: Graphene nanostructures offer a compelling platform for near-unity absorption due to their tunable plasmonic response and large effective index change modulation. We numerically demonstrate a tunable Salisbury screen absorber in which graphene nanoribbons act as the resistive layer, combined with a low-index dielectric spacer and a metallic back reflector to enhance radiative coupling to plasmonic resonators. An asymmetric Fabry–Pérot cavity model explains the absorption mechanism. Full-wave FEM simulations show up to 100% mid-infrared absorption, tunable via graphene chemical potential, nanoribbon width, and spacer thickness. For refractive index sensing, the device exhibits a high sensitivity of ∼2500 nm/RIU and a figure of merit of ∼32/RIU. The results highlight the potential of graphene-based absorbers for mid-infrared photodetectors and highly sensitive refractive index sensing applications.

title: REBot: Reflexive Evasion Robot for Instantaneous Dynamic Obstacle Avoidance_supp1-3643278.mp4
authors: ZIHAO XU
publish: N/A
abstract: Dynamic obstacle avoidance (DOA) is critical for quadrupedal robots operating in environments with moving obstacles or humans. Existing approaches typically rely on navigation-based trajectory replanning, which assumes sufficient reaction time and leading to fails when obstacles approach rapidly. In such scenarios, quadrupedal robots require reflexive evasion capabilities to perform instantaneous, low-latency maneuvers. This paper introduces Reflexive Evasion Robot (REBot), a control framework that enables quadrupedal robots to achieve real-time reflexive obstacle avoidance. REBot integrates an avoidance policy and a recovery policy within a finite-state machine. With carefully designed learning curricula and by incorporating regularization and adaptive rewards, REBot achieves robust evasion and rapid stabilization in instantaneous DOA tasks. We validate REBot through extensive simulations and real-world experiments, demonstrating notable improvements in avoidance success rates, energy efficiency, and robustness to fast-moving obstacles. title: Formation Containment for Multi-Agent Networks With Cooperative-Competitive Interactions in Two-Dimensional Space
authors: Lei Shi, Darong Huang, Guangdeng Zong, Cong Chen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control
abstract: Cooperation and competition relationships are ubiquitous in multi-agent networks. A good cooperative relationship is likely to prompt neighboring agents to draw close each other, while a competitive relationship can easily lead to neighboring agents moving away from each other. This paper aims to investigate how to implement formation containment for multi-agent networks with both cooperative and competitive interactions in two-dimensional space, where the followers are unaware of the topology information and the expected formation information, but the leaders are. The leaders form a connection matrix based on the expected formation information, and then utilize it to build interaction relationships with the group of followers. The followers design asynchronous distributed control protocols based on the interaction information of local neighbors and adjust their own states. By establishing topological and algebraic conditions for cooperative and competitive relationships, it is theoretically confirmed that followers can still gather into the convex hull formed by the leaders and form the expected formation, even if the network contains both cooperative and competitive relationships. At last, the theoretical results of this paper are validated through numerical simulations.

title: Real-time rodent pupillometry on an embedded platform for neuromodulation
authors: Sunguk Hong, Mingeun Cho, Sung-Min Park
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Systems and Rehabilitation Engineering
abstract: Pupillometry has recently emerged as a sensitive biomarker for autonomic and cortical activity, offering a non-invasive readout for neuromodulation research. However, existing commercial and deep learning–based pupillometry systems are primarily designed for humans, rendering them unsuitable for rodent experiments due to differences in ocular morphology, fur-induced optical artifacts, and the computational demands of high-resolution imaging. In this study, we present a low-cost, integrated real-time rodent pupillometry system built on an embedded platform. The proposed rule-based pupillometry algorithm was optimized with adaptive ellipse fitting, RGB masking artifact suppression, and greedy tracking, achieving robust performance under infrared illumination without requiring GPU acceleration. By minimizing errors caused by complex fur patterns and rodent-specific ocular features, our approach achieved an 86.0% detection rate in rat pupillometry, substantially surpassing the 63.1% attained by existing approach. The system was validated in vivo through vagus nerve stimulation (VNS) experiments in Long-Evans rats, where dynamic changes in pupil size reliably reflected stimulation intensity. By enabling an effective evaluation of VNS, these findings highlight the utility of our system as a practical preclinical tool and underscore the broader potential of pupillometry as a non-invasive biomarker for neuromodulation.

title: Computing Capability Optimization for STAR-RIS-Assisted WP-NOMA-MEC Systems
authors: Peng Ni, Jia Zhu, Yulong Zou, Ying Yang, Xianyang Liu
publish: IEEE Communications Letters
abstract: In this letter, we investigate a wireless-powered mobile edge computing (WP-MEC) system, and propose a simultaneously transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surface (STAR-RIS)-assisted non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) scheme, referred to as SRIS-NOMA. In the proposed SRIS-NOMA scheme, with the assistance of the STAR-RIS, multiple passive users first harvest energy from a power station (PS) and then leverage the harvested energy for local computation and task offloading to the base station (BS). To maximize total computation bits (TCB) of the SRIS-NOMA scheme, we jointly design the time allocation, local computing frequency (LCF), users’ transmit power, BS’s receive beamforming (BRB), and the STAR-RIS coefficients. Specifically, the optimal time allocation solution is determined by one-dimensional search, while closed-form solutions for LCF, users’ transmit power, and the BRB vector are derived, and efficient solutions for the STAR-RIS coefficients are obtained using the successive convex approximation (SCA) method. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed SRIS-NOMA scheme surpasses the benchmarks in terms of TCB performance.

title: MFIG-Net: Map-Free Multi-Agent Trajectory Prediction for Signalized Intersection Scenarios
authors: Weiqiang Wang, Zechao Ma, Xiaoming Liu, Shangjiang Yang, Yuqi Yang, Hanqing Xia
publish: IEEE Internet of Things Journal
abstract: Signalized intersections are among the most crash-prone elements of urban traffic networks. Their complex layouts and heterogeneous road users pose substantial challenges for accurate trajectory prediction. Although high-definition (HD) maps are widely used to boost prediction performance, their high construction and maintenance costs and limited update frequency hinder practical deployment. Meanwhile, existing map-free models still struggle to reach the accuracy required in such complex settings. To address these issues, we propose MFIG-Net (Map-Free Intersection Graph Network), a map-free, multi-agent trajectory prediction framework tailored to signalized intersections. MFIG-Net comprises three components. First, a Multi-Source Feature Encoder (MSFE) builds per-agent node embeddings by jointly encoding motion histories and static attributes together with traffic-signal phase semantics; the latter are represented using remaining-time sinusoidal positional encodings passed through an MLP to capture phase transitions. Second, the interaction layer combines a Conflict-Aware Graph Attention (CAGA) module—modeling dense spatial interactions via physically grounded, directed edge features and enhanced multi-head attention—with a Mamba-based temporal block that captures long-range dependencies through linear-time selective state-space dynamics. Third, a Laplace Mixture Density Network (MDN) decoder produces K multimodal future trajectories per agent with per-timestep scale parameters and mode probabilities, yielding accurate and calibrated uncertainty. Experiments on the SinD dataset from two-phase signalized intersections in Tianjin and Xi’an validate the effectiveness of the proposed model. Additional evaluations on the Argoverse dataset further demonstrate its applicability across diverse urban scenarios, where it outperforms most existing map-free approaches.

title: Human-Like Autonomous Driving Car-Following Behavior Learning Based on Adversarial Training and Uncertainty-Aware DDPG
authors: Xiaobo Chen, Jinpeng Zang, Feng Zhao
publish: IEEE Robotics and Automation Letters
abstract: Designing effective car-following (CF) models is essential for the development of safe and efficient autonomous driving systems, enabling ego vehicles to adjust their speed based on leading traffic. However, current data-driven CF models, particularly those based on reinforcement learning (RL), often face challenges in engineering reward functions and adequately addressing uncertainties in vehicle motion predictions. In response, this letter introduces a novel human-like CF policy learning approach that synergizes the Generative Adversarial Imitation Learning (GAIL) framework with an enhanced Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (DDPG) algorithm, utilizing both human driving data and environmental interactions. We first develop a deep ensemble learning model for robust leading vehicle motion prediction with uncertainty quantification. Then, we employ GAIL to learn an implicit reward function, thereby avoiding the manual design of the reward function in DDPG. Moreover, we augment the state with predictive insights for proactive decision-making, and incorporate a dual critic strategy and behavior cloning loss to improve learning stability and mimic human-like driving. Extensive evaluations on multiple naturalistic driving datasets, complemented by thorough ablation studies, demonstrate the effectiveness of our proposed approach in achieving superior accuracy, safety, and comfort in CF tasks. The code of our method will be publicly released.

title: Electrical Impedance Analysis of CBD in Aqueous Media: A Prototype Approach Using B2 Graphite Electrodes
authors: Juan M. Canchila Madera, Eduardo Lema Florez, Oscar Iván Campo, Leonel I. Montealegre-Sánchez, Paulo C. Calvo, Faruk Fonthal
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Colombian BioCAS Workshop
abstract: This work presents the development of a method to evaluate the electrical properties of micellar aqueous solutions encapsulating cannabidiol (CBD) at different concentrations using electrical impedance spectroscopy (EIS), including the design of a prototype with B2 graphite electrodes and an experimental protocol subjected to variations in temperature and UV radiation. A variation of approximately 5Ω per <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$43.48 \text{mg} / \text{mL}$</tex> of CBD was observed with respect to the control solution (approximately 5 Ωfor each doubling of concentration); also, the impedance decreased inversely with temperature and increased to stabilize at about 17Ω above the initial value after UV irradiation.

title: Prototype of an Embedded Electrical Impedance Tomography System for Coffee Bean Evaluation
authors: Luis Miguel Capacho-Valbuena, Jaime Velasco-Medina, Jorge Iván Marín-Hurtado
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Colombian BioCAS Workshop
abstract: This paper presents the development of a low-cost, embedded Electrical Impedance Tomography (EIT) system for the non-invasive evaluation of coffee beans. The system includes a 3D-printed chamber with eight stainless steel electrodes, an analog front-end based on an ESP32 SoC, and a Python-based graphical interface. developed in Python using the PyEIT library for real-time image reconstruction. The architecture prioritizes modularity and affordability, making it suitable for research and educational contexts. Functional tests confirm the stability and coherence of the measurements, and the reconstructed images reveal impedance variations across the sample. This prototype lays the groundwork for future agro-industrial applications in quality assessment using EIT technology.

title: Funnel Control of Euler-Lagrange Systems with Independent Control Gains
authors: Xiao-Ke Tong, Jin-Xi Zhang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: This paper is concerned with the trajectory tracking control problem for Euler-Lagrange systems subject to model uncertainties, focusing on cases where system nonlinearities are totally unknown. Such unknown nonlinearities render the existing control approaches infeasible. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a low-complexity funnel control strategy with independent control gains. The proposed strategy constrains the tracking errors within a predefined range, enabling the system outputs to track the references with the prescribed speed and accuracy. Furthermore, it is free from the specific information regarding system nonlinearities and disturbances. It also avoids parameter identification, function approximation, derivative calculation and command filtering. Finally, a simulation is conducted to demonstrate the theoretical findings.

title: Coordinated Planning of Ship Speed and Course for Collision Avoidance Based on the Improved Velocity Obstacle Method
authors: Kun Chen, Dewen Yan, Zhi Liu
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: The velocity obstacle (VO) method is widely used in collision avoidance planning, but traditional VO method struggles to coordinate speed and course planning, limiting its practical application in ship collision avoidance. To address this issue, an improved VO method is proposed in this paper. The concept of “ship telegraph” is introduced to discretize ship speed, simplifying speed planning and enabling coordinated speed-course planning. A dynamic calculation method for preset safety distance is designed, which integrates ship maneuvering constraints and environmental interaction constraints to determine the safety threshold, providing a basis for collision risk identification. The effectiveness of the proposed method is verified by simulation experiments: comparative experiments show that it outperforms the course-only adjustment method in avoiding collisions; tests with target ships with randomly varying speeds and courses confirm its robustness. This method enhances the adaptability of VO-based collision avoidance in practical maritime navigation, providing a reference for safe ship navigation.

title: Federated Swarm Intelligence for Adversarial Threat Mitigation through Self-Healing Anomaly Consensus Networks
authors: Faisal Jamil, Shabir Ahmad
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Mission-critical networks (MCNs) increasingly depend on distributed intelligence for intrusion detection but remain susceptible to adversarial threats and poisoned feedback. As cyber-physical systems scale, ensuring secure and adaptive anomaly detection across heterogeneous, edge-centric environments is vital. Centralized approaches suffer from latency and single points of failure, while conventional federated learning lacks trust and poisoning resilience. These gaps expose MCNs to inference inconsistencies, delayed mitigation, and adversarial manipulation under real-time constraints. This paper presents a federated swarm intelligence framework for secure anomaly detection and adversarial resilience in MCNs. The system integrates a hybrid global-local anomaly detection model, composed of an autoencoder and an isolation forest with a reputation-based belief propagation protocol. Each node performs local inference and shares Indicators of Compromise (IOCs) with trusted peers. Trust scores are dynamically updated using a similarity-weighted belief function, allowing the swarm to isolate poisoned nodes and maintain robust consensus. A self-healing loop filters malicious contributions from global model updates, ensuring continuous adaptation to threat evolution. Experimental results across TON_IoT, CICIDS2017, and UNSW-NB15 datasets demonstrate improved detection accuracy, reduced false positives, and resilience against up to 30% adversarial node participation. This work establishes a scalable defense paradigm for edge-intelligent, real-time MCN environments.

title: Practical solutions to reduce high incident energy in the arc flash study
authors: Claudio Sergio Mardegan, Marcio Bottaro, Filipe Barcelos Resende, Wendler Luis Nogueira Matos
publish: 2025 IEEE ESW Brazil – Electrical Safety Workshop Brazil (ESW Brazil)
abstract: The Arc Flash study is essential for enhancing electrical safety by determining the appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) required when accessing electrical panels. The standard that provides guidelines for the Arc Flash study is NFPA 70E. When calculating incident energy, this standard highlight various methods, with the choice depending on several factors, such as voltage level and whether the arc occurs within a panel or in open air. For voltage levels between 208V and 15kV, the IEEE 1584 calculation method is generally applied. Above 15 kV, if the arc occurs within a panel, extending the IEEE 1584 method can be considered. However, if the arc occurs in open air, Ralph Lee’s method, EPRI, or NESC are used. When high incident energy values are identified, particularly in low-voltage industrial systems, certain mitigation techniques should be recommended in the Arc Flash study. As a best practice, if the incident energy exceeds 8 cal/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, mitigation measures must be proposed. The following options should be assessed based on technical and economic criteria: adjusting the protective device settings, implementing a second set of settings, installing an arc protection relay, or utilizing an Arcing Quenching Device (AQD). Ultimately, if mitigation is not feasible, the panel should only be operated when de-energized. Therefore, it is crucial to apply the appropriate incident energy calculation method while also considering possible energy reduction strategies. To support engineers in selecting the most suitable approach for a given system, an Arc Flash study flowchart will be presented, comparing different solutions to minimize the risk of people injury and equipment damage.

title: JAFS: Construction of Japanese Anime Face and Speech Dataset for Cross-Modal Speech Synthesis
authors: Haruto Kikuchi, Takashi Nose, Yu Hayashizaki, Sumiharu Kobayashi, Kei Hashimoto, Akinori Ito
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper presents the construction and analysis of the Japanese Anime Face and Speech (JAFS) dataset for cross-modal speech synthesis from anime-style facial images. Speech data were collected from female characters in Japanese games and paired with similar character images using facial feature ex- traction and similarity matching. The resulting dataset includes 111 speakers and 3,330 facial images. t-SNE visualization of the constructed facial image data shows distinct clusters that retain character-specific features, supporting its potential for anime character-aware face-to-speech synthesis. This dataset lays the foundation for anime character-aware face-to-speech synthesis and offers valuable resources for future research in cross-modal speech synthesis.

title: Analysis of Electrical Fires in Brazil
authors: Joao Pedro Kiedzerski Silva, Jose Barbosa Oliveira, Hedio Tatizawa, Danilo Ferreira de Souza
publish: 2025 IEEE ESW Brazil – Electrical Safety Workshop Brazil (ESW Brazil)
abstract: Electrical fires represent a considerable proportion of accidents in Brazil, generating losses and fatalities. The lack of integrated studies and consolidated data makes it difficult to understand these events. This article analyzes data on electrical fires in Brazil in 2024, highlighting the occurrence by region, month, and cause category, based on 1.191 cases and 50 deaths. Homes were the main place of occurrence (528 cases, 44 %) and accounted for 92 % (46) of fatalities. There was an increase of 19 % compared to 2023 (1.004→ 1.191), totaling an accumulated growth of 104 % between 2020 and 2024. The methodology adopted follows the Abracopel protocol, including news collection, validation with the Fire Department and consolidation in a database. The results show a higher incidence in the Southeast (29 %), but a higher mortality rate in the Northeast (8 % vs. 2 % in the Southeast), indicating a disparity in the prevention and emergency response infrastructure. The study provides an up-to-date overview to support prevention and awareness policies.

title: Study on Hybrid Recycling CLSC Based on Fuzzy Neural Network Robust Control
authors: Haifeng Guo, Shanshan Xie
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: Aiming at the closed-loop supply chain with recycling and remanufacturing time lag, production time lag, order supply time lag, and parameter uncertainty, a class of closed-loop supply chain with a hybrid recycling channel consisting of consumer, retailer, manufacturer, and ecommerce channel is designed. In this case, the recycling channel includes recycling by third-party recyclers and recycling by the manufacturer itself, and the supply chain dynamics are modeled based on the scenario of demand uncertainty. In order to study this type of supply chain, a fuzzy neural network robust control approach is proposed and simulated using MATLAB/Simulink. The analysis of the results shows that the method can effectively suppress the uncertainty effects during the operation of the closed-loop supply chain with mixed recycling channels, so that the inventory, production, and ordering states of the supply chain are ideal, and it has an effective suppression effect on the bullwhip effect.

title: Intelligent Ground Operations at Airports: A Study on the Implementation of Smart Underground Fueling Systems for Aircraft
authors: Chun-Ting You, Cheng-You Yu, Liang-Bi Chen, Szu-Yu Kuo
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study examines the feasibility and acceptance of Smart Underground Refueling Systems at airports. As the demand for air transportation continues to rise, traditional ground refueling methods encounter significant challenges related to efficiency and safety. To address these issues, this research advocates for the implementation of underground refueling systems, which aim to optimize ramp space and mitigate associated risks. Employing the Technology-Organization-Environment (TOE) framework, the study analyzes the perspectives of fuel personnel at two international airports in Taiwan. The findings indicate that a majority of respondents hold a favorable view of the proposed system, perceiving it as a means to enhance both efficiency and safety.

authors: Shruti Jain, Deepak Jain
publish: 2024 Conference on Lasers and Electro-Optics Pacific Rim (CLEO-PR)
abstract: We report novel ZBLAN fibers exploiting S<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">p</inf>FWM, generating single-photons in the 3 to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \mu\ \mathrm{m}$</tex> range. title: Query matching for spatio-temporal action detection with query-based object detector
authors: Shimon Hori, Toru Tamaki
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In this paper, we propose a method that extends DETR, a query-based object detection model, to spatio-temporal action detection. Our proposed method applies DETR to each frame and uses the feature shift. Since object queries may correspond to different objects across frames, we introduce query matching to align queries for the same object across frames.

title: Healthcare Data Exchange: Ensuring Security Through Blockchain Technique
authors: P Kumar, S Senthil Pandi, L Bharath Kumar, R Karthick
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: Blockchain technology integration in healthcare has become a game-changing strategy to solve important issues with safe data exchange. In order to ensure data quality, openness, and privacy, this article investigates a blockchain-based architecture for safe and scalable data sharing in the healthcare industry. The suggested architecture makes use of encryption methods, consensus processes, and smart contracts to facilitate safe stakeholder communication. Modular features designed for real-time auditing, access control, and interoperability are introduced in the suggested model. Datasets that replicate patient records and medical transactions are part of the implementation, and they have been verified by thorough performance measurements. The study highlights how blockchain can be used to solve practical problems like privacy concerns, interoperability problems, and data breaches. The suggested architecture guarantees the security, accessibility, and reliability of critical healthcare data by utilizing sophisticated algorithms such as SHA-256, Merkle Trees, and smart contract-based RBAC. By combining these technologies, a strong answer to contemporary healthcare problems is offered, setting the stage for future developments like AI-powered analytics and Internet of Things-enabled monitoring systems. When compared to conventional systems, the results show increased user trust, security, and efficiency. This study offers a roadmap for next advancements and opens the door for safe, scalable blockchain-enabled healthcare systems.

title: Applicability of Low-Rank Adaptation in Vision Transformer at Fine-Grained Image Classification Tasks
authors: Hikaru Fukusaka, Lin Meng
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: The emergence of Transformer networks has significantly impacted the advancement of AI technology. This influence has extended to computer vision (CV), with the introduction of Vision Transformer (ViT) achieving state-of-the-art (SOTA) results in areas such as image recognition and object detection. A noted drawback of Transformer architectures is their large number of parameters, which poses a significant challenge, particularly in natural language processing, due to severe GPU memory limitations. To address this, Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA), a method for reducing trainable parameters, has been proposed and has garnered considerable attention, primarily in the field of finetuning. This paper analyzes the impact of applying LoRA, originally developed within the Transformer domain, to ViT, which share the same underlying Transformer architecture. The analysis is conducted by fine-tuning pre-trained with ImageNet-21k Dataset and finetuned with ImageNet-1k weights using the Oxford-IIIT Pet Dataset and the Food-101 Dataset. The training of ViT necessitates a large volume of data. This poses a challenge for finetuning in domains where available datasets contain only a limited number of images. The findings of this investigation reveal a 1-2% improvement in accuracy when using LoRA, and demonstrate a reduction of approximately 5GB in GPU memory under a batch size of 128.

title: Contour Analysis System of Thick Plates in Hot Rolling via Machine Vision
authors: Zhidong Guan, Jinliang Ding
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: The hot rolling process of thick plates presents significant challenges in monitoring contour anomalies, which can adversely impact product quality and production efficiency. Tra-ditional monitoring methods often lack accuracy and involve high maintenance costs. This paper proposes a machine vision-based system for real-time contour monitoring during hot rolling. The system captures and processes visual data, integrates sensor-based process parameters, and employs a content-based recommendation algorithm to suggest optimized control variables.By incorporating visual analytics and supporting human-machine interaction, the system enhances production control, reduces operational costs, and improves product quality. Validation with real industrial data demonstrates its effectiveness in contour monitoring, anomaly detection, and process optimization. The proposed approach provides a practical and scalable solution with substantial industrial value.
