title: Skin Cancer Classification Using Deep Learning Techniques
authors: R N Uma Mahesh, G H Anvitha, V G Arpitha, H Vandana, Neha Khanum
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: One of the most common types of cancer in the world is skin cancer, and successful treatment and higher patient survival rates depend on early detection. Manual examination and clinical knowledge are the mainstays of traditional diagnostic techniques, which can be laborious and subjective. In this paper, skin image classification is carried out using a deep Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). Our approach classifies dermoscopic images into three categories: benign, malignant, and normal. The proposed system achieves an accuracy of $84.14 \%$ in the test data set, with a class-specific F1 score of 0.95 for normal, 0.85 for benign and 0.78 for malignant cases. We implement comprehensive data preprocessing techniques and a custom CNN architecture, demonstrating the system’s potential as a reliable support tool for dermatologists in early skin cancer detection.

title: Think Fast, Infer Smart: A Hybrid Distributed LLMs Inference at the Wireless Edge
authors: Abdullatif Albaseer, Elmahdi Bentafat, Moqbel Hamood, Mohamed Abdallah, Ala Al-Fuqaha, Mounir Hamdi
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Deploying large language models (LLMs) at the wireless edge is a promising solution to meet the low-latency, high-computation demands of next-generation AI applications. Although the existing literature has introduced approaches to enable distributed LLM inference, these methods largely overlook the distinct computational and communication characteristics of the two-phase LLM inference process—the pre-fill and decode phases. This oversight leads to suboptimal performance and limits scalability in real-world deployments. To address these issues, we propose a novel collaborative inference framework that strategically minimizes inference latency by optimally distributing computational loads across edge devices, the edge server, and the cloud. Our approach introduces a hybrid framework that combines head-wise parallel processing with layer-wise partitioning of LLM models, supported by a dual-phase optimization strategy. In the pre-fill phase, we optimize assigning attention heads to selected edge devices for parallel computation and efficient resource use. We then optimize for minimal latency by selecting participants, determining head assignments per device, and allocating bandwidth while meeting all constraints. In the de-code phase, our framework adaptively decides whether to execute computations locally on the edge server, offload them to the cloud, or redistribute tasks among edge devices, optimizing this decision based on the remaining latency budget and the sequential nature of the decode phase. The simulation results demonstrate that the proposed framework significantly outperforms the baseline methods, achieving a 56% reduction in inference latency, 40% improvement in bandwidth efficiency and 35% improvement in resource utilization.

title: Predicting Academic Performance: Machine Learning Insights into GPA Determinants
authors: Sakib Hossain, Afzalul Abid Nazir, Subrina Islam Prity, Islam Saiful, Md Saef Ullah Miah, Abhijit Bhowmik
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: This study looks at predicting student GPA using machine learning models based on academic and non-academic data. Random Forest (RF), Gradient Boosting (GB), AdaBoost, Linear Regression (LR), Ridge, Lasso, Support Vector Regression (SVR), K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), and XGBoost are among the models evaluated. R-squared ($\mathbf{R}^{\mathbf{2}}$), Mean Squared Error (MSE) and Mean Absolute Error (MAE) are used to assess performance. The most accurate models were Ridge and Linear Regression with accuracy of $95.68 \%$, which suggested a significant linear connection between variables and GPA. Support Vector Regression (SVR) and XGBoost also performed well but did not surpass the linear models. Because of its simplicity and accuracy, the research identifies Ridge Regression as the best model for predicting GPA, providing insightful information that may help educational institutions support student interventions.

title: Modular Architecture for Robustness Assessment in AI Using Smart Inference
authors: Sergillam B. Oliveira, Eddie B. De Lima Filho, Lucas C. Cordeiro
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This article proposes a modular architecture to assess the robustness of artificial intelligence (AI) algorithms in synthetic inference scenarios. The approach introduces the smart inference pipeline (SIP), which applies configurable transformations to data, labels, and hyperparameters, simulating realistic noise and configuration errors. Five algorithms and five datasets were tested under controlled experiments, whose results show that perturbations consistently reduce model performance, with Gaussian naive bayes demonstrating the highest resilience. SIP supports reproducible and extensible experimentation, offering a solid foundation for robustness testing in AI pipelines.

title: Large-Scale Federated Learning for Hybrid Cell-Free Massive MIMO and Visible Light Communication Systems
authors: S. Mohammad Sheikholeslami, Pai Chet Ng, Konstantinos N. Plataniotis
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Next-generation wireless networks demand scalable and low-latency distributed learning frameworks that can operate across diverse communication environments. This paper proposes CFVLC, a novel large-scale Federated Learning (FL) framework over a resource-constrained wireless network, involving outdoor users connected through Cell-Free massive MIMO (CF-mMIMO) system, and indoor users distributed across multiple environments supported by Visible Light Communication (VLC) technology. To address the extreme system heterogeneity from different environments, CFVLC introduces an optimization problem that jointly performs device selection and resource allocation to minimize training latency across the network. We propose a two-stage heuristic solution that intelligently balances user participation across environments with varying resources and channel conditions. Extensive simulations demonstrate that our approach significantly improves training latency and model performance compared to conventional schemes, highlighting the benefits of integrating outdoor CF-mMIMO and indoor VLC technologies for large-scale FL.

title: Skeleton-based Fall Detection via Graph Convolutional Networks
authors: Futa Misumi, Qiu Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: In rapidly aging societies such as Japan, falls in elderly care facilities often go undetected, leading to severe injuries. While conventional models like ST-GCN are used for skeleton-based fall detection, they suffer from limited accuracy and high model complexity. To overcome these limitations, we propose a real-time fall detection system using BlockGCN, a high-performance graph convolutional network (GCN). Human skeletons are extracted from video using AlphaPose, and joint coordinates are interpolated from 13 to 25 joints to match BlockGCN input requirement. The model was trained on a subset of the NTU RGB+D dataset, focusing on seven fall-related actions, and evaluated using videos from side, front, and rear views. Results show that BlockGCN improved fall detection accuracy by approximately 40% compared to ST-GCN, achieving up to 100% in certain scenarios.

title: Age-Aware CSI Acquisition of a Finite-State Markovian Channel
authors: Onur Ayan, Jiping Luo, Xueli An, Nikolaos Pappas
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: The Age of Information (AoI) has emerged as a critical metric for quantifying information freshness; however, its interplay with channel estimation in partially observable wireless systems remains underexplored. This work considers a transmitter-receiver pair communicating over an unreliable channel with time-varying reliability levels. The transmitter observes the instantaneous link reliability through a channel state information acquisition procedure, during which the data transmission is interrupted. This leads to a fundamental trade-off between utilizing limited network resources for either data transmission or channel state information acquisition to combat the channel aging effect. Assuming the wireless channel is modeled as a finite-state Markovian channel, we formulate an optimization problem as a partially observable Markov decision process (POMDP), obtain the optimal policy through the relative value iteration algorithm, and demonstrate the efficiency of our solution through simulations. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work to aim for an optimal scheduling policy for data transmissions while considering the effect of channel state information aging.

title: Automated Detection and Counting of Nematodes in Microscopy Images Using Advanced Object Detection Models
authors: Haoyu Niu, Andreas Westphal, YangQuan Chen
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: Nematodes are microscopic, non-segmented round-worms that play a crucial role in soil and water ecosystems. While most nematodes feed on bacteria, fungi, or other microorganisms, a small fraction are parasitic to humans, livestock, or crops, attracting special attention from nematologists. For instance, root-knot and root lesion nematodes cause billions of dollars in annual crop losses. Due to their microscopic size and need to extract them from their habitats, identifying and counting nematodes is labor-intensive and time-consuming task conducted by specially trained nematologists. To address this, an RGB microscope nematode image dataset, designed for nematode counting and related research, was developed. This study explored and fine-tunes several object detection models, including You Only Look Once (YOLO) models, Real-Time Detection Transformer (RT-DETR), and Florence-2, for accurate nematode detection. In the results, most models achieved a mean Average Precision (mAP@50) around 0.7, with YOLOv8 outperforming the others, achieving a mAP@50 of 0.75 and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> of 0.9 for nematode counting. This framework represents a novel approach for nematode detection and counting.

title: MERMAID: a Multi-armEd bandit approach foR optiMal cArrier selection In OFDM-based unDerwater acoustic networks
authors: Fabio Busacca, Laura Galluccio, Andrea Panebianco, Sergio Palazzo, Raoul Raftopoulos, Dario Scuderi
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Reliable communication in UnderWater (UW) environments is challenged by limited bandwidth, high temporal variability, and significant propagation delays. Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) has emerged as a promising solution for UW communication; however, its performance heavily depends on dynamic subcarrier selection to adapt to fluctuating channel conditions. This paper presents MERMAID, a novel framework based on a Combinatorial Multi-Armed Bandit (CMAB) approach for adaptive subcarrier selection in Underwater Acoustic Networks (UANs). MERMAID dynamically activates subcarriers based on real-time Packet Delivery Ratio (PDR) feedback to maximize reliability while minimizing energy consumption. Unlike Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) techniques, which require extensive training and high computational overhead, MERMAID is specifically designed for resource-constrained UW nodes, enabling fast convergence and lightweight operation. We implement MERMAID in the DESERT simulator and benchmark its performance against state-of-the-art DRL baselines. Simulation results show that MERMAID improves PDR by up to 21.15% and reduces energy consumption by up to 45.40%. These findings highlight MERMAID as a scalable, efficient, and high-performance solution for real-world Internet of Underwater Things (IoUT) applications. The framework aligns with the 6G vision by advancing intelligent and energy-efficient connectivity in harsh environments, highlighting its potential to extend communication paradigms to UW networks.

title: Safety considerations for electric vehicles in residential condominiums
authors: Estellito Rangel Junior
publish: 2025 IEEE ESW Brazil – Electrical Safety Workshop Brazil (ESW Brazil)
abstract: As a basic characteristic, electric vehicles (EVs) are powered by batteries that can be recharged even at conventional outlets. However, since there is a concentration of buildings in urban centers and EVs will be parked in common areas, the provision of charging points brings some challenges, not only in relation to the capacity of the electrical grid to meet the new demand, but also to the risks of explosions and “spontaneous” fires caused by the EVs’ Li-ion batteries. This article questions the statistics about the possibility of fires in EVs, presents firefighters’ concerns, debates initiatives by regulatory agencies and makes recommendations aiming to reduce the impacts of EVs on Brasilian condominiums built at a time when only combustion-powered cars existed.

title: Towards Zero-Trust Green Security: Intelligent Interference Management and Rechargeable Jamming Mines in Ultra-Dense Networks
authors: Muhammad Shahzad Arif, Sami Muhaidat, Paschalis C. Sofotasios
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Deploying small cells to densify heterogeneous networks (HetNets) provides a scalable way to meet the growing demand for diverse mobile services. Aggressive frequency reuse in ultra-dense networks (UDNs) further enhances spectral efficiency but intensifies inter-cell interference. With intelligent management, this interference can be harnessed to strengthen network-wide physical layer security (PLS). To this end, and in line with green-security principles, we propose that base stations collaboratively shape interference and deploy rechargeable jamming mines (RJMs) to expand secure zones by injecting targeted jamming around potential eavesdroppers, eliminating the need for dedicated jammers. To realize this, we develop a multi-agent reinforcement learning framework in which each BS independently optimizes beam orientation, transmit power, resource block allocation, and RJM activation under a zero-trust model that treats every location as a potential eavesdropper. A hybrid reward function aligns local actions with network-wide security goals, and state-dependent action masking reduces the policy search space. Extensive results show that the proposed approach substantially enlarges secure-area coverage, scales efficiently in ultra-dense deployments, and establishes a practical, sustainable foundation for collaborative PLS in next-generation wireless networks.

title: Brain-Inspired Parallel Data Intelligence: a Generality-Specificity Fused Approach
authors: Lingzhao Meng, Weishan Zhang, Fulong Xu, Liang Han, Shuai Guo, Tao Chen, Yuru Liu, Baoyu Zhang, Shudong Wang, Hui Zhang, Fei-Yue Wang
publish: 2025 21st IEEE International Conference on Mechatronic and Embedded Systems and Applications (MESA)
abstract: Complex systems face incomplete data challenges due to privacy constraints, as well as difficulties in balancing generalization and personalized adaptation in cognitive models. Based on brain cognitive mechanisms and parallel systems theory, we propose the brain-inspired parallel data intelligence approach that fuses generality and specificity through hierarchical collaboration of data intelligence, model intelligence, and decision intelligence (3I). Specifically, data intelligence utilizes virtual data generation engines to adaptively generate virtual data and leverages blockchain to ensure the trustworthy circulation of data. Model intelligence establishes a trusted federated model factory integrating large and small models, achieving personalized model generation and bidirectional knowledge optimization between large and small models. Decision intelligence designs multi-agent collaborative mechanisms to generate specialized decision solutions and support self-optimization. We validated the method’s effectiveness in smart community scenarios. The approach effectively addresses the challenges of incomplete data and balancing generalization and personalization in cognitive models, significantly improving the adaptability and robustness of the system.

title: Iris Recognition with Selectively Denoising, Data Augmentation and CNNs
authors: Guangyi Chen, Wen Fang Xie, Ibrahim Babiker
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: Iris recognition is an extremely important research topic in computer vision. In this paper, we propose a new method for iris recognition. We selectively reduce noise from the iris images with denoising convolutional neural networks (DnCNN) and crop the iris regions by detecting outer circles in the iris images. Without selectively denoising, we may fail to detect iris regions correctly, which is undesirable. We augment the iris images by smoothing and rotating the iris images many times. We train our CNNs with the augmented iris images and then classify the unknown iris images to known classes. Experiments demonstrate that our new method achieves very high recognition rates even when random noise is introduced to the dataset for iris recognition.

title: The Impact of Contact Spot Proximity on the Validity of Greenwood’s Model
authors: Robert D. Malucci
publish: 2025 IEEE 70th Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts (HLM)
abstract: The Greenwood model is an approximate method using interacting micro-currents to obtain contact resistance and micro-current distributions. This process was analyzed to assess the limits that Greenwood’s approximations represent. This was done using the Greenwood method directly and considering the solutions to Poisson’s equation for finite boundary conditions. It was found that Greenwood’s method is reasonably accurate when separation of the contact spots is at least several spot sizes (5 or 6 diameters). When the proximity falls below this level the individual spot constrictions become distorted and adjacent spots appear to merge and exhibit single spot behavior. It is believed that this conclusion is valid for real contact interfaces having varying spot sizes and shapes.

title: Brain Rot Detection in Users: Analyzing Behavioral Insights from Large-Scale User Interactions
authors: Kein Yamada, Hiroshi Watanabe
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Social media are extensively utilized by individuals across all age groups, greatly influencing modern society. However, certain types of content can lead to severe user addiction, often colloquially referred to as “brain rot.” We propose an approach for detecting users with strong social media addiction by analyzing user interaction data and the categorical characteristics of consumed media content. Our method investigates behavioral patterns associated with high levels of addiction using a dataset that captures detailed user engagement metrics. Utilizing SHapley Additive exPlanations for feature analysis, we apply decision tree classifiers and random forest to identify users exhibiting addictive behavior. Our research aims to clarify the factors contributing to social media addiction, providing actionable insights for the social media management of consumers.

title: Application of a Model-Driven OpenROADM System Based on NETCONF and RESTCONF in Data Center Interconnect
authors: Jiawei Qi, Yu Ling
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: This paper describes the design and implementation of a model-driven OpenROADM system for Data Center Interconnect (DCI), utilizing standardized YANG data models together with NETCONF and RESTCONF protocols. The proposed architecture unifies the configuration and management of multi-vendor optical network devices, enabling automated and consistent operations across heterogeneous environments. By integrating northbound interfaces, centralized data storage, business logic modules, and a hardware abstraction layer, the system supports efficient automated configuration, real-time status monitoring, and seamless network management. Comparative evaluations demonstrate that this model-driven approach offers significant advantages over traditional CLI methods in interface consistency, batch processing, automation, and system usability. These results support the development of robust, intelligent, and scalable DCI optical networks.

title: Research on Fusion Positioning Weight Allocation Algorithm Based on Pearson Correlation Coefficient
authors: Li He, Yue Zhang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: With the popularization of applications such as intelligent warehousing and smart buildings, the demand for high-precision positioning in complex environments is growing rapidly. Traditional positioning technologies (such as WiFi, Bluetooth, etc.) have insufficient accuracy due to multipath effects. Although emerging technologies such as UWB and lidar have superior performance, a single technology is difficult to meet the needs of diverse scenarios. To this end, this study proposes a multi-sensor fusion positioning scheme to improve system robustness through heterogeneous data complementation. Aiming at the key problems of multi-source data fusion, Pearson correlation is used to quantify the positioning contribution of each sensor, and an adaptive weight distribution mechanism is established. For the two-dimensional positioning scenario, the weight distribution strategy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$x$</tex>-axis and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$y$</tex>-axis coordinates is further optimized. Experiments show that this method effectively improves the positioning accuracy in complex environments and provides reliable technical support for applications such as intelligent transportation, industrial automation. The research results not only optimize the multi-source data fusion algorithm, but also provide a new idea for the design of high-precision positioning system.

title: Toward Clinically Interpretable Postoperative Prediction: A Diffusion-Based Framework with Unsupervised Geometric Priors
authors: Jiya Yun, Fei Ma, Baoru Huang, Chengyu Wang
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: Predicting postoperative outcomes is crucial for effective communication and planning in aesthetic medicine; however, current approaches often rely on manual measurements performed by clinicians. We present an annotation-free pipeline that integrates unsupervised geometric priors with diffusion-based inpainting to visualise postoperative results. Structural constraints are derived from edge-based features within a standardised periocular region of interest, avoiding reliance on segmentation or landmarks while ensuring anatomical plausibility. We evaluate the pipeline on 131 paired preopera-tive-postoperative eyelid surgery samples under a zero-shot, cross-domain setting without fine-tuning or retraining. Quantitative results demonstrate strong performance across three dimensions: identity preservation, boundary consistency and perceptual quality. Qualitative analyses further confirm that the model produces natural, continuous creases aligned with postoperative morphology, while maintaining subject-specific identity and seamless blending. These findings highlight the feasibility of combining geometric priors with generative diffusion models for the prediction of interpretable and reproducible outcomes. While some failures remain in underrepresented subgroups, the proposed zero-shot, annotation-free workflow demonstrates potential as a lightweight tool for surgical visualisation, with applicability beyond eyelid surgery to broader aesthetic and reconstructive domains.

title: Intelligent Bandwidth Allocation Using Taguchi Optimization for Interference Mitigation in Multi-Station Wireless Networks
authors: Wei-Yu Lin, Wen-Hsing Kuo
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Wireless spectrum technologies are widely used, but adding new devices often causes interference with existing equipment on similar frequencies, reducing efficiency. This paper proposes an automated mechanism for efficient frequency band allocation in multi-device wireless networks. Based on the Taguchi-gradient optimization method, it con-siders device power, channel characteristics, and frequency usage to assign optimal frequencies, minimizing interference and enhancing performance. Simulations show the method achieves an average performance gain of 1.8 dB per device and reduces computation time by 30% compared to brute-force approaches.

title: Traffic Anomaly Analysis of IP Network Based on Kmeans and CART Model
authors: Tiantian Lv, Le Zhang, Qiong Sun, Na Ma, Ying Wang, Siqi Zuo
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: With the rapid progress of network communication technology, anomalous traffic brings more and more complicated problems to communication network management. Therefore, the detection of distributed hidden traffic anomalies has become one of the basic tasks to ensure the security of communication networks, and it is also very important to improve the emergency response capability of communication network systems. This paper proposed a traffic anomaly analysis of IP MAN traffic based on K-means+CART. After feature numerical and principal component analysis of the NSL-KDD dataset, the training instances are divided into clusters using the k - Means++ clustering method by using Euclidean distance similarity in the first place. In each cluster, this paper builds a CART decision tree to represent the density region of normal or abnormal instances, and ultimately the model will be comprehensively evaluated using methods such as TPR, FPR, and ROC curves. The evaluation results show that the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F}$</tex>-measure values of the models whose main features are similar to Dos and Probe attack detection are 0.99 and 0.90, which are good; the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F}$</tex>-measure value of the model whose main feature is similar to R2L attack detection is 0.74, which is fair; and the model whose main feature is similar to U2R attack detection needs to be further optimised.

title: A Hybrid Method Combining Deep Learning and Interpretable Visual Features for Tongue Image Analysis in Traditional Chinese Medicine
authors: Yili Chen, Li Zheng, Shan Liao, Ying Zhu, Wei Yuan
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: Modern diagnosis is paying more and more attention to noninvasive and rapid detection methods. As a representative technology of traditional Chinese medicine (TCM), tongue diagnosis learns the patient's physical condition and pathological level by observing the changes of tongue texture and tongue coating, therefore this field has attracted more and more attention. However, the standard tongue diagnosis depends on empirical judgment, and there is no standard paradigm. In light of this, this study proposes a fusion diagnosis architecture that combines deep learning and manual features. Firstly, a multi-layer nested segmentation model is proposed to achieve more accurate tongue segmentation in complex backgrounds; Then, manual features are extracted from the segmented tongue region, and a machine learning classifier is used for attribute recognition. This method not only improves the segmentation accuracy, but also enhances the transparency and clinical credibility of the model through interpretable manual features, and provides an effective solution for tongue diagnosis automation.

title: Coexistence Study Between GEO and LEO Satellites in the Q/V-Band
authors: Xavier Leturc, Dorin Panaitopol, Sorya Tong, Christophe J. Le Martret
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper studies the coexistence between a geosynchronous Equatorial orbit (GEO) satellite at nadir and a low Earth orbit (LEO) satellite. Both satellites operate in the Q/V frequency band, identified as potential candidate for the service link of 6G non-terrestrial communications. The two satellites on different orbits use either the same communication channel or adjacent channels. As a consequence, communications between the satellites and their associated user equipment on Earth are subject to interference in both downlink (DL) and uplink (UL), thus reducing the throughput. The level of experienced interference depends on the LEO satellite elevation, and on the adjacent channel interference ratio (ACIR) in case of adjacent channel interference. The coexistence results obtained for both DL and UL of the two considered orbits provide guidelines regarding the maximum elevation for the LEO satellite at which the 3GPP requirements are fulfilled. For instance, the required value of ACIR with respect to the maximum acceptable throughput loss is hereby evaluated.

title: Alternatives to Slip Rings - A Review
authors: Glenn Dorsey, Jerry Lichter
publish: 2025 IEEE 70th Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts (HLM)
abstract: A slip ring using sliding electrical contacts is the typical "go to" solution for transferring electrical power and data across a rotating interface. As digital data rates and rotational speeds continue to increase and maintenance requirements become more demanding, slip ring limitations are becoming problematic in some applications. There are four technologies that are being used to address these limitations; two of these solutions are used for data and two are used for power and control. The two data solutions are contactless electrical data transfer and fiber optic rotary joints, and the two power and control solutions are roll rings (rolling electrical contacts) and rotary transformers. All four of these technologies can be used to address limitations of slip rings and provide a reliable, high performance rotary joint. Although these technologies each address inherent weaknesses in sliding contacts, they are not without their own disadvantages. Consequently, these slip ring alternatives have all been slow to make their way into commercially available hardware despite their initial appeal. This review will demonstrate relative advantages and disadvantages of these technical solutions and will highlight promising applications for their implementation.

title: Evaluation of Press-Fit Zone Performance Across PCB Surface Finishes like ENIG, Immersion Tin, Immersion Silver, and OSP
authors: Akshata Sangle, Stefan Goetz, Florian Bruhn
publish: 2025 IEEE 70th Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts (HLM)
abstract: Press-fit zones, originally designed as simple square solid cross-sections for the telecommunications industry, have now become integral to a wide range of applications, from automotive to consumer electronics. Over time, these square pins have been adapted into different shapes and sizes to meet diverse application needs and environmental conditions. Typically, a press-fit zone is inserted into a printed circuit board (PCB) hole, forming a stable, gas-tight connection with the plated through-hole. The overall performance of press-fit zones is largely influenced by both the design of the press-fit and the surface finish of the PCB. The PCB itself has undergone significant advancements, especially in surface finishes. Traditionally, hot air solder leveling was commonly used, but with the introduction of lead-free regulations, alternative finishes have emerged. Among the most commonly used finishes for press-fit applications are immersion tin (ImSn), favored in Europe for its cost-effectiveness, electroless nickel immersion gold (ENIG) and immersion silver (ImAg) for their superior electrical properties, and organic solderability preservatives (OSP), which are increasingly popular in Asia due to their affordability. While extensive research has been conducted on PCB surface finishes alone and their individual benefits and drawbacks, the interaction between press-fit zones and these finishes is still underexplored. This paper examines the interconnection performance of commonly used press-fit zone designs—such as spring shape and eye of needle with PCB finishes including ENIG, ImSn, ImAg, and OSP. Through extensive testing, we analyze insertion and retention forces, contact resistance, and long-term stability to determine the impact of these surface finishes on press-fit performance. The findings provide valuable insights for optimizing press-fit technology in various applications, enhancing the reliability and efficiency of electronic assemblies.

title: Experimental Evaluation of a Power Thyristor-Based Industrial Arc-Flash Quenching Device
authors: Fernando Venâncio Amaral, Victor Hugo Soares Lopes, Claudio Alvares Conceição, Filipe Barcelos Resende, Sidelmo Magalhães Silva, Braz de Jesus Cardoso Filho
publish: 2025 IEEE ESW Brazil – Electrical Safety Workshop Brazil (ESW Brazil)
abstract: Increasing industry demand for a safe work environment has contributed to the proposition of solutions for the mitigation of arcing fault consequences on equipment and operational staff. This has been intensified after arc flash risk was recognized around the world as a danger no less important than electric shock. The latest arc quenching technology utilizes a power electronics-based switching device, consisting of two antiparallel thyristors connected in series with a current-limiting impedance. Upon detection of an arcing fault within the busbar of a switchgear or motor control center, the device activates instantaneously, extinguishing the arc within microseconds. This leads to a near-complete elimination of incident energy. The main advantage of this technology is the possibility of multiple usages without the substitution of any component after an operation, as well as the ability of real-time monitoring of the electronic devices for a reliable operation. On the other hand, the main concern is the application of power semiconductors under off-label conditions, which brought the demand for a deep study on the data sheet ratings and development/validation of a design strategy. This work presents the prototype of such a device, which has been drawn and built for power systems up to 440 V, 25 kA (three-phase, symmetrical bolted fault level), as well as experimental results of tests performed in the laboratory. The premises adopted for the design of the equipment are briefly discussed, and the test setup is described along with oscillograms and image captures of the developing/extinguishing faults. The tests have been progressively executed from low to high voltage and current levels, without and with the actuation of the equipment.

title: Hypervisor-Mediated Co-Design of Cybersecurity and Functional Safety in Vehicle E/E Architectures: A Cross-Domain Assurance Framework
authors: Yuzheng Zhang, Yiming Shu, Zejian Deng, Huizhe Zheng, Chen Sun
publish: 2025 21st IEEE International Conference on Mechatronic and Embedded Systems and Applications (MESA)
abstract: The rise of embodied intelligence in autonomous vehicles, driven by software-defined capabilities, demands a fundamental shift in their underlying Electrical/Electronic (E/E) architectures. While centralized architectures promise the computational power for advanced autonomy, they introduce critical challenges in ensuring safety and cybersecurity. The consolidation of mixed-criticality functions on shared hardware creates significant risks of fault propagation and vulnerability to cyber-attacks. This paper proposes a hypervisor-driven frame-work that provides a resilient foundation for intelligent vehicles. We present an E/E architecture that leverages a Type-1 hypervisor to enforce hardware-level isolation between functions. By partitioning the system into independent virtual machines, we safely co-locate ASIL-D (Automotive Safety Integrity Level) tasks with general-purpose applications, preventing interference and containing threats. Our evaluation demonstrates that this partitioned architecture improves fault coverage by 21.4% compared to non-isolated approaches, significantly enhancing system resilience. This approach ensures that the vehicle’s intelligent systems operate safely, securely, and deterministically, even under complex, dynamic conditions.

title: An Explainable AI Framework for Intrusion Detection Using SHAP and LIME
authors: Deepika Goyal, Sunil K. Singh, Sudhakar Kumar, Vanshika Chilkoti, Kwok Tai Chui, Ching-Hsien Hsu, Brij B. Gupta
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: As cyber threats grow more complex, traditional intrusion detection systems struggle to adapt while remaining interpretable. Though deep learning offers high detection accuracy, its lack of transparency limits use in critical environments. This paper proposes a deep learning-based IDS enhanced with explainable AI techniques SHAP for global feature insights and LIME for instance-level explanations. Using the CICIDS-2017 dataset, the framework combines neural feature extraction with temporal analysis, embedding interpretability into the detection process. This approach balances accuracy and transparency, supporting actionable alerts and regulatory compliance, and paving the way for trustworthy, AI-driven cybersecurity.

title: SHIELD: A Codebook-Based Methodology for RIS-Based Covert Communications
authors: Alexandros I. Papadopoulos, Dimitrios Tyrovolas, Alexandros Pitilakis, Panagiotis D. Diamantoulakis, Antonios Lalas, Konstantinos Votis, Nikolaos V. Kantartzis, Sotiris Ioannidis, Christos Liaskos
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Programmable Wireless Environments (PWEs) leverage Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RISes) to actively shape electromagnetic (EM) propagation, enabling advanced control over wireless channels. Beyond improved performance in B5G/6G networks, this control also introduces new security capabilities. Exploiting this, we propose RF-Fencing: a service that selectively suppresses EM signals toward eavesdroppers while preserving reliable communication for legitimate users, thereby significantly enhancing network covertness. Building on that, in this paper, we introduce SHIELD, the first RF-Fencing algorithm that partitions the PWE into Signal Suppression Areas (SSAs) and Signal Delivery Areas (SDAs) through on-the-fly merging of RIS configurations. Extensive EM analysis confirms SHIELD’s effectiveness in preventing wardens from intercepting critical information and achieving covert communications with minimal impact on legitimate users. Moreover, SHIELD can serve also as a jamming-mitigation mechanism and is applicable across various frequency bands and RIS designs.

title: FPGA-based real-time image tampering detection system for edge computing
authors: Yulin Fu, Jiale Li, Sean Longyu Ma, Chiu-Wing Sham
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: With the proliferation of sophisticated image manipulation techniques, robust and efficient tampering detection has become critically important for multimedia forensics and security applications. Although existing GPU or CPU-based deep learning detection methods are effective, they often rely on cloud services for data transmission, which introduces latency, bandwidth overhead, and privacy vulnerabilities. Edge computing provides a promising solution to this challenge. This paper presents a highly energy-efficient real-time image tampering detection system for edge computing environments. The system achieves significant energy efficiency improvements while maintaining detection accuracy by employing a novel hardware-software co-optimization approach. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed system outperforms comparable GPU and CPU implementations by 1.99× and 122.07× in energy efficiency, respectively.

title: Performance Evaluation of Scripting Languages on IoT Programming Solutions
authors: Xinyu Tan, Ilkka Kivelä, Ismo Hakala
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Integrating scripting languages into Internet of Things (IoT) programming is attracting a diverse community of developers, including casual programmers who may not have the time or inclination to learn complex system programming languages and domain experts (e.g., web developers and machine learning researchers) who are familiar with these languages from their own fields. These languages alleviate the challenges of embedded programming for IoT devices with their simpler syntax, comprehensive libraries, and interactive debugging support. However, the performance overhead of scripting languages on resource-constrained IoT devices is a concern. This paper presents a comparative analysis of five IoT scripting solutions: MicroPython and CircuitPython (Python), Espruino (JavaScript), NodeMCU (Lua), and Statechart4IoT (statechart script). The evaluation focuses on computational performance, event responsiveness, and memory consumption. The results reveal their strengths and weaknesses and provide feasibility information for developers choosing suitable solutions.

title:
State of the Art and First Synthetic Dataset for Misbehavior Detection with Collective Perception in [C-]V2X Networks
                    <sup>*</sup>
authors: Mehmet Fatih Yuce, Mehmet Ali Erturk, Muhammed Ali Aydin, Zeynep Gurkas-Aydin
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: As vehicular networks evolve into fully connected intelligent transportation systems, Collective Perception (CP) enables vehicles and infrastructure to share sensor data for enhanced situational awareness. However, this cooperation introduces new attack surfaces, making misbehavior detection essential for securing [C-]V2X communications. Despite advances in machine learning, no public dataset exists for misbehavior detection in CP scenarios. This work introduces the first synthetic dataset tailored for this purpose and applies a spatio-temporal graph neural network (ST-GNN) model to it. The paper also surveys state-of-the-art approaches to misbehavior detection in CP-enabled V2X and discusses integration into open-source cooperative perception frameworks. By addressing both data and model gaps, this study supports practical and secure deployment of CP in future V2X systems. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first publicly available dataset and evaluation pipeline supporting misbehavior detection over standardized CPMs in [C-]V2X scenarios.

title: AI Assisted Consumer Slicing
authors: Felix Dsouza, Nathalie Romo Moreno, Andreas Roos, Piotr Karaś, Andreas Kassler, Nico Bayer, Changsoon Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: As Fifth Generation Networks (5G) networks evolve, operators have an opportunity to create high-quality customer experiences by ensuring seamless and personalized connectivity through consumer-oriented network slicing. However, effectively managing consumer slices remains a challenge due to dynamic user demands, mobility patterns, and the need for real-time Quality of Service (QoS) assurance. This paper presents an Artificial Intelligence (AI)-driven framework for intelligent service feasibility, qualification, and provisioning in 5G networks, to automate consumer slicing. By leveraging real-time data from the Radio Access Network (RAN) and Core Network (CN), along with Service Quality Indicator (SQI), the framework enables dynamic resource allocation, predictive service qualification, and proactive slice optimization. Key innovations of the frame-work include the coherent integration of AI-driven slice load prediction, mobility-aware service provisioning, and automated QoS assurance via Application Programming Interfaces (APIs), ensuring optimal performance for consumer applications while maintaining compliance with Service Level Agreement (SLA). Experimental results demonstrate the framework’s capabilities in enhancing user experiences by enabling personalized slice selection, reducing service disruptions, and optimizing network resource utilization.

title: A Degradation-Enhanced Battery Remaining Useful Life Prediction Framework Based on Auxiliary Learning
authors: Zhirui Zhao, Juanru Zhao, Ning Li
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: Remaining useful life (RUL) prediction plays a critical role in lithium-ion battery (LIB) health management and predictive maintenance. However, existing models exhibit limited temporal modeling capabilities and often neglect spatial features, hindering their ability to learn complex battery degradation patterns. In addition, current RUL prediction frameworks fail to balance interpretability of optimization objectives with prediction accuracy. To address these issues, a Transformer-enhanced spatiotemporal model called BatFormer and an auxiliary learning-based RUL prediction framework named ALF are proposed. BatFormer extracts temporal and spatial features from historical battery data in parallel, and employs a lightweight gating mechanism for feature fusion, offering an effective solution for modeling complex battery degradation patterns from a spatiotemporal perspective. ALF treats RUL regression as the primary task and state of health (SOH) prediction as an auxiliary task, using degradation-oriented learning to support outcome-oriented learning, thereby enhancing prediction accuracy while improving the interpretability of the optimization objective. Furthermore, ALF is plug-and-play and can be directly integrated into any temporal model to improve its RUL prediction performance. To evaluate the effectiveness of BatFormer and ALF, model and framework comparison experiments were conducted on two widely used public datasets: NASA and CALCE. The results demonstrate that BatFormer significantly outperforms existing models in RUL prediction, and all models show varying degrees of accuracy improvement when integrated with ALF.

title: Stimulus Timing Strategies for Practical Auditory BCI Using Low-Cost EEG Devices
authors: Mikito Ogino
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Auditory brain–computer interfaces (BCIs) provide a vital communication channel for individuals with severe motor impairments, such as amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). A critical factor in optimizing performance in these systems is the stimulus onset asynchrony (SOA), which must be tailored to individual users. However, conventional calibration procedures that explore multiple SOAs are time-consuming and burdensome. In this study, we propose a novel approach to estimate the individual optimal SOA using simulated event-related potentials (ERPs) derived from a single baseline recording with a long SOA. These simulated responses are evaluated using the discriminability-based information transfer rate (dITR) to identify the SOA that best balances speed and accuracy for each user. Our method effectively captures inter-individual variability, including in ALS patients. The optimized SOAs were consistent with those used in previous studies. Furthermore, EEG data were collected using an affordable consumer-grade device (approx. USD 1,000), demonstrating practical feasibility. The findings support the use of adaptive, individualized SOA selection to enhance communication efficiency in real-world BCI applications.

title: Data Imputation using Machine Learning for Enhanced Predictive Modeling
authors: Shubham Kumar, Shubhashish Nayak, Pabitra Mohan Khilar
publish: 2025 Annual International Conference on Data Science, Machine Learning and Blockchain Technology (AICDMB)
abstract: In real-world datasets, handling missing data is still pretty challenging, especially in fields like healthcare, where accuracy and reliability are important. This work investigates the use of various distance criteria, such as Mahalanobis, Minkowski, Bray-Curtis, Canberra, and the Information Geometric Distance (IGD), as a similarity measure for fuzzy CMeans (FCM) clustering to handle missing values in the Fetal Health dataset. Clustering performance is evaluated before and after imputation by adding different missingness percentages to the dataset. A new method uses FCM-based cluster centers and membership degrees to fill in missing data, focusing on the reliability and compatibility of the imputation process. The findings show significant improvements in clustering quality after imputation, as measured by metrics such as the Silhouette score and intra-cluster variance. The robustness of FCM as a clustering technique with different similarity measures for imputation is demonstrated in this work. It provides invaluable insight for real-world healthcare analytics operations by comparing distance criteria for datasets with missing values.

title: On the Mutual Information of Large Stacked Intelligent Metasurfaces Based on Statistical CSI
authors: Anastasios Papazafeiropoulos, Ioannis Bartsiokas, Pandelis Kourtessis, Dimitra I. Kaklamani, Iakovos S. Venieris
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Stacked intelligent metasurfaces (SIM) transceiver design enables precoding in the wave domain while enjoying reduced energy consumption and hardware cost. On this ground and contrary to previous works studying various achievable rates, we derive the ergodic mutual information (EMI) at the large system region in closed form for SIM-assisted multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) systems based on statistical channel state information (CSI). Next, by applying a gradient ascent algorithm, we maximize the EMI with respect to the phase shifts of the two SIMs of the transceiver simultaneously, which saves significant overhead compared to a traditional alternating optimization (AO) approach. Simulations shed light in the performance of the proposed system at the large system limit and provide a comparison under different CSI conditions.

title: Field Task Optimization Based on IoT Data
authors: Deyang Liu, Dashuai Guo, Joseph. K.H. Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Traditional field task scheduling often suffers from inefficiencies due to a lack of real-time visibility into workshop operations. This paper proposes a Field Task Optimization system based on the IIoT to address these limitations through data-driven dynamic scheduling. Built upon the Volapu IIoT Suite, the system features a multi-layered architecture (Perception, Analysis/Optimization, Feedback). It incorporates custom-designed, EMI-resistant collectors for robust data acquisition and preliminary processing via onboard MCUs. The system leverages real-time data for equipment modeling, OEE evaluation, and anomaly detection. It generates optimized scheduling recommendations by assessing production capacity based on OEE and other key metrics. This enables dynamic task allocation and rescheduling, automated alerts for critical issues, and continuous improvement via a user feedback loop. This IIoT-driven approach offers a robust framework for enhancing operational efficiency and decision-making in modern manufacturing.

title: Improving DDoS Attack Detection via DNN and SHAP-based Feature Selection in Transfer Learning
authors: Takeru Saito, Qian Wu, Atsushi Kanai
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: The increasing frequency and complexity of Distributed Denial of Service attacks have driven extensive research into Intrusion Detection Systems based on machine learning. However, discrepancies (deployment shifts) between training datasets and real-world operational environments often significantly reduce detection accuracy.This study proposes a method combining Deep Neural Networks (DNN) and transfer learning to enhance detection accuracy even with limited labeled data. We evaluate three feature selection techniques—SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP), Random Forest, and Mutual Information —and demonstrate that SHAP achieves superior performance, with a Matthews Correlation Coefficient of 0.951 and a Balanced Accuracy of 0.975 using only 200 labeled samples.

title: Blockchain-Based Multi-Party Key Generation Using CSI: A Novel Hybrid Method
authors: Mehmet Ali Aygül, Hakan Ali Çırpan, Hüseyin Arslan
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel multi-party key generation method that jointly utilizes channel state information (CSI) and blockchain technology to enhance security in distributed systems. The proposed method starts by extracting CSI from wireless channels, leveraging the channels’ inherent randomness and reciprocity to generate secure key fragments shared among legitimate parties. Then, the key generation process involves several stages, including quantization, reconciliation, and privacy amplification, ensuring that the resulting keys are secure and synchronized across participants. Blockchain technology is then leveraged to securely commit these keys, ensuring that the key agreements are recorded in a decentralized, tamper-resistant ledger. The proposed method effectively combines the physical-layer properties of CSI with the decentralized nature of blockchain, providing robust protection against eavesdropping and tampering attacks. Theoretical analyses and simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in terms of key mismatch probability and secrecy capacity. Additionally, the randomness of the generated keys by the proposed method is validated using the National Institute of Standards and Technology randomness tests.

title: Optimizing Deployment and Partitioning Strategies for Aerial RIS-aided Uplink NOMA under Residual Hardware Impairments
authors: Mohd Hamza Naim Shaikh, Abdulkadir Celik, Sultangali Arzykulov, Ahmed M. Eltawil, Galymzhan Nauryzbayev
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: The incorporation of reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RISs) and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) presents considerable potential for improving the functionality of ground-based terrestrial Internet of Things (IoT) networks. This paper introduces a novel UAV deployment and aerial RIS partitioning mechanism for the uplink non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA)-based IoT networks under practical hardware constraints. The low-cost hardware of IoT devices results in imperfect successive interference cancellation (SIC) and distortion noise due to transceiver hardware impairments (T-HIs). Specifically, we have optimized the aerial RIS partitioning and its deployment to maximize the minimum rate under the impact of imperfect SIC and T-HIs. The numerical results show that the proposed scheme outperforms the benchmark. Through extensive simulations, we prove that the proposed UAV-based aerial RIS-aided uplink NOMA network significantly enhances the max-min fair rate.

title: Fire Inspection Drone with Laser Spatial Marking
authors: Chao-Chung Peng
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Recent advancements in consumer electronic UAV and its technology have enhanced public trust in drone-based aerial imaging for disaster prevention, particularly in fire detection. With lightweight design, real-time responsiveness, and high efficiency, drones are increasingly used for rapid deployment and aerial surveillance. Moreover, by equipping with optical, thermal, and laser sensors, drones can detect abnormal high-temperature zones and feedback real-time data to ground stations, improving situational awareness and decision-making. To this purpose, key capabilities include irregular flame recognition, fire source estimation, tracking, and spatial coordinate marking, which are essential for timely response and effective resource allocation. This paper focuses on the drone-based fire source localization techniques to support modern fire management systems. Experimental simulation demonstrates the concept of fire source marking system.

title: Enhancing Continuous Emotion Recognition via Visually Diverse Frame Selection
authors: Soki Saigo, Taiga Hayami, Hiroshi Watanabe
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Recent advances in artificial intelligence and computer vision have spurred growing interest in understanding human behavior and emotional states from a third-person perspective. In real-world applications such as security, public guidance, and AI-based scene understanding, it is often necessary to infer emotional states without direct interaction, relying instead on surrounding contextual and interpersonal cues. However, many existing studies rely solely on facial expressions and fail to capture emotions embedded in complex social or situational contexts. Although prior research has attempted to incorporate contextual information, the use of temporal dynamics remains limited. To address this, we propose a method that dynamically selects frames based on inter-frame visual dissimilarity. Experimental results show that our approach effectively captures temporal transitions and enhances the accuracy of continuous emotion recognition in third-person scenarios. Evaluations on the VEATIC dataset, which provides valence and arousal annotations in realistic and socially grounded settings, demonstrate that our method outperforms the baseline that uses uniformly sampled frame sequences.

title: A Blockchain-based DDoS Attack Mitigation Framework for Mission-critical IIoT Environments
authors: Aswani Devi Aguru, Medipelly Rampavan, Firoj Gazi, Md Muzakkir Hussain, Suresh Babu Erukala, Mohammad Abdussami
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: The Mission-critical IIoT (MC-IIoT) networks are highly interconnected and distributed to ensure real-time monitoring and control, where security, reliability, and availability are paramount. These features make MC-IIoT networks vulnerable to Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks that must be mitigated while combating single-point of failure of attack detection systems, limited scalability of industrial control systems, high latency and low reliability. In this paper, we propose a Blockchain-based DDoS attack mitigation framework for MC-IIoT networks which persuades these requirements. Initially, a machine learning-based cascaded model consisting of an autoencoder-enhanced decision tree model and a lightweight isolation forest algorithm performs attack detection and trust score evaluation of IIoT devices. A consortium Blockchain network of IIoT gateways on which this cascaded model is installed performs attack mitigation using a chaincode based on previously evaluated trust scores. The proposed model is evaluated on Hyperledger Fabric and the performance is analyzed with Hyperledger caliper benchmarking. The comparative analysis of the proposed framework with state-of-the-art proves its effectiveness in terms of attack detection accuracy (99.93%), CPU utilization (30%), decreased latency (12.5 ms), increased throughput (21%), chaincode execution time (3 ms) and attack detection rate (99.6%).

title: FedMapTCS: Communication-Efficient FL Framework with Iterative Magnitude-Based Pruning and Time-Correlated Sparsification
authors: Robbie Southam, Peizheng Li, Alexander Herzog, Aftab Khan
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) enables model training across distributed clients while preserving data privacy, yet client limitations in restricted computational power, memory, storage, and bandwidth, pose significant challenges for FL training and execution efficiency. This paper introduces FedMapTCS, a novel hybrid method that enhances FL communication efficiency by integrating FedMap, a technique for gradually learning a sparse FL model, with time-correlated sparsification (TCS) and error accumulation. This approach allows clients to collaboratively train an increasingly sparse global model, reducing communication overhead from the start of the training by selectively transmitting only necessary parameters each round. Extensive evaluation in both independent and identically distributed (IID) and non-IID settings demonstrates that FedMapTCS reduces communication bits by over 60% compared to the FedMap baseline and over 85% compared to federated averaging (FedAvg), while maintaining comparable model performance in IID settings. Under non-IID settings, FedMapTCS achieves better accuracy with up to 3.25× fewer rounds than FedMap, and achieves similar accuracy with 24.7% fewer parameters, highlighting its adaptability to heterogeneous data while maintaining performance. This communication efficiency gain positions FedMapTCS as a promising and effective solution for resource-constrained FL environments.

title: LLMs-based Utterance Class Prediction for Training an Intake Interviewer Agent
authors: Tatsu Kitamura, Takehito Utsuro, Tadahisa Kondo
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study proposes an automatic prediction method for interviewer’s and participant’s utterance classes in intake interviews (i.e., a term in the medical field referring to the initial consultation), focusing on a corpus of distress analysis interviews. The interviewer and participant’s utterances in the DAIC-WoZ dataset are classified into six classes and five classes. We used LLMs with few-shot learning, guided by Client-centered theory. The prediction results demonstrate high accuracy. These findings suggest the potential of LLMs as effective tools for predicting the classes of both the interviewer’s and the participant’s utterances, offering promising implications not only for supporting novice interviewers in intake interviews and training settings, but also as a foundational capability for automated intake interviews conducted by an intake interviewer agent.

title: Railway Switch Health Monitoring Using Machine Learning and Audio Fusion Features
authors: Yu-Chih Wei, Wei-Hung Chi, Meng-Hsien Juan, Jun-Ting Ou
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This paper presents a data-driven approach for railway switch health monitoring and failure prediction using machine learning. We utilize six months of sensor data from four switch sensor groups, recorded every 10ms, to develop a three-stage feature engineering pipeline. The approach progresses from raw sensor features to statistical optimization, culminating in audio-fusion features using generative AI-created audio and MFCC extraction. A two-layer MLP with optimized hyperparameters achieves 94% accuracy in three-class classification (Normal/Warning/Fault). This work demonstrates the effectiveness of combining traditional sensor data with synthetic audio features for enhanced railway switch condition monitoring and provides a foundation for future RUL prediction systems.

title: Mini-LEDNet Image Enhancement Network for Mini-LED Application
authors: Yu-Cheng Fan, Jian-Ping Wang, Tzu-Lun Fang, Hsuan-Yang Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: The advancement of display technology has captured significant attention, particularly the growing interest in Mini-LED and Micro-LED innovations. The introduction of Mini-LED technology has provided remarkable improvements in contrast and color expression. A combined approach utilizing low-brightness image enhancement networks alongside deblurring networks offers a promising solution, yet only a few of studies have explored the integration of these two tasks. In this paper, we presents a high-quality image enhancement network built upon the Mini-LEDNet architecture and introduces a novel Neural Network to further enhance image quality. In developing the Mini-LED model, we implement local dimming technology to achieve superior image effects.

title: Designing for Clarity : Real-Time Collaboration Tools for Interdisciplinary Healthcare Teams
authors: Tzu-Ling Huang, Ko-Chiu Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Effective interprofessional collaboration is essential in clinical care but often challenged by fragmented communication, lack of documentation, and the limitations of existing coordination tools. Based on interviews with seven clinical professionals, this study highlights common challenges such as information overload, difficulty prioritizing messages by urgency and relevance, and the need for more streamlined and transparent coordination. In response, we propose a real-time communication system tailored for interdisciplinary healthcare teams, informed by the Elaboration Likelihood Model (ELM) to support users under both high and low cognitive load.

title: Optimized Satellite Participation in Federated Learning over LEO Constellation Networks
authors: Madyan Alsenwi, Eva Lagunas, Jorge Querol, Mohammed Al-Ansi, Dinh-Hieu Tran, Yan Kyaw Tun, Symeon Chatzinotas
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper presents an intelligent device selection framework for Federated Learning (FL) in Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite constellation networks. In particular, the high mobility, intermittent connectivity and long communication delays in LEO satellite networks significantly impact FL convergence and model performance. To address these challenges, we formulate a device selection optimization problem that determines the optimal subset of LEO satellites to participate in global model aggregation at each round. The objective is to minimize the average loss while satisfying latency constraints. To solve the formulated problem, we develop a deep reinforcement learning (DRL)-based solution that enables adaptive satellite selection considering the stochastic nature of satellite connectivity and channel variability. The proposed framework selects participating satellites dynamically based on their communication latency and computational capabilities to improve the overall efficiency of the FL process. Simulation results show that the proposed approach accelerates convergence compared to conventional synchronous FL while maintaining model accuracy.

title: Anti-Interference RIS-Aided Positioning Method Based on PSO Algorithm
authors: Yongkang Su, Shuangshuang Han, Ziyuan Yang, Tongmu Liu, Tianhao Jian
publish: 2025 21st IEEE International Conference on Mechatronic and Embedded Systems and Applications (MESA)
abstract: To address the insufficient anti-interference capability of positioning systems in complex wireless environments, this paper proposes a reconfigurable intelligent surface (RIS)-aided positioning scheme based on particle swarm optimization (PSO), and verifies its anti-interference performance improvement via Cramér-Rao lower bound (CRLB) theoretical analysis. First, a RIS phase response model accounting for hardware nonlinearities is constructed, with polynomial expansion characterizing the nonlinear mapping between incident signal intensity and reflection phase. Second, a composite interference model integrating multipath effects, sinusoidal disturbances, and random noise is designed—multipath interference is simulated by time-varying delays, random phases, and attenuation coefficients, while sinusoidal disturbances represent periodic electromagnetic interference. Furthermore, a PSO-RIS joint optimization framework is adopted, taking the minimization of positioning error bound (PEB) as the objective function and introducing L1-norm regularization constraints to enhance solution sparsity and suppress false multipath interference. Experimental results demonstrate that under various interferences, the PSO algorithm achieves higher positioning accuracy than the traditional quasi-Newton algorithm.

title: Uncapped photovoltaic connectors – a combined field and chamber study to verify and elucidate degradation
authors: David C. Miller, Rachael L. Arnold, Delos Ashcraft, Peter L. Hacke, Steven C. Hayden, Oscar Hathaway, Aubrey Jackson, Chun-Sheng Jiang, Jimmy M. Newkirk, Greg Perrin, Kent Terwilliger
publish: 2025 IEEE 70th Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts (HLM)
abstract: "Uncapped connectors" are left open to the environment prior to PV system installation, where corrosion and contamination may occur between mechanical mounting and their subsequent electrical connection. We conducted a study to verify the damage mode and further inform the industry on the presently widespread practice of uncapped connectors. Replicate connectors were deployed in the summer of 2023 in: hot-dry Barstow, CA; subtropical Gaithersburg, MD; and ocean side Prince Edward Island, CAN. Connectors were returned and then additionally aged using combined-accelerated stress testing (C-AST). Characterizations included: visual and thermographic imaging, resistance-current sweep, HiPot wet leakage insulation, and scanning electron microscopy (morphology and composition, surface and depth-profiling). Deconstructed samples (from the field and after C-AST) showed overt differences between outdoor locations, including: morphology (surface cracking), contamination (minerals, salts, and organic matter), and chemical integrity (surface scale and corrosion). While the performance of field-aged, uncapped connectors was not immediately distinguished from plugged or unaged connectors, all uncapped specimen assemblies ultimately failed C-AST. The humid locations failed 3 - 5 test sequences earlier than the hot-dry location, emphasizing the adverse impact of water and salt. Having confirmed the damage mode of uncapped connectors from simple, prolonged exposure to the outdoor environment, we recommend to always use the manufacturer’s protective end caps, from the time of module manufacture until PV is fully installed in the field.

title: Semi-Coherent Detection of Long Range (LoRa) Modulation over Multipath Channels
authors: Jinho Choi
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Long-range (LoRa) modulation offers reliable transmission performance for devices and sensors in Internet of Things (IoT) applications. LoRa modulation is a chirp spread spectrum (CSS) technique with orthogonal signaling, which results in low spectral efficiency but enables a low error rate even at relatively low signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs). In this paper, we propose a semi-coherent detection scheme that performs coherent detection using estimated channel state information (CSI) in multipath channel environments, which is obtained from the decision results of noncoherent detection. This scheme not only achieves performance close to that of coherent detection but also eliminates the need for pilot signal transmission, which is required in conventional coherent detection schemes at the expense of spectral efficiency. Simulation results demonstrate that the performance of the proposed semi-coherent detection scheme is close to that of coherent detection under various channel conditions.

title: Beam Misalignment Fading in THz D2D ISAC: From Communication to Sensing
authors: Samuel Sani, Akhtar Saeed, Ozgur Gurbuz, Wolfgang Gerstacker
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Terahertz (THz) integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems promise ultra-high data rates and precise sensing capabilities, enabled by narrow and directional beams. However, such beams are susceptible to beam misalignment (BM) fading caused by platform instability. While statistical models for BM fading exist for communication links, their extension to sensing applications, especially in drone-to-drone (D2D) scenarios, remains unexplored. In D2D ISAC networks, misalignment effects from the aerial platforms impact both the forward and return paths. This paper presents closed-form statistical models for BM fading in THz ISAC, addressing both monostatic (co-located transceivers) and bistatic (separated transceivers) sensing configurations, and considering both the spot-filling regime (target larger than beam) and the spot-limited regime (target smaller than beam). The proposed models facilitate the extension of BM fading analysis to sensing in drone-to-drone THz ISAC systems and have been validated through Monte Carlo simulations.

title: Transferring Vision-Language-Action Models to Industry Applications: Architectures, Performance, and Challenges
authors: Shuai Li, Yizhe Chen, Dong Li, Sichao Liu, Dapeng Lan, Yu Liu, Zhibo Pang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: The application of artificial intelligence (AI) in industry is accelerating the shift from traditional automation to intelligent systems with perception and cognition. Vision-language-action (VLA) models have been a key paradigm in AI to unify perception, reasoning, and control. Has the performance of the VLA models met the industrial requirements? In this paper, from the perspective of industrial deployment, we compare the performance of existing state-of-the-art VLA models in industrial scenarios and analyze the limitations of VLA models for real-world industrial deployment from the perspectives of data collection and model architecture. The results show that Pi0, after fine-tuning, achieves approximately 60% success rate on simple grasping tasks, while the positional error in high-precision placing tasks reaches up to 2.2 cm and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12.4^\circ$</tex>. There is much room for performance improvement in complex industrial environments, diverse object categories, and high-precision placing tasks. Our findings provide practical insight into the adaptability of VLA models for industrial use and highlight the need for task-specific enhancements to improve their robustness, generalization, and precision.

title: A Double-Covertness Design for Integrated Sensing and Communication Systems
authors: Yi Zhou, Qiao Shi, Pingzhi Fan, Zheng Ma, Kezhi Wang, Erdal Panayirci
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: In this work, a novel double-covertness framework is developed for integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) systems, where both the radar and communication signals are protected from being maliciously detected by adversaries. Specifically, a new measurement named joint intercept probability (JIP) is proposed for characterizing the double-covertness performance. Next, an optimal power allocation strategy is designed to minimize the JIP, subject to certain quality-of-service (QoS) requirements for communication and sensing. Simulation results verify the effectiveness of our proposed solution and demonstrate the intrinsic relationship among power allocation, JIP and different QoS requirements.

title: Estimation of Human Motion Using Digital Twin for Safety Assessment
authors: Xiaohan Xiang, Masahiro Tanaka, Yutaka Kikuchi
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Acquiring motion data is important for developing a human digital twin. Recording human motion using traditional motion capture devices is often costly and inconvenient for collecting large-scale data across diverse scenarios, particularly in farm work, which frequently involves hazardous conditions. This study proposed a motion estimation method for the human digital twin, aiming at conducting a safety assessment in agricultural tasks. This method can not only estimate the final postures, but also the intermediate frames. This method enables the human digital twin to evaluate various human movements in a virtual work environment. Furthermore, this method is expected to facilitate the optimization of movements based on safety criteria.

title: Actionable Extension of Permittivity Operational Range in Liquid Crystal Coaxial Phase Shifters
authors: Jinfeng Li, Haorong Li
publish: 2025 10th International Conference on Communication, Image and Signal Processing (CCISP)
abstract: Liquid crystal (LC) phase-shifting networks have garnered significant research and development interest around the globe due to their potential to reduce costs and enable the production of reliable, phase-modulating phased array antennas' feeds for next-generation millimetre-wave (mmW) communication systems. These networks also play a crucial role in reducing energy consumption per bit, aligning with the efficiency demands of future communication technologies. This study numerically demonstrates that by addressing fabrication challenges or relaxing pre-alignment constraints on the use of polyimide (PI), the achievable tuning range can exceed initial design targets (without PI). The comprehensive phase shift-to-insertion-loss ratio can be improved by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$43.8 \% / \text{dB}$</tex> (42.8 %) at 60 GHz. These findings highlight the potential for further optimisation of liquid crystal-based phase-shifting networks, paving the way for enhanced performance towards standardisation and commercialisation in advanced communication applications.
