title: Prediction of Dynamic Gait Stability using Kinematic Motion of Center of Mass: Enhancement by Stratified Learning
authors: Hiroki Watanabe, Shogo Okamoto, Haoyun Peng, Yasuhiro Akiyama
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: The Margin of Stability (MoS) is a key metric for assessing dynamic postural stability during human walking. Although MoS is typically calculated using motion capture systems, this study aims to predict the minimum mediolateral MoS using only center of mass (CoM) velocity data. Time-series data of tri-axial CoM velocities during single steps were analyzed using Principal Motion Analysis, a stochastic learning method for multivariate time-series data. To account for variability in gait patterns, unsupervised clustering was applied, and separate predictive models were developed for each cluster. The results demonstrated that stratified learning significantly improved prediction accuracy compared to a single-model approach, reducing the root mean square error (RMSE) from 21.6 mm to 18.5 mm. These findings indicate that incorporating gait stratification into predictive modeling can enhance the accuracy of MoS estimation based solely on kinematic data.

title: REM-Based Beam Management with GNSS Location Error Mitigation in Urban Millimeter-Wave Networks
authors: Enrico Tosi, Aron Schott, Marina Petrova, Ljiljana Simić
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: 5G-NR in FR2 relies on beamforming and accurate beam alignment between the gNodeB (gNB) and the user equipment (UE) to address challenging channel conditions. Maintaining beam alignment for a mobile UE requires frequent updates via beam-sweeping and directional radio frequency measurements, entailing high delay and signaling overhead. Location-aided beam management has emerged as a promising solution for reducing this overhead by combining UE location with historical directional beam training information to construct radio environment maps (REMs) for effective beam alignment. However, the highly site-specific nature of millimeter-wave (mm-wave) propagation makes REM-based beam management vulnerable to performance degradation due to errors in UE location information, e.g., obtained via global navigation satellite system (GNSS), affecting the accuracy of both REM construction and querying. This paper proposes a 5G-NR standard-compliant solution to mitigate GNSS location error in REM-based beam management, by constructing our rank-REM from multiple UE directional channel measurements and multi-beam monitoring for connected UEs. Our results, based on ray-tracing in an urban environment, show that our proposed REM construction and querying strategy effectively mitigates realistic GNSS location error, substantially enhancing link stability for a mobile UE by reducing radio link failures (RLFs) and handovers, thus enabling effective REM-based beam management for 5G-and-beyond.

title: Softwarized RIS Steering System: Signal Detection Use Case
authors: Marta Sieradzka, Łukasz Kułacz, Adrian Kliks
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: In recent years, Reconfigurable Intelligent Surfaces (RISs) have emerged as a dynamic research area, enabling real-time control over signal propagation. However, deploying multiple RIS boards in practice requires fast and efficient remote steering of their parameters. This paper introduces a modular, software-defined RIS steering system that allows real-time adjustment of the reflection characteristics of deployed RISs. The system is validated through a spectrum sensing use case, demonstrating improved detection performance through signal enhancement.

title: RIS-assisted Tag-side Pre-processed Spatial Modulation in Backscatter Communication
authors: Negin Kazemipourleilabadi, Mutlu Koca
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: This paper addresses the need for enhanced control over signal propagation in wireless communication using reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS). We propose RIS-assisted backscatter communication (BC) systems, introducing a linear pre-processing-based spatial modulation (SM) technique for data transmission. Our work focuses on signaling design, phase shift optimization, and bit error rate (BER) evaluation through Monte-Carlo simulations. Results demonstrate that RIS-assisted pre-processing in BC enhances transmission reliability and energy efficiency, offering a promising solution for next-generation low-power communication systems.

title: Synchronous Enhancement of Sensitivity and Frequency of Piezoelectric Micromachined Ultrasonic Transducers Operating in the Second-Order Flexural Mode
authors: Xuefeng Hu, Zhengqian Zhao, Taotao Ding, Xunyan Ma, Zhi Ding, Baoyin Hou, Lufeng Che
publish: Journal of Microelectromechanical Systems
abstract: Piezoelectric Micromachined Ultrasonic Transducers (PMUTs) are widely used in sensing applications, where high-order modes of PMUT can be used to enhance sensing accuracy. However, in existing works, when PMUTs work at a high-order resonance mode, their weak amplitude of flexural vibration and sound pressure cancellation from opposite membrane motions result in low sensitivity. Here, we demonstrate a novel PMUT with double-turn slots at the edge of the membrane, transforming the fully-clamped membrane into a suspended structure, thus modifying the mode shape. When the PMUT operates in the second-order mode, the structure alleviates sound pressure cancellation, and enables large vibration amplitude, thus enhancing both sensitivity and frequency. AlN-based PMUT prototypes are fabricated on a 4-inch wafer with CMOS compatible processes for validation. Compared to fully-clamped PMUTs operating in the fundamental resonance mode, the central displacements of the two devices with different slot angles are increased by 153% and 84%, their frequencies are improved by 59% and 189%, respectively, and the round-trip sensitivity is enhanced by 5.47 dB. As demonstration examples, pulse-echo-based ranging and imaging are explored using a <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$3\times 5$</tex-math> </inline-formula> PMUT array. The ranging accuracy is 0.65 mm with a maximum distance of 50 mm, and the imaging deviation is 0.6 mm at a distance of 2 cm. These results demonstrate great application potential of this innovative design.

title: Realistic Interactive Facial Reaction for Simulated Patient
authors: Tri Tung Nguyen Nguyen, Dinh Tuan Tran
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Conventional approaches to visualizing dynamic human facial expressions—-such as flat-panel displays or static mannequins–fall short in delivering immersive, responsive experiences, especially in applications like medical simulation and virtual interaction. We present a novel visualization framework that leverages 3D Gaussian Splatting (3DGS) to drive photorealistic, real-time facial avatars across both stereoscopic 3D displays and virtual reality (VR) environments. Our system renders view-dependent expressions with volumetric continuity, enabling avatars to convey nuanced non-verbal feedback such as pain or discomfort in real time. The framework integrates FLAME-based expression modeling, Gaussian-based neural rendering, and multi-view calibration for seamless projection to holographic displays and immersive headsets. By bridging the gap between facial expression generation and high-fidelity 3D visualization, our approach sets the foundation for next-generation training systems, social VR, and embodied human-computer interaction.

title: In Silico Molecular Docking Analysis of Nilotinib-Mediated Inhibition of Alpha-Synuclein Phosphorylation in Parkinson's Disease
authors: Katherin L. Sierra-Contreras, Valentina Jiménez-Acosta, Santiago Noguera-Rosero, Diana C. Rodríguez, Alvaro D. Orjuela-Cañón
publish: 2025 IEEE 4th Colombian BioCAS Workshop
abstract: This article employs an innovative molecular docking approach to explore alternatives to the palliative treatments historically used for Parkinson's disease management. Specifically, we analyze the interaction between residues 91 and 39 of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha$</tex>-synuclein protein and the drug nilotinib, as opposed to its conventional application targeting cAbl kinase to inhibit phosphorylation - a process frequently associated with Lewy body formation. Our results demonstrate successful docking of nilotinib with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha$</tex>-synuclein, with the optimal interaction exhibiting a binding energy of -5.00 kcal/mol and ligand efficiency of -0.17 kcal/mol/atom. This investigation aims to evaluate the potential for significantly mitigating phosphorylation effects in Parkinson's disease, thereby providing a robust foundation for future therapeutic development.

title: Predicting User Susceptibility to Phishing: A Machine Learning Study Combining Spear Phishing Simulations and Questionnaire Responses
authors: Kosuke Yamashita, Qian Wu, Atsushi Kanai
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: The number of information security threats transmitted via email, such as phishing and spear phishing, has been rapidly increasing. To mitigate these threats, it is essential to cultivate individuals capable of independently recognizing phishing emails. Although information security education programs are being implemented, their effectiveness remains limited, particularly for those most vulnerable to targeted attacks. In this study, we conducted a web-based spear phishing simulation and a questionnaire targeting university students to investigate user characteristics associated with vulnerability and to explore the feasibility of building predictive models to identify vulnerable individuals. The results reveal that vulnerable individuals tend to perceive themselves as good communicators, have low self-assessments of their security practices, and exhibit traits associated with carelessness. Furthermore, predictive models based on Support Vector Machines and decision trees proved effective for identifying these individuals, achieving F1-scores of 0.72 and 0.80 respectively through stratified k-fold cross-validation.

title: Audio-Visual Integration and Self-Relevance: the Impact of Instagram Music Stories on Viewer Perception
authors: Yi-Jung Yang, Chien-Wen Cheng
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: This study investigates how different music-visual integration interfaces influence users’ sense of self-relevance when viewing Instagram Stories. As Instagram expands music features across Stories, posts, and notes, music serves as a symbolic medium—emotionally expressive yet open-ended— offering a nuanced alternative to text in public self-expression. Common interface types include static images with album covers, animated lyrics, dynamic videos, and externally shared music posts. In a simulated browsing setting, 31 participants aged 20–30 engaged with four interface types, completed a self-relevance scale after each, and participated in brief interviews. Results showed significant differences in self-association across interfaces, highlighting how design shapes psychological engagement and offering empirical insights for optimizing audio-visual content.

title: Research on a Cost-Benefit Estimation Methodology for Old Ship Retrofitting
authors: Liu Jinxing, Zhang Mingyu, Zhao Yang, You Kaikai, Wang Jiahao, Dai Xiaoqiang
publish: 2025 7th International Conference on Industrial Artificial Intelligence (IAI)
abstract: Under the current background of the electrification transformation and development of the shipping industry, shipowners have doubts about the expected returns of the electrification retrofit of old ships. This paper proposes a cost-benefit estimation methodology for the retrofit of old ships. According to the power grid topology in different retrofit schemes, the ship energy management strategy model is constructed to estimate the ship's operating costs during voyage tasks and analyze the investment payback period required by the retrofit schemes. Under the assumption of 120 voyages per year, Config III can recover the refitting cost in as short as 3.2 years and obtain an additional 428% of revenue during the remaining service life of the ship.

title: Anomalous IoT Behavior Detection Utilizing Time-Series Embedded Representation
authors: Ryusei Eda, Nozomu Togawa
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th International Conference on Consumer Electronics - Berlin (ICCE-Berlin)
abstract: In recent years, with the widespread use of IoT (Internet of Things) devices, security issues in hardware devices have become critical. In particular, IoT devices that run applications on the OS have complex power consumption waveform due to the overlap of steady-state power consumption by the OS and hardware and power consumption by the applications. Conventional anomalous behavior detection methods using power consumption need to remove the steady-state power consumption from the measured power consumption, but if the steady-state power consumption is complex, it may not obtain correct anomalous behavior detection results. In this paper, we propose a method for detecting anomalous behaviors of IoT devices using time-series embedded representations. The proposed method converts measured power consumption waveform into embedded representation sequence using autoencoder. Then, it detects anomalous behaviors based on the prediction-errors of the embedded representations. We applied the proposed method to an IoT device implemented using a Raspberry Pi4, and successfully detected anomalous behaviors while the recent state-of-the-art method cannot detect them.

title: OTFS Modulation on SDR Platform: Experimental Demonstration and Performance Analysis
authors: Muhammad Nauman, Lukasz Lopacinski, Nebojsa Maletic, Matthias Scheide, Jesús Gutiérrez, Milos Krstic, Eckhard Grass
publish: 2025 IEEE 36th International Symposium on Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications (PIMRC)
abstract: Utilization of the Delay-Doppler (DD) domain enables the recently proposed two-dimensional (2D) Orthogonal Time Frequency Space (OTFS) waveform to provide consistent performance under high mobility communication systems. OTFS outperforms existing standard waveforms under such time-frequency selective channels, making it a waveform candidate for future wireless communication systems. In this work, we present an implementation of an OTFS waveform-based system on a Universal Software Radio Peripheral (USRP) X310 Software Defined Radio (SDR). This system is tested in a realistic indoor office environment at a 5 GHz carrier frequency band with 150 MHz bandwidth. The resulting constellation diagrams were observed for BPSK, 4-QAM, and 16-QAM modulated OTFS symbols. Furthermore, for 4-QAM symbols, several communication metrics, such as Bit Error Rate (BER) and Error Vector Magnitude (EVM), were evaluated against different gains at the USRP. The resulting constellation diagrams, BER, and EVM graphs show a successful implementation of our OTFS system.

title: Electrical Contact Resistance and Roughness Over Many Scales
authors: Robert L. Jackson
publish: 2025 IEEE 70th Holm Conference on Electrical Contacts (HLM)
abstract: The roughness of surfaces spans over many scales, and asperities can be the size of nanometers up to millimeters. This work employs previously measured ‘nearly complete’ surface spectrums to model surface contact. These spectrums include data from sub-nanoscale tunneling electron microscopy cross-sections of surfaces. To account for these small scales, the rough surface contact mechanics models consider scale dependent material properties such as yield strength and electrical conductivity. The ranges of included scales of surface features are then varied to evaluate their theoretical influence on electrical contact resistance. This provides insight into the importance of atomic scale roughness in electrical contact and different contact pressures.

title: SmellFly: Investigating Olfactory Display in VR using a Small Drone
authors: Ryosei Unoki, Parinya Punpongsanon
publish: 2025 IEEE 14th Global Conference on Consumer Electronics (GCCE)
abstract: Providing olfactory stimuli in virtual reality (VR) environments is a promising approach to enhancing users’ sense of presence. In this study, we proposed a system for delivering olfactory stimuli to users using a drone. We implemented a workflow where the drone autonomously moves away when the user approaches the olfactory spot in the different scenarios. Experimental results showed that closer retreat distances increased users’ awareness of airflow, suggesting that physical sensations influence overall experience.
